Subject: RE: [sfraves] TO  HAPPYCORE HATERS

I find it funny for a scene that prides itself on acceptance of all types
that people would be so against one type of music.  My nephew likes ice
cream just like I do.  Does that make me a child?  Do I need to "leave never
never land behind"?  No, it means that there are things in this world that
some people like and some people don't.  Those of us who can claim to be
somewhat mature can recognise these differences and move on.  Those of us
who can't will stick around and argue until we are blue in the face about
how my dad can beat up your dad.

I love happycore.  It makes me want to dance and move.  It brings a smile to
my face.  I need a break sometimes from D&B and House and Trance.  I am over
21 and I maintain a stable job in a large company.  I pay my own bills.  I
totally support myself.  I live 1700mi away from mommy and daddy.  Don't
tell me that because I like a certain music, I need to grow up.

If you don't like it, don't listen to it.  There is always another room.
And if there isn't, that's your fault for choosing to go to a party you
shouldn't be at.

Just my two cents,
Jaden

right a FIVE year old can relate to HHC. Says a lot...

Bass, foo foo trance, hard trance, hard house, Gabber,  NRG, classical, rock, 
hip-hop, and contemperary music. And while I'm sure you can all think of

well. So while some of it may be inane, YOU CANT SAY ALL HAPPYCORE IS BAD. 
And if you do  you don't sound smart and "too good for HC." You just sound 
ignorant and stupid. So I hope this puts an end to this debate....cause you 
can say happycore is all bad....but its not, and your wrong....PERIOD

Subject: RE: [sfraves] TO  HAPPYCORE HATERS


Amen brother.

I'm known as a "junglist" to most people, but if it wasn't for cheesy trance,
cheesy breaks, and happy hardcore I'd have never found the rave scene in the
first place..

Well that and orbital..

I had more fun dancing to HHC last friday than I've had @ any party in months,
if you can't handle hardcore then don't go to those clubs.

BTW, what's a guy gotta do to get some non-happy hardcore around here?  My
friend is an EXCELLENT DJ but because he spins dark/hip hop hardcore he never
gets any gigs at all..  Where's the love?

Date: Thu, 16 Aug 2001 20:18:47 -0700
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
From: "Jaden" <jaden375@yahoo.com>
Subject: RE: [sfraves] TO  HAPPYCORE HATERS
Message-ID: <GOELLMOBIKCHNEEKEFHCIEMBCEAA.jaden375@yahoo.com>

I find it funny for a scene that prides itself on acceptance of all types
that people would be so against one type of music.  My nephew likes ice
cream just like I do.  Does that make me a child?  Do I need to "leave never
never land behind"?  No, it means that there are things in this world that
some people like and some people don't.  Those of us who can claim to be
somewhat mature can recognise these differences and move on.  Those of us
who can't will stick around and argue until we are blue in the face about
how my dad can beat up your dad.

I love happycore.  It makes me want to dance and move.  It brings a smile to
my face.  I need a break sometimes from D&B and House and Trance.  I am over
21 and I maintain a stable job in a large company.  I pay my own bills.  I
totally support myself.  I live 1700mi away from mommy and daddy.  Don't
tell me that because I like a certain music, I need to grow up.

If you don't like it, don't listen to it.  There is always another room.
And if there isn't, that's your fault for choosing to go to a party you
shouldn't be at.

Just my two cents,
Jaden

> >im curious what was your religion and its basic premises...
> >I was a member of a triumverant (sp?) once.
>
>The idea for the religion was to worship Schrödinger's Cat.
>Or more precisely, the belief system was that the
>Schrödinger's Cat paradox in quantum physics proved
>that consciousness was an unsolvable mystery.
>
>I only got one convert, my polynesian friend Jenn (who I know
>some people on the list have met).
>
>Unfortunately, it turned out I was wrong. In 1991, A physicist
>named Wojceich Zurek, at the Los Alamos National Laboratory in
>New Mexico, proved that consciousness does not cause quantum
>decoherence. In 1998, physicist and cosmologist Max Tegmark
>proved the opposite, that quantum decoherence does not cause
>consciousness. So the mystery of consciousness has been
>solved. As a result, the Schrödinger's Cat religion has been
>disbanded.
>

Subject: [sfraves] Invibe, Psychotica, & Family

     So my early evening to mid was spent w/ Brandon & this was the 1st tim=
e we kicked outside off a Rave!  LoL  It was Dope jus' chillin' & talkin' &=
 stuff!  We even went to the market to gt junk food!  He's totally tryin' 2=

 my calander on that!  Hmmm, but yeah, whenever y'all get the chance to, ki=
ck it w/ someone off the list!!  Oh yeah, we even kicked it w/ Miki & it wa=
s Dope hangin' w/ her for that quick min!  So Dope Kickin' it w/ Brandon!  =
Actually it was his alternate ego I was hangin' out w/!

     Then I went to Psychotica!  It was nice seein' my Ratkoonrat Fam again=
 'cause I don't get to see them all too often like back in the day when we =
were 2gether like everyday!  Checked out downstairs & Jungle was spinning!!=
  I totally tried getting into it & I did!  I mean, downtempo was also bein=
g spun along side the Jungle which made it hella fun for me to dance.  But =
man, after an evil Jungle set like Genome spun on Monday, I was in the mood=
 to hear darker shit & the Jungle was kinda to mellow for me earlier @ Blak=
es!

     NRG came  next & I was Groovin'!!  I did bump into Cliff & Siarra (SP)=
!  It was CooL seein' those 2!!  Another reason I WAITED a while there was =
'cause I was suppose to meet up w/ Veronica, but she never should the 2 hou=
rs I was there!  I mean, I totallyhad fun there seein' & kickin' it w/ ever=
yone, but 1 thing man, the vibe all around, aside from the Dope people I kn=
ew, was yucky!!  i mean, seriously, the energy was not connected @ all & th=
ere was a total felt seperation between the DJs & The Groovers!!  I ain't s=
ayin this 2 knock the crews of the night, but it was a Gross Vibe I ain't f=
elt in a long time!  It may have gotten better when I left & I'm totally su=
re spirits Rose up like totally, but it wasn't there when I was there!!  I =
Still Love Ratkoonrat & Psychotika!  But hella people doggin each other & n=
o unity!  Maybe it was jus a woerd night!

     Another upside to Blakes earlier was seein' my Homegirl Jeanie work ba=
r 'cause she's barely workin' weeknights anymore!!  It was also Dope seein'=
 Matt!  yay

     So I head over to a goin' away shindig next for My homies Chris & Gabe=
!!!  Aawwww, I'm gonna miss them when they're in Europe!!  But hung out w/ =
my other Fam & although it was tempting, I didn't drink 'cause Insomnia the=
 night before & not sleeping & drink w/ a lil' food in my tummy would not o=
f mixed & I woulda got tore up was to quickly!  So I jus' enjoyed jus' talk=
in' & well, talkin' w/ every1!!  It was Fun!!  It was also kinda Groovy wat=
chin' boxin' matches!  LoL... Did more bonding w/ Veronica!!  Oh yeah, & Au=
die's hair eas so Cute!

    Then driving home, there were 3 deers & a skunk running down my street!=

d of hiting the skunk!  OK, I try & sleep now!

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: free day party 8/19 "Not Everyone Understands..." 

All right people, it's that time again for another fabulizz day in the sun
with us. Bring tons of blankets to rest on, lots of water to share, and
don't forget to wear something comfortable to shake yo booty in! For those
boozers out there you need to bring plastic cups to drink out of or Mr. Park
Ranger will give you a fat (no ph!) ticket. This looks to be our last day
party of the summer so don't miss out!

"All house...all day...until the sun leaves your face."

Sunday August 19th 2001 AD

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm

Received: (qmail 3461 invoked from network); 17 Aug 2001 17:43:51 -0000
X-Originating-IP: [64.165.54.92]
From: "'LoOnDrOp' ......" <loondrop@hotmail.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Bcc: 
Date: Fri, 17 Aug 2001 10:43:22 -0700
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <F223qRFapNuT1FM1JOM000008bd@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 17 Aug 2001 17:43:23.0210 (UTC) FILETIME=[1C79FAA0:01C12744]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] my point...was Too Mych Haterism...

Alrgiht...i kinda figured id strike a chord with thta one but here is the 
underlying reason for this.   I was being intentionally facetious.  However 
i was kinda looking for a reaction from some of the hater of happycore who 
like willie.  Either that or this is simply some sorta damage control to 
making a stupid post. I can on occasion be wrong BUt at least i can admit 
it.

heres the thing.  truely musical preference is simply a matter of personal 
taste and the ability to appreciate a wide variety different sounds.  What 
sounds good to one person may not sound so great to another. DUH! BUT...no 
one type of music, which is a form of art, is any better of worse than any 
other.  a persons artistic expression of thought and form, by it's nature, 
cannot be good or bad or right or wrong, better or worse.  Those kinds of 
descriptions are relative, and are often defined by societal influences.  
FOR the majority of persons who do not know who they are themselves, and are 
not in touch wiht their true feelings, societal influences (such as the 
"opinions of friends they dont want to alienate," "because i want to impress 
a chick," "because i dont want so and so to think im lame" become one's 
opinion.

now, i listen to happycore, trance, jungle, country, rock, metal, oldies, 
classic rock, classical, and i spin french house.  i like what i listen to 
because it accentuates the differences in style.  I like the depth and 
emotion in classical and its new age counterpart trance.  i like the eagles 
and metalica.  i like sarah evans, regardless of what the passengers in my 
car say about it (thats whats good about being the driver).

im getting ot a point here soon i promise...

I think that most people who hate on a particular genre of music only do it 
for one reason.  I think that when a person says they hate something its 
really that deep down inside they like it, and are embarrased to say so.
too worried about one's own reputaion to know what they enjoy.

okay ill stop rambling now.  oh and if you dont like what i have to say, 
dont bother reading my posts. they're all like this, out of habit i like to 
play devils advocate.

..oo00--LoOnDrOp--00oo..

"Im not a slacker....
     I just refuse to cooperate with society!"

Subject: [sfraves] Ecstasy Saves The World - Pot, MDMA, and too damn many happy people

Heres the link:

d

Ecstasy Saves The World
Pot, MDMA, and too damn many happy people

By Mark Morford, SF Gate Columnist <mailto:mmorford@sfgate.com>

Wednesday, August 15, 2001
  _____


What would be really just randomly fabulous is if the UC Santa Barbara would
suddenly buck the trend and find some progressive moral fiber and discover a
sudden impulse of commonsense justice and just up and decide to go to court
and defend its recently arrested pot-growin' professor.
You know, that religious-studies prof and her husband who were recently
busted for growing upwards of 58 pot plants in their home
<http://sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/n/a/2001/08/12/state1813EDT0075.DT
L>  and are accused of, well, growing 58 pot plants in their home that you
can potentially dry and smoke and then feel all funny and warm afterwards,
similar to alcohol but not nearly as dangerous or addictive or famously
violence-provoking but which for some reason is still illegal.
And wouldn't it be wondrous indeed if institutions like UCSB would begin to
disregard what I imagine must be a relatively antediluvian policy regarding
employees caught with benign herbs, a policy which I'm sure forces them to
issue a reprimand and an official statement and a disapproving scowl, and
instead bail out the professor and openly declare to all the world that pot
busts like this one are ridiculous and pointless and arbitrary and
ultimately insulting?
Thus reinforcing what most of us already know: That while marijuana ain't
exactly health food, no one but the most uninformed or panicky anti-drug
zealot actually thinks it's genuinely dangerous to the public at large
anymore, really, especially in harmless gilded little towns like Santa
Barbara, especially not when compared with the demons of alcohol or
television or unchecked Republicanism.
Maybe this is what is required. Maybe our public institutions need to modify
their drugs policies, forward-thinking corporations come right out and say
they don't mind what employees do in their spare time, will in fact defend
them, or at least quit with the Puritanical puling and the drug testing
<http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/2001/08/1
2/CM163746.DTL>  and the faux-concern, everyone finally acknowledging that
most drug policies are merely shallow maneuvers designed to make the powers
that be look honest and virtuous and deeply concerned when in fact they're
mostly just posturing for the cameras and the polls and the shareholders,
and/or trying to force everyone to conform to certain behavioral norms
because otherwise those kids are just too damn scary what with all the
dancing and the sex and the crazy smiling and the non-violence.
And while we're indulging utopian dreams, what if our goodly scientists and
psychologists and politicians and even casual users were allowed to give
honest accounts of, say, Ecstasy and its real effects? Just come right out
and thwart the panicky disinfo constantly being spit out by the DEA and the
FBI and even CNN, and instead divulge that it's really not an epidemic at
all, that millions of people are safely discovering the joys of MDMA and are
doing just fine.
Sure MDMA use is rising dramatically and there are more Ecstasy-related
emergency-room visits than ever (nowhere near the massive scale of our pal
alcohol, mind), simply because many uninformed folks abuse the stuff and
don't know what they're doing, a problem that has little to do with the idea
of debauched nihilistic youth and everything to do with how much how much
the powers that be refuse to address the problem in fair and honest terms
that don't openly mock and degrade the intelligence of the millions of
casual users everywhere. Which is not to say dumb or otherwise persistently
naive people won't abuse the drug anyway, but that can be said of just about
anything.
And let's go even further: What if our media and our officials could
honestly reveal that MDMA really ain't all that bad, that it's even
comparable in overall harmlessness to our UCSB's professor's goodly
marijuana, all things considered and as far as chemical stimulants go (read:
they all take a toll on your health -- it's just a question of balance), and
that if it's pure and delivered in the right dose MDMA is almost completely
safe and non-addictive can actually be just terribly fun and inspiring and
soul-expanding and even world-altering for the better?
Which is only a slight hyperbole, honestly, despite what you've probably
heard and despite the BS you see via CNN's overblown special reports
<http://www.mapinc.org/safe/v01/n1183/a08.html> , as they trot out
not-very-bright teens to tell overly dramatized, exaggerated horror stories
about their, like, totally like, gnarly experience with MDMA at this party
this one time, because that's what viewers and politicians and TV news
directors want to see.
Maybe they could even come right out and announce with a big smile that if
you're going to enjoy Ecstasy, do so in moderation and drink lots of water
and test the stuff first to make sure it's not laced with other sundry vile
crap, and don't imbibe it to excess because that's simply stupid and
dangerous and in extremely rare cases could actually kill you, which has
happened on occasion but again, only because of serious abuse or
complications resulting from severe hyperthermia (overheating) and not
nearly to the scale and violence and epic idiocy of booze.
And then they could finally add that we're only talking openly and honestly
like this because we care about our kids and our citizenry and we wish to
inform and protect them and let them know some drugs can be a fascinating
and worthy psychological and cultural experience, if you're ready for them,
instead of constantly cramming harmful alarmist rhetoric and misinformation
<http://dailynews.yahoo.com/h/abc/20010807/hl/gma010807_ecstasy_1.html>
down their disbelieving throats, which only causes resentment and rebellion
and mistrust. Newsflash: All drugs are not all bad all the time. Now shut up
and pop another Xanax, senator.
Instead we have cops cracking down on rave culture, authorities shutting
down parties and dance clubs and utterly benign gatherings, trying to
somehow rein in the flood of mostly joyous Ecstasy and throttle youth
culture for its own good.
We have ridiculously tendentious news reports and brow-furrowed politicians
pretending to care and drawing up narrow-minded legislation and further
alienating young people and intelligent culturally savvy adults users across
the nation. Hell, we're not even half as enlightened as the Swiss
<http://www.ecstasy.org/info/swiss.html> .
We have people like Governor George H. Ryan of Illinois, who just signed one
of the nation's harshest anti-Ecstasy laws, wherein a person convicted of
possessing a mere 15 pills in his militantly unfriendly little state will
receive a mandatory minimum sentence of four years in prison. Right. That
oughta do it.
Sometimes it seems just painfully clear: In terms of social enlightenment,
we have not progressed a single inch.
  _____

Thoughts for the author? Email him <mailto:mmorford@sfgate.com> .
Mark Morford's Notes & Errata column appears every Wednesday and Friday on
SF Gate, just like a special magic bunny of love. He also writes the Morning
Fix, a deeply skewed daily email column and newsletter. Subscribe at
sfgate.com/newsletters/


--Boundary_(ID_3Jgwa/E2Gex0m+3ACajE3A)--

Subject: Re: [sfraves] TO HAPPYCORE HATERS

The point of my email wasn't that people who don't like HHC are bitter 
people. I just firmly believe that you can't tell someone that their opinion 
is wrong- that is why it is an opinion, and that is the reason that all the 
"Trance Sucks. No wait, Jungle sucks more..." threads on this list are so 
pointless. Same goes for the way people dance to whatever music they listen 
to- I may not like the way they dance, but it is a form of self expression, 
and so it is not my place to judge it.

I personally don't like HHC, and so I would not call it "quality music", but 
that is my opinion, and everyone else is entitled to their own. Saying that 
HHC isn't quality music is not a fact- it is subjective, based upon your 
personal standards for what makes music good. Stating something like that as 
if it were a fact implies that everyone is judging from the same standards 
(the standards of the person speaking), or that they should be. This is a 
fairly egocentric viewpoint and one that I think would be debated heatedly 
by the majority of the list. It just seems like there is a smaller 
proportion of people who listen to HHC, so not that many people are speaking 
up when people bash it. I wonder, though, what would be said if this thread 
was relating to jungle, house, techno, or breaks instead of HHC. I would be 
willing to bet that there would be more people speaking up about the rights 
everyone has to their own opinion.

As far as my response to Ryan, it was a response to several emails that have 
been posted by him recently. That, and it was supposed to be private, but I 
hit the damn "Reply All" button. I know, I'm a dumbass. :-)

Oh, and on a completely unrelated note: has anyone noticed that this is a 
KICKASS weekend for all the househads out there??? Hmmm.... Donald Glaude, 
Eddie Amador, Nick Nice, and the ENTIRE LINEUP at ASR.... Do you know how 
excited I am to put on my dancing shoes???

Becca

::I will now return to lurking...::

Subject: Re: [sfraves] donald glaude tonight?  decibel?

I've been to Decibel but not when it's being taken
over by a production crew so I don't know if things
change when someone else is throwing the party. If
everything stays the same, the dress code is strictly
enforced. No tennis shoes or jeans and everyone is
macked in club gear. The club is in the basement,
under Cafe Carousel. The space is pretty big and they
keep it well ventilated. That last couple of times
I've been there, the music was GREAT! Although, the
crowd was a bit too upscale for my taste. 

Rick

HHC == pop music

I'd listen to it more, but I keep hearing the 
same samples/sequences/patterns (only slightly changed

or so) over and over.  maybe i need to listen to
it more; a wider range other than Apex's stuff.

:)

At the end of my first bad acid trip, I realized
that there is indeed a purpose to pop music (thus its
equivalent) and that it has its place in the world -
you know it's been a bad night when you grok the
importance of the Spice Girls

Doug

This FRIDAY, AUGUST 17th we invite you to...
 
           :: n:CODE ::

               DNA LOUNGE|
 http://www.dnalounge.com|
     375 11th Street . SF|
             415.626.1409|___________________________
 ------------------------|10pm - after hours
                         |$10 before 11pm / $15 after
                         |For the 21+ crowd

This FRIDAY, and EVERY FRIDAY the DNA LOUNGE brings you "CODE"
CODE Friday nights will bring you DJs from the mad laboratory,
with the music to prove it.

CODE Friday nights include...

      n:CODE: Pure four on the floor.  Trance.  Techno.
              First and third Fridays of the month.
      d:CODE: Fully breakbeat genres.  Breaks.  Drum+Bass.
              Second and fourth Fridays of the month.

Lineup for the 17th features:

         ----> MAIN ROOM:

         ----> Terrac (Cloud Factory / DeepSpace12) - www.terrac.com
         ----> Sir Nod (Cloud Factory, FnF)         - www.sirnod.com
         ----> Amber (Epiphany / iamthedj.com)      - www.iamthedj.com
         ----> Plateshifter (Otherworld / FnF)

----> Live webcasting!  Separate audio and video feeds!
       http://www.dnalounge.com/audio
       http://www.dnalounge.com/cam

DNA LOUNGE . http://www.dnalounge.com . 415.626.1409

Subject: Re: [sfraves] TO  HAPPYCORE HATERS


Won't last?  HHC like it or not is here to stay.  If I remember correctly it's
been around well past the "phase" stage already(that being 2-3 years).

I really don't know shit about it, I just like to dance to it, and YES you can
dance to it, if you're not a house listening sloth..  HHC is like jungle, it
caters to the party people with energy, unlike downtempo/house/trance that some
party kids have a hard time staying awake to, let alone dancing slow enuff to.

As far as garage, I've been of the perception that trance/house beats with a
jungle style bass roll in the background is garage, whereas 2 step has that 
"extra" step in the beat that makes me fall all over myself when I try to dance
to it, but then again I have difficulty with anything under 140bpm cause I'm
hyper and I like to get down, not slowdance..

There's plenty of room in this scene for ALL types of music, STOP HATING.

Date: Fri, 17 Aug 2001 10:20:06 -0700 (PDT)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: Dustin Bowls <djdustinbowls@yahoo.com>
Subject: Re: [sfraves] TO  HAPPYCORE HATERS
Message-ID: <20010817172006.2682.qmail@web20205.mail.yahoo.com>

Let's face it...HHC will not last. It's getting to the
point where everything is going house. Look what
happened to speed garage....they just changed the name
to two step...WTF? I guess it serves it's purpose by
attracting the kiddies....

Message-ID: <336655BB7E20D411900200508BC2710D0CB8F269@sjcxmb02.corp.covad.com>
From: "Hampton, Scott" <shampton@Covad.COM>
To: "Sfraves (E-mail)" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Date: Fri, 17 Aug 2001 13:37:46 -0700
MIME-Version: 1.0
X-Mailer: Internet Mail Service (5.5.2653.19)
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] nrr: capturing streaming music

i found this application and thought that a lot of you might find it
intresting:
http://www.highcriteria.com/productfr.htm#prod_TR

it's a program called total recorder from a company named high criteria.  it
lets you capture pretty much any streaming audio you may be listening to and
save it to your hard drive.

i know a lot of you are like me and browse the web for streaming mixes and
live sets.  it saves the files in high quality wav format, so it's easy to
put on a cd.  

it's frustrating to find a really good mix that isn't available anywhere
that you would like to have to listen to in the car, now you can save it and
burn it for later :)

lots of luv
Scott

Subject: Re: [sfraves] TO HAPPYCORE HATERS

At 11:28 AM -0700 8/17/01, Becca Plevin wrote:
>The point of my email wasn't that people who don't like HHC are bitter
>people. I just firmly believe that you can't tell someone that their opinion
>is wrong- that is why it is an opinion, and that is the reason that all the
>"Trance Sucks. No wait, Jungle sucks more..." threads on this list are so
>pointless. Same goes for the way people dance to whatever music they listen
>to- I may not like the way they dance, but it is a form of self expression,

Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org

Message-ID: <20010817204830.77921.qmail@web14609.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Fri, 17 Aug 2001 13:48:30 -0700 (PDT)
From: Uncle Noah <unclenoah@yahoo.com>
To: "Sfraves \(E-mail\)" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <336655BB7E20D411900200508BC2710D0CB8F269@sjcxmb02.corp.covad.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: capturing streaming music



an alternate solution for windows users is to activate
your soundcard's internal loop-back without the need
for extra software...

double click on the little speaker in your system
tray.  this will bring up the Volume Control panel. 
go to the menu that says "Options" and select
'Properties'

You'll get a secondary window describing your sound
device and you'll see a section with some radio
buttons.  click the button next to 'Recording' and
then hit the "OK" button.

Now you'll see a control panel much like the volume
control, but it's title will be "Recording Control". 
Here you'll have sliders to control the input from
various sounces like 'Microphone' 'Line' 'Modem' and
others.  look for one that says 'StereoMix' or
something to that effect... you may have to play
around a bit to find out what your particular sound
device calls the loop-back.

once you've got it figured out, select that input
(only) and close those controls up.

now you can open up SoundForge or Vegas or Peak or
whatever sound recording software you use and when you
tell it to record, it will record whatever is flowing
through your soundcard.  so you'll just have to tune
in to the stream you want and hit the record and stop
buttons at the appropriate times.

i know that my sound card has this, and i'd think most
of 'em do.  it's a bit of a tricky solution and it
takes a few times before you really get the hang of
doing it (you wind up playing the "Why am I not
hearing anything?" game the first few times you try
it), but once you get the concept, you can record
anything that comes through your computer, then
manipulate it in your audio editor and use it as you
see fit.  all without having ot buy extra software.

> i found this application and thought that a lot of
> you might find it
> intresting:
> http://www.highcriteria.com/productfr.htm#prod_TR

> it's a program called total recorder from a company
> named high criteria.  it
> lets you capture pretty much any streaming audio you
> may be listening to and
> save it to your hard drive.
> 
> i know a lot of you are like me and browse the web
> for streaming mixes and
> live sets.  it saves the files in high quality wav
> format, so it's easy to
> put on a cd.  
> 
> it's frustrating to find a really good mix that
> isn't available anywhere
> that you would like to have to listen to in the car,
> now you can save it and
> burn it for later :)
> 
> lots of luv

Subject: Re: [sfraves] TO HAPPYCORE HATERS

Ok, dude, I, on the other hand, do mean disrespect. You knock Happykore,
and then hide behind a lame 90s-ism "No disrespect...". PUH-LEASE. Listen
to yourself, everything that you're saying about Happykore, "It's not
music", "Weird", "Kids stuff", "Can't dance to it", is what 90% of the
country says about RAVES IN GENERAL! OHH!!! But nevermind! Let's have our
non-weirdos have parties and let the TRUE freaks listen to Happy Hardcore!

I suppose that if ones lacks the imagination or the dancing ability to
dance to Happy hardcore. Actually, I take that back. Dancing to Happy
Hardcore doesn't take a huge amount of imagination nor a huge amount of
skill.

BUT!

What it does require is a lot of energy, and being comfortable enough to
COMPLETELY AND UTTERLY release your inner FREAK. You have to dance harder
than you have ever danced before. You have to kick your feet above your
head, flip over, jump around, scream as loud as you can, spin and twist and
go totally and completely NUTS. Wanna know how to dance to Happykore? Ask
some friend of your who goes/went to ska shows and have them show you how
to skank. Now go skank harder than you've ever skanked before, and THAT, my
friend, is how you dance.

You could learn something from that 5 year old.

-Damien

WE ARE SF FUTURISM WORLDWIDE!  Live it and Love it -- SF Styles Seen!

This Saturday, August 18th, 2G1

IT'S LOCALS WEEK! YOU SOLDIERS KNOW WHAT THAT MEANS.
Our club was built on the locals, thriving when the locals play.
You know how Eklektic is when there is no hype!

Our playaz for this session will be:

JUJU (phunckateck/phuturo/and labels galore) The man, killing it with 
all releases and making his mark internationally, and to think what 
seems just months back. Juju was learning how to make tracks with Obi 
-UFO! JUJU is headlining the home front for all who dig his dark 
stylie.

4REAL (bbs/groundscore) Groundscore's latest team addition, 
representing BBS in NYC and GS outta SF, this man has it locked down 
coast to coast and goes to town.  4REAL is JUJU 's favorite local DJ 
right now, and the energy these two toss out on the same bill is 
immeasurable.

stage's (along side

do it again,
for the eklektic rukus!

EK room.  He is working his ass to the bone to get from Sac to EK 
every week, where he sets-up, rocks shit, gets down and breaks down, 
(and so much more) as he masters his art from all angles on the 
underground railroad.

Adrian Soleto makes his fourth appearance at Hektic this year having garnered
approval from the likes of Rennie Pilgrem and Danny Mac of late following his
Introduction via FTD, PL-X looks to step it up a notch for the sf faithful.

with his punchy nex-step and fired up nu-breaks

FELIX THE DOG (GS/In-Flight Ent./30Khz UK)

trip behind him,

Organization: Nebcorp.com: ruling your world since 1998
X-Mailer-Holy-War: Get Mutt, it bites!
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: playing sound card INPUT on Winamp

[DJ Teks <johnjeffreyf@yahoo.com>]
> Does anyone know how to play an input(ie. turntable,
> tape recorder) through WINAMP player?
> Winamp allows you to play an internet site, audio cd
> drive, and location on your computer....But I cant
> find out how to play an outside source thats an input
> on your computer sound card.

You don't play it through WinAmp... you just play it. WinAmp is a *player*:
it takes data and turns it into other data that your sound card can
understand.  The sound card then actually turns it into an analog signal
(or perhaps digital) which is sent out to your speakers or amp or whatever
you use to play back sound from the computer.

If you have something plugged into your computer's input and you're
wondering why you can't hear it, WinAmp is not the place to find the
answer.  Take a look in at the mixer (double click on the the little
speaker icon in your desktop tray or go to Start-> Programs ->
Accessories-> Multimedia -> Volume Control).  If I recall correctly, input
volumes are muted by default.

If you could describe what's hooked to what and most importantly what you
are actually trying to accomplish, that would greatly aid myself and others
in helping you fix your problem.

-- 
Ari							there is no spoon

http://www.nebcorp.com/~regs/pgp for PGP public key

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] In Defense of Happy Hardcore

The development of happy hardcore was an important response to both the rise 
of a pretentious intelligent electronic music mantra that did not hide its 
disdain for rave culture and a trend toward darker music in the British rave 
scene.  It was intended to provide music for fast, active dance with a 
positive spirit and it retains that goal today.

The happycore scene is actually the only surviving element of dance culture 
in England that still views itself as a rave scene, having resisted the 
general transition of the scene into a club-centered culture.  If you walk 
into a happycore event today in England (or check ush.net) you will still 
meet people who are self-consciously ravers whereas if you attend other 
events there, people will tell you that the rave scene died a decade ago.

A derogatory tone has been used on this list to call happycore childlike.  
I would agree that happy hardcore is consistent with the Taoist notion of 
returning to the inner child, the part of oneself that is the purest form of 
a child of God.  This is hardly a disadvantage in my opinion as it allows a 
release of the energy of youth and a conscious return to the playful spirit 
of human community.  In this spirit, happycore is one of the few electronic 
music genres that promotes singing along to the lyrics, a fundamental part 
of ancient music and dance ritual.  As such, it provides another pathway for 
people to enter the scene from other music communities.

I have no problem with differences of taste in music but I believe that 
hatred of certain music is typically tied to prejudice against the people 
who listen to the music (scorn for rap with racial overtones, hatred of 
country with a disdain for rural America, and anti-newkids hysteria with a 
need to feel better than early-teenage girls.)  The responses on this list 
provide evidence that the resistance to happycore is also based on contempt 
for an audience that epitomizes the candy raver stereotype.  It was this 
original derision that allowed rave culture to be targeted and separated 
from other appreciation of electronic music.

Disrespect of a people due to their choice of music is our exact charge 
against government and society in reference to the rave crackdown in 
general.  I would therefore advise that each of us be a part of the 
celebration of our diversity rather than unwitting accomplices in the 
culture war.

Matt Grossmann
icq: 4984980
aolim: godisunity
matthewg@uclink.berkeley.edu

_________________________________________________________________
Get your FREE download of MSN Explorer at http://explorer.msn.com/intl.asp

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] nrr: capturing streaming music

I was just talking with my friend about this today.. my experience is that
older legacy systems just can't keep up with the streaming of real-audio
while writing it to the same disk as it caches, even with DSL.. kind of a
buffer underun thing where the music is played out while the processors
write previously saved data to disk.. anyway.. I use a minidisk to record my
audio-streams and then using my digitial spidif inputs/ or analog and dump
it to a wave file for editing.. works great everytime with no interuptions..
so if you have the means.. I highly recommend it! - Ferris Beuler :)
Cheers
Ranger
-----Original Message-----
From: Uncle Noah [mailto:unclenoah@yahoo.com]
Sent: Friday, August 17, 2001 1:49 PM
To: Sfraves (E-mail)
Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: capturing streaming music




an alternate solution for windows users is to activate
your soundcard's internal loop-back without the need
for extra software...

double click on the little speaker in your system
tray.  this will bring up the Volume Control panel.
go to the menu that says "Options" and select
'Properties'

You'll get a secondary window describing your sound
device and you'll see a section with some radio
buttons.  click the button next to 'Recording' and
then hit the "OK" button.

Now you'll see a control panel much like the volume
control, but it's title will be "Recording Control".
Here you'll have sliders to control the input from
various sounces like 'Microphone' 'Line' 'Modem' and
others.  look for one that says 'StereoMix' or
something to that effect... you may have to play
around a bit to find out what your particular sound
device calls the loop-back.

once you've got it figured out, select that input
(only) and close those controls up.

now you can open up SoundForge or Vegas or Peak or
whatever sound recording software you use and when you
tell it to record, it will record whatever is flowing
through your soundcard.  so you'll just have to tune
in to the stream you want and hit the record and stop
buttons at the appropriate times.

i know that my sound card has this, and i'd think most
of 'em do.  it's a bit of a tricky solution and it
takes a few times before you really get the hang of
doing it (you wind up playing the "Why am I not
hearing anything?" game the first few times you try
it), but once you get the concept, you can record
anything that comes through your computer, then
manipulate it in your audio editor and use it as you
see fit.  all without having ot buy extra software.




--- "Hampton, Scott" <shampton@Covad.COM> wrote:
> i found this application and thought that a lot of
> you might find it
> intresting:
> http://www.highcriteria.com/productfr.htm#prod_TR
>
> it's a program called total recorder from a company
> named high criteria.  it
> lets you capture pretty much any streaming audio you
> may be listening to and
> save it to your hard drive.
>
> i know a lot of you are like me and browse the web
> for streaming mixes and
> live sets.  it saves the files in high quality wav
> format, so it's easy to
> put on a cd.
>
> it's frustrating to find a really good mix that
> isn't available anywhere
> that you would like to have to listen to in the car,
> now you can save it and
> burn it for later :)
>
> lots of luv
> Scott
>

This is why I laugh at the RIAA and their attempts to encrypt music.  Even 
if they do succeed (right now the formats don't work on all cd players), I 
can still run the cd player's output into my sound card and record a wav, 
and then compress it to mp3...  making the cd's unrippable isn't a solution.

sarilion

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nrr: capturing streaming music

[Sarilion <raver@sarilion.org>]
> This is why I laugh at the RIAA and their attempts to encrypt music.  Even 
> if they do succeed (right now the formats don't work on all cd players), I 
> can still run the cd player's output into my sound card and record a wav, 
> and then compress it to mp3...  making the cd's unrippable isn't a solution.
> 

While this is true, that has to be decoded to analog *somewhere* upstream
of the speaker cone, they're trying to move it a lot closer to speaker
cone:  USB speakers that will only play watermarked streams are here today
or will be very soon.  Additionally, while you can always re-digitize the
analog stream, and with good gear, the quality lossage will be minimal, it
sure does make it major pain in the ass! Right now I can pop in a CD and
have my auto-rip script email when it's done.  *boom* one step.  With what
you're talking about, I either need to, by hand, record the whole stream
and chop it up, record each track individually, or jump through some hoops
and write a bunch of code to automate that process.

*thinks about it a bit*

Hmmm... that wouldn't be too difficult.  Perhaps I'll apply that logic to
this CD I have that I can't seem to rip.  I'll get back to you on that.

-- 
Ari							there is no spoon

Subject: [sfraves] Hatin on...

I believe posts in nature similar to "XXXX sucks,
YYYYY sucks; and, you suck" are all considred
"Trolling" (definition: Don't make posts that are
inflammatory just to get people riled up.  Substance
is the key to not being labeled a troll.)this behavior
is acknowledged by 90% of newsgroups on the entire
internet. XXX sucks because it's too fast for me/too
slow for me/too happy for me/too big for me/etc is not
substance. It's opinion that no one cares to hear and
especially redundantly repeated(unless you are
planning on starting a "XXXXXX sucks club" and are
looking for recruits, in which case the mailing list
is probably not the best place to do that in the first
place). 
/Val

& Ryan knock on me whenever I mention it & I get flak from hella people, bu=
t I don't give a shit!  Many of U don't like it, Fine!  I think it's kinda =
extreme to be totally verbal about it!!!  But yeah, a few things:


-Hardcore was created a few years after "The Scene" totally took off in the=
 UK!  When Hardcore parties got "stail" after a few years, Happy Hardcore (=
actually Happy Gabba is what it was originally called) was created!  This b=
rought back life into the Hardcore scene, but HappyHardcore took on a life =
of it's own!  I read a book about this!

-Hardcore & Happy hardcore is actually making a rise in NorCali!  I've spok=
en to many DJs & some promoters who told me that slowly, it's coming up in =
the Bay Area!  NorCali does have a Hardcore scene from what I heard, but I =
was told that it is Hardcore is coming up!
THas anyone ever noticed the websites & mailing lists ffor Happy Hardcore?

-Happy Hardcore is music!  Happy Hardcore, like Trance, contains elements f=
rom other types of music like breakbeats!  Also, Hardcore in General has br=
anched of to other forms!  Happy was probably the 1st, but there's also Tra=
ncecore, or what Aryck recently told me he has a record to Gangster Hardcor=
e, etc.!  So no, I'm sorry, but this music ain't gonna die out!  U can also=
 spin HHC w/ jungle & I've seen DJs do that!  There are people who made car=
eers from Happy Hardcore too!=20=20

-Everyone knows how much I Looooooooove Breakbeats, but man, I Looooooooooo=
ve Happy Hardcore!

     You Love Your music & HappyHardCore Lovers Love Happy Hardcore!  I Als=
o Love Jungle, BREAKBEATS, Trance, Freestyle, Oh man, Love DownTempo, & any=
thing I can dance to!  But if knockin' HappyHardcore totally puts you in a =
better mood 'cause U have nothin' else to than to take the time to voice yo=
u opinion and yak bout how U think it suck, then you seriously need to get =
a life!  LoL   OK, I'm gonna listen to Happy2BHardcore Vol 2 & take a showe=
r!!  Hello 2Day!

ZIGMUND VOID [halflife]

seraphim for rocking the house, and leaving everyone happily exhausted =
per usual.  this week, straight from the edges of darkness (aka =
switchcraft records), ANEURYSM will bring out the dead with his original =
dark and hard style and a selection of his own first rate cuts.  be sure =
to check out this rare club appearance from a popular dj/producer in the =
sf underground party scene.

the vibe starts at 9:30 and goes until 2:00 a.m., so plenty of time to =
plan ahead for going in late on tuesday.

At 04:40 PM 08/17/2001 -0700, Osby wrote:
>     OK, yeah, Hi, ummmmm, I tried to not post about this topic 'cuase
y'all know how I stand w/ all this & I jus' thought people were being
stupid, but HELLO 2DAY!  I LOVE HAPPY HARDCORE!!!  I make this known!!
People accept me for it!!  Ok yeah, Andy knocks on me whenever I talk about
it!  Becca & Ryan knock on me whenever I mention it & I get flak from hella
people, but I don't give a shit!  Many of U don't like it, Fine!  I think
it's kinda extreme to be totally verbal about it!!!  But yeah, a few things:
>
>
>-Hardcore was created a few years after "The Scene" totally took off in
the UK!  When Hardcore parties got "stail" after a few years, Happy
Hardcore (actually Happy Gabba is what it was originally called) was
created!  This brought back life into the Hardcore scene, but HappyHardcore
took on a life of it's own!  I read a book about this!
>
>-Hardcore & Happy hardcore is actually making a rise in NorCali!  I've
spoken to many DJs & some promoters who told me that slowly, it's coming up
in the Bay Area!  NorCali does have a Hardcore scene from what I heard, but
I was told that it is Hardcore is coming up!
>THas anyone ever noticed the websites & mailing lists ffor Happy Hardcore?
>
>-Happy Hardcore is music!  Happy Hardcore, like Trance, contains elements
from other types of music like breakbeats!  Also, Hardcore in General has
branched of to other forms!  Happy was probably the 1st, but there's also
Trancecore, or what Aryck recently told me he has a record to Gangster
Hardcore, etc.!  So no, I'm sorry, but this music ain't gonna die out!  U
can also spin HHC w/ jungle & I've seen DJs do that!  There are people who
made careers from Happy Hardcore too!  
>
>-Everyone knows how much I Looooooooove Breakbeats, but man, I
Looooooooooove Happy Hardcore!
>
>     You Love Your music & HappyHardCore Lovers Love Happy Hardcore!  I
Also Love Jungle, BREAKBEATS, Trance, Freestyle, Oh man, Love DownTempo, &
anything I can dance to!  But if knockin' HappyHardcore totally puts you in
a better mood 'cause U have nothin' else to than to take the time to voice
you opinion and yak bout how U think it suck, then you seriously need to
get a life!  LoL   OK, I'm gonna listen to Happy2BHardcore Vol 2 & take a
shower!!  Hello 2Day!
>
>==
>Later {8O)
>Pe@ce-->Just Me-->O§BY
>

----- Original Message -----=20
From: DNA=20
To: Bryan Oley ; sacraves@hyperreal.org=20
Sent: Friday, August 17, 2001 6:28 PM
Subject: Re: In Defense of Happy Hardcore


> Read it

Done that.

> and think before you flame

Done that. =20

Heh.

Please pass this on to whatever idiot is trying to pass this bullshit =
off as fact!

>  The happycore scene is actually the only surviving element of dance =
culture
> in England that still views itself as a rave scene, having resisted =
the
> general transition of the scene into a club-centered culture.=20

What absolute fucking drivel.
Taking this apart line by line, the 'happycore' scene is no surviving at =
all.
It is as near to dead as something can be without decomposing.
Record sales - if you can call them that - are so pathetic now, only the =
most narrow minded fool can pretend it has a fanbase of note any more.
Hard House, seen by many thousands of listeners and clubbers, is seen as =
a natural progression of what Hardcore once was, and is very happy to be =
seen as rave music.  Although England has never (and we fucking hope =
WILL never) have Candy Kids, our closest equivelent is exclusive to Hard =
House.
Happy Hardcore is now almost universally seen on this island as =
pathetic, laughable noise.
It is not played at ANY events around the Country, other than the 1 or 2 =
organisations still trying to promote it.
Of those, only 1 has put on any event of respectable size in the last 12 =
months, and that success was arguably due more to the popular venue it =
was being held at closing forever immediately after the event.

England is moving further and further away from club culture with every =
weekend that passes, and large scale dance parties or festivals is now =
taking hold as the successor.

> If you walk into a happycore event today in England (or check ush.net) =
you will still
> meet people who are self-consciously "ravers" whereas if you attend =
other
> events there, people will tell you that the rave scene died a decade =
ago.

If you walk into a happycore event today in England, or check ush.net, =
you will meet the same 30 or 40 people, all the time.
Ush.net IS the UK happycore scene.
Each rave is little more than a meet up for them.

If you attend other events in the UK and ask people if they are ravers, =
especially if you ask from a standpoint of defending happy hardcore, =
it's not surprising at all that they distance themselves from it in an =
extreme way.
The rave scene YOU are referring to, however, DID die a long time ago.
>From late 95 onwards, happycore was it's own scene, forever desperately =
trying to cling on to what once was.
It has been in a continual decline since then, and is now at such a =
pathetically no-existant level, you have to wonder about the =
accumulative effects of drugs for anyone still holding hope for its =
future.

> A derogatory tone has been used on this list to call happycore =
"childlike."

That's because happycore is the most worthless, ridiculous shite on the =
Planet.
And I say that from a standpoint of someone who made it professionally =
for several years, and started his musical career in it.
It is garbage, most often made by people with little to no musical =
ability, who more often than you may expect, didn't understand the basic =
principle of having all the music in tune.
It's music for adolescent drug users by adolescent drug users, =
shamelessly so, and for that reason, I would go beyond "childlike" as a =
description, and move further towards "Utter Bullshit".

> I would agree that happy hardcore is consistent with the Taoist notion =
of
> returning to the inner child, the part of oneself that is the purest =
form
> of: a child of God. =20

... The FUCK?!?

Did I miss a page here?

Why are so many people in the US determined to find religion claptrap in =
every damn thing they can?
Jesse Ventura is my idol, for his statement: "Religion is nothing more =
than a crutch for the weak".

> This is hardly a disadvantage in my opinion as it allows a
> release of the energy of youth and a conscious return to the playful
> spirit of human community.

Uh huh.

Or, looking at it another, slightly more grounded way, it's hardly =
surprising that a music form tailored for Ecstacy users is often seen to =
be listened to by very happy, uninhibited people.

Perhaps it is the love of our Lord, Jesus Christ, moving through their =
unbalanced souls, and realigning their inner light with the true will of =
God, causing these sensations of joy and rapture????

Or maybe it's a bunch of kids on drugs, acting like a bunch of kids on =
drugs.
And, for the record, and to stop the inevitable comments of "But I like =
it and I don't do drugs", you don't have to be on drugs to act like =
someone on drugs.

> In this spirit, happycore is one of the few electronic
> music genres that promotes singing along to the lyrics, a fundamental =
part
> of ancient music and dance ritual.  As such, it provides another =
pathway
> for people to enter the scene from other music communities.

What the flaming wizzle shizzle are you people smoking in San Francisco?
Toilet Bleach?

What a major shocker that is.. nursery rhyme music for crackheads, and =
the kids sing along like a bunch of 8 year olds learning the alphabet..

> I believe that hatred of certain music is typically tied to prejudice =
against the people
> who listen to the music...

Yes, I will agree with that.
I don't get on with idiots that take pills.
I don't get on with cutesy wootsy kids.
I don't like people that can't control themselves when they go out to =
places.
So it's no surprise I don't get along with a bunch of cutesy wootsy kids =
that get out of their head on a trillion pills and lie around the floor, =
massaging lotion into each others arms while puking in the corner and =
telling people they just met that they love them.

BUT, it's not just the clientelle - it's the mindless, brainless =
thumping of a music that stretches the term of 'music' to its limit.
It's marginally more musical than gabba and 'terrorcore', but only by a =
tiny sliver of a percent.

> The responses on this list provide evidence that the resistance to =
happycore=20
> is also based on contempt for an audience that epitomizes the "candy =
raver"
> stereotype.=20

And what's wrong with that?

You love to keep talking about the early rave scene and how it was back =
then, so let's talk about that for a moment.
There were NO Candykids.
There was no-one acting like a candykid.
For the most part, you would be lucky to find someone under 20 going to =
raves.
They were huge electronic music festivals, more like a psychadelic theme =
park with music than the events that go on today.
Those people that got too messed up were shunned by the crowd, who went =
about their business.
Candy Kids on the other hand, revel in the kind of behaviour that used =
to get people thrown out of events, in order to make the event better.
There are people like me out there that DON'T enjoy socialising with =
these kinds of mental case screw ups, don't like being near them, and =
certainly don't want to be round them when going out somewhere.
You may tell me my kundalini spirit is not tempered properly, or that my =
inner child needs more emotional nourishment, but I consider myself far =
more normal for disliking these damn children than the people that are =
quite happy to just step over them when they collapse on the dancefloor.

> Disrespect of a people due to their choice of music is our exact =
charge
> against government and society in reference to the rave crackdown in
> general.=20

You know, I have grown up with raves, raving and rave culture.
Your American Candy Kid freakshow has absolutely NOTHING to do with the =
roots of the rave scene, and they should have been kicked out of your =
dance music scene a long, long, long time ago.

It is NO surprise to ANYONE outside the USA why the Government is =
cracking down on raves!!
You're allowing these fucking retards to still be a part of it!!
Let's stop ignoring the truth here - These days, Candy Kids at an event =
ALWAYS equals drugs and idiotic kids taking stupid substances in stupid =
quantities.
Do you really think the Government would be as bothered if they didn't =
look and act like such degenerate crackheads???

> I would therefore advise that each of us be a part of the
> celebration of our diversity rather than unwitting accomplices in the
> culture war.

And in contrary to that, I would advise that if you have any love for =
dance music in your life, you do NOT allow these stupid little children =
to run amock at your events, and you do NOT turn a blind eye when they =
lie around the floor, wondering what Planet they're on.

If you clean up your raves, then your raves will no longer be seen as =
the drug-sustained insanity that they - quiet rightly - are being seen =
as.

Stop pretending to yourselves that the rave scene is just an innocent =
celebration, and start taking action against the bullshit that has =
almost destroyed it for you.

If you don't, then you'll be kicking yourselves for standing by and =
doing nothing when the scene has been strangled by worried authorities.

> aolim: godisunity

Ahhh, that explains a lot.

-D

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Re: TO HAPPYCORE HATERS

>>>>>
From: DNA
Subject: Re: In Defense of Happy Hardcore
Please pass this on to whatever idiot is trying to pass this bullshit off as 
fact!  >>>>>>

That would be me.

>>  The happycore scene is actually the only surviving element of dance 
>>culture in England that still views itself as a rave scene, having 
>>resisted the general transition of the scene into a club-centered culture.

>>>>>>
What absolute fucking drivel.
Taking this apart line by line, the 'happycore' scene is no surviving at 
all.
It is as near to dead as something can be without decomposing.
Record sales - if you can call them that - are so pathetic now, only the 
most narrow minded fool can pretend it has a fanbase of note any more.
>>>>>>

I never said it was the most popular genre, nor do I think that is relevant 
to the discussion.

>>>>>>
Hard House, seen by many thousands of listeners and CLUBBERS, is seen as a 
natural progression of what Hardcore once was, and is very happy to be seen 
as rave music.  Although England has never (and we fucking hope WILL never) 
have Candy Kids, our closest equivelent is exclusive to Hard House.
>>>>>>

I love hard house and the people in that scene as well but I do not believe 
they see themselves as ravers.  Any even-minded observer entering a hard 
house room and then a happycore room at a British party would agree that the 
happycore kids are most like American ravers and a closer equivelent to 
'candy kids.'

>>>>>>
Happy Hardcore is now almost universally seen on this island as pathetic, 
laughable noise.
It is not played at ANY events around the Country, other than the 1 or 2 
organisations still trying to promote it.
Of those, only 1 has put on any event of respectable size in the last 12 
months, and that success was arguably due more to the popular venue it was 
being held at closing forever immediately after the event.
>>>>>>

I agree that happycore is treated with contempt by mainstream club culture 
in England.  It may not be played at massives, but there certainly are many 
happycore events in England.  One need only check the ush.net calendar.

>>>>>>
England is moving further and further away from club culture with every 
weekend that passes, and large scale dance parties or festivals is now 
taking hold as the successor.
>>>>>>

If this is true, I am happy to hear it.  As of a year ago when I left, this 
was not the case.  There is definitely a massive festival circuit but I 
don't think you could reasonably say that they are moving away from club 
culture.

 > If you walk into a happycore event today in England (or check ush.net) 
you will still
 > meet people who are self-consciously "ravers" whereas if you attend other
 > events there, people will tell you that the rave scene died a decade ago.

>>>>>>
If you walk into a happycore event today in England, or check ush.net, you 
will meet the same 30 or 40 people, all the time.
Ush.net IS the UK happycore scene.
Each rave is little more than a meet up for them.
>>>>>>

These are good people, including some friends of mine.  I met far more than 
40 people at happycore events.

>>>>>>
If you attend other events in the UK and ask people if they are ravers, 
especially if you ask from a standpoint of defending happy hardcore, it's 
not surprising at all that they distance themselves from it in an extreme 
way.
The rave scene YOU are referring to, however, DID die a long time ago.
>From late 95 onwards, happycore was it's own scene, forever desperately 
trying to cling on to what once was.
It has been in a continual decline since then, and is now at such a 
pathetically no-existant level, you have to wonder about the accumulative 
effects of drugs for anyone still holding hope for its future.
>>>>>>

With a very derisive tone, this is the same thing that I said.  Some people 
are content to let the rave scene die and think that it died long ago.  
Others still consider themselves ravers and are trying to evolve and 
continue.  These are mostly the happycore kids.

 > A derogatory tone has been used on this list to call happycore 
"childlike."
 > I would agree that happy hardcore is consistent with the Taoist notion of
 > returning to the inner child, the part of oneself that is the purest form
 > of: a child of God.

>>>>>>
... The FUCK?!?
Did I miss a page here?
Why are so many people in the US determined to find religion claptrap in 
every damn thing they can?
Jesse Ventura is my idol, for his statement: "Religion is nothing more than 
a crutch for the weak".
>>>>>>

Spirituality is evidently not part of the rave scene contemplated here.  My 
message, however, was that a return to the youthful spirit can be an 
important release in modern society.  That message is not dependant on 
religious affiliation.

 > This is hardly a disadvantage in my opinion as it allows a
 > release of the energy of youth and a conscious return to the playful
 > spirit of human community.

>>>>>>
Uh huh. Or, looking at it another, slightly more grounded way, it's hardly 
surprising that a music form tailored for Ecstacy users is often seen to be 
listened to by very happy, uninhibited people.
Perhaps it is the love of our Lord, Jesus Christ, moving through their 
unbalanced souls, and realigning their inner light with the true will of 
God, causing these sensations of joy and rapture????
Or maybe it's a bunch of kids on drugs, acting like a bunch of kids on 
drugs.
And, for the record, and to stop the inevitable comments of "But I like it 
and I don't do drugs", you don't have to be on drugs to act like someone on 
drugs.
>>>>>>

I have not seen any evidence that happycore ravers are any more likely to do 
drugs than people who listen to other genres.  Happycore is certainly 
tailored to dancing quite hard.  For some, this may take drugs; for me, it 
does not.

 > In this spirit, happycore is one of the few electronic
 > music genres that promotes singing along to the lyrics, a fundamental 
part
 > of ancient music and dance ritual.  As such, it provides another pathway
 > for people to enter the scene from other music communities.

>>>>>>
What the flaming wizzle shizzle are you people smoking in San Francisco?
Toilet Bleach?
What a major shocker that is.. nursery rhyme music for crackheads, and the 
kids sing along like a bunch of 8 year olds learning the alphabet..
>>>>>>

I am not embarrassed to sing along; it is one of the oldest ways to 
appreciate music.


 > I believe that hatred of certain music is typically tied to prejudice 
against the people
 > who listen to the music...

>>>>>>
Yes, I will agree with that.
I don't get on with idiots that take pills.
I don't get on with cutesy wootsy kids.
I don't like people that can't control themselves when they go out to 
places.
So it's no surprise I don't get along with a bunch of cutesy wootsy kids 
that get out of their head on a trillion pills and lie around the floor, 
massaging lotion into each others arms while puking in the corner and 
telling people they just met that they love them.
>>>>>>

This is a beautiful illustration of the contempt for rave culture.  In my 
opinion, it is not in our interest either to perpetuate these stereotypes or 
to espouse hatred toward music that is tied to a hatred of the people in our 
community.

 > Disrespect of a people due to their choice of music is our exact charge
 > against government and society in reference to the rave crackdown in
 > general.

>>>>>>
You know, I have grown up with raves, raving and rave culture.
Your American Candy Kid freakshow has absolutely NOTHING to do with the 
roots of the rave scene, and they should have been kicked out of your dance 
music scene a long, long, long time ago.
It is NO surprise to ANYONE outside the USA why the Government is cracking 
down on raves!!
You're allowing these fucking retards to still be a part of it!!
Let's stop ignoring the truth here - These days, Candy Kids at an event 
ALWAYS equals drugs and idiotic kids taking stupid substances in stupid 
quantities.
Do you really think the Government would be as bothered if they didn't look 
and act like such degenerate crackheads???
>>>>>>

Some of us are on the other side of this culture war.  We do not believe 
people should be denigrated for the style of music they choose or for the 
style of clothing they wear.  I do not wish to throw anyone out of the 
scene.  I'm willing to help anyone who needs help with drugs or other 
problems or to consider harm reduction strategies for the scene as a whole.  
The solution, however, is not to move the scene entirely into clubs and 
concert venues and ban all items that remind you of the kids you disdain.

Matt Grossmann
icq: 4984980
aolim: godisunity
matthewg@uclink.berkeley.edu

Yes, that's right... I am finally home from my little "around the world" =
excursions.  I got back from Costa Rica last night... To refresh you all =
on my travels... I was in New Zealand in June, Egypt in July, and Costa =
Rica in August.  And I made a little 2 week pit stop in L.A.  ANYWAY, I =
won't BORE you with TOO much of what I did...=20

New Zealand was for work, I drect a chorus and they were on tour... WHOO =
HOOO!

I have friends and family in Egypt so I PARTIEDDD like no other, as =
usual... Yes, I've visited the sites (like 10 years ago...), but =
actually... This year, I had a request for sand and a picture in front =
of the  pyramids with a flyer, so I HAULED MY ASS to the pyramids, got =
on my knees looking like a fool and picked up holy sand. :-D

And Costa Rica was KICK ASS... I went rafting, deep sea fishing, toured =
the rainforest (met some monkeys), saw an active volcano with lava =
dripping down the side... You know, all that envoirnmental shizznet.  My =
father is teaching down there, so he told my brother and I to COME on =
down. :) =20

Anyway, I hope you guys had a KILLER summer, just like I did. I know I =
missed a million parties, but I'm just looking out for pictures and what =
not.  ~*MUWAH*~
It's GOOD to be home,
Sabrina

Subject: Re: [sfraves] WE

Adam asserted:
>     We bitch and complain about our scene. Yet when the time comes to
>support shit. We judge it by how cool the dj's are. What happened to the
>thought that "I am the party"??  Its not that the dj makes the party.
>The dj is one party of huge picture. The people make it. You make it.

Exactly. How many times have you heard someone complain about the other 
people at the party? And I think, "Wait a minute! YOU are the people at the 
party!"

If you want a good vibe, you should recruit your own friends to go. Or you 
could walk talk to the people waiting in line at the toilets, or at the bar 
or at the coat check. You could smile at people instead of checking them 
out. Or, as Adam suggested, you could dance.

What do you do when the dancefloor loses its vibe and it fills up with 
sloppy drunks, shoving you out of the way or grabbing your ass?

Just keep dancing. Face forward, close your eyes and feel the bass.

You ARE the vibe, you ARE the party.

pax,
k

b. some french body lotion that i applied to my skin
after shaving, and then i sat outside in the sun.  

so, what does an allergic reaction mean to someone
like me or maybe you too? well, i am not always being
glamorous, simply because i am EXHAUSTEd, however, i
do like 
to shave my legs, and even though i do not look like a
big hairy gorilla, i have not been able to shave my
legs 
since last sunday, so i am not happy about that, plus,
i have a rash..also, my hair is lovely, however, i
found 
some really pretty hair color in a box for a very good
price that i invested in, but now i cannot even do the
little 
test patch on my arm to see if i able to safely use
the hair color until my current rash goes away...you
see, if 
one product is giving you a rash, you want to be sure
that that is the only thing that is giving you a rash
so 
that you can be sure never to use it again. anyway, i
am so annoyed, plus, even though i put sunscreen on my
face, 
i am still getting burned, and also, since i have this
stupid 
allergic reaction, i can't wear shorts or a cute short
skirt, because the sun might have played a role in my
current 
skin condition. ugggggggghhhhhhh!~!!!!!!!!!!! at
least, i am still able to wear pink lip gloss. :)

From sfraves-return-71410-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Sat Aug 18 22:18:58 2001
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-71410-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>

Mime-Version: 1.0
X-Sender: lists>deepfog.com@pop.deepfog.com (Unverified)
Message-Id: <v04220807b7a499bc07cb@[216.15.60.33]>
Date: Sat, 18 Aug 2001 15:17:06 -0700
To: SFRavEs Mailing List <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
From: Deepfog <lists@deepfog.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii" ; format="flowed"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] [DF-corner] Struggle for Equality

Deepfog's Corner
Saturday, August 18, 2001

--------------------------
Struggle for Equality
--------------------------

"I know why you pull me ovah, it's because I'm black, isn't it?"

"No, it's..."

""&*^^^*&#!  You just don't like me cause I'm black, right?"

"Sir, you're not black."

"Oh.  That's right.  I forgot."

Don't mind me, I'm just making this up as I go along... =]

---

This week we've seen more of what is undeniably a sharp increase in 
the number of arrests and alleged harrassment by all three branches 
of our government.  Right now it seems like they have us ravers 
backed into a corner --- with perhaps no way out.  The eternal 
question, of course, is what, if anything, do we intend to do about 
it?  Online discussions about the subject are randomly rampant; 
people get tired of the debates after a while, but it is nevertheless 
important to get that point of view out on the table.

Some claim we can compare the struggle of the underground rave 
movement to the struggle of Ghandi and Dr. King, while others claim 
that it does not, and it's insulting to even suggest it.  In reality 
though, it may not be entirely accurate to compare them, for Dr. King 
and Ghandi are not living in 21st Century America, a place which is 
relatively clean and civilized, to a certain point, but is riddled 
with control which we have asked for more of progressively over 
generations.  Probably the most important thing they did not have 
that we have is the Internet.  Now that we are able to communicate 
cheaply and instantaneously around the globe, our personal level of 
importance has equalized in some way.  Television, radio and film 
were great steps in achieving what we are today, for better or worse. 
One major drawback of that era, however was there was no medium which 
the average person could voice their opinions and have the same 
potential audience in numbers as there is today.  In fact, this very 
article is a product of such change.  Now anyone that wants to step 
up to the podium and be Dr. King can, and they don't have to worry 
about cancellation due to lack of ratings.

But what about equality?  Isn't it proper and necessary for any group 
that feels unfairly treated to protest?  Why has dancing become such 
a big issue?  If the world isn't ready for us, they can stay home, 
but leave us alone and let us dance.   Taking the parties more 
underground won't always work...though only inviting people you know 
and keeping it small is probably safer in the short run; that, 
however, can start bordering elitism very quickly and make things 
stale due to lack of new people interacting with them on a scene 
level.  Sure, we can all form small groups, but it's not going to 
guarantee people won't be harassed in the way they are today.  Are we 
going to allow this to continue without a fight and hope it will just 
go away?

It won't.

fog out


---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

(Associated Press) San Francisco, CA - Apparently there will be no 
ambient music at Rant ' Rave this evening.  Rumor has it the entire 
Ambient Mafia was abducted late last night into a Russian nuclear 
submarine.  The greedy bastards wanted to be entertained personally 
and they are now headed for the Arctic Circle.  The United States 
government has sent out 3 Urban Assault Vehicles in search of their 
safe return and the aircraft carrier Nimitz has changed course, 
though this is completely unrelated to the Ambient Mafia's 
predicament.

Subject: [sfraves] [bsp] Clean Plate Club - TONIGHT! - w/ Midwest legend NICK NICE


Tonight's the night!

An Sibin's probably going to be packed, so
get there early and don't be left out.

Dress to dance. Dress to SWEAT.

--------------------------------------------------------

Ten reasons you'd be a damn FOOL to miss Nick Nice tonight:

(1) Plays the fattest, funkiest, sexiest disko/tech/HOUSE music ever.

(2) Threw the first rave party EVER in the Midwest, Oct. 31, 1991.

(3) Blowin' up dancefloors for 14 years running.

(4) Was resident DJ at Queen, the then #1 club in Paris, and has
     guested at Le Rex, the current top club in France, as well as
     guesting on Bob Sinclar's "Yellow Mix" radio program.

(5) Revered as a GOD by his legions of fans worldwide.

(6) Owner/operator of one of the Midwest's most respected dance
     music stores, Nice Musique.

(7) Runs his own record label, Milk Tank records.

(8) Was the mentor of Clean Plate Club's spectacular resident DJ,
     Chad Mindrive.

(9) Will be dropping bombs from his collection of over 30,000 records.

(10) Dozens more reasons that none of us, frankly, have the time
       to get into.


-------------------------------------------------------

big appetite presents....

CLEAN PLATE CLUB

Saturday, August 18th
(& every 3rd Saturday)

An Sibin
1176 Sutter @ Polk, SF
21+ w/ ID - limited capacity

9pm - 2am
$7 (free til 9:30)
new sound! more BASS!

"Arguably the city's best, and most unsung, tech house
party for Midwest refugees."   -   Flyer Magazine



Featuring an unforgettable 3 hour soul-shaking set by
the founding father of the Midwest rave scene in his
long overdue FIRST EVER San Francisco performance:


===========  N I C K   N I C E !  =============

milk tank records / nice musique : madison, wi

14 years, 30,000+ records, and one forever-changed planet
later, Nick finally gives the SF housecats a thorough feeding.

11:00pm - 2:00am

(house, disco-house, tech-house, & more house!)



plus Clean Plate Club resident and Nick's longtime friend:


=========== CHAD MINDRIVE ==============

nice musique / clean plate club : sf

If Nick Nice were Yoda, this man would be Luke Skywalker.
Joining him on the decks one more time - family reunion style.

9:00pm - 11:00pm

(deep, crisp and funky house & tech-house)

-----------------------------------------------------------------------

Appetizers anyone?

"Nice History", an interesting history lesson on the origins of
the Midwest scene and a chronicle of Nick's rise to greatness.
http://www.subversiveindustries.com/nicehistory.htm

An online streaming set...
http://www.nstend.com/2012/madfam4/dotm_db.asp?n=8


Once again, let's keep it simple and just say that if you truly love
house music, this is one DJ you owe it to yourself to experience.
It would be a gross understatment to say that you will NOT
leave disappointed. 


------------> Greg "still hungry after all these years" Bird

X-Priority: 3 (Normal)
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook IMO, Build 9.0.2416 (9.0.2911.0)
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V5.00.2919.6600
In-Reply-To: <F62zGNsokLQ8aZRhQdO0000b3a0@hotmail.com>
Importance: Normal
X-Loop-Detect: 1
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] WE

And another thing:
   Speaking as both a DJ and a person who gets on the floor and dances, we
really do like it when YOU dance!!!  Spinning isn't just about being a great
DJ--its about giving and taking.  I guarentee you that if you're all
dancing, the DJ will be even more pumped, and probably give you an even
better set in return.  I'm not sayin' the DJ has nothing to do with the
nite--i mean, you gotta know how to spin, and you gotta know what people
what.  But it is about interaction and the crowd and DJ definitely build off
of each other and vice versa.

Does any of that make sense??

.:nomadic:.
www.nomadicDJ.com

<<<<{dance like no one's watching}>>>>

-----Original Message-----
From: K Gray [mailto:kehgray@hotmail.com]
Sent: 18 August 2001 06:56
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] WE
Importance: Low


Adam asserted:
>     We bitch and complain about our scene. Yet when the time comes to
>support shit. We judge it by how cool the dj's are. What happened to the
>thought that "I am the party"??  Its not that the dj makes the party.
>The dj is one party of huge picture. The people make it. You make it.

Exactly. How many times have you heard someone complain about the other
people at the party? And I think, "Wait a minute! YOU are the people at the
party!"

If you want a good vibe, you should recruit your own friends to go. Or you
could walk talk to the people waiting in line at the toilets, or at the bar
or at the coat check. You could smile at people instead of checking them
out. Or, as Adam suggested, you could dance.

What do you do when the dancefloor loses its vibe and it fills up with
sloppy drunks, shoving you out of the way or grabbing your ass?

Just keep dancing. Face forward, close your eyes and feel the bass.

You ARE the vibe, you ARE the party.

pax,
k
www.dancingisnotacrime.com

Subject: [sfraves] Rant N Rave CANCELLED IMPORTANT PLEASE READ!!!!  (Gianni)

     Well, Everyone It seems like we've lost another great all ages bay area 
venue. Thanks to whoever is hiding behind the made up name of 
"MysticalMayhem@hotmail.com" is we've now lost our venue for RANT "N" RAVE.  
Yes, RANT N RAVE as of now is CANCELED. It seems that the CHP got an 
anonymous call as did the Sacramento headquarters of our venue. Well, 
Needless to say I'm very upset. I just can't understand how some of you 
people think. I could sit here and vent for hours about this but instead I've 
choosing to try to make something positive out of this. I hope that the 
person and or persons responsible for this, is reading this. If we as a 
community are going to EVER survive all the negative publicity from the 
outside media then we must stick together at some level. Yes, We are always 
going to have disagreements, and even people we just don't like. I understand 
that, that's life, But if this scene is to EVER survive we have to understand 
that sometimes we have to look out for ALL OF OUR best interests, for the 
Scene's best interests. The survival of the bay area rave scene depends on 
this. I can say that there goes one more great all ages venue, for ever!!! 
Not just a venue for me, or Yarrow, or you but for ALL of us. So I guess I'm 
pleading to you (who ever you are) To please think before you act, Think not 
only about your enemy, think not only about you, but think about the entire 
industry that WE are all a part of. Everytime you do this your killing a 
little bit more of the bay area rave scene. If WE don't stop hurting 
eachother soon, this scene that we all love will no longer exist. I have just 
one more thing that I'd like to add, I've been playing out of town quite a 
bit and I can honestly say that 70% of the raves/clubs that I play at suck 
compared to our own BAY AREA. We are all so spoiled, The bay area ROCKS!!! So 
lets all try to save it before we lose it forever. 
For all you who had planned a great night with us and purchased presales 
please go back to the store for the ticket price less the service charge. We 
are truly sorry for any inconvenience this has caused and I'd hope that we 
have your continued support.  

        
                                    
                                    respectfully 
                                                
                                                Gianni

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
