Subject: Re: [sfraves] WE

Yeah, I kinda agree with this. I mean, I'm not going to lie, there have
been crowds that have completley gotten my spirits down, whether it be
that there were just way too many kids on drugs, or mean hard guys
pushing me around, or whatever the circumstance are. A lot of times if I
am in that kind of situation I find myself kind of sulking in the corner
thinking 'why am I here?' but lately if by chance I end up at such a
party where I'm just not feeling the vibe I work at making the best of
it. Take invasion for example! Very e-tarded party. Got there, kinda
bummed by the crowd and the silly little nieve kiddies running around.
Tired and stuck there I took Osby and John and joined e-puddles! Then
Jeff came and joined us later. Very funny. We made up silly names and
just joined the crowd as the sober e-tards! I don't often find myself at
too many parties like that, but the few I am at where things arn't that
great, I just try to make the best of it and adapt the best I can to my
surroundings. I'd say the best way to enjoy a party is know what kind of
crowd, music, crews, ect. please you and go with that, but every now and
then we find ourselves in places where we don't quite fit in. It can be
upsetting at times, but I guess thats when you just have to give in and
let yourself have some fun!
-Nicola-
K Gray wrote:
> 
> Adam asserted:
> >     We bitch and complain about our scene. Yet when the time comes to
> >support shit. We judge it by how cool the dj's are. What happened to the
> >thought that "I am the party"??  Its not that the dj makes the party.
> >The dj is one party of huge picture. The people make it. You make it.
> 
> Exactly. How many times have you heard someone complain about the other
> people at the party? And I think, "Wait a minute! YOU are the people at the
> party!"
> 
> If you want a good vibe, you should recruit your own friends to go. Or you
> could walk talk to the people waiting in line at the toilets, or at the bar
> or at the coat check. You could smile at people instead of checking them
> out. Or, as Adam suggested, you could dance.
> 
> What do you do when the dancefloor loses its vibe and it fills up with
> sloppy drunks, shoving you out of the way or grabbing your ass?
> 
> Just keep dancing. Face forward, close your eyes and feel the bass.
> 
> You ARE the vibe, you ARE the party.
> 
> pax,
> k
> www.dancingisnotacrime.com

From sfraves-return-71425-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Sun Aug 19 02:39:55 2001
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-71425-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 99745 invoked by uid 1104); 19 Aug 2001 02:39:53 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 99735 invoked from network); 19 Aug 2001 02:39:53 -0000
Message-ID: <20010819023948.83991.qmail@web12308.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Sat, 18 Aug 2001 19:39:48 -0700 (PDT)
From: "John B." <svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Im back, Im sorry, and thanks to all of you.


'Kay I quit filtering out SFRaves a couple of days ago, and I think Im ready
for a fresh start.

Once again, I'd like to apologise for all the negativity I was spewing out a
few weeks ago.  To anyone whom I offended, I'm sorry.

Leslie, in particular...  when you came down on me for bitching about the
livermore cops, and the enviroment at maratime hall....  when I signed off, I
described your replies as flameing me.  I'm sorry.  I was way out of line, and
your responses were level-headed and much more productive than mine ever have
been.  I truely am sorry.  The scene is so much stronger because of people like
you.

It's no excuse... but a bit of an explanation.  As anyone familiar with my
posts might gather, I have a probelm with authority figures, legitimate or
otherwise.  When said authority figures abuse the power with which they are
entrusted, I get pissed off, and tend to rant unproductively.  When
ILLEGITIMATE authority figures abuse their imaginary powers, I fly off the
handle totally.

I have always beleived that with additional power, comes a greater
responsibility to wield that power responsibly.  I think, because of the
greater power the people grant the police, they SHOULD be held to a higher
standard than the rest of us.  When they illegitimately abuse that power, and
they do NOT suffer reprecussions, I think we take one more step towards a
police state.  So, when the police DO abuse that power, I firmly beleive that
repucussions should be swiftly forthcoming.

THAT is why I have, in the past, fancied ideas of hidden webcams to record the
actions of the cops in the event of a bust, and even the "rich patron raver" to
initiate crippleing lawsuits against police who get out of line.  If they
cannot keep themselves in line, then to turn their own system against them,
would be the next best thing.  Yes, they were "pie in the sky" ideas.  Sure, I
was and am hopelessly naieve and optimistic.  But then, without hopeless
optimism, where would the world be?  Hell, California was BUILT on hopeless
optimism.

Besides... the thought of someone like Steve Jobs or Larry Ellison keeping an
abusive cop tied up in court till he can't afford his doughnuts just gives me
warm fuzzies all over.  Well, this IS California, and anything can happen
here... maybe someday *I* could be the one on the offensive instead of
defensive.

But enough idle speculation.  It wasn't appropiate for the list, and I'm sorry.

On a more positive note, the last few weeks have greatly improved my outlook on
life and my attitude.  I'm still jobless.  But I'm feeling much better about
it.  And prospects seem to be picking up a bit.  I'm a fair bit less bitter at
the world, and have swung my outlook a fair bit more in th positive direction
in the last few weeks.

And a big thanks to all of you who have been there for me... those of you who
read the list at least.  Ditto to those of you who don't... but they won't see
this.

It's amazing to think of the changes in my life since moveing here, and
becoming part of this scene.  A year and a half ago, when I was first moving
here I would never have guessed that I would have made so many friends, so
fast.  Hell, I would never have guessed that I would set foot into another
rave... and like it.

So many of you have been so kind, even when I was a complete stranger (hell,
still am to a lot of SFRaves, to be sure).  That's nothing like I ever found on
the east coast.  Thats one reason I'm loveing California so.  And that's one of
the few things that scares me about the job hunt... that I might be forced to
leave all this behind.  There's just too much, too many people, I'm too fond
of, to not be filled with saddness when I think of things like that.

I can't thank all of you enough, for what this scene has come to mean to me.


thanks,
john






__________________________________________________

Okay, on a quicker note...

A purely logistical question.  I'm thinking, this thursday, I'm FINALLY goint
to hit up Ascension, and hopefully meet a few more of the SFRaves mafia.  But
I've got a more logistical question than anything else....

Where the F*#%@!$ do you park near Blakes in Berkeley????  When I get over to
Berkeley, Im most always BARTing it.  Obviously not an option for an event
ending @ 2am.  So I gotta drive.  But having seen the vacinity of Telegraph on
foot, I despair of finding a place to park.  And all the garages Ive seen are
closed well before 2am.

Anyone kind enough to point me to wherever all nite garage or lot all you
SFRavers use?

If I make it (90% likely), I'll be there in my obnoxiously orange "Mr T" shirt.
 I pity the fool who doesn't say hey.

And who else is gonna be at Sound Aslyum?  I definately plan to be there. 
Anyone wanna suggest a couple of meet-ups?  Or maybe we'll just have a roll
call later and describe what we'll be wearing?


cya,
john

work...  i spent 8 years as a government contractor banging my head against
the wall because of all the stupid game-playing gov. employees do that
wastes so much taxpayer money.  But as one gets older, you realize how to
temper that idealism - but I hope to never lose it.  It is just a matter
of knowing what exactly you can change

> >It's no excuse... but a bit of an explanation.  As anyone familiar with my
> >posts might gather, I have a probelm with authority figures, legitimate or
> >otherwise.  When said authority figures abuse the power with which they are
> >entrusted, I get pissed off, and tend to rant unproductively.  When
> >ILLEGITIMATE authority figures abuse their imaginary powers, I fly off the
> >handle totally.
> >
> >I have always beleived that with additional power, comes a greater
> >responsibility to wield that power responsibly.  I think, because of the
> >greater power the people grant the police, they SHOULD be held to a higher
> >standard than the rest of us.  When they illegitimately abuse that 
> power, and
> >they do NOT suffer reprecussions, I think we take one more step towards a
> >police state.  So, when the police DO abuse that power, I firmly beleive 
> that
> >repucussions should be swiftly forthcoming.
> >
> >THAT is why I have, in the past, fancied ideas of hidden webcams to record
>the
> >actions of the cops in the event of a bust, and even the "rich patron
>raver" to
> >initiate crippleing lawsuits against police who get out of line.  If they
> >cannot keep themselves in line, then to turn their own system against them,
> >would be the next best thing.  Yes, they were "pie in the sky" ideas.
>Sure, I
> >was and am hopelessly naieve and optimistic.
>
>you forgot idealistic.  And I agree with you 100% actually.  I forget your
>posts and whatever the fuss was, but your theory about power and
>responsibility
>is perfectly sound.  It is just that the real world doesn't work like that
>a lot of the time and it is frustrating when you can see how things *should*
>work...  i spent 8 years as a government contractor banging my head against
>the wall because of all the stupid game-playing gov. employees do that
>wastes so much taxpayer money.  But as one gets older, you realize how to
>temper that idealism - but I hope to never lose it.  It is just a matter
>of knowing what exactly you can change

damnit, does that mean I can't spark a violent revolution?

trying to throw money at the courts to  try and fix things..

>Yeah, I kinda agree with this. I mean, I'm not going to lie, there have
>been crowds that have completley gotten my spirits down, whether it be
>that there were just way too many kids on drugs, or mean hard guys
>pushing me around, or whatever the circumstance are. A lot of times if I
>am in that kind of situation I find myself kind of sulking in the corner
>thinking 'why am I here?' but lately if by chance I end up at such a
>party where I'm just not feeling the vibe I work at making the best of
>it. Take invasion for example! Very e-tarded party. Got there, kinda
>bummed by the crowd and the silly little nieve kiddies running around.
>Tired and stuck there I took Osby and John and joined e-puddles! Then
>Jeff came and joined us later. Very funny. We made up silly names and
>just joined the crowd as the sober e-tards! I don't often find myself at
>too many parties like that, but the few I am at where things arn't that
>great, I just try to make the best of it and adapt the best I can to my
>surroundings. I'd say the best way to enjoy a party is know what kind of
>crowd, music, crews, ect. please you and go with that, but every now and
>then we find ourselves in places where we don't quite fit in. It can be
>upsetting at times, but I guess thats when you just have to give in and
>let yourself have some fun!

To: sfraves@hyperreal.org

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Mailer: AOL 5.0 for Mac sub 28

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Rant N Rave CANCELLED IMPORTANT PLEASE READ!!!!  (Gianni)

Well, Andy is like this, The California National Guard is a state run 
facility, On the back of their contract they have a clause stating that they 
can stop (cancel) anything at their facilities at any time. This clause is in 
there because its a reserve military base, and in the event that there be a 
fire, flood, riot, ect where they would need the facility ASAP. Unfortunately 
this is their way out. Now this event was ready to go, permits were issued 
from their headquarters in Sacramento. But when you have the CHP, and 
"concerned parents" (Yea right) calling the headquarters in Sacramento 
complaining and accusing the State of promoting drug use, the State (National 
Guard) can and will use their power to cancel the event. I hope this clears 
it up a little more. Have a great day 


                            Gianni  :0)

Subject: [sfraves] nrr...random thoughts of the day

--part1_d2.b29d623.28b16e7a_boundary
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

well
1st of all...who else on the list has a addiction to buying DVD's? i been 
getting alot of dope movies recently. its probably the quality and the 
compact size of the discs that make these things so fun. i been collecting 
the best of Def Comedy Jam(an essential for all the playaz up in here), i got 
snatch the movie, and some other classic movies. and the party is bout to be 
on now because on tuesday THE GOONIES is comin out on DVD. now thats gonna be 
off the hook...
...i heard from people i know that the Ibiza hotel might get into some 
trouble with the other hotels around the area near the airport. there have 
been noise complaints  because of the music being so loud at all hours of the 
nite and hotel guests from other hotels trying to sleep. the worst part is 
the pilots who sleep at the hotels dont get good sleep too and well...if they 
cant sleep youll see a 747 in your front lawn in flames if u catch my drift. 
but yeah just a word of warning for those if they happen to see the ibiza 
hotel in trouble in the near future...
...also for those interested i got a new 2step mix CD coming out called  
"Urban Swing 2001". cassette tape promos will be out real soon and within a 
month the CD will be out on the streets. i just wanted to let yall know that. 
heres the track listing for those interested:
1. Nesha-"whats it gonna be?"
2. Usher-"pop ya collar(g4orce remix)"
3. Pied Piper & the masters of ceremonies-"do u really like it?"
4. Craig David-"re-rewind(album mix)"
5. Hackney Solders(aka Shut up And Dance)-"creeping"

well there it is..hope it didnt take up too much of your time. ok im outties

Subject: [sfraves] Re:  Midwest legend NICK NICE

--MS_Mac_OE_3081074345_9816585_MIME_Part
Content-type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-transfer-encoding: 7bit

"(2) Threw the first rave party EVER in the Midwest, Oct. 31, 1991."

No big deal... but, those years were hard enough work, cost SO MUCH MONEY,
spilled so much blood, and occasionally hard time in jail... that I feel the
record should be set straight.

First off, Nick Nice & Co. are the shit, no doubt... 'true pioneers of the
Midwestern scene.  Minddrive is an old friend and Dj partner of mine. BUT,
you can even ask them and I'm sure they'll remember who actually threw the
first raves in the Midwest.  Mark Farina, Derrick Carter, Spencer Kincey,
Mark Substance, Mystic Bill, Diz along with myself (known then by my full
name, Wade Randolph Hampton) had been throwing underground warehouse parties
in Chicago for 2 years by then. The parties were called '321', 'Substance',
'1466' and 'Wades World' along with the odd Project X - 'Outlaw Parties'
featuring a brash young New Yorker named, Keoki.

We had, in fact, given in to the terminology and started calling this binge
of ours 'raving' by the Summer of '91.  The first midwestern rave was
actually Sept. 13, 1991 and it was called - LIFE, thrown by Blue Sky
Corporation.  The next one was Ultra Life on Oct. 5 and finally, on the Oct.
12 was Energy Rave, featuring none other than DJ JD, now known around the
world as John Digweed.

Where this Wisconsin crew really stepped in and made a change was later the
next year when they took the idea of raving outside... farms, ranches, empty
fields etc. This become the style for a while, and after the dark warehouses
we'd been hanging out in, I have to say it was a welcome change of pace.

Minddrive if you're out there on SFRaves... bounce me your info... I'd love
to hook up.


wishfm


From: Big Appetite <neurolektrik@earthlink.net>
Date: Sat, 18 Aug 2001 16:25:03 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org, dph email list <DPH@topica.com>, tekheads
<tekheads@topica.com>
Subject: [sfraves] [bsp] Clean Plate Club - TONIGHT! - w/ Midwest legend
NICK NICE



Tonight's the night!

An Sibin's probably going to be packed, so
get there early and don't be left out.

Dress to dance. Dress to SWEAT.

--------------------------------------------------------

Ten reasons you'd be a damn FOOL to miss Nick Nice tonight:

(1) Plays the fattest, funkiest, sexiest disko/tech/HOUSE music ever.

(2) Threw the first rave party EVER in the Midwest, Oct. 31, 1991.

(3) Blowin' up dancefloors for 14 years running.

(4) Was resident DJ at Queen, the then #1 club in Paris, and has
guested at Le Rex, the current top club in France, as well as
guesting on Bob Sinclar's "Yellow Mix" radio program.

(5) Revered as a GOD by his legions of fans worldwide.

(6) Owner/operator of one of the Midwest's most respected dance
music stores, Nice Musique.

(7) Runs his own record label, Milk Tank records.

(8) Was the mentor of Clean Plate Club's spectacular resident DJ,
Chad Mindrive.

(9) Will be dropping bombs from his collection of over 30,000 records.

(10) Dozens more reasons that none of us, frankly, have the time
 to get into.


-------------------------------------------------------

big appetite presents....

CLEAN PLATE CLUB

Saturday, August 18th
(& every 3rd Saturday)

An Sibin
1176 Sutter @ Polk, SF
21+ w/ ID - limited capacity

9pm - 2am
$7 (free til 9:30)
new sound! more BASS!

"Arguably the city's best, and most unsung, tech house
party for Midwest refugees."   -   Flyer Magazine



Featuring an unforgettable 3 hour soul-shaking set by
the founding father of the Midwest rave scene in his
long overdue FIRST EVER San Francisco performance:


===========  N I C K   N I C E !  =============

milk tank records / nice musique : madison, wi

14 years, 30,000+ records, and one forever-changed planet
later, Nick finally gives the SF housecats a thorough feeding.

11:00pm - 2:00am

(house, disco-house, tech-house, & more house!)



plus Clean Plate Club resident and Nick's longtime friend:


=========== CHAD MINDRIVE ==============

nice musique / clean plate club : sf

If Nick Nice were Yoda, this man would be Luke Skywalker.
Joining him on the decks one more time - family reunion style.

9:00pm - 11:00pm

(deep, crisp and funky house & tech-house)

-----------------------------------------------------------------------

Appetizers anyone?

"Nice History", an interesting history lesson on the origins of
the Midwest scene and a chronicle of Nick's rise to greatness.
http://www.subversiveindustries.com/nicehistory.htm

An online streaming set...
http://www.nstend.com/2012/madfam4/dotm_db.asp?n=8


Once again, let's keep it simple and just say that if you truly love
house music, this is one DJ you owe it to yourself to experience.
It would be a gross understatment to say that you will NOT
leave disappointed.


------------> Greg "still hungry after all these years" Bird

perhaps

were

between your personal fantasy, and the reality of the
situation.

make light and make jokes, but i can see that it's
having 
a bad effect on our little environment here, and i
don't 
really like it anyway. i actually resent it, even when
i'm smiling. i'm a busy gal. go read some erotica.
peace. :)

Subject: [sfraves] Hard Drives and House History

The PC I've configured for communication and business has been behaving in
an erratic fashion for the past week and on Friday the hard drive died.
Ugh!!!  So I've been incommunicado lately working pretty much non-stop to
replace the drive and rebuild the system.  Since my bread and jam depends on
this computer, my focus has been on repairing and restoring the data.  House
History, therefore, will resume with Issue 26 this coming week.

The only good thing about losing a hard drive is that you get rid of all the
useless crap that you've accumulated over time.  Sort of like moving to a
new house.

Love,

Apollo


"A little nonsense now and then is relished by the wisest men..."

- Roald Dahl, Willie Wonka and the Chocolate Factory


"Spend money on experience, not on goods."

- Ben, Burningman 2000

Subject: [sfraves] URGENT- Bjork Tickets (nrr)

This is an urgent cry to anyone who can help. Bjork is having her concert 
coming up at the Paramount Theatre in Oakland. I was so hyped when I heard. 
I have been a HARDCORE fan for ten years and have been *dying* to see her in 
concert. So, naturally I was set up online to get tickets at 9:30 this 
morning, ready for when they were to go on sale at 10am. Boom, within FIVE 
minutes they were sold out. So me being the devoted fan I am I decided to go 
for the tickets in LA, hoping I would have better luck. So again, I was all 
set up at 11:45 for the tickets to go on sale at 12. This time the tickets 
sold out within THREE minutes. I am so devastated right now. If ANYONE has 
an extra ticket or knows anyone who does, I don't care where it is or who 
I'm sitting next to, I would be forever in debt to you. I AM DESPERATE. Ten 
years now I have been waiting for this. I can't begin to explain really how 
much this concert means to me. Call me at 415.451.8160 if you have any 
leads. Thank you from the bottom of my little Bjork lovin' heart. : )


Alida

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Re: TO HAPPYCORE HATERS



> ----- Original Message -----
> From: DNA
> To: Bryan Oley ; sacraves@hyperreal.org
> Sent: Friday, August 17, 2001 6:28 PM
> Subject: Re: In Defense of Happy Hardcore

I'm not a Happycore lover.  But I'm also not one to diss music that other
people love and gets them dancing.  All this negativity and drama
surrounding an innocuous musical genre mystifies me.

The post from DNA forwarded to the list in response to Matt's eloquent and
thoughtful defense of his musical passion was, however, offensive to me in a
couple of important areas.

First, I think attacking another's religious or spiritual beliefs is out of
order here.  DNA is certainly no intellectual giant.  "Jesse Ventura is my
idol" pretty much summarizes his level of sophistication in philosophical
matters.  What we have here is adolescent, barroom-level prejudice.

And his classification of all Candy Kids as pretty much the core of all evil
in the American rave community is just more mindless bigotry.

Drugs.  Who the hell is this brit to take the high ground on drugs?  The
brit dance scene is drug -free?  Acid house had no connection to
psychedelics?  Those who I know in the UK underground culture tell me crack
is the drug of choice these days at the squat parties. Every music
subculture has some problems with a minority of people, young or old, who
have addiction-related diseases.  You take care of your house, dude.  We
will take care of ours.

Props to Matt for his reasoned reply to this rant designed to provoke more
fruitless, gut-inspired  flaming rather than reasoned debate.

Love,

Apollo



>
>
> > Read it
>
> Done that.
>
> > and think before you flame

> Done that.

> Heh.
>
> Please pass this on to whatever idiot is trying to pass this
> bullshit off as fact!
>
> >  The happycore scene is actually the only surviving element of
> dance culture
> > in England that still views itself as a rave scene, having resisted the
> > general transition of the scene into a club-centered culture.
>
> What absolute fucking drivel.
> Taking this apart line by line, the 'happycore' scene is no
> surviving at all.
> It is as near to dead as something can be without decomposing.
> Record sales - if you can call them that - are so pathetic now,
> only the most narrow minded fool can pretend it has a fanbase of
> note any more.
> Hard House, seen by many thousands of listeners and clubbers, is
> seen as a natural progression of what Hardcore once was, and is
> very happy to be seen as rave music.  Although England has never
> (and we fucking hope WILL never) have Candy Kids, our closest
> equivelent is exclusive to Hard House.
> Happy Hardcore is now almost universally seen on this island as
> pathetic, laughable noise.
> It is not played at ANY events around the Country, other than the
> 1 or 2 organisations still trying to promote it.
> Of those, only 1 has put on any event of respectable size in the
> last 12 months, and that success was arguably due more to the
> popular venue it was being held at closing forever immediately
> after the event.
>
> England is moving further and further away from club culture with
> every weekend that passes, and large scale dance parties or
> festivals is now taking hold as the successor.
>
> > If you walk into a happycore event today in England (or check
> ush.net) you will still
> > meet people who are self-consciously "ravers" whereas if you
> attend other
> > events there, people will tell you that the rave scene died a
> decade ago.
>
> If you walk into a happycore event today in England, or check
> ush.net, you will meet the same 30 or 40 people, all the time.
> Ush.net IS the UK happycore scene.
> Each rave is little more than a meet up for them.
>
> If you attend other events in the UK and ask people if they are
> ravers, especially if you ask from a standpoint of defending
> happy hardcore, it's not surprising at all that they distance
> themselves from it in an extreme way.
> The rave scene YOU are referring to, however, DID die a long time ago.
> From late 95 onwards, happycore was it's own scene, forever
> desperately trying to cling on to what once was.
> It has been in a continual decline since then, and is now at such
> a pathetically no-existant level, you have to wonder about the
> accumulative effects of drugs for anyone still holding hope for
> its future.
>
> > A derogatory tone has been used on this list to call happycore
> "childlike."
>
> That's because happycore is the most worthless, ridiculous shite
> on the Planet.
> And I say that from a standpoint of someone who made it
> professionally for several years, and started his musical career in it.
> It is garbage, most often made by people with little to no
> musical ability, who more often than you may expect, didn't
> understand the basic principle of having all the music in tune.
> It's music for adolescent drug users by adolescent drug users,
> shamelessly so, and for that reason, I would go beyond
> "childlike" as a description, and move further towards "Utter Bullshit".
>
> > I would agree that happy hardcore is consistent with the Taoist
> notion of
> > returning to the inner child, the part of oneself that is the
> purest form
> > of: a child of God.
>
> ... The FUCK?!?
>
> Did I miss a page here?
>
> Why are so many people in the US determined to find religion
> claptrap in every damn thing they can?
> Jesse Ventura is my idol, for his statement: "Religion is nothing
> more than a crutch for the weak".
>
> > This is hardly a disadvantage in my opinion as it allows a
> > release of the energy of youth and a conscious return to the playful
> > spirit of human community.
>
> Uh huh.
>
> Or, looking at it another, slightly more grounded way, it's
> hardly surprising that a music form tailored for Ecstacy users is
> often seen to be listened to by very happy, uninhibited people.
>
> Perhaps it is the love of our Lord, Jesus Christ, moving through
> their unbalanced souls, and realigning their inner light with the
> true will of God, causing these sensations of joy and rapture????
>
> Or maybe it's a bunch of kids on drugs, acting like a bunch of
> kids on drugs.
> And, for the record, and to stop the inevitable comments of "But
> I like it and I don't do drugs", you don't have to be on drugs to
> act like someone on drugs.
>
> > In this spirit, happycore is one of the few electronic
> > music genres that promotes singing along to the lyrics, a
> fundamental part
> > of ancient music and dance ritual.  As such, it provides another pathway
> > for people to enter the scene from other music communities.
>
> What the flaming wizzle shizzle are you people smoking in San Francisco?
> Toilet Bleach?
>
> What a major shocker that is.. nursery rhyme music for
> crackheads, and the kids sing along like a bunch of 8 year olds
> learning the alphabet..
>
> > I believe that hatred of certain music is typically tied to
> prejudice against the people
> > who listen to the music...
>
> Yes, I will agree with that.
> I don't get on with idiots that take pills.
> I don't get on with cutesy wootsy kids.
> I don't like people that can't control themselves when they go
> out to places.
> So it's no surprise I don't get along with a bunch of cutesy
> wootsy kids that get out of their head on a trillion pills and
> lie around the floor, massaging lotion into each others arms
> while puking in the corner and telling people they just met that
> they love them.
>
> BUT, it's not just the clientelle - it's the mindless, brainless
> thumping of a music that stretches the term of 'music' to its limit.
> It's marginally more musical than gabba and 'terrorcore', but
> only by a tiny sliver of a percent.
>
> > The responses on this list provide evidence that the resistance
> to happycore
> > is also based on contempt for an audience that epitomizes the
> "candy raver"
> > stereotype.
>
> And what's wrong with that?
>
> You love to keep talking about the early rave scene and how it
> was back then, so let's talk about that for a moment.
> There were NO Candykids.
> There was no-one acting like a candykid.
> For the most part, you would be lucky to find someone under 20
> going to raves.
> They were huge electronic music festivals, more like a
> psychadelic theme park with music than the events that go on today.
> Those people that got too messed up were shunned by the crowd,
> who went about their business.
> Candy Kids on the other hand, revel in the kind of behaviour that
> used to get people thrown out of events, in order to make the
> event better.
> There are people like me out there that DON'T enjoy socialising
> with these kinds of mental case screw ups, don't like being near
> them, and certainly don't want to be round them when going out somewhere.
> You may tell me my kundalini spirit is not tempered properly, or
> that my inner child needs more emotional nourishment, but I
> consider myself far more normal for disliking these damn children
> than the people that are quite happy to just step over them when
> they collapse on the dancefloor.
>
> > Disrespect of a people due to their choice of music is our exact charge
> > against government and society in reference to the rave crackdown in
> > general.
>
> You know, I have grown up with raves, raving and rave culture.
> Your American Candy Kid freakshow has absolutely NOTHING to do
> with the roots of the rave scene, and they should have been
> kicked out of your dance music scene a long, long, long time ago.
>
> It is NO surprise to ANYONE outside the USA why the Government is
> cracking down on raves!!
> You're allowing these fucking retards to still be a part of it!!
> Let's stop ignoring the truth here - These days, Candy Kids at an
> event ALWAYS equals drugs and idiotic kids taking stupid
> substances in stupid quantities.
> Do you really think the Government would be as bothered if they
> didn't look and act like such degenerate crackheads???
>
> > I would therefore advise that each of us be a part of the
> > celebration of our diversity rather than unwitting accomplices in the
> > culture war.
>
> And in contrary to that, I would advise that if you have any love
> for dance music in your life, you do NOT allow these stupid
> little children to run amock at your events, and you do NOT turn
> a blind eye when they lie around the floor, wondering what Planet
> they're on.
>
> If you clean up your raves, then your raves will no longer be
> seen as the drug-sustained insanity that they - quiet rightly -
> are being seen as.
>
> Stop pretending to yourselves that the rave scene is just an
> innocent celebration, and start taking action against the
> bullshit that has almost destroyed it for you.
>
> If you don't, then you'll be kicking yourselves for standing by
> and doing nothing when the scene has been strangled by worried
> authorities.
>
> > aolim: godisunity
>
> Ahhh, that explains a lot.
>
> -D

Subject: Re: [sfraves] WHAT IS YOUR FIRST LOVE? was (DAFT PUNK dancing in GAP COMMERCIAL)

There are many things I love and many moments that I cherish...but my first 
love would have to be the moment I solved the Rubik's cube. Oh my God, that 
damn little cube got me so aggravated in fourth grade. My dad had given it 
to me as a gift, but as I started playing around with it, it felt more like 
a device of torture. I was so close to just peeling the stickers off and 
placing all same-colored ones on each side....but alas, on July 3rd of that 
year, 2 days before my birthday...I had conquered the monster, the beast 
known as the cube of Rubik. :-P I'm kidding, by the way, my first love would 
have to be a tie between sports and gettin my groove on to great music.

RAVIN RIZ

Subject: [sfraves] BSP Ayame every Wednesday in San Rafael

--0-2115715678-998264509=:2959
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii


Hey guys I just wanted to let you all know there is going to be a weekly club every Wednesday night frpm 9pm-2am with Hardcore, Hard house, Trance, and DnB.  The location is The New George's Club @ 842 $th St. in San Rafael.  Admission is $10 and it is 18+ 

Opening night is this Wednesday the 22nd with Tracer, Cloudskipper, Tronic, Yacko One, and Moo Moo.

8/29/01------ Cloudskipper, Val Sparks, Reese, Tronic, and Moo Moo

9/5/01---- Tronic, Cloudskipper, Sketchy, Yacko One, and Moo Moo

9/12/01----  Hobbit, Anthony Mad, Reese, Tronic, and Tracer

Lineups for later dates will be out on 9/6/01 for more information visit www.candekids.com

 



---------------------------------
Do You Yahoo!?
Make international calls for as low as $0.04/minute with Yahoo! Messenger.
--0-2115715678-998264509=:2959--

Received: (qmail 40797 invoked from network); 20 Aug 2001 03:39:23 -0000
Date: Sun, 19 Aug 2001 20:35:19 -0700
From: Martin Randall <kk@atc.creative.com>
To: ravah luv <ravahluv@hotmail.com>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Message-id: <3B808577.82D81491@atc.creative.com>
MIME-version: 1.0
X-Mailer: Mozilla 4.75 [en]C-{C-UDP; EBM-SONY1}  (Windows NT 5.0; U)
Content-type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT
X-Accept-Language: en
References: <F244VXsUEvmuNkNwL780000bffb@hotmail.com>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] where is nocturnal wonderland (Havasu?)

Yeah - I was there a couple of weeks ago! Havasu City, on Lake
Havasu, is in the middle of NOWHERE. Not sure how you'd get
there from LA (we were going from the Bay Area), but it's past
Bakersfield, over the Tehachapi pass, down to Mojave and across
the Mojave Desert, past Edwards AFB, to Barstow, then keep
going on I-40 for 2 more hours of unremitting desert (make sure
you gas up first!) to Needles, past Needles, across the border into
AZ, then take a right and about 45 minutes from there you hit
Havasu City. It's hot as hell, and just generally a weird artificial
place dropped in the middle of the desert. The most interesting
thing there is London Bridge, which they moved there as a tourist
attraction (those Americans will buy anything!). Find some shade
and drink lots of water! I could believe 6 hours.

Enjoy!
- Martin

    Some of you people hate hhc soooo damn much, BUT YOU DON'T EVER LISTEN
TO IT ! so it's basically ignorance right?

    "That's right a FIVE year old can relate to HHC. Says a lot..."
    2 comments:
        you can't teach an old dogg new trix
        A five year old can relate to it, but so many 20+ year olds can't
understand it and
        don't even know where to begin. . .

I'm not a little kid, Im a responsible small  business owner with 2 college
degrees and 2 jobs !

    This all constantly feels like this gang battle sorta. . .  I'd totally
rather hang out with joyous happy bouncey people than with these old fogeys
who are all "it's too loud, it's too fast". Kinda puts me in a difficult
position though cuz most all of my party buds seem to be anti-hc . . . I've
kinda been doing my own thing lately though, the more I get into hc and that
whole scene (more than just going to parties), the farther I seem to
distance myself from old friends, mostly because of peoples attitudes
towards things I believe and am part of. . .

    but like say la vee (or whatever). . . guess I'll just keep pushin. . .
gets annoying though. . .

one last comment:
        The old businessman type, the ones who wore shirts n ties and combed
their hair to the sides. . . god forbid if you'd ever wear ::gasp:: AN
EARRING. . . these same businessmen aren't competing well anymore, why ?
Because they failed to open their eyes and look and listen for new thoughts,
ideas, ways of life. . . And the people quickly taking their place are the
people with visions, not the old "if it ain't broke don't fix it" attitude,
but the new "lets break it and make a new one" attitude.

You know you're too old when you quit before you start. . .


aryck

> anonymous call as did the Sacramento headquarters of our venue. Well,
> Needless to say I'm very upset. I just can't understand how some of you
> people think. I could sit here and vent for hours about this but instead
I've
> choosing to try to make something positive out of this. I hope that the
> person and or persons responsible for this, is reading this. If we as a
> community are going to EVER survive all the negative publicity from the
> outside media then we must stick together at some level. Yes, We are
always
> going to have disagreements, and even people we just don't like. I
understand
> that, that's life, But if this scene is to EVER survive we have to
understand
> that sometimes we have to look out for ALL OF OUR best interests, for the
> Scene's best interests. The survival of the bay area rave scene depends on
> this. I can say that there goes one more great all ages venue, for ever!!!
> Not just a venue for me, or Yarrow, or you but for ALL of us. So I guess
I'm
> pleading to you (who ever you are) To please think before you act, Think
not
> only about your enemy, think not only about you, but think about the
entire
> industry that WE are all a part of. Everytime you do this your killing a
> little bit more of the bay area rave scene. If WE don't stop hurting
> eachother soon, this scene that we all love will no longer exist. I have
just
> one more thing that I'd like to add, I've been playing out of town quite a
> bit and I can honestly say that 70% of the raves/clubs that I play at suck
> compared to our own BAY AREA. We are all so spoiled, The bay area ROCKS!!!
So
> lets all try to save it before we lose it forever.
> For all you who had planned a great night with us and purchased presales

Hey Kidz...

    Tonite we're pleased to bring you one of the latest artists to emerge
and continue the great Spundae progressive house tradition, Jonathan Ojeda.
He'll be dropping the latest in smooth and deep progressive house choons.
We'll be talking a lot about the label he helps to run and represents,
Spundae Recordings, as well as giving away cds and tickets.
     We also have the privilage of bringing you the huge sounds of Rowan
Blades, one half of the powerful production duo Breeder!  Rowan and his
partner, Simon Noble have brought such massive hits as "The Chain" and
"Twilo Thunder," absolute floor staples for the likes of Sasha, John Digweed
and Jerry Bonham. Rowan also runs the the favorite label, Rythm Syndicate,
and was previously a member of the 90's production team, Pariah.
    We're not sure how the structure of tonite will work yet, but you can be
guaranteed of at least two hour sof progressive!  Stay chooned... ;-)

*Let the Music Get You High*

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR:  Anyone know of any cgi scripts that can block
 certain IP's

Usually, you would need to configure your web server to reject requests
from IP addresses you specify. This is generally not a CGI script issue,
unless your site's content is being generated by a CGI script, in which
case you could still go the web server config route, or add code to check
for the IP addresses into the CGI script itself.

Hope this helps,

dan

KLUTE BIO [as if you didn't already know =3D]
=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=
=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=
=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D

(KLUTE aka Tom Withers biography courtesy of www.kluteproductions.co.uk)

>From the earliest recordings to his forthcoming second album for =
Certificate 18, the sound of Klute has remained at the cutting edge of =
drum & bass for close to a decade. Tom Withers, the production force =
behind the project, fuses elements of Techno elements with intricate =
beats and emotive arrangements to form a distinct hybrid.=20

Although now eclipsed by his work as Klute, Tom's induction to the music =
industry came in the eighties with his role in the notorious skate punk =
band 'The Stupids' however, after three albums, ever-increasing =
attention got the better of the band and they split.=20

Following the break up Tom took some time out to travel around the US, =
where he first discovered 'electronic' music, as he explains. "I started =
listening to a hell of a lot of techno, but when I came into it all of =
the strands were pretty much lumped together so that if you went out you =
would hear anything from Belgian rave to progressive house." "Becoming =
involved in the music was never a calculated move, more something which =
just ended up happening. I bought a drum machine but found that I was =
more interested in having my own sounds and it seemed a logical step to =
buy a sampler - I haven't really picked up the guitar since."=20

On returning to England in 1993 he settled in Ipswich, with his early =
material surfacing on Deep Red although it was his recordings under the =
KLUTE pseudonym ("the word has aesthetically pleased me since I was a =
child," he laughs) at Certificate 18 that brought widespread attention. =
Already enjoying considerable success with artists such as Photek and =
Digital, the label suited Tom's techno influences. His singles have =
stretched the genre, with the eerie, deep space manoeuvres of 'Total =
Self' contrasted against the seminal 'Leo Nine,' which captured the =
essence of Speed with delicate synth constructs propelled by tumbling =
percussives and an unforgettably deep bassline.=20

"I've tended to just do what I do and not think too heavily about the =
concepts behind it," says Tom. "It's those times when I'm lost in the =
space of a track that it really starts happening for me. Different =
things please different minds, but it is the challenge of making =
something new and avoiding things that are perhaps too obvious or =
familiar that keeps me interested. I listen to quite a wide variety of =
music but have always tended to be quite marginal; outside looking in - =
so a 'science fiction feel ' for me is more abstract than buzzing =
computers and dark sounds. I'm very much into portraying an image, but =
try to present that image in a distorted manner so a track or a title =
could mean any one of many things. I guess my music isn't the easiest to =
get into, and if I had to provide a description it would be as intimate =
terrorism in that I try go out of my way to stretch expectations of what =
music."=20

After four years at Certificate 18, Tom released the debut KLUTE =
longplayer, 'Casual Bodies.' The album extended on the singles, coupling =
a complex blend of sounds sourced from the vaults of Detroit Techno with =
complex beat programming, which worked with as opposed to pulling =
against the atmospherics. The resulting level headed feel allowed the =
more unusual tracks to leap from the system with liquid agility, =
abstract sounds built into molten landscapes of percussion. Adds Tom; =
"Casual Bodies is a reference to the mass of people out there without =
referring to them as individuals. For me and my musical background I =
feel that the first album is often the burning one - tearing it out of =
the garage and getting that fury out of you and once completed it is =
almost as though you're free to expand and develop what you are doing a =
lot further."=20

He feels his recently completed second album, 'Fear of People,' is quite =
different from the first. "It's difficult for me to offer a perception =
of this one as I'm still settling on it, other than I am more relaxed =
with what I'm doing and feel able to do more on the musical side of =
things." In explaining the curious title he adds, "Again it's not =
necessarily a negative or paranoid thought, more two fingers to the =
pretentiousness which seems to accompany a lot of the dance music scene =
and an observation of the reluctance of a lot of people to take their =
music a step further.=20

The real reason behind the title is to reflect what seems to be a =
prevalence of fear in modern day living, whether that's a fear of crime =
or missed opportunities and we almost encourage ourselves to be equipped =
with this fear.=20
I wanted to move away from that and adopt a deeper and emotional outlook =
within my music. I think a lot of people have been turned off by certain =
elements of drum & bass, and I would hope that 'Fear of People' =
demonstrates a side of the music which doesn't exclude anyone and shows =
that there is still much that can be done within the genre."=20

This is demonstrated in the album, with the introduction of vocals =
acting to further humanize the electronics while the instrumental =
material is as focused as ever with multi faceted rhythm sections =
balanced by melancholic low end and thoughtful melodic leads.=20

"To me drum & bass is a form of music which has always been out on a =
limb and the tracks that have shocked me are those that have expanded on =
what went before them," explains Tom. "Whether that's people using the =
technology in ways that you're not supposed to or just turning around =
sounds in different ways. As far as I am concerned people taking chances =
is the future and I would like to think that my material falls into that =
category."=20

Words: Kingsley Marshall=20

=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=
=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=
=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D
LATEST KLUTE NEWS straight from the mouth (courtesy of =
www.kluteproductions.co.uk )
=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=
=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=
=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D=3D

hrs London time for the second KLUTE presents the Certificate 18 show on =

the studio I.M. and say hello. If you are unfortunate to be able to tune =

Commericial Suicide 002!!!.....more........

finally be in the stores now.........thanks to everyone for their kind =
comments.
Suicide 002 is 99% confirmed to be PSYCHOSOMATIC/ GALAXIAN..........but =
as i'm trying to keep Commercial Suicide on it's toes it could end up =
being totally different......i'll decide right before the =
cut.......which will be at the end of July......so were looking at a =
September release.
Dont forget......COMMERCIAL SUICIDE will mainly be a vehicle for my =
music but I'm already talking with other artists so my mind is open. If =
anyone has anything they'd like to send me to consider for the label =
please send it to the following address;

Klute
PO BOX 22977
London, N10 3GZ.
England.

Although the first few releases will be in a drum and bass direction =
this will slowly change , I don't want to limit COMMERCIAL SUICIDE to =
any one thing...=20

------------------------------------------------------------

Other Releases
WE R THE ONES REMIX/ CHICKS DOC SCOTT REMIX is in your stores right now =
in very limited quantities.........full release comes in July.........i =
believe.=20
We R the ones which has already been going down nicely with the likes of =
Doc Scott, Lee, Daniel Savine, Dara, Diesel Boy, Dom and Roland, Andy C, =
Total science, Randall, Marcus Intellex, Goldie and myself all dragging =
a needle through it in a club environment.=20

Sometime later this year will be a release on 31 RECORDS. Dawn of reason =
and Song Seller are amongst my favourite tunes ive ever made and I'm =
proud to have them released on 31. Big respects to Doc Scott for being =
someone who truly sticks his neck out in the name of music. Expect this =
around September/ October....i'll keep you posted.

I've been busy in other areas also.........ive contributed a couple of =
techno tracks to a forthcoming playstation game along with Total =
Science, Paradox and Shut Up and Dance........I'll let you know what's =
up with this of course when I get more information.
Also a couple of my past tunes have been picked up for =
adverts..........and you guessed it.........more details later.=20

Subject: [sfraves] Breeder aka Rowan Blades is playing this week at ascension

I've just been told that Rowan Blades, more commonly known as Breeder, will
be playing Ascension this Thursday. I personally still love Twilo Thunder
and The Chain so it's going to be damn cool to see him play in such a small
venue. Usually this is the kind of DJ you have to listen to while suffering
through throngs of people at 1015. I added a bit on who he is and what he's
done that came from the Gatecrasher site.
http://www.gatecrasher.co.uk/connected/djs/rowanblades/


R O W A N B L A D E S
Discography
Breeder - 'The Chain' / 'Clayface' (Rhythm Syndicate)
Breeder - 'Twilo Thunder' / 'Beetlejuice' (Rhythm Syndicate)
Breeder - 'Rockstone' (Rhythm Syndicate)
Breeder - 'Tyrantanic' (Rhythm Syndicate)
Breeder - 'New York FM' (Rhythm Syndicate)
Pariah 'Unnamed' (Rhythm Syndicate)
Remixes
Tilt - 'Children' (Deconstruction) Breeder mix
Grace - 'Not over Yet' (Code Blue) Breeder mix
Brother Brown - 'Under The Water' (FFRR) Breeder mix
Orbital - 'Nothing Left' (FFRR) Breeder mix
Orbital - 'Nothing Left' (FFRR) Pariah mix
Space Manoeuvres - 'Stage One' (Hooj Choons) Pariah mix
Evolution - Phoenix (Fluid UK) Breeder mix

R O W A N B L A D E S
Career Rowan Blades is best known as half of the massively successful
Breeder. Breeder's first two singles, 'The Chain' and 'Twilo Thunder', have
sold in excess of 25,000 copies world-wide, having first come to prominence
on Sasha's near-legendary 'Global Underground - San Francisco' compilation.
'Twilo Thunder' has since gone on to achieve great commercial success with
lucrative licences to compilations from the Ministry of Sound and Euphoria
2, which have sold over 500,000 copies between them. Breeder's third, fourth
and fifth tracks, 'Tyrantanic', 'Rockstone' and 'New York FM' have been
showcased on Sasha and John Digweed's last 'Northern Exposure - Expeditions'
compilation, as well as on John Digweed's 'Global Underground - Hong Kong'.
With over 20,000 pre-sales for Tyrantanic, things look set to continue in a
similar vain to how they have started, and in doing so stamping out any
doubt that they are a 'one hit wonder'. This rapid rise to prominence has
resulted in several high-profile remix projects. These include Tilt's
'Children', Planet Perfecto's classic 'It's Not Over Yet', Brother Brown's
'Under the Water', Orbital's 'Nothing Left', and Evolution's 'Phoenix'. On
the back of this success, Rowan has started a new project with Gaetan
Schurrer, who has engineered for Sasha. With successful remixes of,
Orbital's 'Nothing Left' (FFRR), and of Space Manoeuvres 'Stage One',
released on Hooj Choons, as featured on Sasha's recent Global Underground,
they seem to have established themselves without even releasing their first
single.

Breeder's success on Rowan's own Rhythm Syndicate record label has boosted
the label to a position of prominence within the dance music community.
Rowan has since been able to sign four new tracks to Rhythm Syndicate for
release next year, and has prospective mixes from the likes of Slacker, Tilt
& Evolution to name a few. Add to this the status of Rhythm Syndicate
Records as one of the top 10 independent dance music stores in the UK,
helping compile Pete Tong's Buzz Chart play-lists for Radio 1, and Rowan's
record empire is one of the most influential in the country.
Rowan's DJ-ing career has taken him all over the world. Having played in
Britain for gigs like Bedrock & Gatecrasher the success of Breeder has
enabled him to elevate himself onto an international stage. Breeder is
currently the biggest selling non-pop dance act in Norway, Rowan has played
there with great success, as well as in Sweden, and at a gig for 14,000
ravers in Copenhagen. The burgeoning American demand for dance music has
seen Rowan play at the legendary Shadow Lounge in Miami, as well as boat
parties on the Hudson. The nascent Chinese scene has seen Rowan playing at
The Face in Canton, attracting only 100 people less than Paul Oakenfold!
Most recently, Rowan taken his Rhythm Syndicate record label and the Breeder
name to Hong Kong as the main attraction of a huge gig for Clubstar
Entertainment's. He has also establish a monthly residency in Moscow for
Club Xlll. Closer to home, Rowan has a bi monthly with Union @ Space in
Leeds. He also still maintains his monthly residency with More Tea Vicar,
the Cambridge organisation for whom he has played with Sasha, Carl Cox and
Danny Howells, as well as the annual Strawberry Fayre festival, at which
Rowan played last year to 20,000 people.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Microsofts Tracking Your Websites

Guys,

Please don't follow the instructions on this web site.  I've read through
this tutorial and this person doesn't actually have much clue as to what
they are talking about and some of their instructions will possibly damage
your install of windows or programs that you use.

There certainly are privacy issues involved in using windows and other
microsoft products, something that people who are in the know (true
security professionals... if you're really interested, subscribe to the
bugtraq mailing list on www.securityfocus.com) are looking at every day.

Trust me on this, if you follow those instructions, you could be very
sorry.

Oh, and there's nothing really nefarious going on there.  It's Windows
doing its thing in its normally brain-dead way.

Subject: [sfraves] Ecstasy Experts Challenge NIDA

--Boundary_(ID_Ujvk8fgsuyXQyeTe+Gz89A)
Content-type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-transfer-encoding: quoted-printable

Ecstasy Experts Want Realistic Messages
Brian Vastag,  =A9 JAMA August 15,2001

As the popularity of the drug ecstasy (MDMA) continues to climb --11% of =

high school seniors have tried it, according to a National Institute on=20
Drug Abuse (NIDA) survey -- behavioral researchers are recommending=20
control strategies that may seem antithetical to ever-expanding law=20
enforcement efforts. Instead of focusing on eradication and punishment,=20
these social scientists take another tack: they encourage harm reduction =

that acknowledges the realities of ecstasy.=20

>> Read More at: http://www.alchemind.org/topclnews.htm


--Boundary_(ID_Ujvk8fgsuyXQyeTe+Gz89A)--

public

children

really

history..things are changing though, thankfully, just
be 
glad, if you are female, that you weren't in the
workforce during the seventies, if you weren't, and if
you 
were, my extreme admiration and condolences...okay,
song writing is like cooking..sometimes there are fast
cookers, 
and sometimes, there are many ingredients and many
hours and many years to perfect a good recipe, but it
is all worth it. :)

Subject: [sfraves] new music

all-
    this is what i've gathered from the people who have been cool enough to
give me their opinion on the matter ... DJs just want to know what cames out
on vinyl in one big mass that they can sort out for themselves.
  
since i spend all this time recording and listening to music, i feel like
maybe it would be worth sharing what i see and hear with people who might
not be lucky enough to have immediate access to what comes into the vinyl
stores.

this access to new stuff has been what has fueled my passion for music for
this long, so hopefully i can pass that on.

there are Real Audio clips for like 95% of these at
http://alienrecords.net
if something is missing an audio clip and ya really want to hear it, let me
know at grant@virtualmediahost.com and i'll make sure it gets up there.

thanks-
grant stevens
http://alienrecords.net

floors better. Elysium Music is MUSIC FOR THE FUTURE and unlike you we =
will not do things that hurt the fans just because we don't like =
something that is going on. So go home and cry to your mommy because =
when the last record spins, the people will know for themselves who to =
support.

To all our faithfull fans, we love you and thank you for your support. =
Please ignore this e-mail it is political BULLSHIT that we have tried to =
ignore. However some haters will never stop hating, mean while we will =
never stop bringin you the music you love!

Peace



Josh Illion - josh@elysiumusic.com
Executive Producer/Artist Management
Elysium Music International
http://www.elysiumusic.com
Telephone/Fax: 1.877.504.2887

 -----Original Message-----
From: 	Ari Gordon-Schlosberg [mailto:regs@nebcorp.com]

Subject:	Re: [sfraves] Microsofts Tracking Your Websites

Guys,

Please don't follow the instructions on this web site.  I've read through
this tutorial and this person doesn't actually have much clue as to what
they are talking about and some of their instructions will possibly damage
your install of windows or programs that you use.

There certainly are privacy issues involved in using windows and other
microsoft products, something that people who are in the know (true
security professionals... if you're really interested, subscribe to the
bugtraq mailing list on www.securityfocus.com) are looking at every day.

Trust me on this, if you follow those instructions, you could be very
sorry.

Oh, and there's nothing really nefarious going on there.  It's Windows
doing its thing in its normally brain-dead way.

--- "innocentchild" <innocentchild@hotmail.com>
> wrote:
>I've just been told that Rowan Blades, more commonly known as Breeder, will
>be playing Ascension this Thursday. I personally still love Twilo Thunder
>and The Chain so it's going to be damn cool to see him play in such a small
>venue. Usually this is the kind of DJ you have to listen to while suffering
>through throngs of people at 1015. I added a bit on who he is and what he's
>done that came from the Gatecrasher site.
>http://www.gatecrasher.co.uk/connected/djs/rowanblades/
>
>
>R O W A N B L A D E S
>Discography
>Breeder - 'The Chain' / 'Clayface' (Rhythm Syndicate)
>Breeder - 'Twilo Thunder' / 'Beetlejuice' (Rhythm Syndicate)
>Breeder - 'Rockstone' (Rhythm Syndicate)
>Breeder - 'Tyrantanic' (Rhythm Syndicate)
>Breeder - 'New York FM' (Rhythm Syndicate)
>Pariah 'Unnamed' (Rhythm Syndicate)
>Remixes
>Tilt - 'Children' (Deconstruction) Breeder mix
>Grace - 'Not over Yet' (Code Blue) Breeder mix
>Brother Brown - 'Under The Water' (FFRR) Breeder mix
>Orbital - 'Nothing Left' (FFRR) Breeder mix
>Orbital - 'Nothing Left' (FFRR) Pariah mix
>Space Manoeuvres - 'Stage One' (Hooj Choons) Pariah mix
>Evolution - Phoenix (Fluid UK) Breeder mix
>
>R O W A N B L A D E S
>Career Rowan Blades is best known as half of the massively successful
>Breeder. Breeder's first two singles, 'The Chain' and 'Twilo Thunder', have
>sold in excess of 25,000 copies world-wide, having first come to prominence
>on Sasha's near-legendary 'Global Underground - San Francisco' compilation.
>'Twilo Thunder' has since gone on to achieve great commercial success with
>lucrative licences to compilations from the Ministry of Sound and Euphoria
>2, which have sold over 500,000 copies between them. Breeder's third, four=
th
>and fifth tracks, 'Tyrantanic', 'Rockstone' and 'New York FM' have been
>showcased on Sasha and John Digweed's last 'Northern Exposure - Expedition=
s'
>compilation, as well as on John Digweed's 'Global Underground - Hong Kong'.
>With over 20,000 pre-sales for Tyrantanic, things look set to continue in a
>similar vain to how they have started, and in doing so stamping out any
>doubt that they are a 'one hit wonder'. This rapid rise to prominence has
>resulted in several high-profile remix projects. These include Tilt's
>'Children', Planet Perfecto's classic 'It's Not Over Yet', Brother Brown's
>'Under the Water', Orbital's 'Nothing Left', and Evolution's 'Phoenix'. On
>the back of this success, Rowan has started a new project with Gaetan
>Schurrer, who has engineered for Sasha. With successful remixes of,
>Orbital's 'Nothing Left' (FFRR), and of Space Manoeuvres 'Stage One',
>released on Hooj Choons, as featured on Sasha's recent Global Underground,
>they seem to have established themselves without even releasing their first
>single.
>
>Breeder's success on Rowan's own Rhythm Syndicate record label has boosted
>the label to a position of prominence within the dance music community.
>Rowan has since been able to sign four new tracks to Rhythm Syndicate for
>release next year, and has prospective mixes from the likes of Slacker, Ti=
lt
>& Evolution to name a few. Add to this the status of Rhythm Syndicate
>Records as one of the top 10 independent dance music stores in the UK,
>helping compile Pete Tong's Buzz Chart play-lists for Radio 1, and Rowan's
>record empire is one of the most influential in the country.
>Rowan's DJ-ing career has taken him all over the world. Having played in
>Britain for gigs like Bedrock & Gatecrasher the success of Breeder has
>enabled him to elevate himself onto an international stage. Breeder is
>currently the biggest selling non-pop dance act in Norway, Rowan has played
>there with great success, as well as in Sweden, and at a gig for 14,000
>ravers in Copenhagen. The burgeoning American demand for dance music has
>seen Rowan play at the legendary Shadow Lounge in Miami, as well as boat
>parties on the Hudson. The nascent Chinese scene has seen Rowan playing at
>The Face in Canton, attracting only 100 people less than Paul Oakenfold!
>Most recently, Rowan taken his Rhythm Syndicate record label and the Breed=
er
>name to Hong Kong as the main attraction of a huge gig for Clubstar
>Entertainment's. He has also establish a monthly residency in Moscow for
>Club Xlll. Closer to home, Rowan has a bi monthly with Union @ Space in
>Leeds. He also still maintains his monthly residency with More Tea Vicar,
>the Cambridge organisation for whom he has played with Sasha, Carl Cox and
>Danny Howells, as well as the annual Strawberry Fayre festival, at which
>Rowan played last year to 20,000 people.
>
>---------------------------------------------------------------------

>For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V5.50.4133.2400
In-Reply-To: <20010820234803.47883.qmail@web14203.mail.yahoo.com>
Importance: Normal
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] RE: Is the UK a 2nd world country?

No, I just get tired of people who travel to abroad and when things are not
like the US they rag on them.  For being so advanced, it is amazing how
Europe laughs at us because of our childish behaviors when it comes to
technology.  I have seen the behind the scenes things that you might not
have since I worked for a technology company and saw the behind the scenes
things.  Americans tend to take for granted what they have and then when
they go abroad and it is different or not as convenient as they are used to
they call them second world...  If there is ANY European country that is
close to being second world it would have to be Germany because of the years
that it was divided and the soviet union raped the country..

 -----Original Message-----

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Is the UK a 2nd world country?

Having lived in both countries I can say that depending where you are in
either country, it's the same.  I'd say London is about as technologically
advanced as the SF Bay Area.  OK, so the roads are a bit narrow over there,
but they definitely have a better train system!!  And they came out with a
fully digital cellphone system waaay b4 here.  However, it is nice to have
good, cheap internet access here!!  However, all in all, they're about the
same.  In addition, if you were to go to Dorklestshire England, and Bumfukk
Nowhere USA, you'de probably notice similarities in the extent to which they
are undeveloped.  Conclusion:  both these places vary equally from a 1st to
a 2nd world country.

Now, if you really want to argue something, look at the media:  Is it evil
and indecent to display on the telly a nipple or more than a quarter of a
butcrack (the US) or someone getting shot and over 15 minutes of commercials
in one go (the UK)

Well, wherever you are from, electronic music is universal, so keep the love
alive!!

.:nomadic:.
www.nomadicDJ.com

From sfraves-return-71532-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Tue Aug 21 01:12:14 2001
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-71532-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 19386 invoked by uid 1104); 21 Aug 2001 01:12:12 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 19374 invoked from network); 21 Aug 2001 01:12:12 -0000
Message-Id: <5.0.2.1.2.20010820165923.009ff070@pop3.norton.antivirus>
X-Sender: apollo/mail.speakeasy.org@pop3.norton.antivirus
X-Mailer: QUALCOMM Windows Eudora Version 5.0.2
Date: Mon, 20 Aug 2001 18:24:44 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] THE MONKEYS RETURN!!!

Last Friday Twelve Monkeys returned with "Little House" at a new, improved 
venue but with that old house vibe.

When I heard that the new venue was to be Club Decibel on Market I confess 
I was a bit surprised.  I haven't been to any parties there, but from what 
I heard from friends this was an upscale venue with a clubber dress 
code.  Little House with a dress code?  This was a horrifying concept, 
indeed.  But one never knows these days.

I really wanted to dance again to the amazing Donald Glaude, as well as 
Eddie Amador.  What to do?  I needed my house music fix, and 
desperately.  But anyone who knows me knows that I wear gear to dance and 
sweat in, not designer appearance-oriented wear.

I searched my closet for clothes that might pass the muster at an upscale 
club.  I came up with a black shirt and cargos that could pass as 
"slacks."  But no shoes.  Like, I don't buy Prada.  I have boots.  I have 
skate and other shoes for dancing.  And I have a couple pairs of "business" 
shoes I wear on those rare occasions when I must appear in a suit.  But 
these shoes are so uncomfortable I couldn't see attempting to dance in them 
to Glaude.  So I found a pair of black skate shoes, buffed them up so that 
they might look like dress shoes, and hoped for the best.

Ah, me of little faith.  To think that my friends at Twelve Monkeys would 
force me to dance to house in a dress-code environment.  One look at the 
line waiting to get in and I knew things would be as they were and should 
be.  One comes to a house music party to dance, not to be seen in 
fashionable clothes.

We arrived in time for the beginning of Amador's rockin' set, a combination 
of old favorites and some new beats.  Yes, house is a "spiritual thing," as 
well as a physical thing.  Everyone was up and dancin' for "House 
Music."  I positioned myself right in front of the DJ booth and danced for 
nearly the whole two hours of Eddie.  Just stopped to take a break for a 
smoke and some brew.

Then Glaude.  Now, I like to train spot as well as dance, so I got up right 
next to the turntables before the set change 'cause I really wanted to 
watch the master closely.  Well, when Glaude took the tables it was like a 
Dionysian frenzy up there.  Everyone rushed the tables cheering and waving 
arms wildly.  The experience was almost like a mosh pit.  There was such a 
press that the turntables skipped twice from the throng bumping into the 
table at the beginning of the set.  All good, though.  Donald smiled, and 
for the most part everyone was as respectful as they could be in those 
close quarters.

Close it was, and hot.  Everyone sweatin' and dancin' wildly, arms in the 
air.  I spent almost an hour body to body with the other dancers -- and we 
danced as one, literally.  Was no other way.  It was exhilarating and, lord 
knows, intimate.  And sweaty.  And ecstatic.  I reached that very desirable 
level where you are absolutely one with the music and the others.  No 
thought.  Just feeling the beats and the bodies.  Really excellent:)

Glaude was, as usual, f__ckin' extraordinary.  Last time I danced to his 
house was back in January.  This set was totally different from what he 
spun back then.  Fresh, surprising.  Went directly to my tribal spirit.  A 
lot of the new music was like the old experiments in hip house.  Glaude had 
an amazing guy rapping over the PA to da' house/break beats and it, for me, 
was not only a welcome change but more evidence that house is a vital and 
evolving genre.  Back to the roots, and something new comes forth.  Glaude 
is not predictable.  Nor is the house music genre.

I watched Glaude's facial expressions as he mixed.  When building into a 
new record his eyes were distant, facial expression that of a person 
listening for a message from the gods.  Then, when the music was right he 
smiles and launches into his arm-waving interactions with the crowd.  Each 
new record is displayed in the air, a la Keoki, and dropped on the 
table.  Anticipation and fulfillment.

The vibe at Twelve Monkeys was that funky, lovin', respectful househead 
family ambiance.  All the old crowd was there.  As well as some new 
blood.  Much happiness for me, for sure.

My friend Ben Davis from Housewares was spinning some wicked house 
upstairs.  Unfortunately,  he was up against Glaude downstairs.  Ben is a 
worthy DJ and a passionate househead.

Props to Aaron and the Twelve Monkeys crew for bringing Little House back 
to the house party mix.  Deeply missed you guys, and it was hugs and love 
all around.  Great party, the new venue works for me, and I'm happy the 
tribe is back together again.  Looking forward to next month.

Love,


Apollo


---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

From: girlcat <technoslut23@yahoo.com>

Subject: [sfraves] (nrr) my friend is out of jail!  but support still needed for other genoa protesters

i had written last week asking for support to help get
my friend andy, who was arrested w/ the publix theatre
caravan, out of jail in genoa.  i just wanted to
follow up and thank everyone who wrote any letters or
called the italian embassy or anything and to let
everyone know he's out!  yay!  i am very, very
relieved, although i believe he still faces charges. 
it's really hard to deal w/ someone you know dealing
w/  torture and abuse in prison so i'm really, really
glad he's ok.  

however, there are still people in jail from the
protests, including some friends of my friend in
germany.  there's going to be a marathon performance
festival on thursday eve. in front of the italian
consulate (broadway and webster streets, in pacific
heights) from 4pm to midnight to keep the issue in the
public eye and to help pressure the italian government
to release all the other prisoners.  the theme is "art
is not a crime."  (since the publix theatre people are
a theatre troupe.)  

below is more information.  since this was written,
the publix theatre people have been released. 
however, as noted above, they still face charges, and
their are also at least 25 other people still in jail
from the protests.  (and so far the death toll is up
to at least 3.)  
ART IS NOT A CRIME
A PERFORMANCE MARATHON TO
RELEASE PUBLIX THEATRE CARAVAN 
& ALL GENOA/G8 ACTIVISTS FROM 
ITALIAN JAIL & DROP ALL CHARGES
THURS. AUG. 23, 4pm-Midnight
Italian Consulate, 2590 Webster @ Broadway,SF
(6 blocks W. of Van Ness on Broadway)
Theater, dance, spoken word performance, including:
Dance Brigade, Samsara, Keith Hennessy , Art and
Revolution Street Theater Collective, Gravity Physical
Theater, Village Culture, Tango for Protest, Folk
This!, Body Cartography, Teli Carduci, Drew Dellinger,
Dan McCale aka John WTO, fire artists, DJs, and many,
many  more.
Bring: art, music, theater, dance, words, friends...

At midnight we will sendoff the Bay Area Caravan  to
Borderhack, a three day Festival near Tijuana to
"Delete the Border" (there is still space-bring a bag
if you want to go. info www.de-lete.tv/borderhack)

On Monday July 24, the Publix Theatre Caravan, an
international multimedia performance group, was
stopped and 25 performers (and their dog Pogo) were
arrested and beaten by Italian police near Genoa,
Italy. The group had performed at the G8 protests in
Genoa, as part of a European tour, using theater to
express their belief in ending internment and
deportations and creating a world with out borders or
nations . They were arrested in the wake of the brutal
police  repression which resulted in at least one
death during the G8 Summit. The imprisoned group
includes Bay Area activist/performer Andy, who has
worked locally with Reclaim Mayday, Food Not Bombs and
Reclaim the Streets. Publix Theater Caravan  is group
of  artists, musicians , actors, independent media
workers and experimental theater  activists from
Austria, US, Slovakia, Germany, Australia, and Sweden.
The group is accused of vandalism, endangering public
safety and being  the core of the "black bloc," due to
the presence of stage  props, a black bra and several
black T-shirts amongst their belongings.  Twenty
members of the group were released last week as a
result of international publc pressure, but 19 of them
still face charges and up to 15 years in prison. Five
members of Publix Theater and over twenty other
activists remain in jail.This is part of an escalation
of repression against polical street theater and the
anti-corporate globalization movement in North America
and Europe repression which continues even more
severely in the Global South and in communities of
color in the North. 
Publix theatre info:
www.no-racism.net/nobordertour/index_uk.html
More info on local support: genoadefensesf@yahoo.com

Subject: Re: [sfraves] RE: Is the UK a 2nd world country?

At 05:05 PM 08/20/2001 -0700, Sir Dapy Of Dorkdom wrote:
>No, I just get tired of people who travel to abroad and when things are not
>like the US they rag on them.  

well, there's travel abroad for two weeks and then there is live there.
I have no patience for the people who go for two weeks and think they've
"done" Europe - and then there's the "AMERICA!!! rah Rah RAH" kneejerk
position which really ticks me off.  I think you're talking about that

But when you live there, you do notice the little differences - social
ones certainly.  Most of it is probably coming from the fish out of the
water feeling, but aspects of the uk could be better  (america too, certainly)

and I never said I didn't like it there.  Just that certain creature
comforts could be better (but they go hand in hand with rampant consumerism)

>For being so advanced, it is amazing how
>Europe laughs at us because of our childish behaviors when it comes to
>technology.  

huh?  I would say they laugh at us because of our provincial immature
social attitudes (e.g. violence for entertainment is acceptable vs. all
the fuss over NYPD Blue's showing of a naked ass, under 21s can't drink at all
etc)  I have a post somewhere from a guy who went to Italy and he absolutely
could not get his friends over there to grasp the concept that under 21s
weren't
allowed in bars at all or that teenagers couldn't drink low alcohol beverages.
It may have been a bit of a language barrier, but they couldn't grasp that
a father couldn't take his 17 yr old son to a pub and buy him a alcoholic
lemonade.
The concept of alcohol as this forbidden evil thing was just incomprehensible

>I have seen the behind the scenes things that you might not
>have since I worked for a technology company and saw the behind the scenes
>things.  Americans tend to take for granted what they have and then when
>they go abroad and it is different or not as convenient as they are used to
>they call them second world...  

well, i'm an engineer and i know how things could be better.  Different
I can deal with, but inefficient...  perhaps it is a matter of my
sophistication
(i.e. knowing what the possibilities are)?

>If there is ANY European country that is
>close to being second world it would have to be Germany because of the years
>that it was divided and the soviet union raped the country..

East Germany, sure.  But my friend (West German) was quite ticked with
aspects 
of the UK

Doug

Subject: [sfraves] trees n beats was what i needed :)

hey everyone :)  trees n beats was so mellow and relaxing...... it
was such a great weekend!  it was my first time at camp and sons, and
man, that place is so awesome...... i could totally live there and
just eat food from the garden all day :)  there wasn't as many people
there as i expected, but it was nice 'cause it gave it a real
intimate vibe...... i felt like i knew everyone there by the time the
weekend was over :)  got to meet some really cool people......
knowmad (who i've been talking to forever, but never met), rachel
(only got to talk to her for a minute, but she's so nice!), hula girl
julie (i just happened to be camping *right* next to her), and i
found out too late that i was also camping right next to magick, so
i'll have to chat it up with him next time :)  the music was really
great, too, and i was totally diggin' that reggae band friday
night...... i didn't know there was going to be any live instrument
bands there.  anyway, all in all it was an awesome weekend that
totally mellowed me out :)  i'll probably be at ascension this week
with my little sister who's visiting from out of town, so i'll see
you all there.......

~envirogirl
