Subject: RE: [sfraves] Re: TO HAPPYCORE HATERS

Okay, since the beginning of this thread, this has been reall bugging me.

"FIRST WORLD": Western Bloc: USA, France, *UK*, Germany, Japan, and all
those allies, etc, etc
"SECOND WORLD": Soviet/Communist Bloc: USSR, China, Cuba, etc
"THIRD WORLD": Everything else

I can't remember who coined the terms, but they have very specific,
originally created to seperate the two sides in the cold war, the US and
its allies, the USSR and its allies, and finally, all the countries who
aren't in either of the first two "worlds".

So, in other words, this whole discussion about the UK being a "Second
World" country was inane to begin with.

-Damien


At 4:19 PM -0700 8/20/01, Sir Dapy Of Dorkdom wrote:

>countries in the world.  But good god, don't ever think England isn't nearly
>as advanced as the US, just because you don't see it all over the place like

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Czech hero Electromajk on Radio Teknique 8/21/2001

--------------DE56D1CEEBC1E84655ED69B9
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 8bit



    Tuesday August 21st

         Teknique

    in association with

        Selekta.com

        brings you                                               [Image]

        Electromajk

      plus your hosts

    Dragn'fly + DJ Pat

 Once again in our quest to bring you all things techy, we bring you
 another major force of innovation on the global scene.  Tune in from
 1pm to 4pm PST to catch a super special Wet & Hard set from Czech hero
 Electromajk along with live mixing from hosts Dragn'fly & DJ Pat.

 To tune in click here:

 http://www.selekta.com/multimedia/teknique.asp


 This mix from Electromajk is deep as fuck and loaded with the insane
 amount of sexual energy that only an Eastern European could deliver.
 For those unfamilar with the Wet & Hard movement, it is a new breed of
 post-techno techno.  To some It is the sound of the pornoground, to
 others it is simply sexmusic.  Regardless of the adjectives used, it
 is the secret sound of your imagination.  Wet & Hard is hot kunst,
 supa-stylish, state of the art club music for a hot new generation of
 ever-so-slightly exhibitionistic no-holes-barred clubbers. Music for
 all those, whose adventurous lives have become endangered, through the
 unimaginative low grade tediousness of tv-trance.   Wet & Hard is a
 techno-fantasy release of harddrive beats combined with sexually
 soaked bouncy basses,  all pumping and pounding, creating a throbbing,
 thrusting, thumping, thrilling... thingy...errmmm ... sensation???
 Whatever, it´s music to make her wet and him hard!

  [Image]The music has been becoming more popular every day with
         releases and remixes by Oliver Klein, Corvin Dalek, Alex
 Flatner, etc finding homes on major labels throughout Europe, but the
 main force behind the movement is the sex driven nightclubs of Eastern
 Europe.   It is here that the DJs crafted their own sound that is
 slowly taking over the world and it is with great pleasure that Radio
 Teknique will be presenting a series of shows focusing on Eastern
 Europe's top club DJs and their drive to inject techno with an
 overdose of sexuality.

 Our first installment will highlight Prague's Electromajk, a recent
 addition to the MFS family.  He is quickly becoming a major player on
 the European club scene playing regularly in places like Berlin, Ibiza
 and Malta along with regular appearances in his hometown.   His
 reputation is top notch with both clubbers and DJs alike and we think
 you will see why after listening to the show.

 For more information on him, please check out

 http://www.electromajk.com

 For those of you unfamiliar with the show, Radio Teknique is a weekly
 internet broadcast hosted by Dragn'fly and DJ Pat featuring electronic
 music on the techy side of things (you may even hear some tech-polka
 now and then!).   For more information about the show (such as past
 guests, future guests, playlists, etc) or to listen, please visit:

 http://www.selekta.com/multimedia/teknique.asp

 Listening requires realplayer G2....if you don't have it, get it
 here:  http://www.real.com

 For more information about your hosts, please check out:

 http://www.djdragnfly.com
 http://www.dj-pat.com

 During the show, we can be reached via AIM at RadioTeknique so feel
 free to give us a hollah, request your favorite tech-polka choon, talk
 shit, etc!

 P.S. : We are terribly sorry for all of the technical delays we have
 had trying to get AndyW on the show.  We actually have it all worked
 out now and will be featuring him soon!!!

 P.P.S.  We will not be broadcasting on the 28th because we will both
 be at Burning Man, but we will resume the following week with a
 special set from a very special artist (can you say live at the Love
 Parade???)  Lookout world...

                             [Teknique Logo]

hosted by Dragn'fly and DJ Pat featuring electronic music on the techy
side of things (you may even hear some tech-polka now and then!).&nbsp;&nbsp;
For more information about the show (such as past guests, future guests,
playlists, etc) or to listen, please visit:</font></font>
<p><font face="Arial,Helvetica"><font color="#FFFFFF"><font size=+1><a href="http://www.selekta.com/multimedia/teknique.asp" target="_blank">http://www.selekta.com/multimedia/teknique.asp</a></font></font></font>
<p><font face="Arial,Helvetica"><font color="#FFFFFF">Listening requires
realplayer G2....if you don't have it, get it here:&nbsp; <a href="http://www.real.com" target="_blank">http://www.real.com</a></font></font>
<p><font face="Arial,Helvetica"><font color="#FFFFFF">For more information
about your hosts, please check out:</font></font>
<p><font face="Arial,Helvetica"><font color="#FFFFFF"><a href="http://www.djdragnfly.com" target="_blank">http://www.djdragnfly.com</a></font></font>
<br><font face="Arial,Helvetica"><font color="#FFFFFF"><a href="http://www.dj-pat.com" target="_blank">http://www.dj-pat.com</a></font></font>
<p><font face="Arial,Helvetica"><font color="#FFFFFF">During the show,
we can be reached via AIM at <b><font size=+1>RadioTeknique</font></b>
so feel free to give us a hollah, request your favorite tech-polka choon,
talk shit, etc!</font></font>
<p><font face="Arial,Helvetica"><font color="#FFFFFF">P.S. : We are terribly
sorry for all of the technical delays we have had trying to get AndyW on
the show.&nbsp; We actually have it all worked out now and will be featuring
him soon!!!&nbsp;</font></font>
<p><font face="Arial,Helvetica"><font color="#FFFFFF">P.P.S.&nbsp; We will
not be broadcasting on the 28th because we will both be at Burning Man,
but we will resume the following week with a special set from a very special
artist (can you say live at the Love Parade???)&nbsp; Lookout world...</font></font>
<br>&nbsp;</td>
</tr>

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Release review Sat 18th???

Deep Dish was off the hook. I didn't make into any of
the other rooms. I was there for one reason...DEEP
DISH. The music was slamming....typical to what you
would here on any of there cd's. The crowd was mixed
and seemed to enjoy what they heard. 
There was only one thing that annoyed me
though....people with cameras. I understand the two
that we there taking pictures for magazines...but
those other people who were camped out in front of the
dj's just snapping away. I was there to party and
dance my arse off, but every couple of minutes it was
like excuse me....can I take a picture? I swear for at
least an hour there was none stop flashing. 
One thing that I saw that was freaking cool was people
asking Deep Dish for an autograph. Can you beleive it,
a dj being asked for his autograph? Cooooool!! Hell, I
would have asked for one, but was to busy getting my
groove on....
In all, it was a blast. It was nice to see Deep Dish
again and I can't wait till the next time. Anyone else
go?

directly lower the quality of life? Are you fucking kidding me? Are you a
socialist or something? Personally and IMO, my daily mindless consumerism
raises the quality of life for *me*. I know that much. Maybe you just dont
has as much disposable income or maybe you truely believe that buying toys
and presents for yourself somehow makes you less happy, but if I couldnt buy
as much crap as I do I would be *less* satisfied. I mean, seriously, if I
wasnt able to buy as much stuff dont you think I'd be more likelly to be
upset with my quality of life??!???!??

People who say idiotic things like, "I'm against organized religion. I'm a
Wiccan." Here's a hint... You said Wiccan and I knew precisely what you
meant. My definition of religion: "Belief that things that are not real are
as important or more important than the real concrete world in which we
live." Don't try to throw some pretentious dogshit at me about "How do you
know what's real" or I'll slap you in the head. "Feel that? Well that's the
REAL world." Believe in something supernatural? Does at least one other
person share the same belief? Do people who share this belief have a
collective name? THEN YOU'RE IN AN ORGANIZED RELIGION, DUMBASS! Stop trying
to be trendy.

Subject: [sfraves] More on Trees N Beats


Trees N Beats WAS awesome!  Great vibe, location, and music.  
Props out to the people who put it on... including some help from the 
Humboldt kids representing.  Dj Touch and Dj Receiver from Arcata 
finished the party off with tight sets.  Right before them Christian 
Clark played a sick-ass set  (I think some older tracks thrown in).  
Also props to Alanzo earlier in the night.... his shit took me there!

A great night for star gazing, too!  No moon to obstruct and no city 
lights.  We had the milky way and a million stars to go with our trees 
and beats!  Thanks for the fun time.

chris

Mornin All!

trees n beats was absolutely mystical in it's beauty....if you didn't go you
certainly missed out - I was smiling so hard the whole weekend I thought I
was gonna sprain a cheek muscle or something.  Many thanks to all of the
down to earth ppl I came into contact with.  Heya envirogirl email me for a
link to the next campout I'm going to I would love to hang out with you &
your grinning crew some more~~~~ I figure that I might as well go out in a
blaze of camp out glory!!!

I will tell you my evil plot--->  I was hoping to entice you, our local SFR
poet Laith, the radient Julie the hula girlie, and the ever entertaining
knowmadae into creating our own SFR campsite.

By the way I wanted to thank all you for treating my brother Wesley so nice!
It was his first party and since he always feels socially inept it was nice
to see him placed in a situation where everyone was accepting and
encouraging him to be part of it all.  He was quote unquote touched by the
outward friendliness and giving sense of our community.  If Steve is out
there I want to let you know that I saw him last night and he has been
wearing that visor you gave him non-stop since you placed it upon his little
newbie head on Sat. night!!!!  ohh the love!

all smiles till the next time ;)

<>rachel<>

p.s.  just wanted to send out another thank you to Laith for the personal
book of poetry which was tucked beneath my pillow when I woke up in the
garden.

> d00d, I'm like, really scared that you might not be kidding.  What a scary

Yes, I'm serious. What the hell are you talking about? You don't SERIOUSLY
think I, or 99% of the American population that lives in urban areas would
*actually* be happy living in the forest with not plumbing or electricity,
do you? They have retreats out in the wilderness for people who think that
they want to live out in the wild with basically 0 technology, and guess
what? 99% of THOSE people can't handle it and go back home to their hot
water, fresh food and A/C! Maybe you're just an optomist, but you are also
lacking common sense. Sure I'll give that you can be perfectly happy withOUT
"senseless consumerism", but to say that I'd be perfectly happy moving from
a city to the middle of the woods and shitting on the ground and bathing in
cold water is recockulous. Not to mention the fact I would die in like 1
week. If you call that a good standard of living you can start handing your
paycheck over to me and I'll buy you a couple acres of BFE forest and then
you can tell me how happy you are. Also, what the hell do you mean by
"you're on the fast track to get scrouge."?? Scrouge isnt even a noun!!!

scrouge \Scrouge\, v. t. [Etymol. uncertain.] To crowd; to squeeze. [Prov.
Eng. & Colloq. U.S.]

I guess when you live in the forest you dont have books or dictionaries,
either!

Laurence

Laurence Maar

People who say idiotic things like, "I'm against organized religion. I'm a
Wiccan." Here's a hint... You said Wiccan and I knew precisely what you
meant. My definition of religion: "Belief that things that are not real are
as important or more important than the real concrete world in which we
live." Don't try to throw some pretentious dogshit at me about "How do you
know what's real" or I'll slap you in the head. "Feel that? Well that's the
REAL world." Believe in something supernatural? Does at least one other
person share the same belief? Do people who share this belief have a
collective name? THEN YOU'RE IN AN ORGANIZED RELIGION, DUMBASS! Stop trying
to be trendy.

- http://negativepositive.gyrate.org/Things-that-need-to-die.html

Message-ID: <20010821193139.62041.qmail@web12303.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Tue, 21 Aug 2001 12:31:38 -0700 (PDT)
From: "John B." <svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com>
To: twinphishy@yahoo.com
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Anyone know of any cgi scripts that can block certain IP's


I wouldn't waste time writeing a cgi script to do this.  And unless your entire
site is CGI generated, it will be a rathar icky mess to get it all to work
right.

The much easier and faster way is to just drop the IP block you want to
disallow in /etc/hosts.deny

It won't stop a determined attacker (the tend to have access to alternate IPs),
but it'll stop the casual schmuck.


cya,
john

Subject: [sfraves] SRR: Rooms available at the doofhouse.

[For those of you that have not heard of the doofhouse, it's where I live.
In the past, it's been the home of various people who are very active in
the scene, including names that you know like Shane & Amber.  Other folks
have been very involved with CloudFactory and FnF.]

http://doof.averystylish.net/

All,

We have a few rooms at DoofHouse that have opened up, and we'd like to
fill them ASAP.  This home has become something very special certainly to
myself as a newcomer, but as equally to those who've lived here, and the
immediate and extended friends and family (both near and far) who have
enjoyed it's comforts.  

Our little community of 8 (James and Alyssa in the garden apt, Bobby in
the upstairs studio, and the 5 of us in the main house) have had a
wonderful run, but change has come rumblin' down the road again as it
inevitably does, and we're having a total of 3 move-outs in the next month
(one in less then 1 week).  We have two spots that are available immediately.

We are looking for 3 mature, communicative, creative individuals who can
hang with our unique and odd quasi-whatever-collectiveesque ravergeekfreak
household/vibe.  Exactly what this means and how it manifests has been a
dynamic continually created by the entire household, but there are
certainly some themes:
 1) While we go to parties and make them happen, we don't want to live in
    one.  Our home is our refuge.  
 2) Various kinds of dance music and it's expression are central aspects to
    most of our lives; some of us are musicians & DJs, and some of us
    involved in lighting or sound production.  SEE #1
 3) We respect eachother and our home
 4) We do our own chores
 5) We talk to eachother
 6) Addictive behavior not tolerated

This is not a good place for recluses or TV zombies, though we reserve the
right to engage in such activities on occasion, and that's cool!

But enough about what we want!

We are located in the Portola neighborhood in the southern corner or San
Francisco, on Hamilton & Silliman (5 blocks from the 101S Silver Avenue
exit).  The common amenities run thicker then the hair on the Wack A Mole
Champion's Hand:

  * DSL
  * Pissin' Boy Fountain - NOW!  With Live Fish, Lilies, and Crawdad!
  * Square Block Rec Center across the street
  * Trellised Sun & Fun Deck (Ivy not included)
  * Fairie/Art Garden
  * Killer kitchen
  * Beautiful Hardwood floors throughout
  * Butloads of curbside parking

ROOM DETAILS
^^^^^^^^^^^^

Room:     Sun Room
Rent:     $771.75/mo (utilities not included)
Deposit:  $656.25
Move-In:  $1428.00
Size      about 8 x 12 FT
Notes:    This is a small room, but with it's big windows and breezy 
          view of the park and neighborhood, what it lacks in size is
          made up for in atmosphere.  Light morning and evening sun, 
          and a spacious closet.  Share beautiful master bathroom with
          master bedroom (separate entrance).

Room:  	  Garden View Room
Rent:	  $823.20/mo (utilities not included)
Deposit:  $700.00
Move-In:  $1,523.20
Size:	  about 10 x 12 ft
Notes:	  Window overlooking the garden, peaceful and sunny. Ensuite bathroom -
          share with one other, built in closet and book case, fits queen
          bed, table, drawers.  Carpeted, and has a nice cozy feel.

Room:     Side Room
Rent:     $750/mo (utilities not included)
Deposit:  $650
Move-In:  $1400.00
Size:     about 8 x 12 ft
Notes:    Looks out to the north.  Quietest place in the house.  Ensuite
          bathroom, share with Garden View Room.  Large closet.  Hardwood
          floors.

CONTACT
^^^^^^^
Please feel free to contact us at the house to ask any questions and/or
arrange for a visit:
  * Ari		doof@regs.nebcorp.com
  * Andrew      mrflores@uclink.berkeley.edu (510) 520-2547

You can also call the house phone and ask for anyone:  415-LUSH-FEST.  
That's right, 415-587-4337.

Ari							there is no spoon

Subject: [sfraves] BSP: Radio Teknique now until 4pm (feat. Elektromajk)

--Boundary_(ID_s2x8DrT+IDaq6tXqLw/msQ)
Content-type: text/plain; charset=iso-8859-1
Content-transfer-encoding: quoted-printable

NOTE: Come chat with us on AIM during showtime...
Our screenname is RadioTeknique...

******************************************
Once again in our quest to bring you all things techy, RADIO TEKNIIQUE=20
brings to your computer speakers another major force of innovation on=20
the global scene.=20

Tune in TODAY (Aug. 21, 2001) from 1pm to 4pm PST to catch a super=20
special Wet & Hard set from Czech hero Electromajk along with live=20
mixing from hosts Dragn'fly (www.djdragnfly.com) & DJ Pat=20
(www.dj-pat.com).=20

To tune in click here at the prescribed times to get your groove on:=20

www.selekta.com/multimedia/teknique.asp=20


This mix from Electromajk is deep as fuck and loaded with the insane=20
amount of sexual energy that only an Eastern European could deliver. For =

those unfamilar with the Wet & Hard movement, it is a new breed of=20
post-techno techno. To some It is the sound of the pornoground, to=20
others it is simply sexmusic. Regardless of the adjectives used, it is=20
the secret sound of your imagination. Wet & Hard is hot kunst,=20
supa-stylish, state of the art club music for a hot new generation of=20
ever-so-slightly exhibitionistic no-holes-barred clubbers. Music for all =

those, whose adventurous lives have become endangered, through the=20
unimaginative low grade tediousness of tv-trance. Wet & Hard is a=20
techno-fantasy release of harddrive beats combined with sexually soaked=20
bouncy basses, all pumping and pounding, creating a throbbing,=20
thrusting, thumping, thrilling... thingy...errmmm ... sensation???=20
Whatever, it=B4s music to make her wet and him hard!=20

The music has been becoming more popular every day with releases and=20
remixes by Oliver Klein, Corvin Dalek, Alex Flatner, etc finding homes=20
on major labels throughout Europe, but the main force behind the=20
movement is the sex driven nightclubs of Eastern Europe. It is here that =

the DJs crafted their own sound that is slowly taking over the world and =

it is with great pleasure that Radio Teknique will be presenting a=20
series of shows focusing on Eastern Europe's top club DJs and their=20
drive to inject techno with an overdose of sexuality.=20

Our first installment will highlight Prague's Electromajk, a recent=20
addition to the MFS family. He is quickly becoming a major player on the =

European club scene playing regularly in places like Berlin, Ibiza and=20
Malta along with regular appearances in his hometown. His reputation is=20
top notch with both clubbers and DJs alike and we think you will see why =

after listening to the show.=20

For more information on him, please check out=20

www.electromajk.com=20

For those of you unfamiliar with the show, Radio Teknique is a weekly=20
internet broadcast hosted by Dragn'fly and DJ Pat featuring electronic=20
music on the techy side of things (you may even hear some tech-polka now =

and then!). For more information about the show (such as past guests,=20
future guests, playlists, etc) or to listen, please visit:=20

www.selekta.com/multimedia/teknique.asp=20

Listening requires realplayer G2....if you don't have it, get it here:=20
www.real.com=20

For more information about your hosts, please check out:=20

www.djdragnfly.com=20
www.dj-pat.com=20

During the show, we can be reached via AIM at RadioTeknique so feel free =

to give us a hollah, request your favorite tech-polka choon, talk shit,=20
etc!=20

P.S. : We are terribly sorry for all of the technical delays we have had =

trying to get AndyW on the show. We actually have it all worked out now=20
and will be featuring him soon!!!=20

P.P.S. We will not be broadcasting on the 28th because we will both be=20
at Burning Man, but we will resume the following week with a special set =

from a very special artist (can you say live at the Love Parade???)=20
Lookout world...=20



~dina


o)(---
www.djdragnfly.com
dragnfly@djdragnfly.com



--Boundary_(ID_s2x8DrT+IDaq6tXqLw/msQ)--

Message-Id: <20010821203834.C8FD22756@sitemail.everyone.net>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] *WOW =) Feelin' the Trees, Feelin' the Beats*

Oh My Goodness! what a Beautiful weekend! i am at a loss for words! 
the ~~VIBE~~ was in full effect yo'!! =) i really needed a small, laid back party to balance everything out that i've been doing, and that's what i got! i mean being in Vegas the weekend before wearing my platform shoes, clubbing, and gambling....and then being at TreesnBeats wearing my slippers getting my feet dirty, eating organic food, and breathing in the fresh air.....wow! what a contrast!! hehheeee! 
everyone, literally everyone was soooooooo friendly! i met so many cool Sfravers-Envirogirl, Rachel, Knowmad (sp.?), Michael , the REd stickman, Dreg, caught up with Laith ( thanks for the wonderful Poetry book-it's awesome!) you guys rock! let's all party again! =) =)
basically, the party was so refreshing-i danced so hard on Saturday night, me and my sis and friends were dancing behind the visuals having a great time! it looked so cool seeing people behind there! and it was so cool just seeeing people dance and go off =) 
man! it felt sooo good just to be dancing outside,no rave funk, just feelin' it , kickin' sand!! =) 
all the djs were good, it was nice listening to some mellow downtempo beats in the day, then hearing harder beats later on in the night =) 
what about that spot??? ** just Georgeous hah??!! ** 
the pond, garden, the clean drinkable water....ahhhhhhh =) =) 
i heard FnF was awesome the week before too =) 
well, all in all the party was sweet and i'm looking forward to next year! 
i'm glad to hear ya'll had a good time-our staff worked hard-mad props to everyone, especially Veronica and Arturo! 
always spreading the Aloha and Plur>>>>love, Hula girl Julie =) =) **muah**
ps: OMG!! guess who i met??!!! Dimitri!! the guy from Groove!!!! i was so **starstruck**! hehheheee! he's the one holding the disco ball in the poster =) he's super cool and wacky =)  I LOVE GROOVE!! so this was one of the biggest highlights of the trip! hahhaa!

People who say idiotic things like, "I'm against organized religion. I'm a
Wiccan." Here's a hint... You said Wiccan and I knew precisely what you
meant. My definition of religion: "Belief that things that are not real are
as important or more important than the real concrete world in which we
live." Don't try to throw some pretentious dogshit at me about "How do you
know what's real" or I'll slap you in the head. "Feel that? Well that's the
REAL world." Believe in something supernatural? Does at least one other
person share the same belief? Do people who share this belief have a
collective name? THEN YOU'RE IN AN ORGANIZED RELIGION, DUMBASS! Stop trying
to be trendy.

- http://negativepositive.gyrate.org/Things-that-need-to-die.html

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] FW: ACLU files Class Action Lawsuit in Defense of Rave Culture (EM:DEF News)

-----> Please FORWARD this message <-----

Electronic Music Defense and Education Fund
August 21st, EM:DEF 2001 Newsletter

1. ACLU files Class Action Lawsuit and Motion Challenging New Orleans
Plea Agreement
2. Midwest Music Summit a Success
3. Electronic Music Cultural Alliance strengthens Indianapolis Rave
Scene
4. Turning the Tables - Work With Your School
5. Donate to EM:DEF

1. ACLU files Class Action Lawsuit and Motion Challenging New Orleans
Plea Agreement
	The ACLU filed a class action lawsuit against Attorney General John
Ashcroft along with a motion for a temporary restraining order and
preliminary injunction in New Orleans today.  Arguing that the plea
agreement in United States v. Barbecue of New Orleans is the result of a
coordinated effort to eliminate rave culture, the ACLU requested an
injunction barring enforcement of a ban on glowsticks, pacifiers, chill
rooms, massage tables and other items listed in the plea agreement.  The
class action lawsuit lists three plaintiffs, and others like them, who
were deprived of their first amendment rights to freedom of expression
as a result of the plea agreement.

The lawsuit and motion assert that all items banned under the plea
agreement are protected under the first amendment, that none of the
items could be classified as paraphernalia (as defined in the Controlled
Substances Act), that rehearsed dancing is a protected form of free
speech, and that the government cannot require a private business to
enforce policies which deprive a third party of their constitutional
rights (even as a condition of a plea agreement).

A Federal Judge is expected to rule on the motion for a temporary
restraining order and preliminary injunction before Friday, when The
State Palace Theater will host a rave event.  The event marks the one
year anniversary of a DEA raid on the Theater, a raid that ultimately
led to a Federal Indictment of Robert and Brian Brunet as well as Donnie
Estopinal under the Crackhouse Statute.  If the judge grants the ACLU's
motion, partygoers will once again be allowed to dance with glow sticks
- leading many to predict a turnout of ravers glowing as they've never
glowed before:-)

The lawsuit and motion can be viewed in their entirety on our web-site
at:
http://www.emdef.org/library_law.html#NewOrleans

The ACLUs press release can be viewed at:
http://www.aclu.org/news/2001/n082101a.html

2.  Midwest Music Summit a Success:
	Indianapolis hosted the Midwest Music Summit from August 10th to the
12th.  The summit gave electronic music a significant credibility in the
eyes of public officials who have declared a war against rave parties.
Scarab Records organized the summit, which featured regional Hip-Hop,
Rock and Electronic Music artists.  The conference drew A&R
representatives from several major record labels, along with many other
professionals.  Expect a growing attendance at next year's summit.

http://www.scarabrecords.om
http://www.midwestmusicsummit.com

3.  Electronic Music Culture Alliance Strengthens Indianapolis Rave
Scene
Indianapolis has also been organizing a grassroots group to defend raves
against attacks from their Mayor's office.  The Electronic Music Culture
Alliance will file papers to qualify as a Political Action Committee.
They have agreed to meet with the Mayor to discuss ways of preserving
rave culture without legal harassment of promoters.  The Electronic
Music Culture Alliance is one more in a series of successful
organizations forming around the country to protect electronic music.
In years to come, America may come to appreciate electronic music in the
same way Jazz is appreciated today.  To preserve the integrity of our
culture, please consider forming a similar group in your area. With a
dedicated team, a little time and a bit of energy, a lot can be
accomplished.  Visit:

http://www.indyemca.com
  ** this site will go live early next week **

4.  Turning the Tables: Work With Your School
	In June, EM:DEF announced our intention to launch a program bringing
turntables and electronic music production equipment into high school
classrooms.  We've been talking with several people, and it appears we
have a strong candidate who shares the vision and dedication to
accomplish this effort.  With Turning the Tables preparing it's launch,
and with school starting across the country, we are turning to you -
students - for help.  Turning the Tables is seking letters we can show
companies in order to convince them of the merits of the program, and to
donate equipment and operating funds.  We also seeking people to sign up
for the program.  You can find out more about how to help by visiting
our web-site at:

http://www.emdef.org/education.html#HighSchools

5. Donate to EM:DEF
EM:DEF's efforts allowed Donnie Estopinal along with Robert and Brian
Brunet to stay in the fight long enough to provide a plea agreement
which could be challenged on constitutional grounds. Private attorney
fees for the managers and promoters were incurred in New Orleans.
EM:DEF is appealing to you for support in this case, and others which
may follow.

We NEED financial support from people to continue this work. We are
asking that everyone concerned about the future of electronic music, and
the protection of constitutional rights in general, make a donation of
$15 or more to EM:DEF. All donations are fully tax deductable. If you
can donate proceeds from an event, or otherwise contribute, we will
appreciate that support as well.  Learn more...

http://www.emdef.org/contribute.html

Press can contact susan@greengalactic.com
All other inquiries can be directed to will@emdef.org

EM:DEF is a project of The Lindesmith Center

Date: Tue, 21 Aug 2001 22:18:50 
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <F2377kBnccYTjr8cU6x00000f45@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 21 Aug 2001 22:18:50.0818 (UTC) FILETIME=[4159D220:01C12A8F]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] RE: Is the UK a 2nd world country?

Sir Douglas of Fraser (aka "Treeboy") believes:

> > > I should have mentioned the quality of life seemed
> > > better - less mindless consumerism

And Sir Laurence del Maur provoked discussion with:

>Maybe I just want to bitch.... but how does "less mindless consumerism"
>directly lower the quality of life?

I would like to begin my response by pointing out that Doug used the 
modifier "mindless" in respect to consumerism. In other words, he agrees 
that certain creature comforts are necessary for quality of life, ie, flush 
toilets and running water, but that gold-plated flush toilets and water taps 
are merely an excuse to purchase and not necessary to your personal quality 
of life. Unless of course, you are alergic to all metals except gold and you 
break out in a nasty rash when you touch mere stainless steel.

However, Doug, I have also lived in the UK for extended periods of time. I 
believe that in the middle classes, especially in the more prosperous south 
(ie, London area), mindless consumerism is as rampant as it is here. Witness 
the abundance of cel phones and the redecorating mania.

My view of excessive material goods being necessary for quality of life:

Load of bollocks.

Gie me a f**kin' break. Laurence, do you presume to tell me that Nintendo or 
a dvd player or a newer model car is as necessary to your quality of life as 
having being able to sleep uninterupted, having more food in your house than 
you can eat in one sitting, being able to see and hear and touch the people 
you love? Pop quiz to SFRaves: would you rather have a good night's sleep or 
a razor scooter?

Think about the moments in your life that made you happiest. By yourself or 
with others. Don't friends give you more quality of life than the clothes 
you are wearing?

And, if you think all consumerism is mindless, think again. We all consume, 
but we can become mindful consumers. Buy recycled content paper, reused 
clothing and reusable containers. Buy what you need: food, shelter, some 
clothing.

Close the Gap. Choose life.
K

Subject: [sfraves] ASR day party review

Hey,

Well yeah, I was there on Sunday.. warm in the sun, cool in the shade.. and 
then there was the wind.. early on the canopy over the altar took off, but 
it was rewarded with secure stakings, and it stayed put.  Later on, while 
Tony was mixing, the main canopy decided it was time to go too.  It was 
decided to pack it up, rather than trying to put it back and secure 
it.  Good turnout.. I shoulda counted, but I guesstimate around 60-100 
people were there.  Met some coo peeps, some of which I've already 
forgotten, and the rest I'll slaughter spelling: Dregaron Starlight, 
Michael; the cliff explorer, Greg, Leslie, Martin Randall.. um that's all I 
can think of right now.. The music was great, I don't think one set stands 
out in my mind as being best, but I liked the booty house I heard from 
Crisco and Tony.. I had a good time, even walked around a lil bit and 
noticed there's a huge parking lot full of cop cars near by, a skate park, 
and a large collection of shopping carts surrounded by hills of 
dirt.  Shout outs to Jeremy, Andy, Jessica, and OSBY for keeping me company 
and entertained..

sarilion

Subject: Re: [sfraves] RE: Is the UK a 2nd world country?

Yes, but no one has disproved my assertion yet! The original statement was:

> > > > I should have mentioned the quality of life seemed
> > > > better - less mindless consumerism

Which means, logically that:
[more] mindless consumerism = [worse] quality of life.

Which makes no sense!
So, I said:

> >Maybe I just want to bitch.... but how does "less mindless consumerism"
> >directly lower the quality of life?

And someone has yet to prove that more mindless consumerism actually LOWERS
the quality of life. Sure, you dont NEED consumerism to have a high quality
of life, but having more certainly wont lower it! If I have XXX amount of
stuff, and then suddenly I decide to go on a shopping spree and now have
XXXXXX amount of stuff. How am I worse off? If anything I'm better off!
Certainly, in my perspective my quality of life is improved both by the
ability to buy more things and having more things.

Thus, what is implied by the statement "I should have mentioned the quality
of life seemed better - less mindless consumerism" is *bullshit*.

Thanks =)

Laurence

-----
Laurence Maar
Developer, Alliance United
-----
People who say idiotic things like, "I'm against organized religion. I'm a
Wiccan." Here's a hint... You said Wiccan and I knew precisely what you
meant. My definition of religion: "Belief that things that are not real are
as important or more important than the real concrete world in which we
live." Don't try to throw some pretentious dogshit at me about "How do you
know what's real" or I'll slap you in the head. "Feel that? Well that's the
REAL world." Believe in something supernatural? Does at least one other
person share the same belief? Do people who share this belief have a
collective name? THEN YOU'RE IN AN ORGANIZED RELIGION, DUMBASS! Stop trying
to be trendy.

Subject: RE: [sfraves] ASR day party review

Hell yeah! Love that booty house music! That was a great party. Thanks for the review. I must add my description, though. Poor Osby was hungry that day, and I can't stand to see a hungry dude (maybe cause I'm a southern boy from Texas), so we drove to Raley's. Andy recommended the deli section, and so I bought Osby some Salisbury steak and Mac 'n cheese, and I got poppers, I mean jalapeno peppers breaded and stuffed with cream cheese. Next time I'll buy a bucket of poppers cause Andy wanted some! Now I know what he likes.

You know how one good deed deserves another? It came true because when we returned to the park, there was a choice parking spot near the party. Sunday in any Bay Area park can get crowded; it was great not having to park a mile away.

Anyway, I learned a lesson as well. You can stand around like a wall-flower (at any party, daytime or otherwise), or you can mingle and dance. Osby kept trying to get me to meet people on my own, and I was just chilling, until the music got me and I danced like a fool. I also met Sarilion, Alex, Dreg, Joe, Andy, and other ravers.

There is nothing quite like listening and dancing to music under a clear, beautiful sky with a bountiful breeze, mainly because it's not hot outside, like it can be during an underground (indoor) party. 

Thanks to ASR; I am looking forward to your next party, indoors or outside.
Greg

Received: (qmail 17943 invoked from network); 21 Aug 2001 22:55:15 -0000
X-Originating-IP: [208.232.78.218]
From: "DJ Howlin' Bob" <djhbomb999@hotmail.com>
To: lmaar@au-ins.com, kehgray@hotmail.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org
Bcc: 
Date: Tue, 21 Aug 2001 15:54:44 -0700
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <F272lETZSmiiKMUdZEx0000c1ff@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 21 Aug 2001 22:54:44.0732 (UTC) FILETIME=[452F03C0:01C12A94]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] RE: Is the UK a 2nd world country?

>Yes, but no one has disproved my assertion yet! The original statement was:
>
> > > > > I should have mentioned the quality of life seemed
> > > > > better - less mindless consumerism
>
>Which means, logically that:
>[more] mindless consumerism = [worse] quality of life.
>
>Which makes no sense!

to the contrary.  "mindless consumerism," to me, implies both an absolute 
glut of products of indifferent quality (ergo, "mindless": "mindful" 
consumption would at a minimum entail awareness of relative quality) and the 
equally "mindless" pursuit of "more," regardless of the actual return one 
received from one's consumption.  if you consume tons of crap, you're still 
consuming crap, and IMO the majority of consumer goods on offer nowadays are 
precisely that.

Thus, if the energy expenditure, expense, and stress entailed in "mindless 
consumerism" is not recompensed by the positive value received from the 
items consumed, then the idea that "[more] mindless consumerism = [worse] 
quality of life" is indeed logical, and IMO has been proved repeatedly, both 
in my own experience and my observation of others.

--hb

yes, i *did* take Logic in college ;o)

Subject: Re: [sfraves] RE: Is the UK a 2nd world country?

> yes, i *did* take Logic in college ;o)

YES! Someone did properly address my statement!!! Thank you! And, I agree,
your points are all correct!! =)

However...

> to the contrary.  "mindless consumerism," to me, implies both an absolute
> glut of products of indifferent quality (ergo, "mindless": "mindful"
> consumption would at a minimum entail awareness of relative quality) and
the
> equally "mindless" pursuit of "more," regardless of the actual return one
> received from one's consumption.  if you consume tons of crap, you're
still
> consuming crap, and IMO the majority of consumer goods on offer nowadays
are
> precisely that.
>
> Thus, if the energy expenditure, expense, and stress entailed in "mindless
> consumerism" is not recompensed by the positive value received from the
> items consumed, then the idea that "[more] mindless consumerism = [worse]
> quality of life" is indeed logical, and IMO has been proved repeatedly,
both
> in my own experience and my observation of others.

Personally I find the act of consumerism itself to be rewarding. There is no
cost / exenditure other than monetary related to the act, because to me, the
act itself is a leisurely activity. Also, because it is leisure I dont think
there is a stress component at all, or if there is it is small enough that
it is innately offset. That is to say that spending time in a mall, oggling
all sorts of shit and using my credit card are innately rewarding in the
same way someone else might find, say, walking in the park rewarding. I
consider it a leisurely activity. And, therefore, if in addition the
products I have mindlessly or mindfully purchased add a value to my life,
that further increases my quality of life. 1) Because the act was rewarding
and 2) the addition to the quantity of items I have has increased. =)

That is just me personally of course, I'm not speaking for anyone else. =)

But, yeah, tons of crap being sold nowadays.... I agree...

Laurence

-----
Laurence Maar
Developer, Alliance United
-----
People who say idiotic things like, "I'm against organized religion. I'm a
Wiccan." Here's a hint... You said Wiccan and I knew precisely what you
meant. My definition of religion: "Belief that things that are not real are
as important or more important than the real concrete world in which we
live." Don't try to throw some pretentious dogshit at me about "How do you
know what's real" or I'll slap you in the head. "Feel that? Well that's the
REAL world." Believe in something supernatural? Does at least one other
person share the same belief? Do people who share this belief have a
collective name? THEN YOU'RE IN AN ORGANIZED RELIGION, DUMBASS! Stop trying
to be trendy.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] ASR day party review

Ok, I've been meaning to write this since Sunday, and you've finally
made me do it!

Another beautiful Sunday afternoon in the park with the ASR family.
Thanks to Tony especially for putting this together, and to all that helped.

It's been a long time since I got out, so it was really great to reconnect
with old friends JeremyB, AndyW, Leslie (you'd have been in trouble if
you hadn't shown up!), Patrice the TeknoDiva (of course!), Isaac, Michael
(the BreadStickman),Usa, Emi and many others. And I put a lot of faces
to names too - that was the best part. I finally got to meet the famous Osby
(Hello2Day!), Sarilion, Dregaron Starlighter (sp?!), GregVP, Alida and
Veronica (hi!) from the HJBC, and of course the delightful Amy T. And
probably others I've missed here. It was really good to be reminded how
much you guys all mean to me (aahhh).

I heard more than I wanted to know about Michael and Dreg's T&B
experiences (ask them!)! And chatting with Dreg about life, the
universe and Tucson was great. And picking people's brains for
recommendations on mixers and turntables (I'm shopping) was
very useful too.

I'd have to say my favorite set of the afternoon was Tracy's - although
it was officially "house only" I think she strayed a little towards the
techno camp, which was alright by me!!

It's funny how that spot always gets the wind - walking back to the
car to get my jacket, cuz I was freezing, as soon as I got out of that
spot it was warm and sunny! Hmm... And having the DJ "booth"
fly away was interesting! Props to whoever was spinning as that
happened for keeping their cool!

So anyway, it was a great party to socialize, chat, get to know one
another, meet new folks and actually be able to carry on a conversation,
and listen to great music at the same time.

Thanks again to the ASR family for another great afternoon in the park!
See you at the next one!

- Martin


gregvp@sprynet.com wrote:

> Hell yeah! Love that booty house music! That was a great party. Thanks for the review. I must add my description, though. Poor Osby was hungry that day, and I can't stand to see a hungry dude (maybe cause I'm a southern boy from Texas), so we drove to Raley's. Andy recommended the deli section, and so I bought Osby some Salisbury steak and Mac 'n cheese, and I got poppers, I mean jalapeno peppers breaded and stuffed with cream cheese. Next time I'll buy a bucket of poppers cause Andy wanted some! Now I know what he likes.
>
> You know how one good deed deserves another? It came true because when we returned to the park, there was a choice parking spot near the party. Sunday in any Bay Area park can get crowded; it was great not having to park a mile away.
>
> Anyway, I learned a lesson as well. You can stand around like a wall-flower (at any party, daytime or otherwise), or you can mingle and dance. Osby kept trying to get me to meet people on my own, and I was just chilling, until the music got me and I danced like a fool. I also met Sarilion, Alex, Dreg, Joe, Andy, and other ravers.
>
> There is nothing quite like listening and dancing to music under a clear, beautiful sky with a bountiful breeze, mainly because it's not hot outside, like it can be during an underground (indoor) party.
>
> Thanks to ASR; I am looking forward to your next party, indoors or outside.
> Greg

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] RE: Is the UK a 2nd world country?

perhaps this is where disagreement comes in:

>Personally I find the act of consumerism itself to be rewarding. There is 
>no cost / exenditure other than monetary related to the act, because to me, 
>the act itself is a leisurely activity. Also, because it is leisure I dont 
>think there is a stress component at all, or if there is it is small enough 
>that it is innately offset. That is to say that spending time in a mall, 
>oggling all sorts of shit and using my credit card are innately rewarding 
>in the same way someone else might find, say, walking in the park 
>rewarding.

for myself, unless i'm shopping for something i really want/need/am into 
(new CDs, outdoor wear, bike parts, more CDs...) i find the need to get off 
my arse, onto MUNI, and out to the shops to be onerous.  Perhaps i'm too old 
and tired for recreational shopping ;o)

and there's also the additional stress factors outside of the act of 
consumption itself: e.g., how many more hours does one have to 
work/commute/do things you'd rather not do in order to pay for the objects 
of consumption?  and what (time with dear ones, rest time, hot sex, 
contemplation, sleep, and of course dancing!) is one giving up in order to 
perform that labor?

tangentially, this is why the whole cost/benefit analysis approach to 
political issues gives me the Orwellian willies...the result is utterly 
dependent on what one considers as "benefits" and/or acknowledges as 
"costs."

--hb

ow, my brain hurts...i was up burning compilation CDs for my radio show at 
Burning Man until 2AM.  Burners, tune to 90.3 COUAC and listen for the 
strains of the Holiday In Risk Theme...

Subject: Re: [sfraves] RE: Is the UK a 2nd world country?

> for myself, unless i'm shopping for something i really want/need/am into
> (new CDs, outdoor wear, bike parts, more CDs...) i find the need to get
off
> my arse, onto MUNI, and out to the shops to be onerous.  Perhaps i'm too
old
> and tired for recreational shopping ;o)

Ahhh... yes... recreational shopper is probably the best term for what I
describe. I like that. It should be a title. =)

> and there's also the additional stress factors outside of the act of
> consumption itself: e.g., how many more hours does one have to
> work/commute/do things you'd rather not do in order to pay for the objects
> of consumption?

Ah ha! But see, for me, recreational shopping is a reward and the benefit
from having to work so hard to earn all that money. After working so hard
and once I've accumulated this disposable income, what better way to spend
it, relieve stress and inrease my quality of life but mill around at the
mall and spend that money =) That is one of many points where my work
translates into benefit. You see, I'm going to have to do all that hard work
anyway, and if I didnt have this outlet with which to reap the benefits of
this work (through consumerism), I would be more dissatisfied with having to
do that work.

> and what (time with dear ones, rest time, hot sex,
> contemplation, sleep, and of course dancing!) is one giving up in order to
> perform that labor?

Of course, everything has its priorities. I mean, I certainly would rather
be having hot sex and you're probably like me in that I am contemplating and
doing nothing most of the time, meaning that getting off my ass can be a
chore, but its a worthwhile one once I'm there and having fun. Same applies
to things for me like going out to parties or going the beach, etc. Sure it
takes time and energy to start off, but once you are doing those things it
was worth it. I mean, thing about how much time and energy it takes to pull
a bunch of ravers off their ass and get to the party. That's 50 times more
energy than it take for me to go to the mall. I'm just saying that my
mindless consumerism does in fact have a place in my
things-to-do-for-fun-amusement-etc list and it certainly adds to my
happiness coefficient.

> tangentially, this is why the whole cost/benefit analysis approach to
> political issues gives me the Orwellian willies...the result is utterly
> dependent on what one considers as "benefits" and/or acknowledges as
> "costs."

Defaintely! And to add to that, one person's benefit could be valueless to
another individual if not a minus entirely.

> ow, my brain hurts...i was up burning compilation CDs for my radio show at
> Burning Man until 2AM.  Burners, tune to 90.3 COUAC and listen for the
> strains of the Holiday In Risk Theme...

Ohhhh nice.

Laurence

Laurence Maar

People who say idiotic things like, "I'm against organized religion. I'm a
Wiccan." Here's a hint... You said Wiccan and I knew precisely what you
meant. My definition of religion: "Belief that things that are not real are
as important or more important than the real concrete world in which we
live." Don't try to throw some pretentious dogshit at me about "How do you
know what's real" or I'll slap you in the head. "Feel that? Well that's the
REAL world." Believe in something supernatural? Does at least one other
person share the same belief? Do people who share this belief have a
collective name? THEN YOU'RE IN AN ORGANIZED RELIGION, DUMBASS! Stop trying
to be trendy.

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

On the subject of the UK and consumerism, et. al., here is a segment of the=
=20
most recent YOUpgrade ezine from Fraser Clark in the UK.  Looks like some=20
of you are "Moderns" and others "Cultural Creatives."  Fraser would see the=
=20
rave subculture as composed of primarily "Cultural Creatives."
_______________________________


THE CULTURAL CREATIVES

WE'VE BEEN CALLING THEM ZIPPIES FOR YEARS. NOW RESEARCH FROM THE US HAS=20
DISCOVERED A NEW "CLASSLESS CLASS" - THE CULTURAL CREATIVES.

A brand new book THE CULTURAL CREATIVES offers new perspectives that could=
=20
help the environmental and social justice movements find new paths,=20
sidestepping the troubles that have stymied them in recent years.
THE CULTURAL CREATIVES was written by Paul Ray and Sherry Ruth Anderson who=
=20
have spent more than a decade doing survey research to discover the values=
=20
that Americans hold dear. ("Values are the best single predictor of real=20
behavior," they say.) They find that, based on fundamental values, U.S.=20
citizens can now be classified into three major groups:

=B7 MODERNS - 48% of Americans (93 million adults) with a median family=20
income of $42,500.
=B7 TRADITIONALS - 24.5% of Americans (48 million adults). (Dying)
=B7 CULTURAL CREATIVES - 25% (50 million adults) (and even more children?)=
=20
(Growing)

We all recognize Moderns and Traditionals, but most people don't even know=
=20
that Cultural Creatives exist. The Cultural Creatives themselves are=20
unaware of their huge numbers.
Here lie the seeds of a cultural revolution -- one that's already well on=20
its way.

MODERNS - The dominant subculture of our time, they make the rules we all=20
live by, control the civil service, the military, the courts, and the=20
media. Some of them operate the multinational corporations. Their ideology=
=20
is laid out for us every day, in detail, in pretty much every communication=
=20
medium. Their belief in a technological economy is reshaping the face of=20
the globe. They tend to dismiss other cultures and ways of life as somehow=
=20
inferior.
"The simplest way to understand today's Moderns is to see that they are the=
=20
people who accept the commercialized urban-industrial world as the obvious=
=20
right way to live. They're not looking for alternatives."
To Moderns, growth is not only good, it's essential.

MODERNS' BELIEFS (most important)
(a) making loadsa money
(b) climbing the ladder of success with measurable steps toward one's goal
(c) Having lots of choices (as a consumer, or voter, or on the job)
(d) being on top of the latest trends, styles and innovations
(e) supporting economic and technological progress at the national level
(f) rejecting the values and concerns of native people, rural people,=20
Traditionals, New Agers, and religious mystics.

TRADITIONALS. At the end of World War II, Traditionals were 50% of the=20
population, but today they're 25%, and shrinking as dying Traditionals are=
=20
not replaced by younger ones. Traditionals tend to be older, poorer, and=20
less educated than others.
Traditionals are often pro-environment and anti-big business. They're=20
outraged at the destruction of the world they remember, both natural areas=
=20
and small-town life.
"Many Traditionals are not white bread Republicans but elderly New Deal=20
Democrats, Reagan Democrats, and old-time union people as well as social=20
conservatives in politics."

TRADITIONALS' BELIEFS (among other things)
(a) patriarchs should again dominate family life
(b) FEMINISM is a swearword
(c) men need to keep their traditional roles and women need to keep theirs
(d) family, church, and community are where you belong
(e) customary and familiar ways of life should be maintained
(f) it's important to regulate sex -- pornography, teen sex, extramarital=20
sex, abortion
(g) men should be proud to serve in the military
(h) all the guidance you need for your life can be found in the Bible
(i) preserving civil liberties is less important than restricting immoral=20
behavior
(j) freedom to carry arms is essential
(k) foreigners are not welcome

CULTURAL CREATIVES. What Ray and Anderson discovered during a decade of=20
research is that the Moderns and Traditionals have now been joined by a=20
third subculture within the U.S., 50 million strong (26% of all adults) --=
=20
and growing.

CULTURAL CREATIVES' BELIEFS (10 OR MORE AND YOU'RE ONE!)
(a) love nature and are deeply concerned about its destruction
(b) are strongly aware of the problems of the whole planet and want to see=
=20
action to curb them, such as limiting economic growth
(c) would pay more taxes or higher prices if they knew the money would go=20
to clean up the environment and stop global warming
(d) give a lot of importance to developing and maintaining relationships
(e) place great importance on helping other people
(f) volunteer for one or more good causes
(g) care intensely about psychological or spiritual development
(h) see spirituality and religion as important in their own lives but are=20
also concerned about the role of the religious Right in politics
(h) want more equality for women at work and want more women leaders in=20
business and politics
(i) are concerned by violence and abuse of women and children everywhere on=
=20
Earth
(j) want politics and government to emphasize children's education and well=
=20
being, the rebuilding of neighborhoods and communities, and the creation of=
=20
an ecologically sustainable future
(k) are unhappy with both left and right in politics and want a new way=20
that is not the mushy middle
(l) tend to be optimistic about the future and distrust the cynical and=20
pessimistic view offered by the media
(m) want to be involved in creating a new and better way of life
(n) are concerned about what big corporations are doing in the name of=20
profit: exploiting poor countries, harming the environment, downsizing
(o) have their finances and spending under control and are not concerned=20
about overspending
(p) dislike the modern emphasis on success, on "making it," on wealth and=20
luxury goods
(q) like people and places that are exotic and foreign, and enjoy=20
experiencing and learning about other ways of life

Cultural Creatives are not defined by particular demographic=20
characteristics, they can be accountants, social workers, waitresses,=20
computer programmers, hair stylists lawyers, chiropractors, truck drivers,=
=20
photographers or gardeners.
The large majority are quite mainstream in their religious beliefs. They're=
=20
no more liberal/conservative than the mainstream, but tend to reject=20
"left-right" labels.
Really, their one distinguishing demographic characteristic is that 60% of=
=20
them are women, and most Cultural Creatives tend to hold values and beliefs=
=20
that women have traditionally held about issues of caring, family life,=20
children, education, relationships, and responsibility.
In their personal lives, they seek authenticity -- they want to walk their=
=20
talk and are also intent on finding wholeness, integration, and community.
Cultural Creatives are quite clear that they don't want to live in an=20
alienated, disconnected world. Their approach to health is preventive and=20
holistic, though they do not reject modern medicine. In their work, they=20
may try to go beyond earning a living to having "right livelihood" or a=20
vocation.
"In the twenty-first century, a new era is taking hold. The biggest=20
challenges are to preserve and sustain life on the planet and find a new=20
way past the overwhelming spiritual and psychological emptiness of modern=20
life. Though these issues have been building for a century, only now can=20
the Western world bring itself to publicly consider them. The Cultural=20
Creatives are responding to these overwhelming challenges by creating a new=
=20
culture."
New businesses, new management styles, new technologies, new forms of=20
social organization, and new decision-making techniques (the precautionary=
=20
principle, for example) -- the Cultural Creatives are constructing a new=20
world in our midst, largely ignored by the media.
By different paths, 50 million Cultural Creatives emerged from (or were=20
influenced by) social movements of the '60s and '70s. Ray and Anderson=20
describe 20 such movements that have spawned Cultural Creatives who, in=20
turn, have begun to put a positive spin on movements that have been mainly=
=20
oppositional. "Slowly a lesson has been drifting in on one movement=20
organisation after another. At some point, opposing something bad ceases to=
=20
be enough, and they must stand for positive values, or produce a service=20
that is important to their constituency,"
Ray and Anderson see this shift occurring in the environmental movement.=20
"Cultural Creatives are urging the environmental movement into a new phase.=
=20
Having educated us through protests and information, some are moving beyond=
=20
that now, to develop new kinds of businesses, technologies, and cooperative=
=20
ventures." There's a long way to go, but it's a start.
A major impediment to further innovation is the fact that Cultural=20
Creatives all think there are very few of them when in fact there are very=
=20
many of them. Therefore, "They do not know that they have the potential to=
=20
shape the life of the twenty-first century. Like an audience in a theater,=
=20
Cultural Creatives all look in the same direction. They read the same books=
=20
and share the same values and come to similar conclusions - but rarely do=20
they turn toward one another. They have not yet formed a sense of 'us' as a=
=20
collective identity; nor do they have a collective image of themselves=85
"Since they are part of a subculture that cannot yet see itself, these=20
millions of Cultural Creatives do not know what a potential they carry for=
=20
our common future."
Peter Montague (National Writers Union, UAW Local 1981/AFL-CIO)
Paul H. Ray and Sherry Ruth Anderson, THE CULTURAL CREATIVES (New York:=20
Harmony Books, 2000). ISBN 0-609-60467-8
<http://www.culturalcreatives.org/>.




--=====================_31694115==_.ALT--

From sfraves-return-71622-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Aug 22 03:27:05 2001

> Yes, but no one has disproved my assertion yet! The original statement
was:
>
> > > > > I should have mentioned the quality of life seemed
> > > > > better - less mindless consumerism
>
> Which means, logically that:
> [more] mindless consumerism = [worse] quality of life.
>
> Which makes no sense!
> So, I said:
>
> > >Maybe I just want to bitch.... but how does "less mindless consumerism"
> > >directly lower the quality of life?
>
> And someone has yet to prove that more mindless consumerism actually
LOWERS
> the quality of life. Sure, you dont NEED consumerism to have a high
quality
> of life, but having more certainly wont lower it! If I have XXX amount of
> stuff, and then suddenly I decide to go on a shopping spree and now have
> XXXXXX amount of stuff. How am I worse off? If anything I'm better off!
> Certainly, in my perspective my quality of life is improved both by the
> ability to buy more things and having more things.
>
> Thus, what is implied by the statement "I should have mentioned the
quality
> of life seemed better - less mindless consumerism" is *bullshit*.

of NO ONE GIVES A FUCK.

-------

Hello everyone,

I've put together a nice blurb on the electronica-optica debut next
Saturday. I've been settling a lot of last minute details and changes for
this special event, as well as many, many, many hours on our shop in the
city <<ELECTRONICA OPTICA>> which will be opening in October.

Many of us are really excited about this debut. Funny thing is, this is
still going to be an event like the ones we all go to all the time:
DJs, lights, decor, alters, dancers, and some visuals.

The only difference for us, really, is that the VJs and video artists
are taking main stage from the DJs... imagine that! The VJs are
actually getting time slots like DJs always get. That may not seem
like much of a change, but to the VJs, it's all of sudden, like, respect.

The good part for you guys is, most of these VJs are putting together
all their best content, some of it pre-burning man screenings of brand
new work. Since they're the stars and they don't have to water it
down for an 8 hour show.

Call the info line next week for more details.

If you want to get involved working on this event, let me know at:
radley@elemental.nu.

Suryummy sez: Don't forget to bring your butterfly photon catchers, cause
when it comes down to it those iridescent little buggers will be the
talk of the town, just you wait!!!

We hope to see you all there!

-radley

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: jobseeker? the Job Fairy can help ;^)

hi all,

some of you know that -- in addition to being the 'fairy rave mother' i am
also the Job Fairy -- I am a recruiter of many years, and in today's
do-it-yourself job market, i am a coach and lead workshops in how to figure
out what jobs are for you, and how to get yourself noticed in the crowd.

below is the information about my next workshop on sept 15th -- it's a smal=
l
group, in a really magical setting, and is perfect for anyone needing some
focus and inspration in their search, or anyone feeling confused about how
to stand out in this market.

and, if you can't make this, or prefer one-on-one, i also do private
coaching sessions that produce remarkable results.. 

feel free to email or call me with questions. (my office is closed from
august 27-sept 3, though, so have a great holiday)

leslie



--------------------------------------

The Job Fairy presents:

........The Secrets of Magical Resumes and Job Searches........

Saturday, September 15, 2001 - 10:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m
Triton Hotel, 342 Grant Avenue @ Bush, San Francisco
Suite 200 "Creative Zone" Conference Room

$125 includes 1/2 hour personal follow-up coaching call
To register, and for more information, call Leslie Ayres at 510.232.5255

No crystal balls or magic wands required. Getting a magical job starts with
knowing who you are, being real about what you have to offer, and presentin=
g
it--in your resume and in person--in a way that=B9s irresistible to the peopl=
e
who can hire you.

We all know that the job market has undergone a dramatic change. Two years
ago, a qualified job-seeker was bombarded wihth choices.  Today, after the
"dot-bomb" economy and fallout of the past 18 months, hiring is starting
again. But every posted opening gets hundreds of responses, outside
recruiters aren't the resource that candidates used to count on, and so it
takes real know-how to stand out in the crowd.

This workshop is designed to teach you how to make your job search simpler,
faster, and more focused. You will learn to evaluate new opportunities, and
how to present your individuality, your talents and your experience with
confidence and results.

In this day-long workshop, we=B9ll cover:

... Getting clear on your values and priorities
... Generating a checklist of parameters to evaluate possibilities
... Getting perspective on your transferable skills for new career
directions
... Shifting your relationship to your resume to one of power and freedom
... Creating a resume that represents the real you=8B-and gets noticed by the
people who matter
... How to easily customize a stand-out resume for any position
... Secrets of uncovering unlisted jobs,
... How to get your resume noticed and on top of the stack
... Preparing for powerful and honest interviews
... Handling tough interview questions
... Keeping the faith and focus for as long as it takes

Who will benefit from this workshop:

... Job seekers wanting a resume they love that will get them interviews
... Career changers needing to repackage themselves and their talents for a
new industry
... Professionals needing to stand out in highly competitive fields
... People feeling stuck or discouraged in their search and want a new
perspective
... Anyone who wants to get training in presenting themselves with honesty
and confidence

About The Job Fairy

Leslie Ayres has been a career coach and counselor since 1980, and
attributes her success to a deep belief that life works best when you follo=
w
your passions.

As a staffing agency recruiter, and now owner of her own recruiting firm,
she has coached thousands of people at all levels in their job searches.
Resumes are her special love, because a well-written individualized resume
can be the most powerful tool to gain entrance to dream jobs, and the
process of writing a great resume is the foundation for selling yourself
into the job of your dreams.

     "I never thought that I would find writing a resume
      as simple and easy as I do now. Leslie has designed
      and developed a thorough process for getting to the
      essence of who you are and what you want people to
      know about you after reading your resume."
                           Medea Maraia, Coaching Client

Leslie=B9s approach is both human and pragmatic, and her warmth, honesty and
humor cut through the confusion that job seekers face, leaving them with
confidence and clarity. She=B9s a popular speaker on careers and job searches
at events like the World Trade Club=B9s annual Careers in International
Business Symposium, Digital Eve, and Women in Techonology. She has presente=
d
resume workshops for the EDD, and is often quoted on career issues in
magazines and newspapers.

The workshop will be held in downtown San Francisco at the Hotel Triton=B9s
incredible Creative Zone conference room. This beautiful haven is conducive
to generating new ideas and ways of looking at your career. Space is
limited, so register now to guarantee your place.

The $125 cost includes workshop materials, lunch and a half-hour follow-up
private telephone coaching session. Bring your resume, severl different ads
or posting for jobs that spark your interest (whether you're qualified for
them or not), and an open mind.

Pre-registration required; just call or email today!
