Subject: [sfraves] Quality of Life (long)

All right!!  Philosophical flamewars are the best kind!

----------------------------------------------------------------

Lady Grey (what brought on that nomenclature?) said....

>Sir Douglas of Fraser (aka "Treeboy") believes:

>> > > I should have mentioned the quality of life seemed
>> > > better - less mindless consumerism

>And Sir Laurence del Maur provoked discussion with:

>>Maybe I just want to bitch.... but how does "less mindless consumerism"
>>directly lower the quality of life?

>I would like to begin my response by pointing out that Doug used the 
>modifier "mindless" in respect to consumerism. In other words, he agrees 
>that certain creature comforts are necessary for quality of life, ie, flush 
>toilets and running water, but that gold-plated flush toilets and water taps 
>are merely an excuse to purchase and not necessary to your personal quality 
>of life. Unless of course, you are alergic to all metals except gold and you 
>break out in a nasty rash when you touch mere stainless steel.

  You are talking about essential vs non-essentials.  My definition of
mindless
  would be things bought in a unconcious fashion - i.e. when you are motivated
  by ads and marketing and fashion rather than a really personal desire that
  can be backed up with some substantial reasoning

  Example:

  I needed a new car.  I wanted a convertible.  Not because convertibles
are cool
  (in VA, where it snows???) but because I always liked them because we had
one when
  I was a kid and so there is some emotional resonance beyond that of "oh,
I can
  pick up chicks easier"

  12 yrs later, I still have the same car.  It still works, looks only a
little beat 
  up and the cost of getting a new car outweighs the presumed benefits.  As
for those
  types who buy new cars just because the current one is two years old....

  Contrast my reasoning with those yahoos buying SUVs.  Now there is a
distinction -
  if you really do use that SUV because you're an avid outdoor type, then I
have no
  problem.  But if you bought it just because you're a yuppie lemming, then
you are
  an idiot - in a larger sense, the cost of your decision has more of a
negative
  effect on society as a whole - you aren't using it for its ostensible
purpose - 
  mindlessness...   If all those yuppie were avid outdoor types, I wouldn't
complain
  as much (I'd still bitch about the gas mileage, etc)

  Also, take for instance, my parents.  The kids have been out of the house
  for awhile, my dad had to deal with a chunk of cash, and they didn't like
  the neighborhood anymore.  So moving would be a good idea (and that would
  force them to get rid of most of the accumulated debris of living in one
house
  for 25 years)  So do they buy a reasonably or smaller sized house and stuff 
  the rest of the cash away for going on long vacation trips?  NO!!!  They buy
  a house 3x as large, in a fancier neighborhood, more lawn, and because it
is 
  a bigger house, and they have less stuff to fill it with, they buy MORE
furniture
  Is my mother happier?  well, now that she has a larger house to clean,
and she
  -hates- cleaning (I'm not there anymore...) she now-wants-a-maid.
  From an investment point of view, buying the house probably made sense
(my father
  is strongly Scottish) but they are still fools in the "larger" sense.
Yes, I told
  them so.

  But their values are not mine.  Are the prevalent values in America
worthwhile ones?
  I don't think so.

>However, Doug, I have also lived in the UK for extended periods of time. I 
>believe that in the middle classes, especially in the more prosperous south 
>(ie, London area), mindless consumerism is as rampant as it is here. Witness 
>the abundance of cel phones and the redecorating mania.

  well, AFAIK (according to Derek), "yahs" (as the Scots call them) are a
growing
  percentage of the population.  and I guess I haven't stated enough times
that
  all this is my personal perception.  Perhaps if I had hung out with that
crowd
  more often, I'd have a different perception (that the UK is as bad as
America)
  But I preferred to go to 3 day warehouse parties...  And my general sense
was
  that society in general was not as bad in this regard as in America - I
didn't
  have a sense of being bombarded by excessive advertising, there wasn't a 
  "live to work" type of feeling I got...  but then again, I grew up in the
DC area.


>My view of excessive material goods being necessary for quality of life:

  First we have to define "quality of life" (like having to define mindless)
  That phrase has a different meaning - Laurence is a packrat while Kari
  is more of a philosophical bent.  I lean towards Kari's side, so that is 
  where the misunderstanding between me and Laurence comes from

>And, if you think all consumerism is mindless, think again. We all consume, 
>but we can become mindful consumers. Buy recycled content paper, reused 
>clothing and reusable containers. Buy what you need: food, shelter, some 
>clothing.

  well, now you are talking about responsible consumerism

-----------

Laurence blurts out:

>Yes, but no one has disproved my assertion yet! The original statement was:

>> > > > I should have mentioned the quality of life seemed
>> > > > better - less mindless consumerism

>Which means, logically that:
>[more] mindless consumerism = [worse] quality of life.

>Which makes no sense!

  It does too, when you are using the assumptions I am making  (define
terms!!!)

>So, I said:

>> >Maybe I just want to bitch.... but how does "less mindless consumerism"
>> >directly lower the quality of life?

>And someone has yet to prove that more mindless consumerism actually LOWERS
>the quality of life. Sure, you dont NEED consumerism to have a high quality
>of life, but having more certainly wont lower it! If I have XXX amount of
>stuff, and then suddenly I decide to go on a shopping spree and now have
>XXXXXX amount of stuff. How am I worse off? If anything I'm better off!
>Certainly, in my perspective my quality of life is improved both by the
>ability to buy more things and having more things.

  For you, quality of life = having more stuff to play with.  That is not how
  I would define it.  One has to take care of all that stuff.  I would rather
  go to Europe....

>Thus, what is implied by the statement "I should have mentioned the quality
>of life seemed better - less mindless consumerism" is *bullshit*.

  I seem to have struck a nerve here....

---------------

Now Howling Bob chimes in....

>>Yes, but no one has disproved my assertion yet! The original statement was:
>>
>> > > > > I should have mentioned the quality of life seemed
>> > > > > better - less mindless consumerism
>>
>>Which means, logically that:
>>[more] mindless consumerism = [worse] quality of life.
>>
>>Which makes no sense!

>to the contrary.  "mindless consumerism," to me, implies both an absolute 
>glut of products of indifferent quality (ergo, "mindless": "mindful" 
>consumption would at a minimum entail awareness of relative quality) and the 
>equally "mindless" pursuit of "more," regardless of the actual return one 
>received from one's consumption.  if you consume tons of crap, you're still 
>consuming crap, and IMO the majority of consumer goods on offer nowadays are 
>precisely that.

  Great Bob, another definition of mindless.  But you are coming from the
cost/
  benefit (quality) angle and i was coming from the psychological motivations 
  position.  Instead of "mindless" for your concept, I would say
"worthwhile/worthless"

>>Thus, if the energy expenditure, expense, and stress entailed in "mindless 
>>consumerism" is not recompensed by the positive value received from the 
>>items consumed, then the idea that "[more] mindless consumerism = [worse] 
>>quality of life" is indeed logical, and IMO has been proved repeatedly,
both 
>>in my own experience and my observation of others.

  Restating - quality of life is correlated with the worth of what you
consume.
  If all you buy/eat/etc is crap, your QOL will be lower than what's possible.
  But crap is a term defined by an individual.  My grandfather loves going to
  Eat n' Park (think cheap version of Denny's).  He doesn't care about fine
wine
  or smoked salmon.  This is why my dad refuses to go to Pittsburgh anymore
  because he cares about smoked salmon and hates Eat n' Park.  I on the other
  hand have the attitude of it's just food, so who cares, as long as it's
reasonably
  edible.

-------

Laurence retorts:


>Personally I find the act of consumerism itself to be rewarding. There is no
>cost / exenditure other than monetary related to the act, because to me, the
>act itself is a leisurely activity. Also, because it is leisure I dont think
>there is a stress component at all, or if there is it is small enough that
>it is innately offset. That is to say that spending time in a mall, oggling
>all sorts of shit and using my credit card are innately rewarding in the
>same way someone else might find, say, walking in the park rewarding. I
>consider it a leisurely activity. And, therefore, if in addition the
>products I have mindlessly or mindfully purchased add a value to my life,
>that further increases my quality of life. 1) Because the act was rewarding
>and 2) the addition to the quantity of items I have has increased. =)

>That is just me personally of course, I'm not speaking for anyone else. =)

  well, I think your position is *bullshit*, but it's your life, so I have
no say

now bob:

>for myself, unless i'm shopping for something i really want/need/am into 
>(new CDs, outdoor wear, bike parts, more CDs...) i find the need to get off 
>my arse, onto MUNI, and out to the shops to be onerous.  Perhaps i'm too old 
>and tired for recreational shopping ;o)

>and there's also the additional stress factors outside of the act of 
>consumption itself: e.g., how many more hours does one have to 
>work/commute/do things you'd rather not do in order to pay for the objects 
>of consumption?  and what (time with dear ones, rest time, hot sex, 
>contemplation, sleep, and of course dancing!) is one giving up in order to 
>perform that labor?

Laurence:

--Ahhh... yes... recreational shopper is probably the best term for what I
--describe. I like that. It should be a title. =)

  aaahhhhh...  considering that your e-mail alter ego is the infamous
Jennifer 
  Love Hewitt, I am not surprised.  You are truly in touch with your
feminine side
  I on the other hand only buy what I need or really want and hate to spend
  any more time than necessary

> and there's also the additional stress factors outside of the act of
> consumption itself: e.g., how many more hours does one have to
> work/commute/do things you'd rather not do in order to pay for the objects
> of consumption?

--Ah ha! But see, for me, recreational shopping is a reward and the benefit
--from having to work so hard to earn all that money. After working so hard
--and once I've accumulated this disposable income, what better way to spend
--it, relieve stress and inrease my quality of life but mill around at the
--mall and spend that money =) That is one of many points where my work
--translates into benefit. You see, I'm going to have to do all that hard work
--anyway, and if I didnt have this outlet with which to reap the benefits of
--this work (through consumerism), I would be more dissatisfied with having to
--do that work.

  again, it's a matter of personal priorities - I would rather work less, earn
  less money, and have experiences rather than a lot of stuff.  In the long
run,
  stuff is useless

> tangentially, this is why the whole cost/benefit analysis approach to
> political issues gives me the Orwellian willies...the result is utterly
> dependent on what one considers as "benefits" and/or acknowledges as
> "costs."

--Defaintely! And to add to that, one person's benefit could be valueless to
--another individual if not a minus entirely.

  So why in the world did we have this argument?

had to have the last word since I started it,
Doug

Furthermore, we've already been sold out for the last two months. We don't =
want anyone to be upset when they arrive after travelling a great distance =
to find they can't get in. So, come down early, have a drink or grab a bite=
 to eat at the reastaurant upsatirs, and guarantee that you get to see one =
of the most incredible sets ever at one of the greatest club nights ever.
=20
ASCENSION - Every other Thursday @ Blakes
2367 Telegraph Ave - Berkeley
ID Required
$5 for 21+
$7 for 18-20
510.848.0886 for directions

=3D=3D
Later {8O)
Pe@ce-->Just Me-->O=A7BY

People who say idiotic things like, "I'm against organized religion. I'm a
Wiccan." Here's a hint... You said Wiccan and I knew precisely what you
meant. My definition of religion: "Belief that things that are not real are
as important or more important than the real concrete world in which we
live." Don't try to throw some pretentious dogshit at me about "How do you
know what's real" or I'll slap you in the head. "Feel that? Well that's the
REAL world." Believe in something supernatural? Does at least one other
person share the same belief? Do people who share this belief have a
collective name? THEN YOU'RE IN AN ORGANIZED RELIGION, DUMBASS! Stop trying
to be trendy.

Subject: [sfraves] srr - Cops bust up "RAP" Party

------=_NextPart_000_0007_01C12AF0.40A8B380
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

So at least the rave scene isn't receiving ALL the bad press on =
parties-gone-bad.  This bust sounds worse than most that I've read =
about...   anyone else have details???

>From Mattier and Ross, SF Chronicle
http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=3D/c/a/2001/08/22/MN27075.DTL=


SATURDAY NIGHT FEVER: These may be the dog days of August, but when it =
comes to parties -- they nearly blew the roof off the town the other =
night.=20

By the time it was over, more than 100 cops, many in riot gear, =
descended Saturday night on busy Van Ness Avenue and Sutter Street to =
break up a rap party attended by some 1,500 rambunctious teenagers.=20

According to police Lt. Larry Barsetti, it all started earlier in the =
week when somebody called the old Regency theater -- which was turned =
into a private dance hall a couple of years back -- to book the place on =
short notice.=20

"He said it was for a national fraternity party, and that there would be =
about 600 people," Regency co-owner Craig Lipton tells us.=20

And when the organizer showed up the next day with a $7,500 cash down =
payment, the Regency didn't ask many questions.=20

But come Saturday night it quickly became apparent that the Regency got =
more than it bargained for -- as teenagers from all over the Bay Area =
started rolling up, while the promoters stood outside selling tickets to =
anyone walking by.=20

Added fun: The event was also being promoted on KMEL radio as an "after- =
hours dance party."=20

The night manager approached the promoter and told him to stop letting =
people in, as the place was quickly exceeding capacity.=20

The promoter refused, and when the manager threatened to call police, =
things apparently turned ugly.=20

"The promoter told her, 'If you call the police, we are going to trash =
the building,' and he threatened her," Lipton says.=20

At which point, the shaken manager locked herself in her office and =
frantically began phoning both her boss and the police.=20

Before you can say busta rap, scores of squad cars, riot cops and =
sheriff's deputies descended on the scene, shutting down the party and =
driving hundreds of kids into the streets -- just as movie theatergoers =
from across the street were getting out.=20

But instead of a riot, the police-rapper confrontation turned into a =
giant street party that blocked traffic on Van Ness and the nearby =
neighborhood for the better part of an hour as youngsters danced in the =
street.=20

Final score: one street fight, three drunken youngsters detained and =
more than two dozen teenagers trying to storm a doughnut shop near Van =
Ness and Geary.=20

By time all the kids had returned to their cars and hit the freeways, it =
was close to 2 a.m. And police were both exhausted and angry.=20

"No doubt about it," says Barsetti, "it cost the city a few bucks."=20

But at least they didn't get the doughnut shop.=20


------=_NextPart_000_0007_01C12AF0.40A8B380--

outbursts and namecalling"

seriously, laurence, it starts by saying you are talking about "organized
religion" and then building an argument with "My definition of religion"
(that's like telling a "dumb blonde" joke and starting  with "my definition
of blonde is..." -- it rather misses the point) .... 

and then it rambles on to apparently thinking you can disprove the
supernatural by whacking someone in the head (right, that's how to disprove
non-physical realities, using physical evidence, um, yeah)...

and then you end up with screaming and namecalling.  and the "trendy"
comment is amusing. those damned trendy pagans, always trying to keep up
with the hippest new things, century after century after century.

one argument against recreational shopping from the other thread-- giving it
up could leave time for deeper intellectual pursuits. like studying what
other deep thinkers over the centuries have seen, believed, understood,
wondered about. believe me, developing your mind is far more rewarding than
buying more crap. 

there is always more than meets the eye -- because our eyes limit us in
really seeing what is there. until you figure that out... you will remain
blind.

leslie



----------

Laurence Maar

People who say idiotic things like, "I'm against organized religion. I'm a
Wiccan." Here's a hint... You said Wiccan and I knew precisely what you
meant. My definition of religion: "Belief that things that are not real are
as important or more important than the real concrete world in which we
live." Don't try to throw some pretentious dogshit at me about "How do you
know what's real" or I'll slap you in the head. "Feel that? Well that's the
REAL world." Believe in something supernatural? Does at least one other
person share the same belief? Do people who share this belief have a
collective name? THEN YOU'RE IN AN ORGANIZED RELIGION, DUMBASS! Stop trying
to be trendy.

- http://negativepositive.gyrate.org/Things-that-need-to-die.html

Subject: [sfraves] Favorite artists by genre w/MP3s

Hey hey...
Just ordered my new stereo for my van, a very nice Clarion CD player, and it 
plays MP3s! So now I'm going all over the place looking for MP3 mixes. I 
want to know who your favorite artists are in the following genres, so I can 
hunt down some more good MP3s. If they already have a website and you know 
they've got MP3 mixes, that's best, but if they don't, I'll look around 
'till I find some. But yeah, who do you think spins the coolest:

Progressive trance
Psychedelic trance
Trancey/melodic breaks
Electro/Nu Skool breaks
Tribal house
Tech house
Deep house (no vocal!)
Funky/disco house
DnB/jungle
2-step
Tech-step
all those weird steps I don't know :P
Ambient

Thanks in advance!
-=Chris=-

Subject: [sfraves] srr - Cops bust up "RAP" Party

--0-626153587-998508365=:86988
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Disposition: inline


Hm... encouraging news there.  Maybe the tide is turning and the short
attention span of the cops is swinging back towards their earlier targets.

Who knows, maybe death metal will make a comeback and be the next favorite
"evil influence on the children".

You know, as discouraging as it is, to be the current target of the police, it
does help, to look back and realise that the rave scene is only the latest
target of hatred and fear of the previous generations.  And oh so many
scapegoats they had...

Just before electronica (does ANYBODY have a better word yet?) became their
target for hatred, Marilyn Manson was turning the kids into satanists.

Before that, rap was turning them into cop killers.

Before that, grunge was turning them into... uh... smelly people who wear lots
of flannel?

In the late '80s, Death Metal was, once again, going to turn the kids into
satanists.

In the mid '80s, Madonna was going to turn America's teenage girls into slutty
whores, much to the dismay of the right wing zealots.  But makers of '80s teen
movies were thrilled.

Early '80s...  I forget what punk rock was accused of doing "to the children". 
But I do remember that Jello Biafra was actually prosecuted by congress for
part of it.  I guess punk rock just challanges blind obedience to authority too
much for the xtian right.

Back into the music of our parents generation....

Disco was... well... it was disco... ugh... 'nuff said.

My mom told me once, that HER ancestors were convinced that KISS stood for
"Knights In Satan's Service".

Ozzy and Alice Cooper... oops, there's satanism AGAIN!?!?!?  Sheesh.  I guess
closed-minded people who hate the young really DON'T have much of an
imagination.

Jim Morrison... arrested in Florida for some "moral perversion" or another.

Oh... and the Beatles.  All that talk about "giving peace a chance", and,
"imagine there's no country; nothing to kill or die for; and no religion
too..."  Obviously the fab four were determined to turn our youth into a hoarde
of godless commies.

Putting the current situation in perspecive does yield just a little optimism. 
Most every youth culture to emerge in the last several decades has been the
object of hatred and persecution at the hands of the obsolete.

But in every case, the cops eventually find some other target to beat up upon. 
Not that that means for a second, that, in an ideal world, they shouldn't be
retaliated against for every abuse of their power.  But maybe they are shifting
their attention off us for awhile.

Maybe Shug Knight getting out of prison WAS a good thing after all.


peace,
john


brady@thebal.com wrote:

>So at least the rave scene isn't receiving ALL the bad press on =
>parties-gone-bad.  This bust sounds worse than most that I've read =
>about...   anyone else have details???

>>From Mattier and Ross, SF Chronicle

Claudia Pfister, a spokeswoman for a Berlin animal rights group, said that

Subject: Re: [sfraves] srr - Cops bust up "RAP" Party

i can't agree with this line of thinking.

first, it sounds like the police weren't involved in this at all until the
venue manager asked them to be -- because it sounds like the promoters were
less than honest with their intentions, and certainly not very professional
in their dealings (of course, there may be more to the story)

second, just because the bullets are being aimed in another direction at any
given moment, doesn't mean that the war is over.

in fact, something like this could make it even more difficult to do events.
once again, while we may perceive hiphop as "not us" -- you cannot assume
that the rest of the world does... to many, it's just another example of
"young people who don't respect property and can't behave"

leslie

>
>Hm... encouraging news there.  Maybe the tide is turning and the short
>attention span of the cops is swinging back towards their earlier targets.
>
>Who knows, maybe death metal will make a comeback and be the next favorite
>"evil influence on the children".
>
>You know, as discouraging as it is, to be the current target of the police, it
>does help, to look back and realise that the rave scene is only the latest
>target of hatred and fear of the previous generations.  And oh so many
>scapegoats they had...
>
>Just before electronica (does ANYBODY have a better word yet?) became their
>target for hatred, Marilyn Manson was turning the kids into satanists.
>
>Before that, rap was turning them into cop killers.
>
>Before that, grunge was turning them into... uh... smelly people who wear lots
>of flannel?
>
>In the late '80s, Death Metal was, once again, going to turn the kids into
>satanists.
>
>In the mid '80s, Madonna was going to turn America's teenage girls into slutty
>whores, much to the dismay of the right wing zealots.  But makers of '80s teen
>movies were thrilled.
>
>Early '80s...  I forget what punk rock was accused of doing "to the children". 
>But I do remember that Jello Biafra was actually prosecuted by congress for
>part of it.  I guess punk rock just challanges blind obedience to authority too
>much for the xtian right.
>
>Back into the music of our parents generation....
>
>Disco was... well... it was disco... ugh... 'nuff said.
>
>My mom told me once, that HER ancestors were convinced that KISS stood for
>"Knights In Satan's Service".
>
>Ozzy and Alice Cooper... oops, there's satanism AGAIN!?!?!?  Sheesh.  I guess
>closed-minded people who hate the young really DON'T have much of an
>imagination.
>
>Jim Morrison... arrested in Florida for some "moral perversion" or another.
>
>Oh... and the Beatles.  All that talk about "giving peace a chance", and,
>"imagine there's no country; nothing to kill or die for; and no religion
>too..."  Obviously the fab four were determined to turn our youth into a hoarde
>of godless commies.
>
>Putting the current situation in perspecive does yield just a little optimism. 
>Most every youth culture to emerge in the last several decades has been the
>object of hatred and persecution at the hands of the obsolete.
>
>But in every case, the cops eventually find some other target to beat up upon. 
>Not that that means for a second, that, in an ideal world, they shouldn't be
>retaliated against for every abuse of their power.  But maybe they are shifting
>their attention off us for awhile.
>
>Maybe Shug Knight getting out of prison WAS a good thing after all.
>
>
>peace,
>john

> Who knows, maybe death metal will make a comeback and be the next favorite
> "evil influence on the children".
> 
> You know, as discouraging as it is, to be the current target of the police, 
> it
> does help, to look back and realise that the rave scene is only the latest
> target of hatred and fear of the previous generations.  And oh so many
> scapegoats they had...
> 
> Just before electronica (does ANYBODY have a better word yet?) became their
> target for hatred, Marilyn Manson was turning the kids into satanists.
> 
> Before that, rap was turning them into cop killers.
> 
> Before that, grunge was turning them into... uh... smelly people who wear 
> lots
> of flannel?
> 
> In the late '80s, Death Metal was, once again, going to turn the kids into
> satanists.
> 
> In the mid '80s, Madonna was going to turn America's teenage girls into 
> slutty
> whores, much to the dismay of the right wing zealots.  But makers of '80s 
> teen
> movies were thrilled.
> 
> Early '80s...  I forget what punk rock was accused of doing "to the 
> children". 
> But I do remember that Jello Biafra was actually prosecuted by congress for
> part of it.  I guess punk rock just challanges blind obedience to authority 
> too
> much for the xtian right.
> 
> Back into the music of our parents generation....
> 
> Disco was... well... it was disco... ugh... 'nuff said.
> 
> My mom told me once, that HER ancestors were convinced that KISS stood for
> "Knights In Satan's Service".
> 
> Ozzy and Alice Cooper... oops, there's satanism AGAIN!?!?!?  Sheesh.  I 
> guess
> closed-minded people who hate the young really DON'T have much of an
> imagination.
> 
> Jim Morrison... arrested in Florida for some "moral perversion" or another.
> 
> Oh... and the Beatles.  All that talk about "giving peace a chance", and,
> "imagine there's no country; nothing to kill or die for; and no religion
> too..."  Obviously the fab four were determined to turn our youth into a 
> hoarde
> of godless commies.
> 
> Putting the current situation in perspecive does yield just a little 
> optimism. 
> Most every youth culture to emerge in the last several decades has been the
> object of hatred and persecution at the hands of the obsolete.
> 
> But in every case, the cops eventually find some other target to beat up 
> upon. 
> Not that that means for a second, that, in an ideal world, they shouldn't be
> retaliated against for every abuse of their power.  But maybe they are 
> shifting
> their attention off us for awhile.
> 
> Maybe Shug Knight getting out of prison WAS a good thing after all.
> 
> 
> peace,
> john
> 

i think it all comes down to the moral majority being more stupid and
inbred then the enlightened subcultures...and not knowing how to handle
it.

they are wolves in sheeps clothing...

-niiiick

--part1_11b.35dd08c.28b56b38_boundary--

i got this same response responding when your earlier sig file was enclosed.

and sorry to repeat myself, but funny as it is to you... to me, the new sig
is about as obnoxious as the last one. laurence. do you think you could come
up with something that doesn't rely on a a sense of misplaced
superiority--born from what appears to be ignorance--as its foundation?

unless, in fact, you passionately agree (rather than "loosely agree") with
this one and have really evaluated its appropriateness to your belief system
(rather than "never evaluated" as with the last one) -- and you actually
have support for the assertion that claudia pfister is in fact a "crazy
bitch" -- 

if this signature truly reflects who you are, and what you believe, and
encapsulates your thoughts on the dangers vs. the advantages of censoring
conceptual art, then you should absolutely use it.

but if it, like the other, is simply something that you think is
"heh-heh-they-said-shave-their-balls" bevis & butthead humor, then maybe
something else would be worth defending.

sorry to keep this conversation going, but pursuing clarity in thinking and
communication is always worth the extra effort.

leslie

Subject: Re: [sfraves] srr - Cops bust up "RAP" Party

The Rap Party had no permits.   The police had no prior knowledge of this event.
That venue is now going through a similar process with SFPD, as I went through with
the Bill Graham Civic in order to bring it back from the graveyard of lost venues.

It's actually quite amusing that MB6 will be the FIRST EVER FULLY LEGAL Dance event
EVER to be held at the Civic Auditorium... in it's 40 year history!!!.   Yes, all
previous events held at this venue have been ILLEGAL because no police permits were
ever applied for or issued for ANY OF THEM.

However, the point is, that we now have a chance to SHINE... like never before, and
prove to PD that everything I sold them on (peaceful crowd, respectful audience,
there for the music, Non-violent... etc.) is really the case.     It's ours to keep,
or screw-up.    Lets show then all what we're really about and dispel all the
rumors, and set our own precedent, so we don't have to live in the shadow of media
sensationalism.     It's only a revolution if you're a part of the solution!!!

Keep it alive, Vlad

-----Original Message-----
From: John B. [mailto:svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com]
Sent: 22 August 2001 12:26
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Cc: brady@thebal.com
Subject: [sfraves] srr - Cops bust up "RAP" Party
Importance: Low



Hm... encouraging news there.  Maybe the tide is turning and the short
attention span of the cops is swinging back towards their earlier targets.

Who knows, maybe death metal will make a comeback and be the next favorite
"evil influence on the children".

You know, as discouraging as it is, to be the current target of the police,
it
does help, to look back and realise that the rave scene is only the latest
target of hatred and fear of the previous generations.  And oh so many
scapegoats they had...

Just before electronica (does ANYBODY have a better word yet?) became their
target for hatred, Marilyn Manson was turning the kids into satanists.

Before that, rap was turning them into cop killers.

Before that, grunge was turning them into... uh... smelly people who wear
lots
of flannel?

In the late '80s, Death Metal was, once again, going to turn the kids into
satanists.

In the mid '80s, Madonna was going to turn America's teenage girls into
slutty
whores, much to the dismay of the right wing zealots.  But makers of '80s
teen
movies were thrilled.

Early '80s...  I forget what punk rock was accused of doing "to the
children".
But I do remember that Jello Biafra was actually prosecuted by congress for
part of it.  I guess punk rock just challanges blind obedience to authority
too
much for the xtian right.

Back into the music of our parents generation....

Disco was... well... it was disco... ugh... 'nuff said.

My mom told me once, that HER ancestors were convinced that KISS stood for
"Knights In Satan's Service".

Ozzy and Alice Cooper... oops, there's satanism AGAIN!?!?!?  Sheesh.  I
guess
closed-minded people who hate the young really DON'T have much of an
imagination.

Jim Morrison... arrested in Florida for some "moral perversion" or another.

Oh... and the Beatles.  All that talk about "giving peace a chance", and,
"imagine there's no country; nothing to kill or die for; and no religion
too..."  Obviously the fab four were determined to turn our youth into a
hoarde
of godless commies.

Putting the current situation in perspecive does yield just a little
optimism.
Most every youth culture to emerge in the last several decades has been the
object of hatred and persecution at the hands of the obsolete.

But in every case, the cops eventually find some other target to beat up
upon.
Not that that means for a second, that, in an ideal world, they shouldn't be
retaliated against for every abuse of their power.  But maybe they are
shifting
their attention off us for awhile.

Maybe Shug Knight getting out of prison WAS a good thing after all.


peace,
john


brady@thebal.com wrote:

>So at least the rave scene isn't receiving ALL the bad press on =
>parties-gone-bad.  This bust sounds worse than most that I've read =
>about...   anyone else have details???

>>From Mattier and Ross, SF Chronicle
>http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=3D/c/a/2001/08/22/MN27075.
>DTL=

>SATURDAY NIGHT FEVER: These may be the dog days of August, but
>when it = comes to parties -- they nearly blew the roof off the town the
>other night.

Claudia Pfister, a spokeswoman for a Berlin animal rights group, said that
she feared the event would lead to copycat art, such as, get ready for this:
"people throwing their pet dogs out of windows."

Now this crazy bitch is just trying to get offended. She thinks that people
will see a pile of beef fall from a helicopter, and she's worried they're
going to drop their dog out of a window? For that to happen people not only
have to watch Austrian performance art, but they'd have to think their
window was a helicopter, and then forget that dogs are not cows. You might
as well worry that they're going to shave their balls and learn to fly.

Very well said Vlad, most people don't care about the solution. I would 
say 75% of this scene has no idea what we are talking about or fighting 
for. One of the problems I see is people from other genre's coming to 
raves because they have nothing better to do. Most of the time it's 
those people that cause problems and do all kinds of stupid shit, but in 
some cases ravers do it to. I know for a fact there is a good number of 
ravers out there that believe doing E is something cool and everyone 
should be on E at a rave. I think there needs to be more education and 
more literature published to the general public and to ravers. Until the 
general public gets the horrible stereotypes the government and 
authorities feed to them we have no one on our side other than 
ourselves. So we need to prove to the world we are what we claim to be, 
peaceful loving understanding and respectful. Just my thoughts

Nick

Feel Good wrote:

>The Rap Party had no permits.   The police had no prior knowledge of this event.
>That venue is now going through a similar process with SFPD, as I went through with
>the Bill Graham Civic in order to bring it back from the graveyard of lost venues.
>
>It's actually quite amusing that MB6 will be the FIRST EVER FULLY LEGAL Dance event
>EVER to be held at the Civic Auditorium... in it's 40 year history!!!.   Yes, all
>previous events held at this venue have been ILLEGAL because no police permits were
>ever applied for or issued for ANY OF THEM.
>
>However, the point is, that we now have a chance to SHINE... like never before, and
>prove to PD that everything I sold them on (peaceful crowd, respectful audience,
>there for the music, Non-violent... etc.) is really the case.     It's ours to keep,
>or screw-up.    Lets show then all what we're really about and dispel all the
>rumors, and set our own precedent, so we don't have to live in the shadow of media
>sensationalism.     It's only a revolution if you're a part of the solution!!!
>
>Keep it alive, Vlad
>

Interesting!

See, I laughed at loud at this sig, and I definietely agree with 
it.  Perhaps I should read the entire source article, but I do already know 
of the event they speak of.  Why exactly would people start throwing pets 
out windows?  Because an Austrian artist dropped a cow from a 
helicopter?  That seems quite ridiculous to me!   I saw a picture online of 
a PC box that was dropped from a great height.. most likely it fell out of 
a cargo plane.  I'm sure there were witnesses.. but I doubt they'll go home 
and toss their pc's out the window.  Furthermore, if you were to watch what 
happened to the dropped cow, you'd prolly never want to see something as 
violent happen to your beloved pet.. While person(s) may feel emotionally 
attached to particular cow(s), the cows do not share the sentiment.  It 
could easily be argued that Dogs are capable of much more than cows.. I'm 
sure Claudia feels for the cow, and doesn't want it to happen, but I don't 
think that copy cat art projects are likely.

sarilion

did....

of the time for everything, and you might see his side
of

woman he can....there is a big difference between
MACHISMO 
and a consensual role playing game where dominance and
submission are played out for the benefit and pleasure
of 
both parties involved...MACHISMO is dead...run away
from that guy...
okay then there are the YOUNG GUYS: you might be
significantly older than them, or just plain
developmentally 
more mature than them...they don't know the
difference..
if you are turned off, don't feel bad..if they get
pissed, don't fix it..you are not their mom. PEACE
OUT!!!! :)

just a bunch of hyper active knucklehead b-boy's geeking
off to this new form of break based music called jungle.

us and this music keeps pumpin' on. on saturday, august 25,
916junglist celebrates over two years of broken beat madness!

BILLY LANE \ REASON \ DJM \ FOODERS & MADPLANET
EPIK \ PSOL \ RIFF RAFF

this saturday, august 25th.2001
916junglist is back!

Subject: [sfraves] Suit challenges ban on 'rave' gear

--=====================_32328914==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Suit challenges ban on 'rave' gear
Associated Press
Aug. 22, 2001 08:59:00
NEW ORLEANS - The American Civil Liberties Union filed suit Tuesday 
challenging a ban on items at "rave" dance parties that prosecutors say are 
used to enhance the effects of the popular club drug Ecstasy.
Organizers of a rave in New Orleans had agreed to the ban on glow sticks, 
pacifiers, masks and vapor rubs under a plea bargain with federal prosecutors.
"It's a form of behavior control because they feel these people might do 
something illegal if they posses these items," said Joe Cook, director of 
Louisiana's ACLU chapter. "Maybe next they'll ban dancing since people 
often dance while on drugs. That's the absurdity we're dealing with."
Acting U.S. Attorney Jim Letten said he had yet to review the lawsuit. But 
he said a third party intervening in a criminal plea agreement is highly 
unusual.
"We were cognizant of the legitimate Constitutional rights of individuals 
but also had to consider the welfare, health and safety of the citizens and 
had to strike a balance of various factors in reaching that decision," 
Letten said.
Investigators have linked the raves held since 1995 at the State Palace 
Theater to numerous drug overdoses and the 1998 death of a 17-year-old girl.
The ACLU's complaint was filed Tuesday on behalf of the electronic band 
Rabbit in the Moon - which is scheduled to perform here Friday and whose 
stage costumes incorporate glowing necklaces - and several people who had 
items confiscated at a rave on Aug. 4.
The lawsuit asks for a ruling before Friday's rave.

http://www.azcentral.com/offbeat/articles/0822Rave-ON.html

ACLU Lawsuit Fights Government's Extremist Tactics In
Culture War Against Raves
FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE    :    Tuesday, August 21,
2001 
NEW ORLEANS-- Saying the government's war on drugs has reached
bizarre new extremes, the American Civil Liberties Union today asked a
federal court to prohibit the government from banning the use of glow
sticks, pacifiers and masks at a rave here this weekend.
According to the ACLU complaint, the Drug Enforcement Agency (DEA)
has banned symbols of rave culture such as masks, glow items, pacifiers, and
vapor rub from a prominent dance venue, saying that these items constitute
"drug paraphernalia."
"It is nonsensical to think that glow sticks and masks can be used
to ingest drugs, which is how the law defines paraphernalia," said Graham
Boyd, director of the ACLU's Drug Policy Litigation Project. "It is time the
American public realized that raves are not at all the havens for rampant
drug use that the government has led them to believe and are in fact part of
an established form of youth culture."
Those named in the ACLU's class action lawsuit include a former
military man and an insurance agent whose masks and glow sticks were
confiscated at an August 4 rave, and an internationally renowned performance
group that faces cancellation of an act incorporating glow sticks.
Raves are electronic music concerts that the government seeks to
close because some attendees use the drug Ecstasy. But that approach, Boyd
said, is tantamount to shutting down rock concerts in the 1960s or jazz
clubs in the 1920s because some people are using drugs.
"The government's ban on cultural symbols does nothing to prevent
drug use, while striking at the heart of First Amendment freedoms," said
Boyd. "If the police want to enforce drug laws, then they should go after
drug dealers, but dancing and music are protected by the Constitution."
Earlier this year, the DEA attacked raves by suing the music
promoter and concert hall manager of the State Palace Theater here, a
popular dance and concert venue that frequently hosts raves. The case marked
the first time that the government had used a federal "crack house" law to
prosecute organizers of raves.
Although the DEA's all-out assault on the State Palace Theater fell
short of its goal of conviction, the agency is still pursuing its war
against rave culture. In a plea deal put forth by the DEA, the government
has forbidden all wearing of masks, glow items and pacifiers, and has banned
the use of vapor rub at electronic dance events held at the theater. As a
result, theater staff have been forced to censor the actions and art of its
guests and artists.
Today's lawsuit comes as a result of that plea bargain, which, the
ACLU complaint said, "embodies the government's unconstitutional assault
against the electronic music culture."
In addition to protecting the First Amendment rights of music lovers
and performance artists, the ACLU is also challenging the plea bargain's
violation of theater attendees' right to due process and against
unreasonable searches and seizures.
As described in the ACLU complaint, two guests of the State Palace
Theater were subject to censorship during an event held on August 4. Michael
Behan, an insurance agent who usually attends raves in his "Mr. Bunny"
costume, did not bring masks or glow sticks to that event because of the ban
and was prevented from entering with a hand-held massager. Clayton Smith, a
former member of the United States Air Force's prestigious Sabre Drill Team,
had his glow sticks and pacifier confiscated at the August 4 event.
"As a member of the Sabre Drill Team, I incorporated dance and
acrobatic movement into my routine that I would first try out on dance
floors with glow sticks," said Smith. "Although I am no longer a member of
the team I still like to go to raves and try new moves. I feel it is my
right to be able to do so."
In addition, Steven McClure, the founding member of Rabbit in the
Moon, an internationally renowned group that has performed numerous times at
the State Palace Theater, has been warned by theater staff that his group
can no longer perform in their usual costume, which incorporates glow
necklaces. The group faces the cancellation of their March 2002 performance
at the theater if they violate the censorship order.
"The DEA, acting on behalf of Ashcroft as 'Big Brother,' has
embarked on a culture crusade to ban innocent behavior at music concerts
while the drug dealers take a walk," said Joe Cook, Executive Director of
the ACLU of Louisiana. "With these perverted priorities, the next target
could be a raid on the local Walgreens to shut it down for selling masks and
glow sticks." 
According to Will Patterson of the Electronic Music Defense and
Education Fund, a group established to provide legal assistance industry
professionals targeted by government censorship of raves, the plea agreement
entered in New Orleans has led many venues across the country to ban the
sale of glowsticks and other items labeled as paraphernalia.
"In effect," he said, "the government has curtailed the growth of an
increasingly popular form of entertainment and has also hampered the
companies who manufacture and sell these items at raves."
The ACLU's complaint in today's lawsuit is online at
http://www.aclu.org/court/behan.pdf <http://www.aclu.org/court/behan.pdf>
An ACLU news release and legal documents concerning the use of the
federal "crackhouse law" against the State Palace Theater is online at
http://www.aclu.org/news/2001/n030701b.html.
<http://www.aclu.org/news/2001/n030701b.html>
EMDEF is online at http://emdef.org/ <http://emdef.org/> .
#    # 
# 
For more information please contact Susan Mainzer at Green
Galactic/EMDEF, 323-466-5141, or susan@greengalactic.com
<mailto:susan@greengalactic.com> .
#    #    # 
Electronic Music Defense and Education Fund
August 21st, EM:DEF 2001 Newsletter

The biggest problem I have with Netscape is that it is so huge, all I want
to put on my machine is their browser.  Unfortunately I can't, I must
install their huge ass package of stuff I will never use.  The integration
of AOL in to Netscape has removed any of the lagging respectability they had
before.  The new browser seems to be a bit quicker then the beta previews,
but in reality almost everyone is making their pages for IE because
Frontpage and IIS are made by Microsoft and dominate the market right now.

If Netscape were to concentrate all of their efforts on their browser and
not a suite they might have a chance.  For email I prefer Outlook 2002, not
because it is a Microsoft product but because it is by far one of the best
all around information manager / email programs on the market.  Netscape
just cannot compare and once you get used to it, it is awesome because all
of the AV software integrates in to it usually and while there are some
quirks, it's not totally as bad as its rep makes people think.

 -----Original Message-----
From: 	John B. [mailto:svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com]
Sent:	Tuesday, August 21, 2001 12:32 PM
To:	twinphishy@yahoo.com
Cc:	sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject:	[sfraves] NRR: Anyone know of any cgi scripts that can block
certain IP's

 << File: [sfraves] NRR_ Anyone know of any cgi scripts that can block
certain IP's.txt >>
I wouldn't waste time writeing a cgi script to do this.  And unless your
entire
site is CGI generated, it will be a rathar icky mess to get it all to work
right.

The much easier and faster way is to just drop the IP block you want to
disallow in /etc/hosts.deny

It won't stop a determined attacker (the tend to have access to alternate
IPs),
but it'll stop the casual schmuck.


cya,
john

Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 14062 invoked by uid 1104); 23 Aug 2001 04:38:07 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 14052 invoked from network); 23 Aug 2001 04:38:07 -0000
X-Originating-IP: [207.214.212.131]
From: "RaVin RiZ" <ravin_riz@hotmail.com>
To: fraser_douglas@yahoo.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org
Bcc: 
Date: Thu, 23 Aug 2001 04:37:33 +0000
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <F248bLAX3cf3ednHM3S0000d537@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 23 Aug 2001 04:37:34.0304 (UTC) FILETIME=[54045E00:01C12B8D]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: IE OR NETSCAPRE 6.0

Having done some beta testing with Windows XP Professional, if you hate IE, 
you'll hate it even more if you upgrade to XP. If you like IE, you'll fall 
in love with the new features and interface. It's XML from head to foot and 
the new .NET strategy is in full swing. So, if you're a Hotmail user and you 
sign in to Passport to check your email, you stay signed in if you just 
close the browser. You have to go through the log out process to actually 
log out. The look and feel of IE for XP is pretty nice; it's very eye 
pleasing. Of course, you need 900 megs of HD space to install just the base 
OS, not including all the other bells and whistles. What else? 
Stability...XP is very stable. I'm running Release Candidate 1 and it has 
yet to crash on me. No compatibility issues thus far either.  Oh and for all 
you Mac heads with your text to speech technology...Microsoft has added not 
only text to speech but buil in voice recognition as well. I tried this out 
with Office XP and it works pretty well in both dictation and voice command 
mode. Built-in CDR software. Smart tags...but they won't be in the final 
code. So, all in all, if you're currently running Windows 95, 98, or ME, the 
upgrade may be worth it just for the stability features as XP uses the same 
NT file system used by 2000. If you're running 2000, you really don't need 
to upgrade unless you're the type that likes to have the latest and 
greatest. So, there's my take on IE 6 and Windows XP. :-)

RAVIN RIZ
AIM: Rzy T
"No matter what stage a person is at in life, one thing must remain constant 
in order to achieve and retain happiness:HAVING FUN!"

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] *Rumor! Re: Sound Asylum tickets!!! * bsp.

Hey all!

I've been hearing a rumor that our party (Sound Asylum, this Friday the 
24th) is sold out already!  THIS IS *NOT* TRUE!!!  I think what happened is 
this:

We didn't drop our tickets off until this past weekend, (late, we know...!)  
Anyhow, some of you may have called up a record store last week or earlier 
asking about tickets for this party.  You may have been told "We don't have 
them" or something to that effect, and misunderstood that for "We're sold 
out."

Just to clear things up, we dropped off presales this past weekend, so *no* 
stores should be sold out just yet!  However, it's wisest to grab your 
presales now, as they are selling quickly!!

Here's the ticket outlets:  Subsonic Underground (Sac), Sticky Vinyl 
(Vallejo), Harmonics (Santa Rosa), Skills (Berkeley), Frequency 8 (SF), 
Solid Grooves (San Jose).

Thanks a bunch!  Here's the info line so you can get more information:
(415) 267-3992.

Here's an image of the flyer:
http://www.dj-d.com/flyers/soundasylum2.jpg.

Alright, then, thanks for reading this, and we'll see you Friday
at the Asylum!!!!

Much Love,

Denise
:)

PS.  Could somebody from the d-list please forward this email to any of the 
other lists i have forgotten (eg., iloveraving).  thanks!

X-MSMail-Priority: Normal

X-MIMEOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V5.50.4133.2400
Message-ID: <OE61SoRKbpG1KiaexdD00007184@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 23 Aug 2001 08:23:40.0653 (UTC) FILETIME=[EA30F1D0:01C12BAC]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: IE OR NETSCAPRE 6.0

Right there with you. I love the feel of Netscape and always used to use it,
but when MSIE didn't quit and supported code better and didn't slaughter
what should be a standard code I switched. The only reason to use Netscape
now is because it's *NOT* Microsoft and to me that's a shitty reason. I
don't like Microsoft but I can't argue with the product compared to
Netscape. Opera is quite good, but still has a ways to come. IE6 that's
included in that WinXP release right now is supposed to be fully CSS2
compliant. Something that makes me very happy. Coming from the graphic
design background and getting into web I hated the lack of control over
type. CSS is a godsend. That new interface for XP and IE6 though... ::GAG::
I'm not into pretty color silly UI's for OS's.

Back to the explorer vs netscape battle. netscape lost years ago for failing
to keep up with standards that web designers want. I check in netscape all
my sights, but only correct the oddities with netscape to a point unless the
client wants *everything* to be completely cross browser compliant. blah.
The web is such a pain in the ass which is why my first love is print. You
can *touch* it. =)

ryan

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm

X-No-Archive: yes

Date: Thu, 23 Aug 2001 03:03:46 -0700 (PDT)
From: Plastic Nuclear Ferret <donut@bayarea.net>
To: nancella <nancella@mindspring.com>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <AGEFJIJABOJDIIHBCNACAELOCOAA.nancella@mindspring.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.NEB.4.21.0108230256390.8141-100000@baygate.bayarea.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] srr: Deejay $ Question

as a DJ, i have been payed about 10 times in my three-year career.

the most was $150, the least ammount was a few drink tickets that i never
received.  the average is about $25.

getting payed depends on many things:

1) how much money the bar makes
2) how stingy the bar/cub owner is (they're usually very stingy)
3) how much you're worth (are you *really* good?)
4) how much they offer
5) how much you ask for

so.............

i dunno.  ask around.  talk to other DJs.  be humble about it, as it's a
tough question to ask ("gee, how much do *you* make DJing?")

unless you're established or something, i'd recommend asking between
$50-$75.

then again, these are just numbers that i pulled out of my ass.  8^)

shane

architecture of the OS is new, not based on NT.

it now.  I haven't bothered to even look at XP, from what I've heard, it 
will suck.  I use win2k here at work, and it's so-so, I still run 98 SE at 
home (most of the time) due to compatibility issues.  I'm not too thrilled 
with 2k, so  don't see how XP could be an improvement.  Orginally I hoped to 
use netscape until a better OS came out, but it doesn't look like that's 
going to happen any time soon.  I have sinking pit in my stomach that I'm

Subject: [sfraves] DJ question

I have a question for the DJ's out there.

So supposing you're playing a set that you want to start out slow
and build in energy/tempo. I'd always assumed you pick slower
records to start with, and go to faster and faster records as the set
progresses. But if you're beatmatching accurately between records,
the tempo will remain identical from one record to the next. So are
you constantly inching up the tempo as the records are playing, using
the pitch control? I'd never noticed this, but I guess this must be
what's happening. (Sorry if this sounds like a dumb question!).

- Martin

going to happen any time soon.  I have sinking pit in my stomach that I'm

ported over tho..

Content-Type: text/plain;

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] DJ question

inching up the pitch would be the key, doing it slowly without noticing, or
sometimes in some tracks it might be in the right place to actually sound
good to notice it. And the easiest place is in the breaks or ambient, and
the tempo being a bit higher when the buildup to beats hit the floor again.
Is a common sense maneuver, makes sure it isn't noticed, or sounds good if
it is, but yeah, the only way to increase it is with increasing the pitch,
but there are a few records out there that the BPM increases during the
track.




andy

-----Original Message-----
From: Martin Randall [mailto:kk@atc.creative.com]
Sent: Thursday, August 23, 2001 10:53 AM
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: [sfraves] DJ question


I have a question for the DJ's out there.

So supposing you're playing a set that you want to start out slow
and build in energy/tempo. I'd always assumed you pick slower
records to start with, and go to faster and faster records as the set
progresses. But if you're beatmatching accurately between records,
the tempo will remain identical from one record to the next. So are
you constantly inching up the tempo as the records are playing, using
the pitch control? I'd never noticed this, but I guess this must be
what's happening. (Sorry if this sounds like a dumb question!).

- Martin

Date: Thu, 23 Aug 2001 12:05:42 -0700
Message-ID: <NFBBLOLNELECECNEIIFJIEAOCDAA.dapydork@yahoo.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Priority: 3 (Normal)
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook IMO, Build 9.0.2416 (9.0.2910.0)
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V5.50.4133.2400
In-Reply-To: <4.3.1.0.20010823100422.00b96968@qix.netcorps.com>
Importance: Normal
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: IE OR NETSCAPRE 6.0

Well, I have used every OS Microsoft has made and started beta testing with
the Chicago project which evolved in to Windows 95.  Same with the Office
suite as well.  Windows XP will eventually be the predominant Operating
System because it has the stability of the Windows 2000 NT Kernel with the
compatibility to Windows 9x/ME that Win2K was lacking.

People tend to give Microsoft a bad rap when in reality Windows 3.11 was
stable considering what it really was, which is a first version.  Sure you
will see people claiming to have copies of Windows 1 and 2, but in reality
they were developer previews and internal test applications and not really
for everyday use.  So for being a first version it was pretty stable and I
think most of the problems that people had with it were related to
configuration, driver issues and the fact that people just did not take the
time or effort to learn to configure and tweak the system properly.  Those
who did will tell you the same thing I am telling you.  As for Windows 95,
it added more features and was very stable, even more stable then Windows
3.11 the only problem is that people who had older hardware and unstable
Windows 3.11 setups wanted the upgrade to work miracles and fix all of their
problems and it didn't.  It wasn't designed to do that.  Windows 95b was
actually even more stable then Windows 95 or even 95a because it did not
support upgrades and had more drivers.  Windows 98 built upon the stability
of Windows 95, but added the integration of Windows and Internet Explorer
and there were problems with the upgrade so once again the uninformed blamed
the OS, not their hardware or setup.  Windows 98 Second Edition fixed a lot
of the stability problems with the IE 4 / Win Explorer merger and led way to
Windows ME which was basically created for the machine manufacturers so that
they could have better rollout tools and an easier way to add all of the
security and service pack and hot fix updates released by Microsoft over the
year since the release of Windows 98.  It also started using a new driver
model closer to that of Windows NT/2K.

Windows XP will replace Windows 98/Me and it will happen very fast because
manufacturer's will begin to stop making windows 9x/Me drivers for their
hardware and once that is done, it usually signals the death knoll for the
operating system.  It's what happened to Windows 3.11 previously.
Understand I am not a Microsoftie, I believe they could do much better then
they have done, but I also believe that they are not nearly as incompetent
as the Linux'ers and Mac'ers wanna make them out to be.

Try looking at older versions of the Mac OS and see how unstable and how
easily it ate itself.  There is no real future in Linux, as it was hyped
like .COM's and with their death knoll signals the same for Linux.

X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook IMO, Build 9.0.2416 (9.0.2910.0)
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V5.50.4133.2400
In-Reply-To: <F45zwTfJJHWlWxedSYw0001695a@hotmail.com>
Importance: Normal
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: IE OR NETSCAPRE 6.0

Not based on NT?  How do you figure it is not based on NT?  It is the same
kernel as Windows 2000, same driver model as well.  The stability comes from
the NT Kernel which is based on ring 0, ring 1 architecture.  The kernel
runs in ring 0 and controls all hardware access, programs and drivers run in
ring 1 and cannot directly access the hardware.  This model means that
shoddy programmers and those who do not follow the rules cannot write
programs that can potentially make a system unstable.  The downside is that
there is no way to protect against programs with memory leaks and drivers
that are just unstable.

The added compatibility modes that allow you to run programs as if they were
running under Windows 9x/Me means that more games will run.  Once
programmers begin writing for the new Kernel, then you wont have
compatibility issues like we have seen in the past.

 -----Original Message-----
From: 	Fat -S1 [mailto:mke_99@hotmail.com]
Sent:	Thursday, August 23, 2001 10:16 AM
To:	raver@sarilion.org; sfraves@hyperreal.org

 << File: Re_ [sfraves] NRR_ IE OR NETSCAPRE 6.0.txt >> XP actually is quite
an improvement over Win2k.  Mainly because the whole
architecture of the OS is new, not based on NT.

It may look a little too user-friendly, but it really is quite stable and
you don't need to restart as much.  It screams on my roommate's P4.

Give it a shot!

-matt

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] DJ question

see, that is one way of doing it, or the way which i
like to use is not to vary pitch control at _all_ but
use records of differing feel. tempo does not ==
energy, sounds, and feel of a record == energy. you
can have the deepest smooth soothing house record at
130 bpm, and right beside it have a floorfilling
bangin diva track chuggin along at 130 too..its jus
how the sounds are put together...

so i'd suggest trying this..working with deeper more
minimal, floaty soft feeling tracks and working into
harder feeling more driving and stompy records to
entice a crowd into a frenzy...

J

> slowly without noticing, or
> sometimes in some tracks it might be in the right
> place to actually sound
> good to notice it. And the easiest place is in the
> breaks or ambient, and
> the tempo being a bit higher when the buildup to
> beats hit the floor again.
> Is a common sense maneuver, makes sure it isn't
> noticed, or sounds good if
> it is, but yeah, the only way to increase it is with
> increasing the pitch,
> but there are a few records out there that the BPM
> increases during the
> track.

----Original Message Follows----
From: "Sir Dapy Of Dorkdom" <dapydork@yahoo.com>
Reply-To: <dapydork@yahoo.com>
To: "Fat -S1" <mke_99@hotmail.com>, <raver@sarilion.org>,        
<sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: IE OR NETSCAPRE 6.0
Date: Thu, 23 Aug 2001 12:05:45 -0700

Not based on NT?  How do you figure it is not based on NT?  It is the same
kernel as Windows 2000, same driver model as well.  The stability comes from
the NT Kernel which is based on ring 0, ring 1 architecture.  The kernel
runs in ring 0 and controls all hardware access, programs and drivers run in
ring 1 and cannot directly access the hardware.  This model means that
shoddy programmers and those who do not follow the rules cannot write
programs that can potentially make a system unstable.  The downside is that
there is no way to protect against programs with memory leaks and drivers
that are just unstable.

The added compatibility modes that allow you to run programs as if they were
running under Windows 9x/Me means that more games will run.  Once
programmers begin writing for the new Kernel, then you wont have
compatibility issues like we have seen in the past.

  -----Original Message-----
From: 	Fat -S1 [mailto:mke_99@hotmail.com]
Sent:	Thursday, August 23, 2001 10:16 AM
To:	raver@sarilion.org; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject:	Re: [sfraves] NRR: IE OR NETSCAPRE 6.0

  << File: Re_ [sfraves] NRR_ IE OR NETSCAPRE 6.0.txt >> XP actually is 
quite
an improvement over Win2k.  Mainly because the whole
architecture of the OS is new, not based on NT.

It may look a little too user-friendly, but it really is quite stable and
you don't need to restart as much.  It screams on my roommate's P4.

Give it a shot!

-matt

Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: IE OR NETSCAPRE 6.0

Do you work for Microsoft's PR department or did you just copy all of that
from Microsoft's website?

With pretty much Microsoft product I have ever used, I have gone through
these steps:

1) Oh *gag*, another Microsoft program that's gonna suck?
2) Oh wow, that actually looks kinda cool, maybe I'm wrong about all this.
3) Hey, that's also a pretty good idea, maybe Microsoft has finally made
something that doesn't suck.
4) Okay, this works, that's kinda weird how they put it together, though.
5) WTF is going on? Ok, I must be retarded or something.
6) Nono, I'm not retarded, this program most definitely sucks.
7) Nono, it can't be. How can a program possibly be this retarded? Did it
just do what I thought it did?
8) Dammit! It just crashed again!
9) Ok, I AM retarded for still using this thing. Jesus Christ.

The only exception to this rule has been IE for the Mac. It's not perfect,
but in reality, Netscape just sucks so much, I have nothing to truly
complain about. But then again, the exception proves the rule, eh =P

>Try looking at older versions of the Mac OS and see how unstable and how
>easily it ate itself.  There is no real future in Linux, as it was hyped
>like .COM's and with their death knoll signals the same for Linux.

Ok, I'm trying to figure out if you really believe this, or if you're just
trying to save your job at this point. If hype were the sole indicator of
failure, then Microsoft would have been dead in the water years ago.
Microsoft is no stranger to hype. Don't confuse the dot-com mess with a
software movement that has generated quality, reliable software. Linux is
doing just fine.

-Damien


At 12:05 PM -0700 8/23/01, Sir Dapy Of Dorkdom wrote:
>Well, I have used every OS Microsoft has made and started beta testing with
>the Chicago project which evolved in to Windows 95.  Same with the Office
>suite as well.  Windows XP will eventually be the predominant Operating
>System because it has the stability of the Windows 2000 NT Kernel with the
>compatibility to Windows 9x/ME that Win2K was lacking.
>
>People tend to give Microsoft a bad rap when in reality Windows 3.11 was
>stable considering what it really was, which is a first version.  Sure you
>will see people claiming to have copies of Windows 1 and 2, but in reality
>they were developer previews and internal test applications and not really
>for everyday use.  So for being a first version it was pretty stable and I
>think most of the problems that people had with it were related to
>configuration, driver issues and the fact that people just did not take the
>time or effort to learn to configure and tweak the system properly.  Those
>who did will tell you the same thing I am telling you.  As for Windows 95,
>it added more features and was very stable, even more stable then Windows
>3.11 the only problem is that people who had older hardware and unstable
>Windows 3.11 setups wanted the upgrade to work miracles and fix all of their
>problems and it didn't.  It wasn't designed to do that.  Windows 95b was
>actually even more stable then Windows 95 or even 95a because it did not
>support upgrades and had more drivers.  Windows 98 built upon the stability
>of Windows 95, but added the integration of Windows and Internet Explorer
>and there were problems with the upgrade so once again the uninformed blamed
>the OS, not their hardware or setup.  Windows 98 Second Edition fixed a lot
>of the stability problems with the IE 4 / Win Explorer merger and led way to
>Windows ME which was basically created for the machine manufacturers so that
>they could have better rollout tools and an easier way to add all of the
>security and service pack and hot fix updates released by Microsoft over the
>year since the release of Windows 98.  It also started using a new driver
>model closer to that of Windows NT/2K.
>
>Windows XP will replace Windows 98/Me and it will happen very fast because
>manufacturer's will begin to stop making windows 9x/Me drivers for their
>hardware and once that is done, it usually signals the death knoll for the
>operating system.  It's what happened to Windows 3.11 previously.
>Understand I am not a Microsoftie, I believe they could do much better then
>they have done, but I also believe that they are not nearly as incompetent
>as the Linux'ers and Mac'ers wanna make them out to be.
>
>Try looking at older versions of the Mac OS and see how unstable and how
>easily it ate itself.  There is no real future in Linux, as it was hyped
>like .COM's and with their death knoll signals the same for Linux.
>

Subject: [sfraves] ***BREEDER @ ASCENSION TONIGHT***

ah! the all important question. We've got residents playing until 12 (BRD, 
Fuckwork and introducing L.R.) and then we've got the huge, crazy
stylings of Rowan Blades a.k.a. BREEDER! I'm totally psyched about this...as 
it's my 2nd to last Ascension before i head back to the east coast...and 
everyone's gonna be there tonight. oh the antici...PATION!

Here's the official BSP below:

By sheer persistance to bring you the best events in the east bay, we 
managed to nab one of the hottest producer / DJ's in the world:

Rowan Blades (a.k.a. Breeder)
This man has done remixes for the likes of Orbital, Planet Perfecto, Tilt, 
and has records out on F.F.R.R. and Hooj Choons. Read more about him @ 
http://www.gatecrasher.co.uk/connected/djs/rowanblades/

He also runs a kick ass record store. Check it out at
http://www.rhythmsyndicate.co.uk/

We feel it's necessary to warn you that we WILL sell out. We only say this 
because Rowan Blades will be the most notorious DJ ever seen at Ascension. 
Furthermore, we've already been sold out for the last two months. We don't 
want anyone to be upset when they arrive after travelling a great distance 
to find they can't get in. So, come down early, have a drink or grab a bite 
to eat at the reastaurant upsatirs, and guarantee that you get to see one of 
the most incredible sets ever at one of the greatest club nights ever.

ASCENSION - Every other Thursday @ Blakes
2367 Telegraph Ave - Berkeley
ID Required
$5 for 21+
$7 for 18-20
510.848.0886 for directions

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: IE OR NETSCAPRE 6.0


On Thu, Aug 23, 2001 at 12:05:45PM -0700, Sir Dapy Of Dorkdom wrote:
> Not based on NT?  How do you figure it is not based on NT?  It is the same
> kernel as Windows 2000, same driver model as well.  The stability comes from
> the NT Kernel which is based on ring 0, ring 1 architecture.  The kernel
> runs in ring 0 and controls all hardware access, programs and drivers run in
> ring 1 and cannot directly access the hardware.  

But would you consider it ambient jungle, or atmospheric/soundscape
drum and bass? Perhaps a whole new vocabulary should be developed
to encompass the particular range of instrumentation and nontraditional
tunings used in present-day Win32 enterprise-class architectures. 

It's off-topic, but last week at DNA Lounge I saw Alan Cox and Andy
Tridgell doing Stoli shots in the goth room, and all of a sudden
Tridge jumps up and starts laughing and kind of monkey-skanking
around the dance floor just like Ballmer did in that video.  Then
he sees some guy wearing an IIS dev group t-shirt and Tridge just
goes NUTS, and he's like JUMPING on the guy's FACE with his 20-hole
hobnailed shitkickers, and screaming about Code Red and saying how
he's going to carve "GET /default.ida?XXXXXXXX..." on the poor frail
bastard's pigeon-breasted torso with this wicked tanto he's
brandishing, and then this big old-skool industrial-culture type
guy wearing a Windows Services for UNIX QA team shirt comes up and
he's trying to pull Tridge off the guy but it's too slippery to get
a grip with all the blood and everything, and out of nowhere Alan
grabs this wispy emo kid by his purple-black forelock and starts
just whipping the kid around like a set of weepy Dead-Can-Dance-listening
nunchucks and clocks the Services for UNIX guy and he's out, and
the emo kid runs off and writes a poem about it, and the bouncers
rush the floor and then it just goes downhill from there.  Richard
Stallman runs up and screams "It's really GNU/Linux!" and I snuck
in a quick rabbit punch just on general principles. The brawl got
kind of messy and last I saw they were bumrushing Alan and Andy out
the door and they're all laughing and shit.  jwz was really cool
about the whole thing, though.  Apparently it happens a couple times
a week. It's worse than the infamous Milpitas hip-hop/KanDeE-kid
escalation of February 2000.  I totally blame the Win32 supporters,
though, they're shady as hell.



Okay, it's really a shame I have to say this now, but experience shows I must:
THE ABOVE DOCUMENT IS SATIRE. NONE OF IT HAPPENED. OKAY, I DID GO
TO DNA LOUNGE AND IN FACT IT'S REALLY AWESOME AND I HIGHLY RECOMMEND
IT TO EVERYONE, ESPECIALLY FRIDAY NIGHTS. BUT EVERYTHING ELSE UP
THERE IS JUST A JOKE, INCLUDING THE MILPITAS HIPHOP KANDEE KID
THING. WINDOWS AS A SERVER PLATFORM IN AN ENTERPRISE ENVIRONMENT
IS A JOKE TOO.  APPARENTLY I HAVE TO REBOOT 2000 JUST TO CHANGE THE
VALUE THE SMTP SERVICE SENDS AS ITS HELO PARAMETER, WHAT KIND OF
BULLSHIT IS THAT?  AND WHO THE HELL WOULD WILLINGLY SELECT IIS FOR
WEB SERVICES AFTER LAST MONTH?  I STILL GET HUNDREDS OF CODE RED
HITS A DAY. I DO NOT ADVOCATE VIOLENCE AGAINST WINDOWS USERS OR
RICHARD STALLMAN.  THANK YOU AND GOD BLESS.


Can we please talk about raves now?

--
Benjy Feen
benjy(AT)feen.com
http://www.monkeybagel.com

Date: Thu, 23 Aug 2001 13:15:46 -0700 (PDT)
From: Jahsh <josh@cloudfactory.org>
Reply-To: Jahsh <josh@cloudfactory.org>
cc: kk@atc.creative.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <F2660EWmRj4fXIAqdkl0000e709@hotmail.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0108231307570.13142-100000@stratus.cloudfactory.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Re:DJ question

> >From: Martin Randall <kk@atc.creative.com>
> >To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> >Subject: [sfraves] DJ question
> >Date: Thu, 23 Aug 2001 10:52:32 -0700
> >
> >I have a question for the DJ's out there.
> >
> >So supposing you're playing a set that you want to start out slow
> >and build in energy/tempo. I'd always assumed you pick slower
> >records to start with, and go to faster and faster records as the set
> >progresses. But if you're beatmatching accurately between records,
> >the tempo will remain identical from one record to the next. So are
> >you constantly inching up the tempo as the records are playing, using
> >the pitch control? I'd never noticed this, but I guess this must be
> >what's happening. (Sorry if this sounds like a dumb question!).

	The tempo of the record is not always inline with the energy of
the record. You can have bumpin house that is way more energetic than
really fast minimal techno. At time in the night you can actually get a
dance floor going stonger by slowing down the tempo so the crowd can
groove to the beat. 

	And to those dj that do just bump up the tempo of the records
through out their set thinking that this will increase the energy of the
dance floor without thinking about the energy of the records themselves
and putting together a set that flows-you need to think things through a
bit more. Jungle Dj's that play records pitched up thinkin it's gonna get
the crowd going and think it sounds better that way, just make me walk
off the dance floor.

	FASTER IS NOT BETTER.

	josh
