Message-ID: <20010826010950.87217.qmail@web13708.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Sat, 25 Aug 2001 18:09:50 -0700 (PDT)
From: li'l ducks <vamprssdru@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] "Down for the Get Down" [article]

more on Chicago's troubled rave scene...

-d 

DOWN FOR THE GET DOWN
Checking in on a much cautious rave scene a year
later
-words by Christine Hsieh
[ur chicago, Aug. 13Sept. 9]

There is no rave scene.  Its dead.
Is this dejected promoter right?  Over a year has
passed since Chicago laid down the law, so to speak,
that effectively shut down much of the citys
developing underground dance party scene.  Now, with
DJs and promoters alike facing fines of up to $10,000
from involvement wit unlicensed events, raves in
Chicago have turned towards a decidedly commercialized
feel in order to survive.
So gone are the days of burnt-out warehouses and
secret map points.  Replacing these formerly cherished
dens of iniquity are large venues (typically the
Harvey Expo Center or the Dolton Community Center),
large lineups and sky-rocketing prices.  There were
always big parties, but somehow it exploded because of
the media and drug use, observes Gabe Rodriguez,
promoter for the Treehouse Collective.  As soon as
[the media] put the spotlight on it, more people would
come and more people heard about it.  It wasnt
something that you had to figure out where it was,
something you had to look forit was right there in
front of you.
Now, with raves slowly edging into popular
consciousness, dissenting opinions and sometimes
unfavorable media coverage threatens to split up a
culture which prides itself on unity and respect. 
Nearly everyone these days, from the average dude next
door to Chicagos top officials, has heard stories of
dark warehouses filled with colorfully dressed youths
sucking on pacifiers, sporting plastic bracelets and
waving glowsticks about to deafening, repetitive
music.  [Lawmakers are] trying to associate these as
paraphernalia at a rave, complains Rodriguez. 
Theres hundreds of glowsticks over at Taste of
ChicagoI guess theyre having a rave.
In addition to heavy fines, strict building codes,
coupled with increasingly stringent inspections, make
the already difficult path towards securing proper
licenses more circuitous and troublesome.  Theres so
much policy going on right nowI think [city
officials] are just trying to shut the whole thing
down, speculates Alfonz de la Mota, DJ and promoter
for Boogie Tribe.  Thats what it looks like.  They
dont want to give us leeway, or let us hear music we
want to hear in the proper environment.  According to
de la Mota, even one exposed wire can shut down entire
proceedings for a party.
These laws, designed to eradicate raves from Chicago,
have successfully pushed most larger scale venues out
of the city and into the suburbs.  Thats not a new
phenomenon, but of late its become they only one;
every raver worth their salt knows of Harvey or
Dolton, the long lines to get into the venues, and the
feeling of condensed sweat dripping from the ceilings.
 Located outside city limits, these spaces do not fall
under any anti-rave ordinances.  [The venues] have a
history with rave promoters so they know whats going
on and make a lot of money, explains Matt Druid, DJ
and head of Bliss Industries.  Its very organized
now.  Its not like back in the day when you could
rent a warehouse and tell the owner you were throwing
a birthday party or a record release party and just go
wild in the place.
Besides offering a virtually bust-proof space, Harvey
and Dolton can accommodate crowds of thousands.  Not
only do promoters enjoy profit from packing more
people into a party in one night, these large venues
and the crowds they attract can offer some security. 
Now, when you want to go into a small venue that can
hold only 400 people, its easier to shut you down,
explains de la Mota.  They can put more stereotypes
on you.  But when youre throwing a party that has
8000 people; theres power in numbers--its easier.
Because if they shut us down, they gotta shut every
big promoter down in Chicago.  House or loft parties
are often sniffed out by police and shut down rather
quickly, thanks in part to noise-level codes in
residential areas and suspicious neighbors.  Even
smaller events in non-residential areas are harder to
pull off, due mostly to wary property owners and the
sheer expense and effort involved.
Put simply, holding small parties really isnt that
practical.  After all, the mess of red tape seems less
and less appealing if the profit margin is nothing
short of scanty.  Furthermore, most DJs are now
reluctant to play at unlicensed parties for fear of
being slapped with heavy fines.  This has been a huge
blow to Chicagos rave scene, with talented DJs moving
out in search of less hostile destinations.  Most
notably, Halo Varga jumped ship and moved to
California after being fined for playing an unlicensed
party.  He is now a popular DJ on the West Coasts
thriving rave scene, and a highly successful produce
under his own name and with Hipp-E under H-Foundation
moniker.  Promoters of larger parties generally have a
larger budget to work with, allowing them to obtain
secure venues and out-of-state and international
talent.  These impressive line ups draw scored of
people to one party, making healthy amount of money. 
However, despite all the complaintstired venues, high
prices, troublesome securitythese large scale raves
(or DJ concerts, depending on who you ask) still
have their advantages.  The bigger parties are
helping the music scenethats their best quality. 
Theyre exposing DJs to a mass market, says Druid.
In the future, aggressive promotion of these large
raves will most likely take on a decidedly
business-like angle.  Its going to be more
professional, predicts Liquid G-zus, DJ for the
Treehouse Collective.  You have to go through all
these permits, get all this permissionyoull have
this company doing your insurance, this company doing
your security.  Instead of just the rave community
doing the parties themselves, youll have other
business people doing the parties with the rave
community.
Small parties, appealing because of the level of
intimacy and lower cost, are slowly disappearing as
promoters encounter difficulties with the police and
city officials.  Even with all the proper licenses and
permits, they often must terminate by 2am.  And at
2am, the partys just getting started.  So, that
leaves Dolton or Harvey, a sad, vicious cycle for the
dance-all-nightr.
As is the nature of electronic music, the constant
progression ad innovation keeps the genre dynamic,
something which many of the smaller rave promoters no
longer find in the rave scene.  I think thats one of
the reasonsI can speak for myselfwhy some promotes
stopped throwing raves, says Druid.  Theres no
excitement in going to the Dolton ad throwing a party
with the same standard DJs that they always seem to
have, and theres no excitement left for those that
have been throwing parties for a while.
Druid now DJs at clubs and produces tunes on his
label, Fusion Sound Lab Records.  Frankie Vega, of the
now-defunct group Mushgroove, currently works A&R at a
record label.  Dust Traxx used to provide support for
other promotions groups, but distanced themselves in
order to concentrate on their musical output.  Future
Forces has also given up the party scene in response
to increasing demand for founder DJ 3Ds skills behind
the decks, and key figures Njoy have moved on a well.
Despite increasing difficulties, some smaller groups
have managed to stay afloat.  Voodoo Child and Shade
Free still do occasional parties, and Flashback/Smooth
Movement pulls off an event every once in a while. 
Fear None and Global Adrenaline now do larger raves. 
The Treehouse Collective continues to set up small,
inexpensive parties, using diverse locations such as
forest preserves and parks to keep interest alive. 
As things get bigger, things will go back
underground, says Tommie Sunshine, DJ and producer at
Dust Traxx, and a man who has watched Chicagos rave
scene fluctuate since its birth nearly a decade ago. 
There has always been and always will be an
underground.
Of course, loft parties still go off, but mostly
through strict invite-only door policies and very
little promotion.  And every once in a while, a small
group will break into a warehouse, set up a generator,
and let loose before scrambling away from the scene of
the crime at daybreak.  These events are rare, but
they keep some of that traditional renegade spirit
from disappearing.
To some, it may appear rather masochistic to persist
in the face of such difficulty.  Thankfully, a deep
love of the music keeps most people from writing off
raves as a passing fad, like the lambada or swing
dancings mid-90s reincarnation.  People wonder,
its such a big hassle, why do you keep on doing it?
 But its all about the music, to keep it going, says
de la Mota.  The only thing thats slowing it down is
the politics.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Hello 2Day....Alter Ego....Bad Ass Man -- Review

Okay I really need to run back up to school, but I really wanted to post a
quick review. My night started out around 6pm when I woke up from the
previous night of good music at Ascension (the residents and Breeder really
tore it up last nite) then the after party over my house where much
craziness ensued. So I got some food, collected my thoughts and headed out
to Berkely to Becca's to begin what was about to be an amazing night. As I
walk up I see Jason (DK) in candy. It was scary, but really interesting to
see. I think the only way to describe Jason is "Bad-assed" So inside I see
Osric (gothby?) and the rest of the crew, it felt like halloween almost,
it's great to see everyones alter ego come out. After that it's time to
assume our stations and make sure people get to this party. I hung around
Becca and Alida entertaining them, and making fun of some intoxicated ravers
accross the street. Then I go to work my map point with Natalie. I played
snake while she made candy and passed out the last clue for the party to the
people that walked up. It was somewhat boring but I was *VERY* touched at
all the great people that came up to me. I got offered everything from
Balance bars to beer. Thank you soo much to all those people that felt some
desire to repay me. Ravers Rawk! Everyone was very friendly and I was now
very excited to get to the party as it looked like we would have a great
group of people. Got to the space and it was grrrrreat! The atmosphere was
great, the sky was beautiful, and the people were dancing. Order had been
restored to the world. Jason spun a very good set, albiet it wasn't his
usual style, I really enjoyed it. And AndyW was equally great bringing out
booty house with andy flavor. Unfortunately I missed Mike, and Ira spin, but
I was a tired kid, and couldn't be as hardcore as I was during summer time.
Thanks to everyone who came out, and for the rest of AEC for an awesome
night.

Plur! 0=)

-Aaron


.:Technolounge:.
www.technolounge.org | aaron@technolounge.org
KidPhawx [ASR, Ignition, SFRP, AudibleEnergy]

Subject: [sfraves] Re: NRR: Aaliyah is dead!

it is true...but very, very SAD! :(

http://www.cnn.com/2001/SHOWBIZ/Music/08/26/bahamas.crash.ap/index.html

Aaliyah killed in plane crash

MARSH HARBOUR, Bahamas (AP) -- R&B singer and actress Aaliyah died Saturday 
when a small plane that was to carry her and eight others back to the United 
States crashed after takeoff in the Bahamas, authorities said.

Eight were killed, and one critically injured man was flown to Florida for 
treatment, officials said.

"We find it devastating and most unfortunate that after having this 
world-famous star Aaliyah and her crew select the Bahamas as their choice 
location for her latest video, the project has climaxed on such a tragic 
note," said Minister of Tourism Tommy Turnquest, who happened to be visiting 
Abaco Island, where the plane went down.

Aaliyah's song "Try Again" earned her a Grammy nomination for best female 
R&B vocalist. She made her feature acting debut in the film "Romeo Must 
Die."

Bahamian national television quoted the civil aviation department as saying 
Aaliyah was among nine Americans on board.

The private plane was leaving the Marsh Harbour airport on a trip to 
Opa-locka, Florida, when it went down Saturday evening, said police 
spokesman Marvin Dames.

Abaco Island Chief Councilor Silbert Mills said those killed included two 
women and six men.

Islander Derek Russell, who worked for the group during the video shoot, 
said he got the artist's autograph before the accident.

"She's a nice girl, a friendly girl," he said.

The cause of the crash was unclear. Kathleen Bergen, a spokeswoman for the 
U.S. Federal Aviation Administration in Atlanta, said the plane was a Cessna 
402 owned by Skystream, a company based in Pembroke Pines, Florida. She said 
the plane crashed at the end of the airport's runway at 6:50 p.m. EDT (2250 
GMT).

Copyright 2001 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may 
not be published, broadcast, rewritten, or redistributed.

Subject: [sfraves] Review: AEC, come as you aren't.  A+

Great renegades are just too rare anymore.  Shane and I arrived very
nervous about the gate situation, replying on the smarts of each guest
to enter when it was okay and keep those lights off (without driving off
the road.)  

A little late, but worth the wait, the equipment all got going.  (Sweet
memories of trolling the excavation site for something to put the
turntables on.)  Thanks to everyone who lent their equipemnt, renegades
can really get a lot of dust and crud in there, but we thank you for it.

*So* many people showed up!  How did this happen?  Nobody knew who the
DJ lineup really was (great fake names), and no-one knew that AEC was an
alternate name for your very own SFR-Planners.  I guess if you have the
right people spread word-of-mouth it will all happen!

Best memories:
- Getting "creative" to set up the turntables and sound
- Seeing the major crowd turnout!
- The stars (especially those shooting ones...)
- The Red Stickman returneth (and somehow not puketh)
- Seeing friends I didn't expect to be there--Jim, Josh, Tracy, Brian B.
- Meeting new friends - Brian (from Lousianna), Jamie, Mike ("Some
friends just brought me.  Everyone is so nice!"), *another* Brian, Adam
128, and so on!
- The industrial excavation equipment, gotta give credit there.

Support your local kick-ass tiny party,
>:)Amber

Subject: [sfraves] nrr:  what is the pitch adjust thingie on one of those turntable things for?

Hey everyone,
             OK, this might seem an odd question, but here goes.  It's well
known that the Technics 1200 was originally a higher end consumer deck
before it got adopted by DJ's as the standard for spinnin records.  However,
it had the pitch adjust, as did many other home turntables of the period,
before DJ's picked it up!  The question I have is:  if people weren't
originally using a pitch adjust for beatmatching, then why was it there??
Anyone have any theories?

Just curious . . .

.:nomadic:.
www.nomadicDJ.com

Subject: [sfraves] AEC ::thank you::

------=_NextPart_000_00EA_01C12DE4.C53A24C0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

A very big thank you to all those that came out last night. We did =
things a bit differently having the multiple mappoints and the 3 clues =
to get to the first mappoint and we're glad to see and hear that you =
enojyed the party. Sorry about the *hi -I'm on crack voicemails* but =
with 30 seconds to say all of that info was a challenge! How long did =
that take you get the VM worked out Alida?? The point of last night was =
to do something fun, but in a more playful manner while keeping things =
simple. We promised ourselves we would throw an outdoor this summer and =
decided a week ago that now was the time. The success of this party =
depended heavily on the responsible nature of the people that came. We =
didn't have a single problem with people not following the rules about =
getting to the party which was a huge sigh of relief. Everyone that came =
really did a great job of keeping the space clean. Cleanup in the =
morning took 5 mintutes! A huge family turnout was great to see and even =
better since everyone was dressed as their alter ego. Gothby wins for =
the best alter ego of the night. If you didn't know him normally you =
would think he was bored with life and wanting to die last night. Great =
to see the stickman emerge once more. Been waaay too long. We were glad =
to see such a large turnout, albeit rather surprised given there were =
only 2 days of promotion for this party. The space worked out great even =
though it was rather sketchy at first. It was great to party there again =
since it had been nearly 2 years since Divination was held there. If =
anyone has pictures from the party please let us know! We'd love to see =
them. The next AEC party is unknown, but be assured that we'll do this =
again in the future.=20

Thank you to all of our crew, DJ's and extended family that made the =
night possible! From sound, generator, mixer, decks, to all the people =
working the mappoints and gate without your help this party wouldn't =
have happened. Things always get crazy before the party, but when it =
comes down to it everything works out. =3D)

aec.lubs.you!



------=_NextPart_000_00EA_01C12DE4.C53A24C0--

Subject: [sfraves] Re: NRR aaliyah

Beautiful.

Damn well spoken D.

Take a moment to bow your head and realize that life in itself is a gift.
And what we do with it determines the path of a million or so other such
paths we may interact with on our travels.  We take alot for granted in
California.  We have our parties here where it seems the worst we recieve is
some ill made attempt to shut down an event by the local police should they
happen upon it.

While in other parts of the country people are being tear gassed, pepper
sprayed, jailed, and beaten in order to preserve their right to do something
as simple as dance.


I know life is hectic, and the days never seem short enough and the nights
never long enough..  But everyonce in awhile, turn your head to the east,
and give a moment of silence to all those people who have, are, and WILL be
fighting for that simple right.  And pray as well kids..

Because someday it may be like that hear...

I bow my head to the loss of talent and all the gifts they had yet shared
with the world.  And can only pray that they have inspired a new generation
of children to not take it all for granted.  Take heart all, look to the
stars..


And Climb.

-B

X-Sender: divan@imap.seas.upenn.edu
Message-Id: <v04003a00b7ae9ff02f20@[10.2.1.9]>

From: Damien <divan@seas.upenn.edu>
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] ***SoundCheck*** Wonderful!!

It may seem surprising to some people, but in betweeb all the SFR email, I
actually go to a rave once in a while.

Well, I had a *great* time at this party. Music Rocked (Forest Green!!
ohmygod!), enough space to dance, good vibe. Seriously, no complaints.
Visuals were totally cool. I was staring at them dumbfoundedly frequently
through the night. Magnificent. It was so nice to go to a party like that.

The only thing I really missed seeing was Kandy Kids!! The crowd at the
party was definitely a "newer" crowd. People were definitely having fun,
but you could tell that that quite a number of them weren't used to having
kids roll on their lap. It was weird (btw, it was my b-day), but I felt
that I've hit my second stage of raving. The first group of ravers I
knew/recognized isn't as present at partied I go to any longer, and I see
lots of new faces. I suppose it's now my time to try and start teaching the
younger ravers. I hope other experienced ravers take on a similar task. If
you feel like parties aren't "old school" enough anymore, then do what you
can to make it like old times.

I also came to realize how important unconditional love is. Whether it's
for your friends or for new people, especially ravers, it's such a
fundamental part of what makes a great rave so great. I'm doing my best to
everyone's time a good one.

Props to Outerworld for throwing a freaking awesome party. Thanks.

-Damien

. . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .

I think Gothby is better too.. I feel bad for not talking or seeing=20
anyone.. but I'm over it.  I'm happy to hear that you acted appropriately=20
Gothby. :)

sarilion


>      I'm so High & I will bring this High w/ me 2 HappyHardCore in Sac=20
> for SMILE!!!  Yay!!!  Wow, it's been such an amazing past few=20
> nights!  Well, I'm still tryhin' get over Osric 'cause man, that was hard=

> strait face & not laugh (except whenever Amber came up to me!  Hello 2Day=

> Amber=3D)  OK, I'm bladding again!!  But ya know, wearing all that gothie=

> stuff was fun!  Hmmmm

Please post this!

September 2, 2001.
Labor day weekend.


Terry Mullen vs. Joey Mazzola      Jim Hopkins vs. David Garcia
1st time bay area network set
Defiantly not for virgin ears!
Jesse Gonzalez             Melanie          Madame Mercury


Glows-ticks


Sahid- Germany        Michael Lui           Cash 22                Kaos

Aaron Lewis               Alain Octavo           Huey                 Hak



Beginning this Labor Day weekend U.V.T presents to you, our grand opening
for after glow Sundays. The mother of all after parties for all 2am after
party glows. Keep up to date with our voice lines for after party updates,
local and international artist appearances, and for special after hour
functions. No more 2am disappointments, your likely to hear them after their
party glow too!


For more Information please call:

No Work, No School, No Court, No worries! Just a Labor Day after glow!
9 pm till 6 am @ Club matrix west
1803 Webster in Oaktown, between 17th and 19th.



800-701- GLOW                   415-273-5170
www.UnityVibeTribe.com

Subject: [sfraves] Question # 8: Should we cooperate/rebel with authorities over drugs?

--part1_d.19c88d8b.28ba8dde_boundary
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

 Should the rave scene cooperate with authorities over their anti drug 
policies? Do you think this will in the long run save our right to dance? 
Should we allow the DEA to impliment censorship (forbiding pacifiers, glow 
sticks, etc,) over our parties? And should we allow police authorities to 
dangle the infamous crack house law and other anti rave laws over us as being 
the price we will have to pay to have a scene?
 Or, do you think the rave scene should be part of a large movement of people 
and organizations that believe drugs should be legalized, especially quasi 
harmless drugs like E, psyedelics and pot, and are fighting for the right of 
adults to be able to injest what ever they want as long as they dont hurt 
anyone else, and not always cooperate with officials believing even in the 
short run we will have our parties shut down and have anti rave and crack 
house laws thrown at us to stop us from dancing?
 Which do you believe, and why?

 Peace, love and hugs! Bodhi ^ _ ^

--part1_d.19c88d8b.28ba8dde_boundary--

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>

list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 77971 invoked from network); 26 Aug 2001 19:27:27 -0000
Message-ID: <20010826192724.21220.qmail@web20106.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Sun, 26 Aug 2001 12:27:24 -0700 (PDT)
From: Booty Shaker <shakedatass20@yahoo.com>
To: BodhiInSF@aol.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <d.19c88d8b.28ba8dde@aol.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Question # 8: Should we cooperate/rebel with authorities over drugs?

First off, E isn't harmless.

Second off, I have mixed feelings about this question.
 In one aspect, I would say yes, fight back, tell the
people who are trying to hold our scene down that we
can't be moved.  Drugs are a part of our scene,
whether you want to admit it or not.  However, for the
authorities to automatically assume that someone with
glowsticks and water is rolling is absurd.

Damn, I can't believe I'm defending glowsticks...I
hate those things.

Anyways, point being, I don't think that it's fair for
the authorities to make laws against throwing parties
just for the sake of a drug crackdown.  They should do
their job and find drug dealers in other places than
in parties.  Security at parties are the ones that
should worry about the kids coming in and what they
have on them.

I'd rather have a place completely drug free that I
can dance at and enjoy the music than a place filled
with people on drugs.  I personally always go out
sober.  I don't see the point of being in an e-pile
somewhere when I can instead be dancing my ass of to a
really great track. 

However, I think that the lawmakers are going to
create laws against raves whether we cooperate or not.
 I'm sure almost all of them could care less about
what we do, but the parents of America are scared that
us "ravers" will corrupt their children.  Parent's are
the ones that vote, and parents are the ones that
lawmakers wish to appease.

It really blows.  I just try to have a good as time as
I possibly can, and try to fight my battles as they
come at me.

(formerly Overworld) party. The crowd is older, been around a bit longer and
generally not active in the mainstream party scene. I wanted to go and see
the new space, but I needed a night of chilling with my gf. Almost stopped
by on the way home, but motivation was nil after the AEC festivities the
night before. Is the place as cool as Overworld (where Relic was held)?? I
hear it's huge so I'll just have to come out to the next party there. hasta

From: "Damien" <divan@seas.upenn.edu>

> It may seem surprising to some people, but in betweeb all the SFR email, I
> actually go to a rave once in a while.
>
> Well, I had a *great* time at this party. Music Rocked (Forest Green!!
> ohmygod!), enough space to dance, good vibe. Seriously, no complaints.
> Visuals were totally cool. I was staring at them dumbfoundedly frequently
> through the night. Magnificent. It was so nice to go to a party like that.
>
> The only thing I really missed seeing was Kandy Kids!! The crowd at the
> party was definitely a "newer" crowd. People were definitely having fun,
> but you could tell that that quite a number of them weren't used to having
> kids roll on their lap. It was weird (btw, it was my b-day), but I felt
> that I've hit my second stage of raving. The first group of ravers I
> knew/recognized isn't as present at partied I go to any longer, and I see
> lots of new faces. I suppose it's now my time to try and start teaching
the
> younger ravers. I hope other experienced ravers take on a similar task. If
> you feel like parties aren't "old school" enough anymore, then do what you
> can to make it like old times.
>
> I also came to realize how important unconditional love is. Whether it's
> for your friends or for new people, especially ravers, it's such a
> fundamental part of what makes a great rave so great. I'm doing my best to
> everyone's time a good one.
>
> Props to Outerworld for throwing a freaking awesome party. Thanks.
>
> -Damien

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Question # 8: Should we cooperate/rebel with authorities over drugs?

we only touch on a tiny, tiny, tiny few of the many
pharmaceuticals that are available to us for temporary
relief 
of illness, cure from illness, mimimizing damage from
illness or the process of aging. the reason why some
of the 
popularly discussed drugs on this list have been made
illegal is because of the horrible side-effects that
people 
have suffered from them and continue to suffer from
them...there are many other drugs that have been taken
off 
of the market..like phen-phen..i think that is how you
spell it..a popular diet pill, and throughout the
years, 
popular barbituates and anti-depressents are either
discontinued or improved upon...i really don't think
that 
there is a big conspiracy going on. i think people are
just trying to protect people's lives and the lives
and safety 
of children and teens. if people do not feel good, and
they want relief, they should turn to the medical
field, 
and not to the rave scene. i, for one, have never ever
appreciated watching people overdose in my presence,
and 
deliberately so, because they know that i am a caring
concerned person, and that if something goes wrong, i
will 
get them to a hospital...screw that...  what a waste
of my good time and energies, and what a horror for
the people around them to see. :)

> dangle the infamous crack house law and other anti

> the price we will have to pay to have a scene?

> large movement of people 
> and organizations that believe drugs should be
> legalized, especially quasi 
> harmless drugs like E, psyedelics and pot, and are
> fighting for the right of 
> adults to be able to injest what ever they want as
> long as they dont hurt 
> anyone else, and not always cooperate with officials
> believing even in the 
> short run we will have our parties shut down and
> have anti rave and crack 
> house laws thrown at us to stop us from dancing?
>  Which do you believe, and why?

Subject: [sfraves] Tina's alter-ego experience

ok, i know i'm a little late posting this, but well it was a long couple of days... 

friday night i totally rushed to get out of work early, but i missed the meeting at becca's house.. so i call ryan and i am informed that i no longer need to work the second map point shift.. so i head out on my way, to find a short detour since 80 was closed, and i finally make it out to the space.... had to pass the gate once cuz of an oncomming car... unfortunately, i have day running lights on my car, so i couldn't turn off my headlights all the way.... and jason was all super candy, and miki too.. it was great...

so the music hadn't quite started yet, but i found amber right away, and ryan was on the phone, and it was dark and i could berely see anything, and then i hear christle's voice... so we went back to my car where i changed into my alter ego.. i had wanted to take it a little more to the extreme, but i realized i gave away all my big pants and other raver-esque clothes.. but i brought it on full force with the candy.. i don't think i ever wore as much of it in one night.... i even revived my butterfly barrettes that i was never seen without back in the day... 

and it was so fucking nice out, such a great view, perfect for stargazing and trying to find all the constellations.. ben, what was the name of the meteor shower that was happening again? (this was the reason for all the shooting stars) 

anyways, it was soo cool to see all the dj's playing music that was so not typical of them, i loved it.. i think it shows some true level of skill when a dj can pick up records that don't really know in a genre they never play, and totally have fun with it! amber, shane, jason, andy.. you all did i great job (i missed ira and michael's sets.. =( i had to go home cuz of work in the morning)...

and it was great to see so many people come out, and a lot of them in their alter-ego nonetheless... i will never forget some of the outfits i saw.. especially ryan wearing lydia's fuzzy pants! but osby definately had the most alter-ego thing going on....

i'm sorry i didn't get a chance to meet more new people, but the ones i did meet totally rock! Natalie and i bonded working the gate in the morning and it was really cool to play guess the constelation and steall wheat thins from christle, i finally re-met atom128, hopefully you'll remember me next time =) and i met the nomadic dj... you are so cool.. i wish i could have traveled even half as much as you have... i'm not sure if the other people i met are on the list, but i know these three are! but if you saw a semi-candied out girl offering everyone herbal crack (mah whong) earlier in the night, that was me =) 

anyways, once again aec/sfr pulled off a great party, mad props to ryan for discovering the space, and to everyone else, i'm so proud that we pulled it together in such a short time, and now that summer is ending, it's about time to start planning an indoor! 

love and hugs and kisses,
tina

Subject: [sfraves] AEC reviewed!

It almost seems pointless to be doing a review at this point, when
everything has already been said, but I still wanted to get my say in:)
This is the first party I've helped out with that I have actually been
on crew, and wow am I proud.  I was so excited when I arrived at Becca's
and see Jason and Miki all candied out and then Alida in full HJBC
garb.  And then of course Gothby or Osrich who made it clear to everyone
that life is miserable (Goodbye Tomorrow!). Just too funny.  I worked
the first shift of the second map point in my little ford escort, so
some of you may have seen me.  At one point we were really nervous
because a suspicious cop decided to park his truck right behind us and
watch for about 20 minutes until the Gilman St. punks provided for a
distraction.  I'm sure we looked like drug dealers just chilling on a
dark corner and having random cars come up to us, but ah well.. nothing
happened!

I got to the party at about 1:30 just as sound was starting, and I loved
how the tables were set up on a truck with the bulldozer as a backdrop.
The space was absolutely beautiful (although very dark) and reminded me
of a combination between the desert and the moon.  Music the entire
night was great, and everyone even enjoyed Jason's NRG which was
untypical of this kind of party.  Michael the red stickman- thank you
for dressing up for us all- it really added so much spirit to the entire
party.  At one point I retreated to my car because I was tired and
grumpy, but came out later thanks to Ryan for cheering me up.  Seeing
Ryan in my old fuzzy pants was damn funny!  Watching the sunrise over
the hills had to be the highlight, and then packing up to leave at 7 AM
with little mess and happy people.  Terry decided to come visit us early
in the morning too.

So thanks to everyone for coming out- the party provided a great closure
to summer, but we'll have to do it again soon!  I love the whole alter
ego concept and the fact that so many people got into it (Tina you were
so cute). Happy B-day's to Becca, Jaime, and Ryan on Weds. =)

Lydia

Date: Sun, 26 Aug 2001 19:18:19 -0700

Mime-Version: 1.0

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Carnivore to add wireless to its menu?

--=====================_23672540==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Carnivore to add wireless to its menu?

by Erich Luening and Ben Charny, ZDNet News


A telecommunications group warns that the FBI may start using its DCS1000 
surveillance system, originally known as Carnivore, to eavesdrop on 
wireless e-mail and cell-phone text messages.

Federal law enforcement officials may use a controversial surveillance 
technology to monitor e-mail and other text messages delivered through 
wireless devices, such as cell phones--a fact that has one 
telecommunications group concerned.

In a letter to Federal Communications Commission Chairman Michael Powell, 
the Cellular Telecommunications & Internet Association (CTIA) warned that 
the FBI may start using its DCS1000 surveillance system, originally known 
as Carnivore, to eavesdrop on wireless communications as early as October.

The CTIA fears the FBI might start using the DCS1000 system because the 
wireless industry has so far been unable to develop a standard for law 
enforcement agencies to monitor e-mails sent between handheld devices.

The FCC has set a Sept. 30 deadline for the wireless industry to submit 
guideline proposals for use of the DCS1000 system.

Although agency officials would not comment on the CTIA's letter, a 
representative said the FCC intends to decide soon whether to extend the 
deadline.

In the Aug. 15 letter, the association's vice president and general counsel 
Michael Altschul wrote: "If the industry is not provided the guidance and 
time to develop solutions for packet surveillance that intercept only the 
target's communications, it seems probable that Carnivore, which intercepts 
all communications in the pathway without the affirmative intervention of 
the carrier, will be widely implemented."

Privacy advocates, civil libertarians and some lawmakers have criticized 
Carnivore because they fear the system may be used to snoop on innocent 
citizens without their knowledge.

The FBI has been using the controversial technology for two years. The 
Carnivore system, which is installed at Internet service providers, 
captures "packets" of Internet traffic as they travel through ISP networks. 
The program monitors millions of mail messages, searching for notes sent by 
people under investigation.

An FBI representative would not say whether Carnivore has been, or will 
ever be, used to monitor wireless communications.

Keith Waryas, a wireless analyst with market watcher IDC, said that even if 
federal officials do snoop on wireless e-mails, they're going to be 
disappointed with what they find.

Although businesses are starting to use wireless networks to send sensitive 
e-mails, it's still a small audience. Wireless consumers such as cell phone 
users are even less apt right now to use such modern services as sending 
wireless e-mails, he said.

Though there has been some movement by criminal enterprises to use the 
Internet, that same push hasn't happened yet on wireless, Waryas believes.

"I don't think the world will come to a standstill," he said. "I don't 
think guys running a drug operation on the corner will have a WAP interface 
(a type of wireless network) for their distributors."

He also pointed out that hackers already have broken into some wireless 
networks. This week marked the release of a product called AirSnort, which 
lets hackers intercept some wireless data transmissions.

"When it comes to wireless, you're talking about broadcasting something. My 
guess is it doesn't take a rocket scientist to intercept those 
transmissions," Waryas said.

There is a bill before Congress that would require the attorney general and 
the FBI director to submit a detailed report on the use of surveillance 
systems, including Carnivore.

http://news.excite.com/news/zd/010824/18/carnivore-to-add

"It is only with the heart that one can see rightly;  what is essential is 
invisible to the eye."
-Antoine de Saint-Exupery

"I'm astounded by people who want to "know" the universe when it's hard 
enough to find your way around Chinatown."
-Woody Allen

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Tina's alter-ego experience

Just a little note that I didn't discover the space. It was the location of
my first outdoor party back in September of 99. The party was called
Divination and had Telene and others there. I think Anthony (Alias) was a
part of it, but since I was so new to things at the time I'm not sure. The
space was actually a backup space since the first one got busted at Golden
Gate Fields. Fred aka Smyl-E directed everyone out to this location. It was
a great night with a small crowd and things looked a hell of a lot different
back then. All that construction that you guys saw out there has only
occured in the last month. I always wanted to have another party out there
since I've never heard about a party happening at that location since. It
worked out this time only because everyone that came followed the rules. If
anyone were to try and host a party there without the level of paranoia that
we had it would surely get shutdown and another space lost.

Fuzzy pants and me are a rare moment. To my knowledge there are no pictures
of me in full candy and fuzzy pants so... HA! I guess that means it never
happened. Those pants actually kicked major ass and it's scary how well they
fit me. Thanks to my Lyds for letting me borrow them. Fun times Fun Times.
So what was going on in the bulldozer cab later that night?? Looked like
foggy windows to me... Kept hearing some reverse sounds goin off too. Crazy
shit yo! Glad to see so many people come out in true AEC form. I missed so
many people out there from what I heard. I had to deal with keeping shifts
going and answering a constant barrage of phone calls. Let's see: Brian
Bellendorf (sp) was there and I still haven't met him. Anthony (Alias) and
Bruce (Uphonic) were rumored to be there as well and I wish I had seen
Anthony so I could verify that he played the original party there. Sarillion
I thought I saw you, but it was dark and I couldn't tell. Migurski you ran
away to the top of the bulldozer with your girl and then POOF you were gone.
Who else did I miss there?? I was running around in an orange vest and black
fuzzy pants with red stars. Not my normal garb by far, but fun none the
less. Tina, Christle, Patrice, Alida, all in *raver* garb was great. Totally
caught me off gaurd to see them dressed like that! Lydia was my sanity for
the night. Had a nice time out in the car with the sound turned down a bit.
Needed some chill/close time and you seemed to as well. Well I think that
beyond what I've already said and what has been said it's all been said.
Horrible sentence, sorry. Looking forward to next time!

ryan.bailey
sninesix.design
www.viberation.com/ryan

short detour since 80 was closed, and i finally make it out to the space....
had to pass the gate once cuz of an oncomming car... unfortunately, i have
day running lights on my car, so i couldn't turn off my headlights all the
way.... and jason was all super candy, and miki too.. it was great...
>
> so the music hadn't quite started yet, but i found amber right away, and
ryan was on the phone, and it was dark and i could berely see anything, and
then i hear christle's voice... so we went back to my car where i changed
into my alter ego.. i had wanted to take it a little more to the extreme,
but i realized i gave away all my big pants and other raver-esque clothes..
but i brought it on full force with the candy.. i don't think i ever wore as
much of it in one night.... i even revived my butterfly barrettes that i was
never seen without back in the day...
>

and trying to find all the constellations.. ben, what was the name of the
meteor shower that was happening again? (this was the reason for all the
shooting stars)
>

typical of them, i loved it.. i think it shows some true level of skill when
a dj can pick up records that don't really know in a genre they never play,
and totally have fun with it! amber, shane, jason, andy.. you all did i
great job (i missed ira and michael's sets.. =( i had to go home cuz of work
in the morning)...
>

saw.. especially ryan wearing lydia's fuzzy pants! but osby definately had
the most alter-ego thing going on....

did meet totally rock! Natalie and i bonded working the gate in the morning
and it was really cool to play guess the constelation and steall wheat thins
from christle, i finally re-met atom128, hopefully you'll remember me next
time =) and i met the nomadic dj... you are so cool.. i wish i could have
traveled even half as much as you have... i'm not sure if the other people i
met are on the list, but i know these three are! but if you saw a
semi-candied out girl offering everyone herbal crack (mah whong) earlier in
the night, that was me =)

From sfraves-return-71943-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Mon Aug 27 02:36:05 2001

From: "Alida Brandenburg" <one_little_etoile@hotmail.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Bcc: 
Date: Sun, 26 Aug 2001 19:35:34 -0700
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <F57FlF8HGmCvoXM7e0C00010adb@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 27 Aug 2001 02:35:35.0189 (UTC) FILETIME=[F3230C50:01C12EA0]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] -Recovery- AEC/Otherworld

My god what a weekend. Friday night I head over to Becca's with Veronica for 
an AEC pre-party meeting. Wow, what a flashback. I defintely felt like I was 
seven again meeting up with friends to go trick-or-treating, especially with 
all the buzzing anticipation. My god, Jason as a candy kid... the 
resemblence to the fish boi in Groove was stricking. And Osby, damn it, I 
was not a go-go dancer, I was H.orny J.ail B.ait C.rew!
     Ten o'clock rolls around and I move upstairs to do the voicemail. So 
I'm taking my sweet time giving out directions (I hate when they are given 
out too fast) when I get cut off less than half way through. Damn. Try 
again. Damn. Time for a rewrite. Try again. Damn. Try again. DAMN! Finally 
got it after I don't know how many times. I'm *so* sorry for those of you 
who had to call so many times. I feel your pain!
     So Becca and I head out to the mappoint and wait. That was interesting 
to say the least. Me with my huge white platforms, knee-high socks, short 
skirt and hair in pigtails was apparently an invitation for harassment. "Eh, 
yo... straight up, me and my bois are just looking for some pussy... you 
think you could help a brother out? We have money." Riiiight....
     So as we're standing there Becca, Aaron, Natalie and I notice some 
lovely young fellows with very orignal raver gear on: big pants, candy, 
binkies, visors... I didn't spot them a mile away or anything! And it didn't 
help that they were gathered around their car blasting sandstorm... eesh... 
so I walk over to talk to these bois to figure out what their bucket is. 
"Are you guys ravers?" "Yeah!!" "So just curious, why do you rave?" Cuz.... 
just cuz!" "Cuz why?" "Cuz... I dunno! It's fun!... Do you know where we can 
get any E?" Oh dear god... "How often do you do E?" I asked. He laughed and 
looked away. "Don't ask me that!!" "Why not?"  "Because I do it soooo much! 
I don't even know how often I do it!" He then asked me again if I knew where 
he could get some E. I talked with them for a bit longer, pleading with him 
and his friends to try to go to a party sober and just dance. "Isn't the 
music enough?" I asked. "I can't just go.. and just... dance!" He gave me a 
baffled look as though I was suggesting he cut his mother's heart out with a 
pencil. I had had enough and was about to retreat when he pulled out his 
mangled lighter. "Like my lighter?" "What did you do to it?" I asked. "Well 
I was rolling really hard the other night-" I cut him off. "And you chewed 
it...?" I was afraid of what the answer would be. "Yeah!!" he said 
enthusiastically. I walked away. Damn... I forget how bad it is sometimes.
     So anyways, work the mappoint with my littler blue ear muffs until 
12:30 then run errands with Becca (chaos!! But we did come up with the HJBC 
slogan: "Sometimes I'm goodie goodie, right now I'm naughty naughty. Good 
call Becca!). Finally get out to the site to find it just getting underway. 
I hardly recognized Amber when she came up to say hallo. And Patrice as a 
thug.. damn.. that took me way to long to gain any sort of recognition. But 
I must agree, Osby took the cake because he stayed in character the whole 
night. There were so many listers there I would have loved to meet! I guess 
I should have been a little more sociable.
     Music was fucking great. The whole party was such a mixed up 
experiment, espcially having DJs spin what they don't normally spin, but it 
all fell into place beautifully. Andy's set was bootaylicious. What was that 
track called with a woman saying something like, "Work me good," or 
something to that effect? And then the music cuts and she says something 
like, "Damn, where's the music? It's like waiting for a man to get it up!" 
That definitely got my ass shaking. Oh, highlight of the night- Andy 
volunteering out of nowhere to spin at my 18th birthday. Damn. That party is 
gonna be epic.
     Thank you to *everyone* who gave us donations. As I walked around 
asking for them with my basket I was greeted by many more than willing to 
help people. Again, thank you. You're the reason we do this and we want to 
*keep* doing this. Any contribution helps, even nickles and dimes! Who was 
that who gave me those saying it was their laundry money? That was cute. : )
     I have pictures yet to be devoloped and I have no idea when I'll post 
them considering I have a 6100 Mac (yes, it should be in a museum) that 
can't do anything... but I'll try to get them up when I get a chance. There 
should be an awesome one of the return of the stickman dancing on the 
tractor if it came out right.
     To sum up, I had an awesome night. Shane, Amber... thanks for stopping 
to shake my hand and telling me how proud you were. *sniffle* I'm sorry.. I 
promised I wouldn't cry! I'm getting feklmept (sp?)... I'll give you a 
topic... Rohde Island- neither a road, nor an island. Discuss!.... There, 
I'm betta now. But really, it was truly touching.
     I had to leave at 5 because I had a show to catch early the next day 
(btw... Aida is a terrible musiclal. All glitz and glam, no substance. This 
is the first play I've seen that I've not enjoyed), so I sadly missed out on 
Terry's fashionably late appearance and Michael passing out the roof of his 
car, but I am happy to say I went home beaming. I have to take a moment to 
say to my SFR planners/AEC kids that I cherish all of you and what we've 
shared and created together. It's truly magical. : )

Oh, did anyone find my handcuffs and HJBC sign during clean up? I forgot to 
grab them.

Soooo slept, went to Aida (gag) and call up Shane about Otherworld. After a 
bit of convincing from him I decide to motivate myself to go. I am *so* 
happy I did. That was probably one of the best parties I've been to in quite 
some time. Music was *excellent* ( I heard my new favorite track for the 
first time since FnF, I wish I knew the name!), people were joyous and warm 
(saw Martin again, hallo!), room to dance, awesome space, mesmorizing 
visuals.... damn. Plus I got to be The Red Stick Girl for a bit. Thanks 
Michael! Oh, and Mr. Andy W... you missed out on my ruffled socks. ; )

Alida
=HJBC=
"Sometimes I'm goodie goodie, right now I'm naughty naughty..."

Message-ID: <001701c12ea3$c1176f50$a3d9fc9e@sauoq>
From: "A. Nonymous" <snowhuoue@mindspring.com>
To: <BodhiInSF@aol.com>, <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
References: <d.19c88d8b.28ba8dde@aol.com>
Date: Sun, 26 Aug 2001 19:55:37 -0700
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Priority: 3
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 5.00.2919.6700
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V5.00.2919.6700
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Question # 8: Should we cooperate/rebel with authorities over drugs?


Bodhi, most of your questions have been good thought provoking exercises,
but this one strikes me as a bit naive.

Should we cooperate with or rebel against authorities over drugs? Who are
"we"? Some among us take drugs. They are already rebelling against authority
though that almost certainly isn't the reason they choose to ingest the
substances they do. Some among us neither take nor distribute nor condone
drug use. They are already cooperating with the authorities though that most
likely has little to do with why they choose to abstain. The truth is that
drug use has nothing to do directly with the rave scene. Long after the last
rave has been thrown, people will gather to dance and some among them will
take drugs.

You ask if we should "allow" the DEA to do this or "allow" the police to do
that, but the fact is that they are already either allowed or disallowed to
take action  based on the laws that exist. The ACLU is challenging their
actions as being illegal in some cases already.

I think the question you have asked hides the real issue. The authorities
are using drugs as an excuse to crack down on people gathering peacefully to
dance. And yes... that is something we should rebel against.





----- Original Message -----
From: <BodhiInSF@aol.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Sunday, August 26, 2001 10:37 AM
Subject: [sfraves] Question # 8: Should we cooperate/rebel with authorities

> Should the rave scene cooperate with authorities over their anti drug
> policies? Do you think this will in the long run save our right to dance?
> Should we allow the DEA to impliment censorship (forbiding pacifiers, glow
> sticks, etc,) over our parties? And should we allow police authorities to
> dangle the infamous crack house law and other anti rave laws over us as
being
> the price we will have to pay to have a scene?
>  Or, do you think the rave scene should be part of a large movement of
people
> and organizations that believe drugs should be legalized, especially quasi
> harmless drugs like E, psyedelics and pot, and are fighting for the right
of
> adults to be able to injest what ever they want as long as they dont hurt
> anyone else, and not always cooperate with officials believing even in the
> short run we will have our parties shut down and have anti rave and crack
> house laws thrown at us to stop us from dancing?
>  Which do you believe, and why?
>
>  Peace, love and hugs! Bodhi ^ _ ^

                Before i begin, id like to let you know that im only 16, =
a junior in High School, and haven't been to a rave. Don't think i dont =
know the music because i live for it.


        Concerning drugs and the raves. I personally don't take/do any =
sort of drugs, nor do i promote its use. However, i really don't crae =
what others do aslong as they don't harm themselves. But to a larger =
extent if the drugs they take make them harm themselves without them =
knowing that is serious.=20
    Concerning the cooperation with authorities, i believ this should be =
done. First off the whole rave-Drug deal/subject should be stopped!! We =
music lovers tshould try to get raves excepted by themselves. Drugs are =
a totaly separate issue, and isn't the point of the rave to come for =
themusic? notthe drugs. So if you want to legalize drugs and yada yada =
yada( by theway the Economist Magazine came out with a amazing report on =
why legalization of drugs would actually be good. www.economist.com) do =
so but dont tie it to legalizing and freeing all the raves. As the =
beastie boys say, "Fight for your right.... toooo =
paaaaaaaaaarrrrrrteeeeeyyyy!"! and then if you want legalize drugs.


I hope this has helped ad more perpestive to the issue. If you disagree =
let me know, kindly please. I don't mean to offend anyone, and hope i =
haven't aswell.=20

Subject: RE: [sfraves] -Recovery- AEC/Otherworld

Lydia W is right--luckily I don't have to spend two hours writing about AEC
coz a lot of it has been said!!  All I want to say tho:

a)  The image I got when I rounded that corner, and saw the silhoette of the
huge dozer with people dancing on it and around it, the jungle permeating
the air, is never going to leave my head

b)  (Please keep in mind I am blond)  Osby actually DID fool me when I asked
him if it was Osby!  I saw him and recognised the hair, and was like "hey
Osby!" and he was like "I'm not Osby.  My name is Osric."  In turn, i was
like "Would you happen to be named Osby on occasion, you alternate ego of
Osby, you!" and he very seriousely said "No. Sorry"  At that point I got
terribly embarrased at talking to the wrong person, stated that I was
terribly sorry but I mistook him for his hair, and left him alone to be
disappointed with his life.

c)  I was glad to meet up with y'all!  Osby sorry you fooled me so well!
Good on ya for staying in character tho.  Good to see Jeff, Aaron, Nathalie,
and all them, in addition to meeting Brooke and Jen (who I now dub Generator
Jen from now on lol).  I even bumped into my friend Jerry, who is part of my
old crew in LA, who i had no idea was at AEC!!!  Oh and Mike the Red Stick
Man you were AWESOME in your appearence today.  Will you be appearing in
full stick attire again anytime soon?  It was also really cool to finally
meet Amber and Shane in person--you're both as cool peeps as u are DJ's =)
And everybody else I met who I can't remember due to my lack of sleep from
this CRAZY weekend, drop me a line =)

Peace!

.:nomadic:.
www.nomadicDJ.com

Subject: [sfraves] one of those silly reviews...for SOund Asylum

hiya,

didnt see any reviews for SOund Assylum,hmmm i wonder why *sarcasm, that
one commercial rave that, that one dj put on...whats her name...the one
people always talk about...the one who just changed her name...i forget
her name, oh well, she IS just a PERSON anyways, not a god, the music is.
, so i thought i'd give it a review...a 5 out of 10, and im being
nice...vibe is everything, and people OD'ing (yes, there was more than
one now...a few unreported (can people start being more resonsable??)
with the combination of a 110 degree venue which is stupid to let happen
since almost ALL od's are because of being OVERHEATED...Can we say RENT,
BARROW, or BUY a commercial fan or two if the venue isnt ventilated
properly, i mean, it DOES mean the prevention of stupid people doing too
many drugs from dying, and certain people with certain attitudes kinda
make the whole damn place seem like another one of those silly commercial
raves where people think their better than one another, its something
thats gettin a little cliche and i dont like it...I do say though, that
it was a nice set up so good job folks...and i hope you had a good
time...im so glad they found those ladders they needed, im sure that all
three of the people who spent forever getting them in the frickin sun all
day and then drove 3 hours to bring them got thanked  cuz they did do it
to stay loyal to the scene and help out, NOT to get in for free, i hope
they know.....im sure denise was greatful for that....she doesnt have to
say thank you, her gratitude is enough....*eyes roll

(oO Jowy - JADED (for many a reasons)- kandy -  kidd oOo)
*~*Dance, Listen, Love, Live*~*
"Live like there is no tomarrow, work like you don't need money, Love
like you have
never been hurt, dance like everybody is watching, and trainwreck like
everyone's listening...!"
Jaded with ware and tear, but always a kandy kidd at
heart....*JowyJadedKandyKid*   :  )

From sfraves-return-71964-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Mon Aug 27 14:24:12 2001
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-71964-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 7783 invoked by uid 1104); 27 Aug 2001 14:24:12 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 7773 invoked from network); 27 Aug 2001 14:24:12 -0000
Message-ID: <20010827142410.43263.qmail@web20104.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Mon, 27 Aug 2001 07:24:10 -0700 (PDT)
From: Booty Shaker <shakedatass20@yahoo.com>
To: Dan <djdan1922@hotmail.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <OE41p2T0apMHi0SYNIP000068ef@hotmail.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Question # 8: Should we cooperate/rebel with authorities over drugs?

I agree with your point here that raves should be
accepted without drugs, but it's a little unrealistic.
 You really can't stop people from doing drugs at
raves.  If they want to do it, they are going to find
a way.  You can, however, *educate* people on the
wonderful aspects of the scene aside from drugs.  We
can also try to educate the media, parents, and local
law enforcement as to why raves are wonderful.  This
is usually done by highlighting why we love the music,
the culture, and dancing.

When I decided to tell my parents about my rave
addiction, I started off slowly.  I had them listen to
my CD's and showed them some flyers.  I then would
always talk about how I would dance all night.  And
then, I watched some news broadcasts with them about
raves and explained that while I personally don't use
drugs, it does go on there.  I also explained that the
media tends to overexaggerate for effect.  

Drugs are a part of our generation, not necessarily
our culture.  Drug use goes on at any club, concert,
or party, regardless of whether it's rave related or
not. 

The answer is not necessarily to get drugs out of our
scene, since that is a bit unrealistic, but it is to
get the media and law enforcement to focus less on our
drug use, and more on our cultural importance.

    Date: Mon, 27 Aug 2001 03:18:28 -0400
    From: "DJ Entropy" <djentropy@mindspring.com>

As you may have noticed, I probably won't be doing the Track Of The Day
on
the weekends, because a lot of people don't read their email on the
weekends, and I'm also busy as hell on the weekends too, so deal with
it  =P

Anyway, hope you enjoyed last weeks bizness, today is something MUCh
different, and much newer, and someone who I am obsessed with AGAIN (he
just gets better and better everytime I hear his stuff).  Not "old
skool",
but I never wanted to do JUST old skool for this anyway.  =)  So here
goes:

Squarepusher - Come On My Selector - 1998 (Nothing Records)

http://djentropy.home.mindspring.com/Squarepusher_-_Come_On_My_Selector.mp3

(watch the wraparound)

Tom Jenkinson is my hero.  As Squarepusher, he simply just makes the
coolest fucking music in the world.  It's really too bad he cancelled
his
US tour, because I would have probably gone here and to NYC and wherever

else I could get to to see him, hehehe.

Anyway, this tune is off of "Big Loada", and I have the EP on vinyl,
which
has 5 of the tunes on it.  I actually played out two of his tunes last
night, and fuck, his stuff is so wikked on a system.  Thsi tune was one
of
the first things I hade heard from him, back when it came out, and it's
fucken insane.  Never has the Lyn break sounded so good!  Woop!

He plays all the basslines himself on a bass guitar, so I heard, and
besides that, this man can program a beat like no other.  If every genre

incorporated this much drumwork, I would run out of money, cause I would

buy everything that came out, heh.

Anyway, this tune rules, so turn it up loud and confuse the hell out of
everyone.  :)

Enjoy!

yep yep!

my company, Abduction Productions, is who produced
that CD.  it's the second such album to come from the
SoCal-Raves list.

for those interested in hearing some samples of the
CD, and possibly picking one up - surf over to my
preview website at http://www.invert.com/~scrcomp002

these willing be showing up in record stores in the
bay area in the next couple weeks, so if you don't get
one online, ask at your favorite record store. 

anyway, marketing this disc right now is my primary
duty, but i've been thinking that after the first of
the year, i'd like to bring this project to the
SFRaves list.  now that i've produced one, i'm certain
that i could produce another.  it's just a matter of
having the resources available and such.

so those who have been working on tracks and who might
be interested, consider this early warning.  :D

in the mean time, please check out the previews on the
website, order a copy of the disc online and tell yoru
favorite record stores that they need to stock this
album!!

Subject: [sfraves] [BSP] SCR.COMP.002 now available!!

Abduction Productions proudly presents:
*******************************************************
                     SCR.COMP.002
    more music from the SoCal-Raves Internet Group
*******************************************************

it is with great pride that i announce the public
release of the must-have underground album of 2001.

10 tracks of original music from members of the
SoCal-Raves list, presented for your enjoyment.  the
music ranges from old school rave to downtempo to acid
breaks to drum & bass to trance to electro and beyond.

you can listen to previews of the tracks and pick up a
copy online at 

http://www.invert.com/~scrcomp002

if you're in southern California, you can currently
get your copy exclusively at Dr. Freecloud's Mixing
Lab in Costa Mesa (http://www.drfreeclouds.com)

other retailers will have them soon!  if your favorite
record store doesn't have them, tell 'em they need to
order it!  i'll be happy to hook 'em up.

Subject: RE: [sfraves] Psytrance

if you are 21, you can hit up thump at 550, and there you will get fliers of
some of the really good parties, there arent too many psy parties advertised
openly. You can also look out for more Neural Enlightenment's being put on
by Michael liu and neuroscience. Thump would be your best bet to get
yourself into the scene.

www.thump-radio.com

rest on his site for those who want a copy.

saw it as a person(s)' effort to put together a CD
(which Noah did suggest doing up here for SFR) for the
community, by the community.  It does take effort to
put something like that together, and he does deserve
to be compensated, if that is what is agreed on.  

I think it's a good idea, and I'd be willing to
purchase it. (SFR CD)

From sfraves-return-71989-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Mon Aug 27 20:22:07 2001
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-71989-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 2703 invoked by uid 1104); 27 Aug 2001 20:22:06 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 2585 invoked from network); 27 Aug 2001 20:22:04 -0000
Message-ID: <20010827202200.50731.qmail@web14608.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Mon, 27 Aug 2001 13:22:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: Uncle Noah <unclenoah@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <20010827193541.82763.qmail@web10902.mail.yahoo.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] [BSP] SCR.COMP.002 now available!!

the bottom line is this:

it costs money to buy the gear to make the tracks.
it costs money to license the tracks from the artists.
it costs money to get the artwork done.
it costs money to have the album mastered.
it costs money to have the album replicated.
it costs money to have the album packaged.
it costs money to ship the album to people.
and it costs money to have a legal business license.

this isn't some
burned-off-my-computer-using-music-that-i-stole-off-napster
DJ mix.  this is a professionally-produced compilation
of original music that people invested their talent,
time and money into making.

and as far as attacking my business practices in terms
of what percentage the artists are receiving off the
sales, i've got two words for you:  free enterprise. 
 
all artists appearing on the CD were compensated for
their work and signed legal contracts with Abduction
Productions.  everything was fair, everything was
agreed upon and everything is 100% legit.  

which is more than i can say for the majority of dj
mixes that most of us own.

when you play a DJ gig at a rave, do make sure you
send a portion of the money you get paid to each of
the artists who's records you spin?  have you legally
licensed every track on every mixtape and CD that
you've produced?  are you making sure to submit your
quarterly statements to the agencies that handle the
licensing of those tracks so they know how many
recorded units you sold, how many times their tracks
were played in open-air environment and how many times
their tracks were broadcasted?  what city is your DJ
business registered in?  what's your state of
California resale permit number?  i'm willing to bet
that the general business practices of the typical
bedroom DJ are far shadier than mine if you really
want to go toe-to-toe on it.  

if someone out there wants to make a freebie album, i
say more power to you.  i'd be very interested in
finding out who you wind up using for gear, software,
art, printing, replication, mastering, assembly,
shipping, business licensing, and event planning
since, in your plan, they'll do their work for free so
you can have the joy of handing out your albums for
free.  

if these people exist, i'd really *really* like to
meet them because i've got some great project that i
just don't have the $$ to produce, but if i could do
it all for free, we'd have some great stuff.

the day i can run a project like this for free, i'll
glady hand them out for free.  until then we live in a
capitalist system where everything costs something.  

*sigh*

__________________________________________________

Subject: Re: [sfraves] one of those silly reviews...for SOund Asylum

ooxkandykidxoo wrote:


> since almost ALL od's are because of being OVERHEATED...

Let's be clear here. An overdose is just that. It results from taking too
large a dose. Overheating is a real and common problem. It is, in fact, much
more common than overdoses are. (We are talking about E, right?) So, I
believe that there were several people that overheated. I find it doubtful
that there were any overdoses.

Let's keep the parties safe people! Free water! Good ventilation! Chill
rooms! And let's not feed the anti-rave propoganda machines by mistakenly
seeing "overdoses" where there are none.

Kimba, 

Something like: 

Order Allow,Deny
Allow from all
Deny from 207.46.197.100

And, if I may bitch a little after answering... 

A. This isn't a question for "linux headz". 
B. This isn't the right forum. 
C. This should have been prefixed with NRR.
D. The documentation is clear. 

Check http://httpd.apache.org/docs/mod/mad_access.html

Subject: [sfraves] Behold (my new demo CD)

Yo Sfravers,
           Well, here it is--my first demo CD made in my time in SF:
Behold.  It's a dark-ish mix of trance, progressive, and a tiny bit of
darkwave that sounds kinda-well-different, and ranges from mellow to hard.
Some of the artists on the disc:  Lexos, Cosmic Gate, Epilepsy, Apoptigma
Berserk, Tekara, Niels Van Gogh, Muse, Roland Klinkenberg, and Vicious
Circles.  Anyways, if you are a promoter, DJ, or enthusiast, and would like
a copy, please email me back personally with a mailing address (or hit me up
at any event I'm going to and i might have a couple in my bag).  If you are
a DJ, i would LOVE to also get a copy of your promo CD or tape in exchange
=)

	Also, for those who I promised a promo to earlier on, sorry I'm so
late--after I got back from the UK, i got very busy, and that combined with
a computer disaster held me up for a bit.  Enjoy!

	Oh yea, and if you know any other promoters or peeps who want it, send'em
over to me.  I'll also be streaming it on my site www.nomadicDJ.com in the
near future, if you want to be nice and help save a little of the CD burning
for me =) (and sign my guestbook, of course!)

Looking forward to hearing from you guys soon

Peace!

.:nomadic:.
www.nomadicDJ.com

From: 	Ari Gordon-Schlosberg [mailto:regs@nebcorp.com]

To:	sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject:	Re: [sfraves] NRR: IE OR NETSCAPRE 6.0

[Sir Dapy Of Dorkdom <dapydork@yahoo.com>]
>
> People tend to give Microsoft a bad rap when in reality Windows 3.11 was
> stable considering what it really was, which is a first version.  Sure you
> will see people claiming to have copies of Windows 1 and 2, but in reality
> they were developer previews and internal test applications and not really
> for everyday use.  So for being a first version it was pretty stable and I
> think most of the problems that people had with it were related to
> configuration, driver issues and the fact that people just did not take
the
> time or effort to learn to configure and tweak the system properly.  Those
> who did will tell you the same thing I am telling you.  As for Windows 95,
> it added more features and was very stable, even more stable then Windows
> 3.11 the only problem is that people who had older hardware and unstable
> Windows 3.11 setups wanted the upgrade to work miracles and fix all of
their
> problems and it didn't.  It wasn't designed to do that.  Windows 95b was
> actually even more stable then Windows 95 or even 95a because it did not
> support upgrades and had more drivers.  Windows 98 built upon the
stability
> of Windows 95, but added the integration of Windows and Internet Explorer
> and there were problems with the upgrade so once again the uninformed
blamed
> the OS, not their hardware or setup.  Windows 98 Second Edition fixed a
lot
> of the stability problems with the IE 4 / Win Explorer merger and led way
to
> Windows ME which was basically created for the machine manufacturers so
that
> they could have better rollout tools and an easier way to add all of the
> security and service pack and hot fix updates released by Microsoft over
the
> year since the release of Windows 98.  It also started using a new driver
> model closer to that of Windows NT/2K.

This is a totally ridiculous paragraph.  I'm sorry, I don't even believe
that this is the forum to have this discussion, but I can't let something
this incorrect pass for the truth around here.

Windows is not stable.  Period. End of sentence.  It hasn't been until
recently that Microsoft has even thought of it as any kind of priority to
deal with any kind of stability issues in their operating systems or even
their applications.

When people like myself talk about stability, we're not talking hours or
days.  We're not talking weeks.  We're talking months, at the least.
What's the longest you've had a Windows box of any flavor go 60 days
without needing to be rebooted?  NT and 2K may approach this kind of
stability, but the 9x/Me series could not go a month without crashing.

You want to talk real stability?  A real OS will be stable enough,
pay close attention here, that a machine running it will stay up
through an entire Microsoft product cycle.  I know of machines in people's
bedrooms that have run for two years or more without a reboot.

In my experience with these pieces of software, I've learned a thing or
two.  I know more about Windows than most people who support it, and I know
about Unix than most people who support (Ah! The joys of being an
engineer!).

Do you know that in Canada, the highest tax bracket of their tax systems
starts pretty low, probably around $75,000/year?  Do know that their
highest tax bracket is 51%?  That's right, more than half of your income
goes to the government as tax.  That's a about a third more than,
percentage-wise than you would pay in the United States.

What's my point?  Saying that Windows is stable is like saying that
Canadians don't have high taxes: it's nuts.  In a world where all
definitions like this are relative, stable is not the way to describe
Windows.  You clearly either a) have no experience running a truly stable
operating system or b) have some other agenda that's making you lie.

/ari, still recovering from the very fucking cool Urban Wasteland last
night.

--
Ari							there is no spoon

Subject: Re: [sfraves] [BSP] SCR.COMP.002 now available!!

I realize stuff costs money. I realize the time/effort/paperwork to do all 
this legit. And I wasn't "attacking" your business practices (although the 
"free enterprise" defense doesn't mean much... people get screwed all the 
time in the name of "free enterprise"). I didn't even know that it was you 
personally putting it out, but that's neither here nor there. I was saying, 
in response to "support the artists etc" that I don't know who's getting 
what.

But I'm not posting this to get into legal semantics, or who deserves what 
money for what work.

All I'm saying is this: You're right. We do live in a capitalist system. If 
you want to sell something, you're free to do that. But so long as some are 
charging for what can be found for free, those that are charging are going 
to have a harder time getting their stuff heard, especially when the artists 
are relatively unheard of. If I got the license for all the tracks in my 
promo and made a snazzy CD insert, mastered it, etc, would you pay me $15 
for it?

-=Chris=-



>From: Uncle Noah <unclenoah@yahoo.com>
>To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] [BSP] SCR.COMP.002 now available!!
>Date: Mon, 27 Aug 2001 13:22:00 -0700 (PDT)
>
>the bottom line is this:
>
>it costs money to buy the gear to make the tracks.
>it costs money to license the tracks from the artists.
>it costs money to get the artwork done.
>it costs money to have the album mastered.
>it costs money to have the album replicated.
>it costs money to have the album packaged.
>it costs money to ship the album to people.
>and it costs money to have a legal business license.
>
>this isn't some
>burned-off-my-computer-using-music-that-i-stole-off-napster
>DJ mix.  this is a professionally-produced compilation
>of original music that people invested their talent,
>time and money into making.
>
>and as far as attacking my business practices in terms
>of what percentage the artists are receiving off the
>sales, i've got two words for you:  free enterprise.
>
>all artists appearing on the CD were compensated for
>their work and signed legal contracts with Abduction
>Productions.  everything was fair, everything was
>agreed upon and everything is 100% legit.
>
>which is more than i can say for the majority of dj
>mixes that most of us own.
>
>when you play a DJ gig at a rave, do make sure you
>send a portion of the money you get paid to each of
>the artists who's records you spin?  have you legally
>licensed every track on every mixtape and CD that
>you've produced?  are you making sure to submit your
>quarterly statements to the agencies that handle the
>licensing of those tracks so they know how many
>recorded units you sold, how many times their tracks
>were played in open-air environment and how many times
>their tracks were broadcasted?  what city is your DJ
>business registered in?  what's your state of
>California resale permit number?  i'm willing to bet
>that the general business practices of the typical
>bedroom DJ are far shadier than mine if you really
>want to go toe-to-toe on it.
>
>if someone out there wants to make a freebie album, i
>say more power to you.  i'd be very interested in
>finding out who you wind up using for gear, software,
>art, printing, replication, mastering, assembly,
>shipping, business licensing, and event planning
>since, in your plan, they'll do their work for free so
>you can have the joy of handing out your albums for
>free.
>
>if these people exist, i'd really *really* like to
>meet them because i've got some great project that i
>just don't have the $$ to produce, but if i could do
>it all for free, we'd have some great stuff.
>
>the day i can run a project like this for free, i'll
>glady hand them out for free.  until then we live in a
>capitalist system where everything costs something.
>
>*sigh*
>
