Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: IE OR NETSCAPRE 6.0

[Sir Dapy Of Dorkdom <dapydork@yahoo.com>]
> You are right, I forgot in my infinite wisdom that you're the worlds most
> knowledgeable IT person and that you know more then the most if not all of
> the IT people who support Windows and *nix in the corporate world.  I'm
> sorry I didn't realize you were on the list and that you would unmask me as
> the charlatan that I am.  I  beg thee please keep the knowledge that I am a
> lowly baker, who's sole function in life is to put the crème filling in
> cupcakes who only plays with computer's in his spare time.

Looks to me like you think that I was flaming you.  I was not.  I was
merely pointing out that calling Windows stable is just not true in the big
picture.  Think of a small African nation, run by a string of dictators.  A
new one rises to power who is not quite as bloodthirsty as the last and
easier on the people.  One resident of this nation says to the other: "Ah,
it's nice to finally have some freedom around here."  Locally, things have
improved, but they sure ain't free.

> 
> You're an engineer eh?  Know more about Windows then those supporting it eh?
> What certifications do you have that say this to the world?  Does any *nix
> vendor or Microsoft or any OS venders recognize you as a seasoned veteran
> with some kind of certification or award?
> 

It looks to me like you're trying to do some dick-swinging.  No thanks.
First of all, this list is not the place for it.  Second of all, I have
nothing to prove to you; I'm very secure in what I know and my place in the
both the larger world and the smaller tech world.  But let me answer you
questions:

1) Yes, I'm an engineer.
2) Yes, I know more about Windows than the average desktop support
tech.  I don't claim to be a Windows professional.
3) I have no certifications or awards.

Cerifications and awards are a whole different discussion that I would more
than happy to have with you, but here's the short version: MCSE, CCNA,
CCIE, all that stuff does not tell anything about how good someone is at
their job.  In the technology sector, we tend to be in the business of
solving problems.  None of those certifications actually teaches you
anything except information that you would need to solve problems with
specific product.  Problem solving is about synthesis.  All that
information is available when you need it.  It's what you *do* with the
information that makes you good (or not).

I know a lot of people who are very, very good at their jobs, both on the
Unix side and the Windows.  The people that I would call "good"?  None of
them have any certifications.  They don't need it.

If you'd like to continue this discussion, I'd love to share my viewpoint
with you.  If you'd like to flame me, go ahead, I don't really give a fuck.
But either way, let's take it off the list.

-- 
Ari							there is no spoon

that at least their training is good.  But have you seen the recent reports
from SANS indicating that MS certified professions lack significant areas of
expertise in even basic security implimentations, making them almost

Subject: Re: [sfraves] NRR: Apache question (was Re: [sfraves] Calling all linux headz -- need help with .htaccess)

["A. Nonymous" <snowhuoue@mindspring.com>]
> 
> Kimba, 
> 
> Something like: 
> 
> Order Allow,Deny
> Allow from all
> Deny from 207.46.197.100

That should actually be:

Order Deny,Allow
Deny from <the-ip-you're-trying-to-block>
Allow from all


> A. This isn't a question for "linux headz". 

No, but a good place to start.

> B. This isn't the right forum. 

That is very true.

> C. This should have been prefixed with NRR.

Also true.

> D. The documentation is clear. 
> 
> Check http://httpd.apache.org/docs/mod/mad_access.html

It's clear if you get the right URL:

http://httpd.apache.org/docs/mod/mod_access.html

:)

Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 93811 invoked from network); 27 Aug 2001 21:51:03 -0000
Message-ID: <20010827215100.33077.qmail@web14603.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Mon, 27 Aug 2001 14:51:00 -0700 (PDT)
From: Uncle Noah <unclenoah@yahoo.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <F77IRZH1NcXEmMtpbHX00000d99@hotmail.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] [BSP] SCR.COMP.002 now available!!


--- Chris V <baronvonvarady@hotmail.com> wrote:
> I realize stuff costs money. I realize the
> time/effort/paperwork to do all 
> this legit. And I wasn't "attacking" your business
> practices (although the 
> "free enterprise" defense doesn't mean much...
> people get screwed all the 
> time in the name of "free enterprise"). 

simmer down now, newbie.  inferring that i'm out to
screw artists isn't exactly PLURry, now, is it?  i
think there are more than a few folks on this list who
can attest to my moral standing and would be willing
to advocate on my behalf that my efforts in The Scene
aren't to screw anyone.  

> All I'm saying is this: You're right. We do live in
> a capitalist system. If 
> you want to sell something, you're free to do that.

> But so long as some are 
> charging for what can be found for free, those that
> are charging are going 
> to have a harder time getting their stuff heard,

so you're advocating criminal/illegal activity since
it's just simply easier than actually paying for a
legit CD.

it's easier to smash the window at the electronics
shop and get yourself a free TV than it is to pay for
one.  

> especially when the artists  are relatively unheard
> of. 

dude, if you really think this way, then what the hell
are you doing in the underground end of the electronic
music scene?  the whole point of what we're all up to
here is creating an environment where there's a
constant flow of new artistic talent.  we're not
looking to see the 60+ year old roocker on tour
playing the same bullshit that's been on the air for
the last 40 years.  The Scene is all about new music
from people you've never heard of blasting out over
the air and giving you feelings like you've never had
before.  

> If I got the license for all the tracks in my 
> promo and made a snazzy CD insert, mastered it, etc,
> would you pay me $15 for it?
> 

first off, if you don't have the licensing for the
tracks on your promo CD, why would you distribute it? 
handing out free copies of someone else's work is
pretty low, don't you think?

secondly, to address your point, if it was an album
that seemed interesting to me and that was the price
for it then yes.  that's the way legal, legitimate
business is run.  

it's the same as laying out money to record stores for
copies of the new Uberzone and Crystal Method CDs,
laying out money for the new pieces of vinyl i pick up
at the DJ shop, laying out money for my lunch at the
burger stand, paying for the gas i put in my Beetle,
etc. etc. etc.  that's what consumer capitalism is all
about.      

you should, by law, have licensing rights to any music
that you're selling or reproducing.  that's not my
rule, that's the RIAA.  ever notice that little spot
on your records and CDs that says something to the
effect of "Unauthorized duplication, performance or
broadcast is prohibited"?  ever heard of the Harry Fox
Agency?  how about ASCAP or BMI?  these organizations
exist to make sure that artists and producers don't
get screwed by folks reproducing their music and
distributing or selling it without properly paying for
its use.  

DJs legally licensing tracks and putting them out on
professional mixed albums is not unheard of.  a quick
look around your favorite record shop will show you
examples from folks like John Kelley, Simply Jeff,
Paul Oakenfeld, Timo Maas, Fatboy Slim and many many
others.

licensing really isn't all that difficult to set up,
and in the end it costs a lot less than getting sued
by a record company or music publishing house.  if
you're seriously considering putting out material for
sale, i highly suggest doing it all legit.

Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

Subject: [sfraves] any dancehall ravers (?)

all-

	from the first time i heard it loud, in the hiphop room at Limelight in 
94, i have been completely stunned by dancehall.  the energy of it still 
renders me speechless.  most know that dancehall gets the least credit for 
dance music, and it deserves so much more (it's what made house and DnB 
cool, and it's all that keeps downbeat alive).
if you don't believe me look under hip hop on
http://alienrecords.net
and listen to some dubs ... blackchiney, sizzla, capleton ... you'll see 
that's no exaggeration
	no soap-boxing here: i just finally have the courage now to dive into it 
and never look back.  but dammit, it's scary.  the shit comes out like 4 
times the speed of any other music and you practically have to buy it off 
the boat to get the real thing.  there has got to be someone else out there 
in rave land that knows some
--> DJs of ALL genres that mix in a healthy dose of dancehall
--> online resources for dancehall fans
--> artists that i haven't heard of that would take some of the guesswork 
out of this

	thanks to all for any help.

grant stevens
http://alienrecords.net

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: RE: [sfraves] NRR: IE OR NETSCAPRE 6.0

That's why I said from ANY OS Vendor.  Hell, I am IBM Certified in some old
shit, from Mainframe days.  I am certified in Digital VMS (another old
outdated OS) and could take the test and get a NCA cert with no problem.  I
am A+ certified and am working on A+ Network Certification as well as
Solaris certification.  I am working on the Microsoft shit because it's a
way to get more money.  My experience and reputation with coworkers and
former employers is enough to tell any prospective employer I am as good as
I say I am.

I guess the real question should have been does he read and comprehend the
English language.  I never said Windows was without faults.  I never said it
was the end all answer to everything and I never said it was perfect.  What
I did say was that a properly configured server with certified hardware
makes for a very stable machine.  I have had Windows 9x workstations a that
would go a week or so without needing a reboot and most of the time the
reboots had to be done because of memory leaks in third party software, not
the OS.  I have also seen workstations that would never be stable.  I have
had servers the same way and my point was just what you and all of the
others in the list are proving, Microsoft and its products get a bad rap
when they do not always deserve it.  You show me the perfect operating
system, one that has NO flaws and NO show stopping bugs and I will bow down
and call it god.  Then let me install it on some hardware and let some
'experienced' programmers write some applications on it.  Then let's talk.

Rather then reply to messages with intelligent comments or arguments I get
the forever childish insults of did I copy this from the manufacturer's
website or am I a brainless member of their religion.  The reality is that
*I* am glad Microsoft makes vastly unstable products because if the current
Wintel industry got on the ball and made PC's that did not need
administration, then I would have to find another job.

How many times has a piece of software or a driver you installed made your
system unstable?  Is that truly Microsoft's fault?

 -----Original Message-----

that at least their training is good.  But have you seen the recent reports
from SANS indicating that MS certified professions lack significant areas of
expertise in even basic security implimentations, making them almost
worthless with respect to commercial online applications outside the LAN.

------------------

in Applied Microeconomics, specializing in semiconductor price modeling and
I need a job extra speedy like before I get ejected from the santa cruz
commune.. :)  PLUR!

Subject: [sfraves] Chris Jackson! --> *Tonight* @ Secret Society (bsp)

Hi all,
Tonight starts our $1 donation door charge. We've enjoyed being able to keep
our night free for the first 6 months, as it has gone extremely well.
Up to now, Mike and I have pulled from our pockets every week for all of our
enjoyment, and as time went on and the SS gained momentum, it seemed our
costs were rising beyond our means. Tho it is a free party, and we like to
think of it that way and keep that vibe, it was getting quite costly for us
to maintain. So, we got input from several of our core members, and decided
as a whole that if we could all help, just a small little bit each week, we
could really take the SS to new heights.. as a collective effort. So with
that, we (Mike, Andy and I) decided that we'd implement a $1 cover charge at
the door, and refer to it as a donation, because that is what you are doing,
donating to the SS cause, to keep it here and this good each week. We don't
want to break into your drink cash stash, so we thought if everyone just put
in a buck, we could still pay for our visuals, decor, and music with a lil
more than just a pat on the back and a thank you. We are sorry if this
detours anyone, we only want to keep our Monday nights as great as they have
been the last 6 months... Thanks for understanding.

Feel free to email me if you have any questions or concerns...

And with that our lineup for tonight is  -->

SECRET SOCIETY - August 27th, 2001
a reunion of people - a revival of culture

Chapter XXXII
Global Techo Takeover w/ hosts

THE AGENT vs. PROFANE (Nova Collective)
ANDYW vs. CHRIS JACKSON (Resource Records)
LI (Viberation)

Secret Society residents
JUSTIN HALE
MICHAEL LIU
ANDYW


Intelligent projections:
Terry @ Viberation

Additional sound treatment:
Neuroscience Creations & Brad @ 305 Sound

Beginning at 9pm every Monday night
21+ ID required
NEW $1 Donation!

Located at 3546 Flora Vista Ave in Santa Clara

Society voicemail - 408.278.5211

Justin Hale

-Illumination Records
-Simply Cosmic Productions

From: "John B." <svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com>

Subject: [sfraves] SRR:  Ugh... Do I need a "raver name" ???


I always avoided making up one before.  Never felt the need, and I'm happy with
"John".  It does get inconvinent sometimes tho...  Especially when you get into
a group with "Jason"s, "Jake"s, more "John"s, and worse... "Josh"s.

I dunno how it happened here... Somehow, Im the only "John" my circles of
friends, and even other "J"s turned out to be rare....  Except when Osby was
rapid-fire-introducing people (A buncha "J"s) to me at Ascension last
thursday....

But back in Florida, it was something else.... I was one of THREE "John"s in a
group of friends that also included two "Jason"s, a "Jeff", a "Jake", and FOUR
"Jennifer"s  (well, two "Jen"s, a "Jenny", and a "Jennifer").

Wacky, eh?  So we developed a series of pseudonyms... some nicknames, some
initials, some lastnames...  It works pretty well, even to this day.

So where's this going?

Wheh I first joined SFRaves, I was still in the habit of useing my last name. 
It was all fine... till I found out that there is a DJ that uses my last name
as his DJ name!!!  Oh, that and everyone always asks me if I'm related to Steve
(It would be cool if I WAS... who wouldn't want to be able to claim that "'Mr
Pink' is my uncle"??? but, to my knowledge, I'm not).

So to avoid confusion, I shortened my mail name to "John B".  NOW, only two
weeks ago, I find out that there is, and has been for years, a DJ who spins by
the name "John B", right here in San Francisco (odd that in a year and a half,
Ive never heard of him tho)....  and a few people at Ascension were asking if I
was him.... ARRRAGGGHHH.

So my question to SFRaves is:  Do I need a "raver name"?  Something so funky or
cheezy that no one will ever confuse me with anybody else?  Do I just stick
with "John B" and keep the name collision and explain to people that, no, I'm
not the DJ John B?  Do I go back to useing my last name and collide with the
national DJ, and go back to getting asked how to pronounce it and if Im related
to Steve?

Or if I *DO* need a "raver name", what should it be?

Hm... if I ever developed musical talent and needed a "DJ Name" (yeah.... hell
will freeze over, pigs will fly, george bush will grow grey matter, and bill
gates will develop a consience befort *THAT* happens), I *DO* know what THAT
would be:  NRTS and it would be an acronym for "No Relation To Steve"...  I
guess I'd just HAVE to spin NRG with a name like that.  Hmmm...



cya,
john

Subject: Re: [sfraves] [BSP] SCR.COMP.002 now available!!


> > But so long as some are
> > charging for what can be found for free, those that
> > are charging are going
> > to have a harder time getting their stuff heard,
>
>so you're advocating criminal/illegal activity since
>it's just simply easier than actually paying for a
>legit CD.

He isn't advocating shit.  He said, if you're going to sell your cd, it 
isn't going to get heard as often as if you gave it away.

>it's easier to smash the window at the electronics
>shop and get yourself a free TV than it is to pay for
>one.

It's also easier to go into a bar and watch tv then to walk into an 
electronics store and buy one.

> > especially when the artists  are relatively unheard
> > of.
>
>dude, if you really think this way, then what the hell
>are you doing in the underground end of the electronic
>music scene?  the whole point of what we're all up to
>here is creating an environment where there's a
>constant flow of new artistic talent.  we're not
>looking to see the 60+ year old roocker on tour
>playing the same bullshit that's been on the air for
>the last 40 years.  The Scene is all about new music
>from people you've never heard of blasting out over
>the air and giving you feelings like you've never had
>before.

Right, and making it harder for those artists to be heard isn't going to 
help them.

> > If I got the license for all the tracks in my
> > promo and made a snazzy CD insert, mastered it, etc,
> > would you pay me $15 for it?
> >
>
>first off, if you don't have the licensing for the
>tracks on your promo CD, why would you distribute it?
>handing out free copies of someone else's work is
>pretty low, don't you think?

No - why would it be low?  a DJ Promo CD is a testament to the DJ's ability 
to combine tracks in a meaningful way.  It is not to claim credit for 
producing the individual tracks, nor to make profit off them.  Distribution 
is to get the DJ bookings, and during the set, their is no guarantee that 
any of the tracks on the promo would be used again.  Perhaps I'm extremely 
dense today, but I don't understand why a DJ doesn't have to license lp's 
spun at a party, but he does if he records the mix?

>it's the same as laying out money to record stores for
>copies of the new Uberzone and Crystal Method CDs,
>laying out money for the new pieces of vinyl i pick up
>at the DJ shop, laying out money for my lunch at the
>burger stand, paying for the gas i put in my Beetle,
>etc. etc. etc.  that's what consumer capitalism is all
>about.

apples to oranges.  Neither Crystal Method nor Uberzone are underground 
music producers seeking fans and dj's to help them get bigger.  They are 
both established, with est. fan bases - they would have nothing to gain by 
giving their cd's away for free.

>you should, by law, have licensing rights to any music
>that you're selling or reproducing.  that's not my
>rule, that's the RIAA.  ever notice that little spot
>on your records and CDs that says something to the
>effect of "Unauthorized duplication, performance or
>broadcast is prohibited"?  ever heard of the Harry Fox
>Agency?  how about ASCAP or BMI?  these organizations
>exist to make sure that artists and producers don't
>get screwed by folks reproducing their music and
>distributing or selling it without properly paying for
>its use.

All Hail the might RIAA!  For they are RIGHT, and kissing their ass is they 
way to make change!  I have a right to backup or make other format copies 
of any music that I purchase; what then prohibits me from playing me tape 
version of oakenfold in my car?  What if (gasp) I have passengers in the 
car that don't own the original CD?

>licensing really isn't all that difficult to set up,
>and in the end it costs a lot less than getting sued
>by a record company or music publishing house.  if
>you're seriously considering putting out material for
>sale, i highly suggest doing it all legit.

that's why pirates frighten the RIAA to DEATH.  They don't have the 
incredible resources necessary to sue everyone single person out there 
willing to share music.

sarilion

think there are more than a few folks on this list who
can attest to my moral standing and would be willing
to advocate on my behalf that my efforts in The Scene
aren't to screw anyone.  

> All I'm saying is this: You're right. We do live in
> a capitalist system. If 
> you want to sell something, you're free to do that.

> But so long as some are 
> charging for what can be found for free, those that
> are charging are going 
> to have a harder time getting their stuff heard,

so you're advocating criminal/illegal activity since
it's just simply easier than actually paying for a
legit CD.

it's easier to smash the window at the electronics
shop and get yourself a free TV than it is to pay for
one.  

> especially when the artists  are relatively unheard
> of. 

dude, if you really think this way, then what the hell
are you doing in the underground end of the electronic
music scene?  the whole point of what we're all up to
here is creating an environment where there's a
constant flow of new artistic talent.  we're not
looking to see the 60+ year old roocker on tour
playing the same bullshit that's been on the air for
the last 40 years.  The Scene is all about new music
from people you've never heard of blasting out over
the air and giving you feelings like you've never had
before.  

> If I got the license for all the tracks in my 
> promo and made a snazzy CD insert, mastered it, etc,
> would you pay me $15 for it?
> 

first off, if you don't have the licensing for the
tracks on your promo CD, why would you distribute it? 
handing out free copies of someone else's work is
pretty low, don't you think?

secondly, to address your point, if it was an album
that seemed interesting to me and that was the price
for it then yes.  that's the way legal, legitimate
business is run.  

it's the same as laying out money to record stores for
copies of the new Uberzone and Crystal Method CDs,
laying out money for the new pieces of vinyl i pick up
at the DJ shop, laying out money for my lunch at the
burger stand, paying for the gas i put in my Beetle,
etc. etc. etc.  that's what consumer capitalism is all
about.      

you should, by law, have licensing rights to any music
that you're selling or reproducing.  that's not my
rule, that's the RIAA.  ever notice that little spot
on your records and CDs that says something to the
effect of "Unauthorized duplication, performance or
broadcast is prohibited"?  ever heard of the Harry Fox
Agency?  how about ASCAP or BMI?  these organizations
exist to make sure that artists and producers don't
get screwed by folks reproducing their music and
distributing or selling it without properly paying for
its use.  

DJs legally licensing tracks and putting them out on
professional mixed albums is not unheard of.  a quick
look around your favorite record shop will show you
examples from folks like John Kelley, Simply Jeff,
Paul Oakenfeld, Timo Maas, Fatboy Slim and many many
others.

licensing really isn't all that difficult to set up,
and in the end it costs a lot less than getting sued
by a record company or music publishing house.  if
you're seriously considering putting out material for
sale, i highly suggest doing it all legit.




__________________________________________________

Make international calls for as low as $.04/minute with Yahoo! Messenger
http://phonecard.yahoo.com/

At 03:14 PM 8/27/2001 -0700, Sir Dapy Of Dorkdom wrote:
>That's why I said from ANY OS Vendor.  Hell, I am IBM Certified in some old
>shit, from Mainframe days.  I am certified in Digital VMS (another old
>outdated OS) and could take the test and get a NCA cert with no problem.  I
>am A+ certified and am working on A+ Network Certification as well as
>Solaris certification.  I am working on the Microsoft shit because it's a
>way to get more money.  My experience and reputation with coworkers and
>former employers is enough to tell any prospective employer I am as good as
>I say I am.

If they're stable.. why is there more money in windows?

>I guess the real question should have been does he read and comprehend the
>English language.  I never said Windows was without faults.  I never said it
>was the end all answer to everything and I never said it was perfect.  What
>I did say was that a properly configured server with certified hardware
>makes for a very stable machine.  I have had Windows 9x workstations a that
>would go a week or so without needing a reboot and most of the time the
>reboots had to be done because of memory leaks in third party software, not
>the OS.

Holy SHIT!  A whole fucking WEEK??  That's completely RIDICULOUS.  You seem 
to think that by insulting Ari, your argument looks better.  It does 
not.  If you could comprehend English, you would have read something like 
"What MS OS can stay up for a whole MONTH?"  Come on, it doesn't take a 
masters in linguistics to understand the difference between week and 
month.  Sure, a configured quake server, with no extra hardware, could 
prolly run in DOS for over a week.  That doesn't make the OS stable, it 
makes it limited.

>  I have also seen workstations that would never be stable.  I have
>had servers the same way and my point was just what you and all of the
>others in the list are proving, Microsoft and its products get a bad rap
>when they do not always deserve it.  You show me the perfect operating
>system, one that has NO flaws and NO show stopping bugs and I will bow down
>and call it god.  Then let me install it on some hardware and let some
>'experienced' programmers write some applications on it.  Then let's talk.

How are we all proving it?  I've yet to see a single instance where MS has 
gotten a bad rap.  I'm not saying linux, OS/2, or OSX is the next 
god-os.  I'm saying MS has too much control over the market, and we all 
suffer b/c of their excuses aka products.


>Rather then reply to messages with intelligent comments or arguments I get
>the forever childish insults of did I copy this from the manufacturer's
>website or am I a brainless member of their religion.  The reality is that
>*I* am glad Microsoft makes vastly unstable products because if the current
>Wintel industry got on the ball and made PC's that did not need
>administration, then I would have to find another job.

Yeah, just like I suck Cisco's cock for making routers that eventually fail 
or have issues.  We're in it for the money, after all, and not into solving 
problems.

>How many times has a piece of software or a driver you installed made your
>system unstable?  Is that truly Microsoft's fault?

When the same driver, written by the same programmers, works better in 
another OS, yes.


sarilion

Subject: Re: [sfraves] [BSP] SCR.COMP.002 now available!!

WOW I know ive seen this thread before... Anyhoo the reason a DJ usually
doesn't have to pay licensing on something he/she spins at an event is
because in the normal music world (the one which all this licensing shit was
set up for, yes that's live music) the space pays licensing fees usually to
ASCAP BMI or another licensing distributor whom take there chunk then pass
along royalties. Most live shows/large parties/ events don't allow recording
devices thus the music is herd once and then potentially bought by the
audience. No one looses money. This is changing really quickly with the
quality of bootlegs getting better and better. not to mention now you have
DJ's plugging into the house and recording there sets live with full sound
quality without the proper licensing then releasing those mix's. That's were
it gets hairy. Live sets must be licensed differently if there going to be
recorded and in our scene allot of them are illegally. The same way radio
stations do. That's one of the reasons your supposed to count attendance at
events (most just guess if that). Some how I feel the kazaa and satellite
debate shortly arising but Surillion there's your answer. Oh almost forgot.
All it takes is one DJ on an independent label getting really big and one
artist on one of his/her earlier mixes seeing that they could make some
money and sewing for an independent label to fold. So I kinda see both your
points of view.

Dancin for SMILES =)
Cliff

	sfraves@hyperreal.org

Mime-Version: 1.0

Content-Disposition: inline
User-Agent: Mutt/1.2.4i
In-Reply-To: <4.3.1.0.20010827160934.00bafef8@qix.netcorps.com>; from raver@sarilion.org on Mon, Aug 27, 2001 at 04:26:55PM -0700
Organization: Nebcorp.com: ruling your world since 1998
X-Mailer-Holy-War: Get Mutt, it bites!
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] [BSP] SCR.COMP.002 now available!!

[Sarilion <raver@sarilion.org>]
> >first off, if you don't have the licensing for the
> >tracks on your promo CD, why would you distribute it?
> >handing out free copies of someone else's work is
> >pretty low, don't you think?
> 
> No - why would it be low?  a DJ Promo CD is a testament to the DJ's ability 
> to combine tracks in a meaningful way.  It is not to claim credit for 
> producing the individual tracks, nor to make profit off them.  Distribution 
> is to get the DJ bookings, and during the set, their is no guarantee that 
> any of the tracks on the promo would be used again.  Perhaps I'm extremely 
> dense today, but I don't understand why a DJ doesn't have to license lp's 
> spun at a party, but he does if he records the mix?

Ah!  Here we see the crux of the issue!  It's not a question of "have to"
or not.  It's a question of will he/she pay licensing for the public
performance of the recorded music.

When you buy a record/CD, you're getting a license for you to listen to it,
and that's it.  Anything else you want to do with it costs more money, paid
to someone like ASCAP or BMI.

Technically, if you have, say, a frat boy style house party, with a keg and
stuff, and you have a boombox playing "Jock Rock, Vol. 7", you need to pay
licensing fees.  No one does.  Nor will you be arrested for it.  Copyright
violation enforcement is the job of the copyright holder (record companies)
not the police.

But yes, the DJ always needs to be licensed for public performance of the
tracks.  And yes, usually that is taken care of by the above-ground venue.
For excellent info on this, I'd suggest reading the stuff that jwz has put
together on his struggle to get DNA Lounge off the ground:

http://www.dnalounge.com/backstage/webcasting.html

> 
> All Hail the might RIAA!  For they are RIGHT, and kissing their ass is they 
> way to make change!  I have a right to backup or make other format copies 
> of any music that I purchase; what then prohibits me from playing me tape 
> version of oakenfold in my car?  What if (gasp) I have passengers in the 
> car that don't own the original CD?

The law is on the side of the RIAA.  I'm not saying it's right, it's just
the law.

> 
> >licensing really isn't all that difficult to set up,
> >and in the end it costs a lot less than getting sued
> >by a record company or music publishing house.  if
> >you're seriously considering putting out material for
> >sale, i highly suggest doing it all legit.
> 
> that's why pirates frighten the RIAA to DEATH.  They don't have the 
> incredible resources necessary to sue everyone single person out there 
> willing to share music.
> 

No, but they have the money they need to get the laws changed so they can
make the penalties much stiffer.  That's the thing to worry about.

-- 
Ari							there is no spoon

From sfraves-return-72030-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Tue Aug 28 00:33:04 2001

Subject: Re: [sfraves] [BSP] SCR.COMP.002 now available!!

>--- Chris V <baronvonvarady@hotmail.com> wrote:
> > I realize stuff costs money. I realize the
> > time/effort/paperwork to do all
> > this legit. And I wasn't "attacking" your business
> > practices (although the
> > "free enterprise" defense doesn't mean much...
> > people get screwed all the
> > time in the name of "free enterprise").
>
>simmer down now, newbie.  inferring that i'm out to
>screw artists isn't exactly PLURry, now, is it?  i
>think there are more than a few folks on this list who
>can attest to my moral standing and would be willing
>to advocate on my behalf that my efforts in The Scene
>aren't to screw anyone.

Newbie? You have no idea how long I've been on the list. Just because I 
don't spout off every other day...

I wasn't saying that you're out to screw artists. You gave "two words: free 
enterprise" as your argument, like that was the end-all to the conversation. 
All I said was that "free enterprise" doesn't mean squat in regards to 
ethics. You didn't say "people on here can vouch for me", you said "free 
enterprise". REPEAT: this is not an attack on you or your ethics, it is a 
rebuke to your "free enterprise" statement.

> > All I'm saying is this: You're right. We do live in
> > a capitalist system. If
> > you want to sell something, you're free to do that.
>
> > But so long as some are
> > charging for what can be found for free, those that
> > are charging are going
> > to have a harder time getting their stuff heard,
>
>so you're advocating criminal/illegal activity since
>it's just simply easier than actually paying for a
>legit CD.

I didn't advocate anything. I said more people will hear it if it's free. I 
didn't mean for you to post their music for free without consulting with the 
artists, I meant the artists should give permission for it to be posted.

>it's easier to smash the window at the electronics
>shop and get yourself a free TV than it is to pay for
>one.

You mean like it's easier to violate a noise ordinance, or trespass or break 
into a warehouse, or jaywalk? Even my by-the-book dad gave me a copy of Doom 
2 days ago. Maybe you should go work for Sony or BMG.

> > especially when the artists  are relatively unheard
> > of.
>
>dude, if you really think this way, then what the hell
>are you doing in the underground end of the electronic
>music scene?  the whole point of what we're all up to
>here is creating an environment where there's a
>constant flow of new artistic talent.  we're not
>looking to see the 60+ year old roocker on tour
>playing the same bullshit that's been on the air for
>the last 40 years.  The Scene is all about new music
>from people you've never heard of blasting out over
>the air and giving you feelings like you've never had
>before.

I've got tons of new music. From people I've never heard of. Didn't pay for 
any of it (and no, they didn't want me to). Technically, those DJs are 
violating copyright law (I guess, you probably know more about copyright law 
than I, but I'm not here to argue copyright law)... but you know what? I 
have their music. I know their names. If I ever see their name on a flyer, 
I'll try to catch the show. THAT'S my point. Why are you in the underground 
scene if you're so intent on charging for it, on integrating it into the 
"capitalist system"?

> > If I got the license for all the tracks in my
> > promo and made a snazzy CD insert, mastered it, etc,
> > would you pay me $15 for it?
> >
>
>first off, if you don't have the licensing for the
>tracks on your promo CD, why would you distribute it?
>handing out free copies of someone else's work is
>pretty low, don't you think?

Yup. I'm scum. I'm sure all the people who got my CD would agree to that. 
And I'm sure Madam Zu, Nick Sentience, and Andy Farley are damn pissed that 
I'm spending my money to get their music to other people.

>secondly, to address your point, if it was an album
>that seemed interesting to me and that was the price
>for it then yes.  that's the way legal, legitimate
>business is run.

But when there's other music that's free, it becomes a question of "is it so 
much more interesting than the free stuff that I'll pay for it?" If there's 
music that costs money and is really good, then music that's free and is 
really good (doesn't even have to be REALLY good, it's free after all), why 
bother with the stuff that costs?

>it's the same as laying out money to record stores for
>copies of the new Uberzone and Crystal Method CDs,
>laying out money for the new pieces of vinyl i pick up
>at the DJ shop, laying out money for my lunch at the
>burger stand, paying for the gas i put in my Beetle,
>etc. etc. etc.  that's what consumer capitalism is all
>about.

I haven't paid for music in a long time. Not because I burn copies or use 
Napster, but because I just look around the net for DJ sites w/mixes, or I 
get free CDs at parties. Why bother with mainstream artists when there are 
those who just want you to hear their stuff? Are you saying the SCR people 
are on par with Crystal Method, Uberzone, Fatboy Slim and Paul Oakenfeld?

And just because "that's what consumer capitalism is all about" doesn't mean 
consumer capitalism is the best way.

>you should, by law, have licensing rights to any music
>that you're selling or reproducing.  that's not my
>rule, that's the RIAA.  ever notice that little spot
>on your records and CDs that says something to the
>effect of "Unauthorized duplication, performance or
>broadcast is prohibited"?  ever heard of the Harry Fox
>Agency?  how about ASCAP or BMI?  these organizations
>exist to make sure that artists and producers don't
>get screwed by folks reproducing their music and
>distributing or selling it without properly paying for
>its use.

Yes, I'm aware of those agencies and their purpose. Have you ever heard of 
the DEA? Hope you've never touched a controlled substance. Ever heard of the 
DPT? Hope you've never jaywalked. Ever heard of the CHP? Hope you've never 
driven over 65mph.

>DJs legally licensing tracks and putting them out on
>professional mixed albums is not unheard of.  a quick
>look around your favorite record shop will show you
>examples from folks like John Kelley, Simply Jeff,
>Paul Oakenfeld, Timo Maas, Fatboy Slim and many many
>others.

Oh, and being the superstar DJ that I am, I of course have the money for 
that. What, you've never heard of The Baron?! I just played a 12 hour set at 
1015 last week! And considering the tens of thousands of CDs I sent out, I'm 
really screwing those guys over. Oh and when I said I sent them for free, I 
really meant I charged $20. My bad.

>licensing really isn't all that difficult to set up,
>and in the end it costs a lot less than getting sued
>by a record company or music publishing house.  if
>you're seriously considering putting out material for
>sale, i highly suggest doing it all legit.

Well, I'm not trying to put music out for sale. I'm just trying to get my 
skills heard. I figured that's what the SCR people were doing, but I guess I 
was wrong.

I would like to reitterate (sp), in case it wasn't clear, that all I'm 
saying is that if you want the MOST people to hear your music, then just 
give it away. Otherwise you cut yourself off from those who don't want to 
pay, who realize there's a free two-hour MP3 or something just around the 
next hyperlink. If you want to sell something, fine. But when people say 
"you should post it free", you'd be better off to just say "oh well, your 
loss" (or is it yours?), than to take it all personal and get in a huff 
about copyright law. And only your own priorities ("$$$" vs 
"exposure/sharing your music") will determine whose loss it actually is.

-=Chris=-

From sfraves-return-72033-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Tue Aug 28 00:35:44 2001
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-72033-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 61883 invoked by uid 1104); 28 Aug 2001 00:35:44 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 61873 invoked from network); 28 Aug 2001 00:35:44 -0000
Message-ID: <00e601c12f59$3d7001b0$6b01a8c0@jem>
From: "John E. Martin" <jem@unixmercenary.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Date: Mon, 27 Aug 2001 17:34:46 -0700
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Priority: 3
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 6.00.2479.0006
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V6.00.2479.0006
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Free Music vs. Paid CDs

I've been following this thread a just wanted to throw in my two cents. I
have a tendancy to agree with both parties on several points, and disagree
on others.

As an artist who writes my own tracks, I'd really just like anyone who's
willing to take a listen and spread the word. I want the world to hear my
music, and would gladly give it
for free to anyone who wants it.

Then I start getting in the blurred lines of, "Well, who's going to pay my
bills?" - I would love nothing more than to spend my entire
day making my music a reality and I'd die to have someone come in and make
sure
all my bills are paid and I can continue to live the livestyle I've grown
acustomed to. At some point, there's a place where every artist needs to
say, "Okay, now I need to start selling my music so I can do that." Maybe
someday I'll actually be able to make a dime off my own stuff so I don't
have to keep my day job. Until that day, you'll hear it for free.

And I --completely-- agree that there are a million artists out there who
are still giving their works away for free that are so extremely unnoticed
and deserve the attention that someone who's collecting $15 for their music.

When you start wanting people to hear your music, I don't think it's to your
benefit to sell the material. Your best bet is typically to pass out the CDs
for free to as many people as you can get to take a copy. Once you've got
them hooked, and you can begin charging. That's how you get to be at the
place you really want to be.

Those who jump and say, "Well, that's not the spirit of the underground
scene!" should step back a moment and picture this scenerio: I decide I'm
going to release my new CD. I'll produce it all on my own at home so I don't
have to pay for a studio. Once it's done, I'm going to print 500 copies with
a 4-color inlay. I intend on giving it away for free to anyone who wants a
copy. Hell, I really want people to hear my music. The problem is, it's cost
me a lot of time out of my personal life, and I've probably taken quite a
bit of time off work because I was up all night working on this CD. So I've
definately lost quite a bit of money here. I don't mind that it's cost me
money, but when you like my CD and you want my to make more, I may not have
the money to do so. Are you going to donate money to me so that I'll
continue to make the music you like or will you just move on to the next
artist who's going to give you what you want for free? My point is: If
you're just going from artist to artist, you're not supporting anyone or
anything but yourself and your wallet. Supporting someone or something is
giving to it. And when I've made my donation to you/your scene, how are you
going to help me as I did you? Just something to think about...

If you don't want to pay $15 for a CD, then don't. If you feel that artists
are ripping you off when you have the opportunity to listen other artists
for free, then you won't hear those artists. You stand the chance of missing
one of those artists who could be what you're looking for.

I'll continue to buy CDs by artists that I enjoy listening to because they
do deserve the money to continue making the music I want to hear. If I don't
pay, and you don't pay, and that other person doesn't pay, then how do we
know we'll get to hear another CD?

I will however draw the line at support for the RIAA. I believe the real
future of "underground artists" is in the independant label and
production/promotion. The RIAA is nothing but a large group of money hungry
executives who show no love for the music, but for the dollar. Musicians who
have started their own labels have had much more control of their music,
even if it is at the cost of distribution and promotion. It may cost me an
extra $2 per CD to cover those costs, but for me, knowing that I'm
supporting those artists and their music makes it well worth it.

Good luck to the SCR screw in your endevours. I really hope you make the
sales to let you keep making the music you enjoy. =)


Peace,
-John
-tekBuddha

Subject: [sfraves] SCR.COMP.002 redux


okay, after going back and forth and back and forth, i
think that what we have here is a failure to
communicate, based on various and sundry assumptions
and and infrences, so let me start from the beginning
and see if i can make this a clear picture.

**************

A few months back, I decided to make a bold move.  It
was time for my business to move in a new direction,
so instead of just putting together mixtapes and
getting DJ bookings, I decided to turn Abduction
Productions into an honest-to-God independent record
label.

As my first project, I decided to make a
professionally-produced compilation CD of original
music from members of the SoCal-Raves internet list.  

I put out a call for submissions and wound up with a
group of artists who were all interested in the
project.  Contracts were drawn, money was spent,
tracks were written, professional artwork, mastering
and replication were all done and now we have the CD.

The first official CD release on Abdcution
Productions:

"SCR.COMP.002 - more music from the SoCal-Raves
Internet group"

This album features 10 tracks of original music
written by members of the SoCal-Raves list.  

The CD made its debut at a premier party in Los
Angeles on Saturday.  Now, the CD is available to the
public.  Units are currently shipping to stores, but
if you don't like going to the store, you're welcome
to buy it online directly from the record label (eg.
me).

If you're the kind of person who likes to hear stuff
before they buy it, or if you just want to be sure
that this CD is really worth the investment, then
check out the preview site I've put up at 

http://www.invert.com/~scrcomp002

I think that you'll agree, even based on these small
previews, that the artists on this album are just as
worthy of your CD investment as any other artist you
could pick up off the shelf at Tower, Rasputin's,
Amoeba, Primal, etc.

what we've got here is artists that typically wouldn't
get the professional-level treatment presented in a
professional manner.  I think that after giving them a
listen, you'll agree that they're just as good, if not
better than the "pros" out today.

so if you like electronic music and you're looking to
buy a CD of brand new stuff from artists you've
probably never heard before, check out SCR.COMP.002

thank you.

From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] GROOVE GARDEN AT MYX:  Tribalicious

Some weekends are pretty arid.  No exceptional parties.  Last weekend, 
however, was one of those where one wishes one had the ability to transport 
oneself instantaneously from one event to another.

AEC, Urban Wasteland, Otherworld, Tomcat's 30th birthday party, and 
Myx.  So many parties, one body.

Fate, or planning, had pretty much determined our weekend a couple of weeks 
ago.  On Friday night we had promised DJ Dragonfly of Groove Garden that we 
would be at Myx to photograph Groove Garden's sets;  Saturday I was 
obligated to spin at a house party.

I'm always eager to spend an evening with Marin's Groove Garden.  They 
always provide such compelling, tribal dance music.  Khaled, Lorin and Dj 
Dragonfly were spinning at Myx Friday and they had me dancing nonstop for 
the whole evening.  Breaks, Drum and Bass, world music, house -- all this 
in the mix, and more.  These guys are truly awesome, and I strongly 
recommend that the next time you see Groove Garden on a flier you get your 
buns to the party for a unique EDM experience.  You don't even need dancing 
shoes.

Groove Garden attracts a warm, sensuous, dedicated group of dancers you 
don't often see at other parties.  Diverse, creative, wildly 
energetic.  Lots of them dance barefoot.  Much improvisation.

And with Groove Garden comes the spirituality and sensuality of old school 
raves.  The Buddha altar with lots of candles, incense, and the message 
tables in back.  Excellent vibe.

The visuals were provided by Viberation, and they were astonishing.  Four 
video sources blended together to make engaging imagery, bits and pieces of 
old Disney animation, soul wrenching landscapes...  The more I see of Terry 
Estioko's work, the more respect I have for him as an artist.  A visual 
artist's soul is on view at a party, and Terry's soul is imaginative and 
lovely.  Certainly one aspect of our community that, I think, will be 
remembered and exhibited when we are all dancing with walkers will be the 
art of the visuals producer.  Visual music.  Perhaps some day Terry's work 
will be exhibited at SFMOMA:)

Joey left in one of his blue funks early, so I rode home in a cab by 
myself.  After wandering about at 4 in the morning in China Basin I was 
picked up by Late Nite Larry, a cab driver I highly recommend 
(7pm-5am/415-606-5770).  Larry was a hippie in the sixties who sold 
psychedelics and such on the Haight.  Native of San Francisco.  When I got 
in the cab, he asked me if I had been DJing that night.  Said no, but that 
I do spin on occasion.  He replies:  "I'll bet you spin 
house."  OK.  Cool.  We get into a long conversation about EDM and 
raves.  Turns out he much prefers ravers and others who love EDM to any 
other type of passenger.  He himself listens to electronic music on his 
radio, and likes the Thump show.  Tells me he would like to attend an EDM 
party but is afraid he is too old and would be rejected.  So I strongly 
encouraged him to try Come-Unity or Thump.  He knew about both parties, 
'cause he focuses his driving on EDM events.  Hope he decides to be venture 
in some night.  And, sweet guy, he knocks $5.00 off my fare when we get to 
my home.

I'm happy to hear AEC went off well, but then what else would one expect 
from the SFplanners group:)  Hope to dance with you all under the moon or 
shooting stars next time.

Love,

Apollo



"It is only with the heart that one can see rightly;  what is essential is 
invisible to the eye."
-Antoine de Saint-Exupery

"I'm astounded by people who want to "know" the universe when it's hard 
enough to find your way around Chinatown."
-Woody Allen

Subject: [sfraves] SMILE =) My Happy Hardcore Saturday


     Wow!!! Soooo Much Fun!!  OK, I gotta vent real quick before I get to
the goodies!  I think it was lame that more than 1/2 the lil' e-tard chicas
there lastnight were tryin' to be all these sexy lil' Raver things!  LoL
They were the ones who couldn't dance anyway!  So Ha!  Oh gosh, & they were
so rude to all bumping into people like everywhere!  I actually tripped one
of them 'cause she really started to piss me off!  I mean, the girls who
were dressed tomboy style were the Dope ones!  Oh yeah, & they knew how to
dance!

     OK, But yeah, the party kicked mondo Ass!!!  It a while to get into the
vibe 'cause it was jus' well, I guess I'm totally a Bay Raver or something
or maybe it's been a while since I been to a candy party!!  Oh yeah, mondo
candy population made me feel so under dressed!!!  LoL  But it was fun!

     OK, Music Rocked!!!  I mean, yeah, there was a Trance room, but I jus'
couldn't stay away from the Happy Hardcore Room!  It was Bad Ass!!  I got
there around 9 something when Mr. Clean was on the decks & yeah, it was a
good warm up to get into the mood of the party!

     I mean, another upsetting factor of this party was well, all the etards
& puddles everywhere!!!  I mean, seriously, it was so hard to find other
sober people there, but there were alota sober people there!!  OK yeah, but
I'm not gonna lie either, I had a ball bein' a baby sitter!!  There was this
1 kid, this lil' who came up to me, totally rollin', when I was sitting down
in the smoking area & I jus gave him a hug!  Then I gave him a massage & his
gf went to check on her friend who was throwing up in the bathroom.  So I
stayed w/ "Candyman" for a while & made sure he drank his water!

     OK, back to DJs!  I guess it was DJ Dummy & MC Verbal in the main room
when all this Hardcore was playing & Wow, So Dope!  It was Groovy 'cause the
MC would tell the crowd to sing along to the HHC Anthems which we did!!
Then Anthony Madd who spun this really Sick!  Aryck, he played that song w/
the hella long intro & that dude who sings you said who sounds like me when
I sing!  He also spun hella records you have!  Ofcourse it was totally Dope
dancin' to Ron D Core spin!!  Hello 2Day, he started his set w/ Trance &
progressively got faster!!  It was Dope 'cause he ended his set playin' this
Dope Ass Gaber songer that would slow  down like in parts of the song &
Simon Apex played these totally sweet chords on his KORG (Oh man, KORG=)!!
It was Dope!!

     Then another one of my Favorite parts was When Simon Apex & these other
Dudes did Live PA!!!  Oh my gosh, new tracks: Drowning, Pergatory, & this
other one, totally fuckin' Awesome songs!!!  It was Dope hearin' the
"Destiny" remix live!  The whole Live PA set was sick!

     Yeah, I mean, all the DJs So Totally Rocked!  I had so much fun!!  It
sucked how they had to keep changing rooms for the music every set!  I
barely danced in the smaller room & kicked it in the smoking area when that
happen!  Oh gosh, so I did become like part of this puddle of etards & it
was fun!!  I was hella kickin'n it w/ Ash & Wolverine!!  OK, yeah, Candy
names in Full effect!  I met Tricks, Sunshine, Bubbles, Budda, Star, Gumby,
Light, I dunno, so many Candy Kids w/ funny names!!  It was Cute!  But yeah,
hella kicked it w/ Ash & CandyMan!

     I did happen to see 4 Cats from the Dublin Crew: Devo, Anthony, James,
& Homeboy I forget his name!  It was Dope Hangin' out w/ them!!

     So yeah, I was there also to kick it w/ Dragnfly!  She got on the decks
& started her lil' hard NRG set!  I hella yelled out loud "FUCK THE DJ" &
hella people started yelling after me!  Then she looked @ me & like took off
her button shirt & she was wearin' her "Fuck The DJ" shirt & everyone
started yellin' somemore!!!  LoL....It was Fun!!  OK, yeah, then she was
probably into her like 3-4 song when the music got shut down!  It was Hella
sad!  It turns out that the party was suppose to go on 'til 3AM & that's
what the contracted stated as well!  But the venue owner was an asshole
about things & came up w/ some lame excuse that the liquoe liscense for his
place ends at 2 and all festivities have to stop at that time!!!  Bullshit!!
It was Lame!

     Apparently, there was an afterparty @ another venue, but that got shut
down as well!  Oh Well!

     But after we left, it was Bubbles, Brian, Dragnfly, Terri, & I & we
were kicki'n it @ the gas station!!  LoL...it was hella funny 'cause that's
where like alota people showed up after leaving the venue!  It was Groovy
hangin' out w/ Dina & everyone at the gas station 'cause people were all
comin' up to our group & takin' pictures!!  It was Cute!!  LoL

     Afterwards, HUng out @ Dina's & Terri's place w/ Bubbles & Brian!  It
was fun jus' talkin' for hours!!

     But yeah, it was a Groovy night!  I mean, another reason I guess I had
a hard time getting into the vibe was 'cause I mean, the night B4, I was
like @ this totally Dope Underground!  I dunno, but it was Fun!!  I do have
a lil' guilt for not goin' to OW & kickin' it w/ Forest & everyone!  I'm
glad U had fun Damien!!  Ya know, come to think of it, I really hope I get a
chance to take some of those Sac Kids to a Real Rave!  It'd probably be
weird for them, but hmmm.  Ok, Im talkin' outta my ass again!!  Oh Wow, I
wonder how ORGY went lastnight?

Later {8O)

Subject: [sfraves] Question # 8 rephrased: Zero tolerance or harm reduction?

--part1_41.10476774.28bc605e_boundary
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

  To A nonymous:
 I respectfully disagree that my question that I posed to the list was naive. 
Enough said about that.
  IM rephrasing the question as, " Zero tolerance or harm reduction, which 
should the scene embrace and why?" There seems to be two camps in the rave 
scene around the drug issue, one which believes drugs are evil and fucking up 
our scene, and another that believes drugs are not the problem per-se, but of 
a few who abuse them. The former tends to advocate a zero tolerance policy 
and would like to have drug free parties and would rather boot out all the 
etards and say good riddance to them, while the latter believes that not all 
people who do drugs are irresponsible, that drugs are in the rave scene 
whether we like it or not and advocates a harm reduction approach to drug 
usage at raves.
 I have tried to phrase all my questions and their subject matter to be as 
neutral as possible, presenting both sides for civilized discussion and 
critique, representing and respecting all answers and opinions on each 
question. So far, everyone has been pretty cool. Thanks! 
 I have deliberately kept my personal views out and not bla bla bla on any of 
the questions because I didn't want to have people get side tracked on what 
Bodhi thinks, potentially provoking flame posts rather than having these 
questions and their subject matter intelligently and respectfully answered 
and discussed.
 Our scene is going through a lot of changes. New and different people are 
partying. Some are bringing positive attributes to the scene and some seem to 
be pulling the scene down, and we often differ on who plays which role. But 
as a scene we will never evolve if we don't discuss all the problems and 
issues about our scene in a "PLUR'y" way. I believe from collectively 
discussing our issues and problems, solutions will come forth and people will 
be inspired to step up to the plate and help implement solutions. It's one 
thing to bitch and flame each other, it's another to talk, listen, disagree, 
and in all our talking, listening, disagreeing find the truth some where in 
the middle way. I hope with my questions IM bringing us there.
 Peace, love and hugs! Bodhi ^ _ ^

--part1_41.10476774.28bc605e_boundary--

If you plan on heading south to L.A. this Labor day holiday..........this=20
might interest you :)

Just in time for the long Labor Day holiday - 01 AFTER HOURS opens its doors=
=20
on Saturday, Sept 1, 2001!  We invite you to join us at our Grand Opening at=
=20
the newly remodeled Martini Lounge in Hollywood.  As part of the 01=20
tradition, we will continue to bring some of the world's finest talent acros=
s=20
the globe. During the month of September we'll be showcasing some of the=20
country's rising talent in special extended sets until 8 in the morning!

On our Grand Opening night, we will feature Part 1 in a series of deep,=20
progressive sessions.
=20
Joining us at 01 AFTER HOURS on Sept 1st are DJ's MAC C from New York City,=20
TROY ROBERTS from San Francisco and 01 resident BRIAN WAHLBERG.
=20
We look forward to you joining us as we kick off the Labor Day weekend=20
celebration at the Grand Opening of 01 AFTER HOURS on Saturday, Sept 1st!
=20
>> TROY ROBERTS (2-4am)
His deep, pulsating, progressive sound has obviously paid off for Troy. He i=
s=20
well known for being able to man the decks in a 4-5 hour session with=20
flawless mixing and programming.  Troy has already been featured as a guest=20
on John Digweed's infamous Friday night Kiss FM radio show (London). A=20
familiar face behind the Spundae decks in San Francisco, he has played=20
alongside DJ giants such as Sasha, Dave Seaman, Carl Cox and Lee Burridge. =20
In the past few years, Troy has nationally released two mixed CD's "Global=20
Phases" and "A New Beginning" - each showcasing skills of a true, programmin=
g=20
master. Not a stranger to electronic dance music, this Progressive House DJ=20
is a definite crowd pleaser and guarantees to keep you on the dance floor al=
l=20
night!
=20
>> MAC C (4am=E2=80=93 8am)
Making his debut in Los Angeles with a special extended set, this talented=20
artist has been on the rise in the New York club scene for the past decade.=20=
=20
Mac C & his partner under the moniker The Low End Specialists have remixed=20
Underground Sound of Lisbon's classic hit "So Get Up" for Kaos Records. They=
=20
are currently remixing Fierce Ruling Diva's "You Got To Believe" for=20
Alternative Route Records and Danny Tenaglia Feat. Lula "Read My Lips" off=20
DT's 1998 Tourism LP for Twisted & Kaos.  Having already played alongside=20
some of the scene's most truly respected house artists such as Danny Tenagli=
a=20
(Vinyl, NYC), Satoshi Tomiie & Omid 16b Nourizadeh, he continues to hold dow=
n=20
his bi-weekly (Open Air) & Monthly (Sound Factory) residencies in NYC. He=20
recently headline at one of the most hottest clubs in Asia, Movement in Kual=
a=20
Lumpur where Dave Seaman, John Digweed and many others have also played. =20
Expect a night filled with Deep, Dark Progressive Rhythms.

>> BRIAN WAHLBERG (1am =E2=80=93 2am)
In today=E2=80=99s electronic music community, it is rare to find a DJ who e=
xudes as=20
much passion, dedication, and respect for the raw sound of music as Brian.=20
His obvious love for the music transcends petty attempts at fame and fortune=
=20
and instead gives to his audience a refreshing reminder of what the scene wa=
s=20
originally created for; the exhalation and praise for the music. Although=20
Brian career on the turntables is relatively short=E2=80=94about three years=
=20
beginning in 1998 - when compared to those of his influences like Danny=20
Tenaglia, Kevin Yost, Eric Morillo and Timo Maas, it is nevertheless=20
impressive. Striving to find an artistic outlet in his life, Brian was=20
introduced to turntables.  He began a dedicated and relentless relationship=20
that allowed his perfectionist persona to shine brightly amidst music he=20
loved. His beginnings were humble, playing small house parties and clubs,=20
until he began playing larger parties with such names as Chris Liebing,=20
Robert Miles, Terry Mullan and Pablo Gargano. His versatile music style give=
s=20
him the opportunity to experiment with different sounds and genres of=20
electronic music. His eclectic blend of house, progressive house, and techno=
=20
gives his music a dark sensuality with a heart-pounding rhythm - so=20
infectious that audiences cannot help but dance. Brian=E2=80=99s style break=
s=20
boundaries of defined lines as he offers a sexy, hard-hitting beat coupled=20
with daring vocals.  His constant stream of in-your-face records will keep=20
you going all night long. This is one DJ you cannot afford to miss. His=20
beautiful sense of timing, maturity, and ability to adapt to his=20
surroundings, makes Brian one of the most promising talents to hit the scene=
.
 =20

unsubscribed from a few with this as the explanation on their un-sub page..

"this is fucking stupid. I signed up to something else snd got this also.  I
don't have a fucking job, get a clue internet marketing companies, you want me
to spend money I don't have but none of you will hire my overqualified ass to
make money to spend in the first place?  FUCK OFF."

Anyone out there wanna give a NT/unix/network admin/technician a job doing
anything?  Fuck I'll even work helpdesk at this point, I have the skills and
can prove it in an interview, I just need a JOB.

this whole working for a living thing sucks, too bad I don't have the means to
record a demo, I wanna make money doing what I love, not what I know how to do,
just like I want a girl to love for for what I am, not what I can be.

Anyone know where I can be loved and paid for what I am?  I'd move there in a
second.  I mean shit, I've shown the girl I love that I'd do anything in the
world for her, and she stays with her current guy she's known for maybe 1 month
because "it could be good".  Was it really THAT bad?  fuck.

                                                     Forever longing,
                                                                  Me.

Content-Type: multipart/alternative;
	boundary="=====================_2460931==_.ALT"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] "Club Drugs" No Longer Just At Raves

--=====================_2460931==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

USA Today reports "club drugs" like E are mainstream, and may be found at 
places like ice skating rinks.  Mainly in the suburbs.  What now?  Will ice 
skates be classified as drug paraphenalia by the ever vigilant DEA?  Should 
parents move their children from the suburbs?

The problem has NEVER been music and dance.  The problem is that people 
always have and will use various drugs.  The solution is to treat addictive 
disease and institute harm reduction and education programs.

Apollo



Popular 'club drugs' overflow rave scene, enter mainstream Ecstasy, GHB, 
ketamine can be found in USA's schools and neighborhoods

Club drugs, popular for years at all-night rave parties, are moving 
steadily mainstream, and kids say the drugs, particularly Ecstasy, are easy 
to get in schools and neighborhoods.

Experts cite the emerging club-drug scene as one of the two key changes -- 
the other being an increasing supply of exceptionally pure heroin -- in the 
''otherwise stable'' illicit drug landscape since 1999.

''Availability of club drugs has increased dramatically across the nation, 
especially for Ecstasy, which has increased in nearly every city,'' 
according to Pulse Check, the twice-yearly drug abuse trend report from the 
White House Office on National Drug Control Policy.

Pulse Check reports that the use of club drugs, which include Ecstasy, 
ketamine and GHB, has emerged or intensified over the past year in 17 
cities: Boston; Chicago; Columbia, S.C.; Denver; Detroit; El Paso; 
Honolulu; Los Angeles; Memphis; Miami; New Orleans; New York; Philadelphia; 
Portland, Maine; Seattle; Sioux Falls, S.D.; and Washington, D.C.

''The data are clear that it's moved out of the club scene,'' says Alan 
Leshner, executive director of the National Institute on Drug Abuse in 
Bethesda, Md. ''We are now seeing the drugs used by everybody. Parents 
can't just say, 'My kid doesn't go to clubs, so I don't need to worry about 
it.' ''

Law enforcement authorities in Miami say that club drugs are ''everywhere, 
even at ice skating rinks,'' Pulse Check reports. In New York, Long Island 
youths are buying the drugs from the Internet and from dealers at local 
malls. In Seattle and Billings, Mont., the drugs are sold on high school 
and college campuses, police say.

Last year, more than 1.4 million people ages 18 to 25 reported taking 
Ecstasy at least once, the National Household Survey on Drug Abuse found. 
Among students surveyed in 2000, 8.2% of 12th-graders, 5.4% of 10th-graders 
and 3.1% of eighth-graders say they used Ecstasy in the past year.

''That means 165,000 eighth-graders, kids who are 13 and 14 years old, are 
experimenting with their own brains,'' Leshner says.

Ecstasy, by far the most popular of the club drugs, produces both stimulant 
and psychedelic effects, and users often dance all night. Ketamine, an 
anesthetic used mostly on animals, is a disassociative drug that produces 
hallucinations. GHB is a tasteless, odorless depressant that sedates and 
intoxicates users and may be used to come down from Ecstasy.

GHB also has been used by rapists to subdue their victims
.
Club-drug users and sellers, Pulse Check says, tend to be ''young, white, 
middle-class males and females'' who use the drugs in combination with 
other drugs, such as hallucinogens, cocaine, heroin, marijuana, 
methamphetamine and prescription drugs. Teens or college-age students may 
gather to ''trail mix'' at a potluck drug party where various drugs are 
pooled and shared.

Most club-drug activity occurs in the suburbs, the report says.

''Ecstasy user and seller groups are also expanding to include more blacks 
and Hispanics, and use and sales settings continue to expand from 
exclusively nightclubs and raves to high schools, streets and open 
venues,'' the report says.
The use of Ecstasy and other club drugs has spawned an entire culture and 
lingo. An Ecstasy high is called ''rolling.'' Ecstasy users become 
bewitched by flashing lights and music with a steady bass beat. Teens may 
attend all-night rave parties featuring techno music and light shows that 
cater to an Ecstasy user's heightened sensitivities to light, sound and touch.

To capitalize on their heightened senses, partiers wave light sticks, tape 
flashing ''belly lights'' to their navels or wear luminescent, flickering 
bracelets called Toobies. Users may wear fuzzy sweaters or other soft 
fabrics. Some Ecstasy users coat surgical masks with vapor rubs for the 
cooling rush sensation.

Ecstasy also causes involuntary jaw clenching, so users suck on pacifiers 
and candy necklaces to alleviate the effects.
Abuse experts and law enforcement authorities say that as users get bored 
with Ecstasy alone, they are experimenting with dangerous drug 
combinations. Ecstasy users may snort a ''bump'' of ketamine to intensify 
the hallucinatory aspects of Ecstasy at the peak of a ''roll.'' As the 
Ecstasy wears off, users may drink a shot glass or capful of GHB to ease 
off Ecstasy's speed effects.

The Drug Abuse Warning Network, which tracks emergency-room visits in 21 
metropolitan areas, reported 4,969 emergency-room visits for GHB overdoses, 
4,511 visits for Ecstasy and 263 visits for ketamine in 2000.

http://www.usatoday.com/usatonline/20010828/3581325s.htm


"It is only with the heart that one can see rightly;  what is essential is 
invisible to the eye."
-Antoine de Saint-Exupery

"I'm astounded by people who want to "know" the universe when it's hard 
enough to find your way around Chinatown."
-Woody Allen

good ol' fashioned trampy fun without me. Sorry :(

FELIX THE DOG, SCIENCE, and SHANE will decode the breaks madnezz 
upstairs.  Get yo' freak on!  And get ready for some blisssssful

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Question # 8 rephrased: Zero tolerance or harm
  reduction?

At 10:47 PM 8/27/2001 -0400, BodhiInSF@aol.com wrote:
>   To A nonymous:
>  I respectfully disagree that my question that I posed to the list was 
> naive.
>Enough said about that.
>   IM rephrasing the question as, " Zero tolerance or harm reduction, which
>should the scene embrace and why?" There seems to be two camps in the rave
>scene around the drug issue, one which believes drugs are evil and fucking up
>our scene, and another that believes drugs are not the problem per-se, but of
>a few who abuse them. The former tends to advocate a zero tolerance policy
>and would like to have drug free parties and would rather boot out all the
>etards and say good riddance to them, while the latter believes that not all
>people who do drugs are irresponsible, that drugs are in the rave scene
>whether we like it or not and advocates a harm reduction approach to drug
>usage at raves.

I guess I'm on the latter camp.. Here's why.. Even if you take the zero 
tolerance approach, it is impossible to enforce.  There will be drug users 
among the law enforcement and the dancers then, as there is now, if not 
more.  If you'd like a social example, I think Alcohol Prohibition fits 
quite well.  The gov't went balls out, tracking down bandits and home 
distillers, and it still didn't work.  There's too many people, too many 
smart people that know how to fool less - smart people.. and too many 
people believing in a common cause, that banded together.

sarilion

Subject: [sfraves] 2 guns and a machete

O.k. i heard about this some time ago, but didn't want
to post it until it could be confirmed but apearntly
they were talking about it on the radio last week so i
guess it would be o.k. to fill you in a little.
Jest-One i know you already know about this, and yes
they guy (who would like to remain nameless) said it
was o.k. i post it.

o.k. so some one from coolworld was having a dinner
party on Mon. Aug 13th.  Two guys who where
aquaintances of Coolworld show up.  After an hour or
so they leave, only to return 30 min. later.  One has
a machete and they both have guns.  They used duct
tape to tie up a lady and told two youngs kids to go
hide under a bed.  Then they proceed to tear apart the
house to search for the safe that holds the money from
Cyberfest.  One of the guys sets down his gun while
searching.  The guy from coolworld picks it up killing
one guy.  The guy with the machete then hacks away at
him severely injuring him.  Then the guy with the gun
shoots and kills the guy with the machete.

O.k. so if you all heard this already then sorry for
the spam.  but wow can you believe that.

Support your local Renegade!!!

Jamie Star

-----> EM:DEF Action Alert <-----

¡Congress Seeks Rave Ban!

Ecstasy Prevention Act of 2001:
On July 19, 2001, Senator. Graham introduced the Ecstasy Prevention Act 
of 2001 [S 1208 IS], with co-sponsors, Senators Grassley, Lieberman, 
Durbin, Landrieu, Clinton, and Schumer.

Elements of this bill concern the Mission Statement of EM:DEF.

The most important is a description in SEC 3 of "EFFECTIVE PROGRAMS" for 
preventing ecstasy use.  These include communities "passing ordinances 
restricting rave clubs," and, "seizing lands under nuisance abatement 
laws to make new restrictions on establishment's use." 

View the bill at:
http://www.emdef.org/S1208IS_EcstasyPrevAct2001.html

Visit the EM:DEF site to learn how you can help stop this bill
http://www.emdef.org/laws_and_cases.html

Donate to EM:DEF.  Suggested donation: $15 for individuals, $50+ for 
professionals.
http://www.emdef.org/contribute.html

Contact EM:DEF with questions:  will@emdef.org
http://www.emdef.org

From: "John B." <svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com>
To: jem@unixmercenary.com

Subject: [sfraves] RE: Free Music vs. Paid CDs


I guess this got started because of the flap over someone possibly useing
tracks without paying the producers.  Honestly, tho, when the flamewar gets
about three or four layers of ">"s deep, I lose track.

But John (oh no... ANTOHER John), said something here that bugged me, and I
figures I'd throw in my $.02 as a music consumer, rathat than a DJ or anything.
 And a big fan of music I am... I can't even keep my entire CD collection at
home, it would take up so much space.

jem@unixmercenary.com wrote:

>If you don't want to pay $15 for a CD, then don't. If you feel that artists
>are ripping you off when you have the opportunity to listen other artists
>for free, then you won't hear those artists. You stand the chance of 
>missing one of those artists who could be what you're looking for.

I would be perfectly willing to pay $15 for a CD...  *IF* that $15 were going
to the ARTIST.  But that's not the case, if you sign to a record label.  Bands
on labels are damn LUCKY if they get .50 on each CD that sells for $15. 
Courtnet love breaks down the math quite well:

http://www.salon.com/tech/feature/2000/06/14/love/index.html

And I will, under *NO* circumstance, put so much as a penny into the coffers of
the RIAA/metallica....  THOSE are the people who see to it that artises only
see a miniscule fraction of their CD sales.  THOSE are the people who have
declared war on my profession.  They have declared war on my generation and my
peers.  And if there is anything I can do to aid in their destruction, I will
not hesitate to do so.

And in the meantime, I refuse to support them.  They have, either foolishly or
usefully, provided a list of their minions:

http://www.riaa.org/About-Members-1.cfm

I take a hardcopy of that list with me whenever I go music shopping.  And if a
CD I want is put out by those people, I do without until its for sale used from
Ameoba, or the other local stores.  That, or I simply napster it and use a CD-R
until such time as I find a used copy.  Or if it's a band, I'll buy it new at
their merchandise table next time I see them live.

*MY* life is made a bit easier in that regard, as most of the music *I* buy
(punk, ska, and EDM  (woohoo, somebody FINALLY gave me an alternative to
"electronica"!!!), tends to be put out by people who think the way I do, and
avoid RIAA/metallica labels themselves, instead going the DIY route or useing
independent labels.

(When you buy USED CDs, the RIAA/metallica doesn't see a penny.  A number of
years ago they used garth brooks as a stooge to try to destroy the legal
principle of "first sale", much like they are useing lars & co. for their
assault on "fair use" rights now.  Also, when a band sells you stuff (even a CD
produced inder a label) at their live shows, the money goes directly to the
band as well).

Yes.... that $2 vinyl sticker you buy from the band at a concert puts more
money in their pocket than if you buy any five of their albums NEW at the
Virgin Megastore.

Another good reason to buy USED CDs is that the profit margin is higher for the
store.  So when you do so, you are supporting the local, independent stores
like Ameoba and Rasputin against the corporate megaliths.

Okay, that's all speaking as a consumer.  I know nothing of performance rights.
 But I have it on reasonably good authiority that BMI/ASCAP are just as
malignant as the RIAA/metallica.  In fact, that's why I can't listen, over the
'net, to one of my favorite talk radio stations from back in Florida.  One or
the other has raised a big stink and is blocking internet broadcasts of a show
I don't even listen to for music, but for the personalities of the hosts.

I'm not saying the IP rights need to be totally scrapped.  Obviously the ARTIST
needs to be compensated for his work in some way.  But I DO firmlt beleive that
the current system has been hopelessly corrupted, at the expense of both the
artist AND the consumer, and it needs to be torn down by whatever means
necessary.


cya,
john

From sfraves-return-72076-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Tue Aug 28 18:59:25 2001
