Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 83614 invoked from network); 28 Aug 2001 18:59:24 -0000
Message-ID: <008201c12ff3$25ecaa30$ec8cf5d1@sauoq>
From: "A. Nonymous" <snowhuoue@mindspring.com>
To: <BodhiInSF@aol.com>, <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
References: <41.10476774.28bc605e@aol.com>
Date: Tue, 28 Aug 2001 11:56:28 -0700
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Priority: 3
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 5.00.2919.6700
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V5.00.2919.6700
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Question # 8 rephrased: Zero tolerance or harm reduction?

BodhiInSF wrote:

>   To A nonymous:
>  I respectfully disagree that my question that I posed to the list was
naive.
> Enough said about that.

Bodhi, I hope you didn't take offense. I respect you and I like the
questions you have been posing to us. I do, however, prefer your rephrased
question in this instance.

>   IM rephrasing the question as, " Zero tolerance or harm reduction, which
> should the scene embrace and why?"

I believe that harm reduction is the way to go with the drug issue in every
case, not just where the rave scene is concerned.

On one hand, a zero tolerance policy amounts to burying your head in the
sand. Drug use continues whether it is "tolerated" or not. On the other, it
compounds the problem.

People that prefer a zero tolerance "solution" generally make the assumption
that there is no such thing as responsible drug use. There is a risk
associated with taking drugs. Some argue that this risk makes taking drugs
an inherently irresponsible thing to do. I deny that. If that were the case,
skydiving couldn't be done responsibly because there is always a risk
involved. The fact is that, that risk can be reduced, and reducing the risk
is exactly what a responsible skydiver or drug user does. A zero tolerance
policy does nothing but make it harder to reduce that risk.

If skydiving were illegal, some people would still jump, only they'd be
jumping with chutes manufactured without regulated safety standards, new
skydivers would learn from people without verifiable credentials, and
skydivers who were caught would find their lives ruined by imprisonment and
legal bills. That's fairly analogous to the current state of recreational
drug use. Thankfully, there are some organizations like Dancesafe that try
to provide education and services to help drug users reduce their risk. A
zero tolerance policy would make it harder or impossible for such
organizations to work effectively. But drug use would continue just the
same.

Allow me one more analogy.

Imagine a long straight stretch of highway where the speed limit is 55 but
where the average speed is actually 65. You have two choices. Enforce the
speed limit or change it. If you enforce it, you can only enforce it
partially because you don't have the resources to stop every car that is
going over 55. Furthermore, the resources that you sink into enforcing the
speed on the highway can't be used elsewhere to enforce the speed on other
roads. The unreasonable hope is that people will slow down out of fear of
being ticketed. The more likely outcome is that, over time, people will
learn to avoid the highway, take more circuitous routes on perhaps more
dangerous roads, and drive even faster so that they can get from point A to
point B in the same amount of time it would take driving on the highway at
65. The point I'm trying to make is that policy needs to take into account
the desires of the people. If the people want to do drugs or drive 65, they
should be allowed. The best we can do is make it safer for them do indulge
themselves.




---------------------------------------------------------------------
To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

night, and while it does not match the box, my hair
does

you first put the color on, and it is super vivrant
for a 
couple of weeks? that's what it is like now, so i am
not completely comfortable with it, but nonetheless,
it is 
rather interesting...my hair is now currently a shade
of color very similar to the color my hair was when i
was 
around eight years old. not what i had planned, but
not unattractive. when i go out to dance, i will get
some nice 
compliments from my friends, but also, in my mind, i
think that since i have eight year old hair along with
my 
current face, i look rather like a knome..sp?...little
science fiction/ fantasy type character...ha! it's all
GGGGGGOOOOOODDD. also, there are a whole lot of people
who 
i am glad never got a chance to meet my grandmother.
what a bunch of rude asses. :)

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Definately for a great cause

--part1_7b.1a285567.28bd48a3_boundary
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit


> Dear Friends,
> Please take a few minutes to read and act on this email.
> On May 23rd 2001 the Taliban authorities in Afghanistan confirmed that
> all Hindus will be required to wear a strip of yellow cloth sewn onto a
> shirt pocket in order to identify themselves. They claim that the measure
> is
> for their "protection". The world has faced this before, in 1939 the world
> was required, at great cost, to rid itself of Hitler's tyranny, it is not
> hard to spot his child. Those who fail to learn from history are condemned
> to relive it.
> The Taliban's record on respecting other religions gives great cause for
> concern that their ultimate aim, upon which they are intent, is
> "religious cleansing". They have already demonstrated their disdain and
> intolerance
> for other religions and traditions by the desecration and destruction of
> the ancient Buddhist statues, our collective heritage, within the
> Afghanistan. Whatever your religion, or even if you have none, we hope
> that you will agree that this fundamentally wrong. Remember,
> "All it takes for evil to triumph is for good men to do nothing".
> Please do not do nothing, add your voice.
> 
> DIRECTIONS:
> PLEASE COPY this email on to a new message, add your name and those of
> your household who wish to participate to the bottom and forward it to
> everyone on your distribution list. If you receive this petition and you
> find that you will be the 251st name on it, please e-mail a copy of it
> to:
> <A HREF="mailto:alastair@om-int.com">alastair@om-int.com</A>.
> It will then be forwarded to the UN.
> 
> Even if you decide not to sign, please be considerate and do not kill
> the petition as you will be denying your friends, and theirs, their
> legitimate voice. Instead return it to <A HREF="mailto:alastair@om-int.com">alastair@om-int.com</A>
>  
>  
> 
> To The Secretary General, Security Council and General Assembly 
> of the United Nations.
> We the undersigned are appalled by the decision of the Taliban
> government of Afghanistan to require all Hindus to wear a piece
>  of yellow cloth sewn onto a shirt pocket in order to identify 
> themselves. An individual's communion with God, however they 
> find him, is a matter of personal conscience and must not be the 
> subject of intimidation or persecution.
> The right of everyone to worship as they wish is fundamental and
> inalienable. The United Nations was founded in order to defeat 
> Hitler and his henchmen who required the same from another 
> religion with all it's horrific consequences. It is completely 
> unacceptable that nearly 60 years later history is repeating itself.
> 
> We ask the following:
> 1. That the Taliban government is made aware in the strongest possible
> terms that the world will not countenance this perversion of human rights.
> 2. That prior to the United Nations and/or it's constituent members
> granting recognition of the Taliban government this obscene policy is
> reversed.
> 3. That the United Nations widen the terms of the trade sanctions
> currently in force.
>

Subject: [sfraves] break fiends alike::delectation

There are many paths to choose from, some like it
smooth and easy, uninterupted with a nice flow.  Some
like it chopped up, fucked with, pitched up, pitched
down, funked out, and rewound.  I guess it depends on
the person, and the mood, and well, the path they
choose.

Break fiends alike, sunday at Golden Gate park,
Delectation, so gosh darn delectable!  I got there
late and was sad I missed the 'ardcore :( , big ups to
the djs I did get to hear, Megatron, Mikey J (keep on
dancin'), and Lex for keeping the path "stepable".

It was sooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooooo nice
seeing my SF junglists, I miss you!!!

Thanks for a different kinda day party!

Love,
Jess

bay areas radio stations have been forced off the air because of stringent
coppyright law. Two shining examples of Legit Net Radio and Broadcast Radio
stations are

KCSM 91.1 www.kcsm.org
The Light   1190 www.gospel1190.com

I watched as they strugled threw the licensing process (KCSM less first hand
and more story time at the dinner table). Record companies make it sooooo
dificult to do things the right way I think most folks around today just say
fuck it. Theres some interesting dialog on this at www.MP3 . I allways found
the neuances of coppyright law to be extreemly funny because in the end

From: "John B." <svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com>

Subject: [sfraves] RE: Free Music vs. Paid CDs


>
> I guess this got started because of the flap over someone possibly useing
> tracks without paying the producers.  Honestly, tho, when the flamewar
gets
> about three or four layers of ">"s deep, I lose track.
>
> But John (oh no... ANTOHER John), said something here that bugged me, and
I
> figures I'd throw in my $.02 as a music consumer, rathat than a DJ or
anything.
>  And a big fan of music I am... I can't even keep my entire CD collection
at
> home, it would take up so much space.
>
> jem@unixmercenary.com wrote:
>
> >If you don't want to pay $15 for a CD, then don't. If you feel that
artists
> >are ripping you off when you have the opportunity to listen other artists
> >for free, then you won't hear those artists. You stand the chance of
> >missing one of those artists who could be what you're looking for.
>
> I would be perfectly willing to pay $15 for a CD...  *IF* that $15 were
going
> to the ARTIST.  But that's not the case, if you sign to a record label.
Bands
> on labels are damn LUCKY if they get .50 on each CD that sells for $15.
> Courtnet love breaks down the math quite well:
>
> http://www.salon.com/tech/feature/2000/06/14/love/index.html
>
> And I will, under *NO* circumstance, put so much as a penny into the
coffers of
> the RIAA/metallica....  THOSE are the people who see to it that artises
only
> see a miniscule fraction of their CD sales.  THOSE are the people who have
> declared war on my profession.  They have declared war on my generation
and my
> peers.  And if there is anything I can do to aid in their destruction, I
will
> not hesitate to do so.
>
> And in the meantime, I refuse to support them.  They have, either
foolishly or
> usefully, provided a list of their minions:
>
> http://www.riaa.org/About-Members-1.cfm
>
> I take a hardcopy of that list with me whenever I go music shopping.  And
if a
> CD I want is put out by those people, I do without until its for sale used
from
> Ameoba, or the other local stores.  That, or I simply napster it and use a
CD-R
> until such time as I find a used copy.  Or if it's a band, I'll buy it new
at
> their merchandise table next time I see them live.
>
> *MY* life is made a bit easier in that regard, as most of the music *I*
buy
> (punk, ska, and EDM  (woohoo, somebody FINALLY gave me an alternative to
> "electronica"!!!), tends to be put out by people who think the way I do,
and
> avoid RIAA/metallica labels themselves, instead going the DIY route or
useing
> independent labels.
>
> (When you buy USED CDs, the RIAA/metallica doesn't see a penny.  A number
of
> years ago they used garth brooks as a stooge to try to destroy the legal
> principle of "first sale", much like they are useing lars & co. for their
> assault on "fair use" rights now.  Also, when a band sells you stuff (even
a CD
> produced inder a label) at their live shows, the money goes directly to
the
> band as well).
>
> Yes.... that $2 vinyl sticker you buy from the band at a concert puts more
> money in their pocket than if you buy any five of their albums NEW at the
> Virgin Megastore.
>
> Another good reason to buy USED CDs is that the profit margin is higher
for the
> store.  So when you do so, you are supporting the local, independent
stores
> like Ameoba and Rasputin against the corporate megaliths.
>
> Okay, that's all speaking as a consumer.  I know nothing of performance
rights.
>  But I have it on reasonably good authiority that BMI/ASCAP are just as
> malignant as the RIAA/metallica.  In fact, that's why I can't listen, over
the
> 'net, to one of my favorite talk radio stations from back in Florida.  One
or
> the other has raised a big stink and is blocking internet broadcasts of a
show
> I don't even listen to for music, but for the personalities of the hosts.
>
> I'm not saying the IP rights need to be totally scrapped.  Obviously the
ARTIST
> needs to be compensated for his work in some way.  But I DO firmlt beleive
that
> the current system has been hopelessly corrupted, at the expense of both
the
> artist AND the consumer, and it needs to be torn down by whatever means
> necessary.
>
>
> cya,
> john

--- Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
> wrote:
><pre>USA Today reports &quot;club drugs&quot; like E are mainstream, and may be found at 
>
>places like ice skating rinks.  Mainly in the suburbs.  What now?  Will 
>ice 
>skates be classified as drug paraphenalia by the ever vigilant DEA?  
>Should 
>parents move their children from the suburbs?
>
>The problem has NEVER been music and dance.  The problem is that people 
>
>always have and will use various drugs.  The solution is to treat addictive 
>
>disease and institute harm reduction and education programs.
>
>Apollo
>
>
>
>Popular 'club drugs' overflow rave scene, enter mainstream Ecstasy, GHB, 
>
>ketamine can be found in USA's schools and neighborhoods
>
>Club drugs, popular for years at all-night rave parties, are moving 
>steadily 
>mainstream, and kids say the drugs, particularly Ecstasy, are easy 
>to get 
>in schools and neighborhoods.
>
>Experts cite the emerging club-drug scene as one of the two key changes 
>-- 
>the other being an increasing supply of exceptionally pure heroin -- 
>in the 
>''otherwise stable'' illicit drug landscape since 1999.
>
>''Availability of club drugs has increased dramatically across the nation, 
>
>especially for Ecstasy, which has increased in nearly every city,'' 
>according 
>to Pulse Check, the twice-yearly drug abuse trend report from the 
>White 
>House Office on National Drug Control Policy.
>
>Pulse Check reports that the use of club drugs, which include Ecstasy, 
>
>ketamine and GHB, has emerged or intensified over the past year in 17 
>cities: 
>Boston; Chicago; Columbia, S.C.; Denver; Detroit; El Paso; 
>Honolulu; Los 
>Angeles; Memphis; Miami; New Orleans; New York; Philadelphia; 
>Portland, 
>Maine; Seattle; Sioux Falls, S.D.; and Washington, D.C.
>
>''The data are clear that it's moved out of the club scene,'' says Alan 
>
>Leshner, executive director of the National Institute on Drug Abuse in 
>
>Bethesda, Md. ''We are now seeing the drugs used by everybody. Parents 
>
>can't just say, 'My kid doesn't go to clubs, so I don't need to worry about 
>
>it.' ''
>
>Law enforcement authorities in Miami say that club drugs are ''everywhere, 
>
>even at ice skating rinks,'' Pulse Check reports. In New York, Long Island 
>
>youths are buying the drugs from the Internet and from dealers at local 
>
>malls. In Seattle and Billings, Mont., the drugs are sold on high school 
>
>and college campuses, police say.
>
>Last year, more than 1.4 million people ages 18 to 25 reported taking 
>Ecstasy 
>at least once, the National Household Survey on Drug Abuse found. 
>Among 
>students surveyed in 2000, 8.2% of 12th-graders, 5.4% of 10th-graders 
>and 
>3.1% of eighth-graders say they used Ecstasy in the past year.
>
>''That means 165,000 eighth-graders, kids who are 13 and 14 years old, are 
>
>experimenting with their own brains,'' Leshner says.
>
>Ecstasy, by far the most popular of the club drugs, produces both stimulant 
>
>and psychedelic effects, and users often dance all night. Ketamine, an 
>
>anesthetic used mostly on animals, is a disassociative drug that produces 
>
>hallucinations. GHB is a tasteless, odorless depressant that sedates and 
>
>intoxicates users and may be used to come down from Ecstasy.
>
>GHB also has been used by rapists to subdue their victims
>.
>Club-drug users and sellers, Pulse Check says, tend to be ''young, white, 
>
>middle-class males and females'' who use the drugs in combination with 
>
>other drugs, such as hallucinogens, cocaine, heroin, marijuana, 
>methamphetamine 
>and prescription drugs. Teens or college-age students may 
>gather to ''trail 
>mix'' at a potluck drug party where various drugs are 
>pooled and shared.
>
>Most club-drug activity occurs in the suburbs, the report says.
>
>''Ecstasy user and seller groups are also expanding to include more blacks 
>
>and Hispanics, and use and sales settings continue to expand from 
>exclusively 
>nightclubs and raves to high schools, streets and open 
>venues,'' the report 
>says.
>The use of Ecstasy and other club drugs has spawned an entire culture and 
>
>lingo. An Ecstasy high is called ''rolling.'' Ecstasy users become 
>bewitched 
>by flashing lights and music with a steady bass beat. Teens may 
>attend 
>all-night rave parties featuring techno music and light shows that 
>cater 
>to an Ecstasy user's heightened sensitivities to light, sound and touch.
>
>To capitalize on their heightened senses, partiers wave light sticks, tape 
>
>flashing ''belly lights'' to their navels or wear luminescent, flickering 
>
>bracelets called Toobies. Users may wear fuzzy sweaters or other soft 
>fabrics. 
>Some Ecstasy users coat surgical masks with vapor rubs for the 
>cooling 
>rush sensation.
>
>Ecstasy also causes involuntary jaw clenching, so users suck on pacifiers 
>
>and candy necklaces to alleviate the effects.
>Abuse experts and law enforcement authorities say that as users get bored 
>
>with Ecstasy alone, they are experimenting with dangerous drug 
>combinations. 
>Ecstasy users may snort a ''bump'' of ketamine to intensify 
>the hallucinatory 
>aspects of Ecstasy at the peak of a ''roll.'' As the 
>Ecstasy wears off, 
>users may drink a shot glass or capful of GHB to ease 
>off Ecstasy's speed 
>effects.
>
>The Drug Abuse Warning Network, which tracks emergency-room visits in 21 
>
>metropolitan areas, reported 4,969 emergency-room visits for GHB overdoses, 
>
>4,511 visits for Ecstasy and 263 visits for ketamine in 2000.
>
><A HREF="http://www.usatoday.com/usatonline/20010828/3581325s.htm" target="_new">http://www.usatoday.com/usatonline/20010828/3581325s.htm</A>
>
>
>&quot;It is only with the heart that one can see rightly;  what is essential 
>is 
>invisible to the eye.&quot;
>-Antoine de Saint-Exupery
>
>&quot;I'm astounded by people who want to &quot;know&quot; the universe when it's hard 
>
>enough to find your way around Chinatown.&quot;
>-Woody Allen
>

--- "John B." <svnlyrbrto@yahoo.com> wrote:

> And in the meantime, I refuse to 
> support [the RIAA]
> They have, either foolishly or
> usefully, provided a list of their minions:
> 
> http://www.riaa.org/About-Members-1.cfm
> 

i whole-heartedly appreciate you posting this.  as
Sar. and others can see, my label, Abduction
Productions, is not here.


> *MY* life is made a bit easier in that regard, as
> most of the music *I* buy
> (punk, ska, and EDM  (woohoo, somebody FINALLY gave
> me an alternative to
> "electronica"!!!), tends to be put out by people who
> think the way I do, and
> avoid RIAA/metallica labels themselves, instead
> going the DIY route or useing
> independent labels.
>

see, here's where the issue actually started - me, as
an independent label, just finished a compilation CD
of underground and unsigned EDM artists from the
SoCal-Raves list.  i advertised here that it is now
available.  this was quickly rebuked and i was told by
more than one person that i should be giving the CDs
away for free, or better yet, just scrub the whole run
that i've done, knock down the sound quality of the
mastering that i paid for and put the tracks online as
mp3s to be downloaded for free.

see, i gathered a group of artists, we went the DIY
route and even used fellow scenesters for all aspects
of production, making sure everyone was fairly
compensated every step of the way.  but this still
wasn't acceptable, at least here on SFR.  :/

THE SELEKTA BROADCASTS 8.28.01 SPECIAL EDITION

Join Mikey J and his guest from Tokyo, DJ
Deka(Selekta/Structure) and DJ
Yu(Selekta/Structure/Bond Era) this afternoon as they
breach that gigantic gap known as the Pacific ocean to
speak the "other" universal language, music.


: Tuesday :
| Jungle/Drum and Bass | 

15TH ST. SESSIONS - with Mikey J
"A varitable smorgisbord serving up the finest in
progressive DnB"
Tuesday - 3:00 pm - 5:00 pm PST
...point.click.learn...
http://www.selekta.com/multimedia/15street.asp
...point.click.listen...
http://www.selekta.com/mikeyj.ram

Stay tuned to Selekta's Junglist Nation section for
more coverage 
than ever before!

Coming soon from Selekta's Junglists will be scene
reports from 
participating cities, guest reviewers, label and
artist 
spotlights, breaking news on the worldwide drum & bass
movement 
and even more music reviews.

If your city's scene isn't being covered here or you'd
like to get 
involved, contact Selekta and submit a writing sample
(250 words) 
on your favorite jungle mix, tune or event. Labels or
artists 
wishing to contribute in any way should contact
Selekta with a 
brief description of the topic at hand. 

Ez
Mikey J

djSyMPLiSTiK
hard house / hi-nrg

               ::: SUNDANCE PARK PICNICS  :::
                   - the grand finale -
                 Sunday, September 30, 2001
                    Start time 10:00am

We have worked very hard to put together an extraordinary lineup of dj's to

won't be looking at the pictures online the next day, kicking yourself for 
not going. It has happened folks.
(view past sundance pics: http://www.liquidcafe.com/peeps2.html )


THE GRAND LINEUP

       ~``Forest of Fantasy ~``

Featuring:

DAVE STEIN (Baltimore, Maryland)
Yes folks, he's coming out to the West Coast just for this!

TELENE (Ear Candy, San Francisco)
Angelic Beauty and heavenly Beats together as one, need I say more?

- plus these exceptionally talented sonic manipulators -
JONATHAN GREATHOUSE (Insomniac/Bump Tribe, SF)
DRAGN'FLY (Epiphany/Teknique, Sac)
DJ PAT (Teknique, Fresno)
PAUL GORDON (Liquidcafe.com, Sac)
GABE XAVIER (Versatile Ent. Sac)
KELLEYGROOVE (U.S./S1/Stealth, Sac)
CONOR (Imagine Music, Sac)
TEEJAY (Dj Cafe, Sac)
SOLFUNK (sac)


   ~``Dunes of Delight ~``

Featuring:
BILLY LANE (Black-locust.com, Sacramento)
Experience the 916junglist mystique. Quite simply, one of the best!!

MEGATRON (MechaSoul/ASR, San Francisco)
Mega-marvelous music. 100% high octane DnB!! The man's off the charts.

- plus these highly skillful technicians -
SLIM & TOFU (UMS/Black-locust.com, Sac)
MIKEY J (Eklektic, Sac)
ROCKIT (Static Productions, Sac)
REASON (Black-locust.com,Sac)
ADRIA (Liquidcafe.com/Ascension, SF)
ETERNAL (YOU Productions, SJ)
CHRISTIAN BIRCKETT (Sac)

-Plus toast master supreme-
MC L-ski (Black-Locust, Sac)

Info: 916.466.9113  415.303.7404
Online: http://www.liquidcafe.com/events.html

Liquidcafe.com, the participating artists, and support crew, have all 
donated their time, talents and energy so as to give back to you the 
Electronic Dance Music community with gratitude for your constant support 
thru door and ticket purchases every weekend all year long.  This one's for 
you!!!


Admission: FREE, ZIP ZIPPO ZERO ZILCH!!


What to Bring:

Blankets
Folding chairs
water, and beverages
Food and BBQ stuff
sunscreen
little nieces and nephews, babies and family
Lots of smiles and happy faces

What not to Bring:

Drugs
Drug Paraphenalia
Binkies
Dust Masks
Bad Attitudes
crappy friends
Disorderly conduct
Anything that would give our scene a bad name.

Note: This will be a family event in a public park, carry yourselves
accordingly.

See ya soon.

Much love and gratitude for a great summer,

Paulie Paul

Liquidcafe.com
"Experience the difference"

Subject: RE: [sfraves] DJ looking for work

I do something different. Besides just using my tables, I also use my
high powered computer to help combine some custom mixes I've made and
other mp3's I can't find on vinyl into my set, therefore allowing me to
play for a good hour or two without sounding the same.

And what makes you think I want to be like other DJ's who have already
proven themselves? That would infer that I have no originality or
creativity. I want to do something different and that's what I'm
shooting for.

djSyMPLiSTiK
www.vulpinearts.com

Delctation deserves a rewind.

That day was made great for us because of the people and the DJ's who
came out and had fun in GGP.  Thank you so much for your support. A big
thanks goes out to the Southbay crew, (Alex, Jessica, etc etc.)
Coming two hours from the south for our little ole' park party.

Half-Lite, Rashida, Dmarie, etc etc. Your dope! Your support has
made us push for another party before things get to cold in SFC.

http://www.soulspun.org/delectation-8-26/djsets/index.html

All DJ's did uber sexy sets, to be honest.

Thanks for the support and love.

Eddie

Subject: [sfraves] DJ looking for work (Freestylie)

aww damn... As a matter of fact on Sat nights when your getting ready to go 
out if you want to hear some decent freestyle listen to 90.5 I think at 10PM 
they play all the old school Hi-energy and play requests too. I thought I 
could stump them with requesting Diamond Girl the Orig track but they busted 
that and Spanish Fly's "Treasure of my heart"

ok my top ten for freestyle:

Stevie B.    -Spring Love
Noel    -Well all his tracks rock!
Connie     -Funky lil beat
TKA      -Well most of there tracks rock
Daze    -Forgot the track my bad
Cynthia  -Most tracks are good
Liz torres   -love story
johny O   -most tracks
George Lamond  -Bad of the heart
Orig Spanish Fly "Treasure of my heart"

also the orig member the lead singer of spanish fly is an old friends 
brother which was kind of weird cause I would cane his songs and then go to 
his house and hang out with his brother..

Peace,
Macadio

Well all I know is what my high powered computer is :) I'm sure lots of
other people have more advanced machines, but to give you an example, my
music box has

800mhz AMD Thunderbird
265MB Memory
GeForce 2 MX
Sound Blaster Live! MP3+ 5.1
8x CD-R
10x DVD-ROM

Built it from the ground up to amaze me and entertain me with digital
audio and video and to help me with my mixes and original compositions.
:) Its been a faithful machine from the start.

really is the same as all the others (wouldn't THAT be depressing?!), but I

Hey all!


After a two-year hiatus the Downtown Art & Music Festival is back!!!

ART
VENDORS
GALLERIES
BEER GARDEN
FOOD
KIDS ZONE
LIVE BAND STAGE
DJ STAGES
ALL AGES
2 DJ STAGES / 1 LIVE MUSIC STAGE

Located in the streets of the historic Artists District in downtown Los
Angeles!

This is an almost free event! ($3 Donation)


Sat Sept 23rd    10am-10pm


Sat. Sept. 24th  10am-10pm





FREEBASS STAGE - SATURDAY


Presented by Freebass Magazine, FEPA, Spundae ,


Higher Source, Destiny Music, Grooveradio &  Majestic Recordings

replaced, but the numbers on the transistory don't match anything else =
anywhere. . .=20

anything ?=20

Phillips Semiconductors in san jose, they referred me to BAE Sales in =
San jose, and the lady from BAE lags and didn't call back yet. . .=20

home ? I have that fat ass TTL manual, but I think that's only for like =

Subject: [sfraves] NRR: What is a high powered computer? was: DJ Looking for work

I can't resist.. I have few things to be proud of:

AMD 1.2 Ghz (no OC) Thunderbird
584 MB RAM
GeForce 256 (yes, a gen 1 card)
Sound Blaster X-Gamer 5.1
Level 1 RAID (UDMA)

plus the usual accessories:

flatbed scanner
scsi cd-r
zip drive
dolby digital / prologic speakers

I haven't made any recent upgrades (like a new video card) because I've 
been spending money on my truck.. hmm one expensive habit replaced by 
another.. THAT's why I don't have scrilla for food..

sarilion

From sfraves-return-72128-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Aug 29 02:31:08 2001
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-72128-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 40294 invoked by uid 1104); 29 Aug 2001 02:31:07 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 40281 invoked from network); 29 Aug 2001 02:31:07 -0000
Date: Tue, 28 Aug 2001 19:23:49 -0700
From: Feel Good <info@globalparty.com>
To: SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Reply-to: comments@globalparty.com
Message-id: <3B8C5235.D5ED18B9@globalparty.com>
Organization: Feel Good Entertainment
MIME-version: 1.0
X-Mailer: Mozilla 4.75 [en] (Win95; U)
Content-type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-transfer-encoding: 7BIT
X-Accept-Language: en
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] Kharma catches up with Ex SF promoter

So here's some dirt...

Im sure some of you may remember the parties back in 91-94 thrown by a
promoter named Roland?    He was partners with Claxton in the Magic
Kingdom & Fantasia parties (at thunder bay), and also did (in
conjunction with Myself & Haliam from Rave called Sharon) The "Love
American Style" Parties, and some UG's and a few clubs at the Truckadero
(Now the Glass Cat... yes it once was a Rave & After-hours venue).
Well he sprung out of SF in 95/96 (too hot) and went to Texas where he
continued throwing big events, and was started a lot of crap and was run
out of that scene ... but NOW Kharma has finally caught up to
Roland...   read on if you're interested.

Key witness who skipped out on D.A. is arrested
S.F. man was freed from jail in Foxglove conspiracy case

Jaxon Van Derbeken, Chronicle Staff Writer    Wednesday, August 22, 2001


San Francisco -- Authorities have caught up with the key witness in the
now-resolved Foxglove conspiracy case -- a San Francisco man who
embarrassed prosecutors by skipping out on a testimony deal that freed
him from jail.

Roland Dabai Tyler, 29, was picked up by agents of the Drug Enforcement
Administration early yesterday at San Francisco International Airport as
he prepared to board a flight to Washington, D.C., with a bogus Irish
passport.

"The DEA received some information that he was going to get on the
plane, and they were waiting for him," said Lt. Jere Williams of the San
Francisco police sex crimes detail. The unit was involved because of a
pending Florida charge against Tyler for the attempted rape of a
91-year-old woman.

Tyler fled after making a deal with San Francisco prosecutors in March
1998 to testify in the Foxglove murder conspiracy case -- and has been
on the lam ever since. He was freed on $100,000 bail in exchange for his
agreement to testify in the then-pending case in which elderly men were
allegedly poisoned with digitalis -- derived from the foxglove plant --
for their money and property.

At the time, Tyler was already wanted for allegedly using a pipe to bash
a man's skull in Austin, Texas.

And on June 13, 1998, after fleeing San Francisco, police said Tyler
attacked the elderly woman at her trailer park in Hallandale, Fla.,
using a stun gun. He has been wanted in Florida for a no-bail warrant
for attempted sexual battery and false imprisonment, but the victim has
died, leaving the case in limbo.

Fred Gardner, spokesman for the district attorney's office, said Tyler
may face local charges of willful failure to appear. He could also be
forced to serve the balance of his agreed-to term under the conditions
of the original plea agreement. Some of the terms are still secret under
a judge's order.

He may also be sent to Florida or Texas to face prosecution for the
crimes he allegedly committed in those states.

Tyler's attorney, Stuart Hanlon, who brokered the deal that got him out
on bail, said that Tyler was to be given credit for the six months he
had served in jail. In addition, he would not serve additional jail time
for the charge of assault with great bodily injury in the Foxglove
conspiracy, and would be placed on five years' probation. He was ordered
to work or attend school full time and to testify truthfully in the
coming trial.

"I think the deal's gone, if he runs," Hanlon said. "The case is over. I
don't think they have anything against him here. They should just let
him go."

Tyler's testimony was considered very important because he was the only
one who claimed to actually have seen the two lead defendants, Angela
Bufford and George Lama, sprinkle poison-laced "magic salt" on the food
of elderly men.

Under a deal in March of last year, the two were given terms for elder
abuse and the murder case was dropped.

Prosecutors originally alleged that at least four elderly men were
bilked out of more than $1 million in cash, property and investments and
then slowly poisoned.

http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/2001/08/22/MNL80346.DTL

>>-----> EM:DEF Action Alert <-----

>>¡Congress Seeks Rave Ban!
>>
>>Ecstasy Prevention Act of 2001:
>>On July 19, 2001, Senator. Graham introduced the Ecstasy Prevention Act 
>>of 2001 [S 1208 IS], with co-sponsors, Senators Grassley, Lieberman, 
>>Durbin, Landrieu, Clinton, and Schumer.
>>
>>Elements of this bill concern the Mission Statement of EM:DEF.
>>
>>The most important is a description in SEC 3 of "EFFECTIVE PROGRAMS" for 
>>preventing ecstasy use.  These include communities "passing ordinances 
>>restricting rave clubs," and, "seizing lands under nuisance abatement 
>>laws to make new restrictions on establishment's use." 
>>
>>View the bill at:
>>http://www.emdef.org/S1208IS_EcstasyPrevAct2001.html
>>
>>Visit the EM:DEF site to learn how you can help stop this bill
>>http://www.emdef.org/laws_and_cases.html
>>

>>professionals.
>>http://www.emdef.org/contribute.html

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Congress Seeks Rave Ban!

At 08:48 PM 8/28/01 -0700, .aryck. wrote:
>     but who calls "raves" raves anymore ? They're all concerts and dance
>parties. All the raves are underground, so they could ban "raves" all they
>want, and the underground would still be as illegal as it alwzays was. . .




not really...


i would *love* to believe the idealized notion of the 'once it blows up, 
we'll just go back underground' theory..  unfortunately, i think it's a bit 
naive..


this isn't 1992.

cops know about parties.

they usually know where people throw parties (yes, even underground ones).

and what's worse - they have their own preconceived notions of what 
actually constitutes a "rave"

you can't just have an old skool warehouse break in anymore and expect it 
to happen.




plus, if legislation like what was passed in chicago is passed nationwide - 
it'd be VERY bad.   i don't care how down people are,  when there is the 
threat of having all their gear seized with thousands of dollars of fines 
on top of that..  no one is going to risk it.




joe

From sfraves-return-72143-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Aug 29 07:00:16 2001
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-72143-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 43505 invoked by uid 1104); 29 Aug 2001 07:00:14 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 43491 invoked from network); 29 Aug 2001 07:00:14 -0000
X-Originating-IP: [64.12.106.47]
From: "Alida Brandenburg" <one_little_etoile@hotmail.com>
To: snowhuoue@mindspring.com, BodhiInSF@aol.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org
Bcc: 
Date: Tue, 28 Aug 2001 23:59:39 -0700
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <F60z6g6m8XFlx6EIfu40000152c@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 29 Aug 2001 06:59:39.0573 (UTC) FILETIME=[2BF3AE50:01C13058]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Question # 8 rephrased: Zero tolerance or harm reduction?

>From: "A. Nonymous" <snowhuoue@mindspring.com>
>To: <BodhiInSF@aol.com>, <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
>Subject: Re: [sfraves] Question # 8 rephrased: Zero tolerance or harm 
>reduction?
>Date: Tue, 28 Aug 2001 11:56:28 -0700
>
> >   IM rephrasing the question as, " Zero tolerance or harm reduction, 
>which
> > should the scene embrace and why?"
>
>I believe that harm reduction is the way to go with the drug issue in every
>case, not just where the rave scene is concerned.

Hmmm... just for the sake of shining the light from another angle, here's my 
take. In truth I am very torn on the subject.

While I 100% support the harm reduction approach, I have to disagree with 
your statement above. I think *especially* where the rave scene is concerned 
a zero tolerance approach could actually be beneficial. Raves are being 
targeted specifically for having an attitude of open acceptance and even 
encouragement of drug use in ways of open trafficking and catering to a drug 
user's heightened senses. If we were to take a zero tolerance approach it 
would eliminate much of the criticism and scrutiny. For example, there is a 
fair amount of drug use at any other sort of music event (we all know that 
throughout history music and altered perceptions have gone together like 
PB&J). Do you see congress meeting to discuss a possible ban on *all* music 
events? No. The difference is that other music events don't seem to have 
such an open acceptance towards drug use.

Again, I am very torn. To have strict regulations such as a zero tolerance 
approach as opposed to harm reduction seems to conflict with much of what 
raving is all about- freedom, unconditional acceptance, and unity. A zero 
tolerance approach suggests a rejection of those who don't abide by the 
"rules," and that there is a certain criteria that must be met for you to be 
allowed to attend raves, therefore breaking apart the unity, freedom and 
acceptance. And if someone breaks the "rules," will we punish them? How will 
zero tolerance be enforced? What sort of positive stimulus could be given to 
the user in replace of a negative stimulus? After all, that's what we're 
about. Positivity.

One might suggest a positive retribution would be education in harm 
reduction. But then we've come around full circle to the age old question, 
which came first, the chicken or the egg?

My point is that if we were to display a zero tolerance attitude it may not 
necessarily result in a dramatic decrease is drug use (although that may be 
a positive side effect), but we would be seen as working alongside the 
government, rather than against them. If you can't beat 'em, join 'em. 
Meanwhile we may be allowed what they see as a privilege and what we see as 
a right, to dance all night, and still have the opportunity for education in 
harm reduction with booths such as Dance Safe. It's a win-win situation in 
some aspects.

Alida
=HJBC=

Subject: [sfraves] AEC drawingsRe: [sfraves] -Recovery- AEC/Otherworld

I just wanted to apologize to Aryck over the list and explain that my 
intentions of my post were not that of malice, but of playfulness. I't hard 
to come across correctly through e-mail. All of you were unable to hear my 
silly giggles. The post was meant to explain why there was no drawing space 
available, not as an attack on Aryck. By the time I got to the space I was 
too involved in other things to start where Aryck left off. And Sarilion- 
many people over the age of five still enjoy drawing. There was no one 
holding a gun to your head saying you had to draw a picture! : ) It was just 
a suggestion to involve people in the party making process.  I actually had 
several people approach me asking where to hang their pictures.

Alida

We hope you all are having a great week and are enjoying this beautiful =
summer weather!  We apologize for the additional email this week, but we =
need your help.  For the past couple of months our emails have been sent =
by a third party.  They have done some great design work creating =
e-flyers for us, and have really added some flair to most of your =
inboxes.   Due to limitations with certain mail servers and programs, =
some of you have only been able to receive plain-text versions of these =
e-flyers.  However, it has been brought to our attention that some of =
you may not be receiving email from us at all.  If you have been having =
trouble viewing our emails or have not been receiving them, please reply =
to this email with the words "FIX IT" in the subject, and we will do our =
best to correct the problem.  Thank you for your help and continued =
support!

Regards,

> >So here's some dirt...
> >
> >Im sure some of you may remember the parties back
> in 91-94 thrown by a
> >promoter named Roland?    He was partners with
> Claxton in the Magic
> >Kingdom & Fantasia parties (at thunder bay), and
> also did (in
> >conjunction with Myself & Haliam from Rave called
> Sharon) The "Love
> >American Style" Parties, and some UG's and a few
> clubs at the Truckadero
> >(Now the Glass Cat... yes it once was a Rave &
> After-hours venue).
> >Well he sprung out of SF in 95/96 (too hot) and
> went to Texas where he
> >continued throwing big events, and was started a
> lot of crap and was run
> >out of that scene ... but NOW Kharma has finally
> caught up to
> >Roland...   read on if you're interested.
> >
> >Key witness who skipped out on D.A. is arrested
> >S.F. man was freed from jail in Foxglove conspiracy
> case
> >
> >Jaxon Van Derbeken, Chronicle Staff Writer   
> Wednesday, August 22, 2001
> >
> >
> >San Francisco -- Authorities have caught up with
> the key witness in the
> >now-resolved Foxglove conspiracy case -- a San
> Francisco man who
> >embarrassed prosecutors by skipping out on a
> testimony deal that freed
> >him from jail.
> >
> >Roland Dabai Tyler, 29, was picked up by agents of
> the Drug Enforcement
> >Administration early yesterday at San Francisco
> International Airport as
> >he prepared to board a flight to Washington, D.C.,
> with a bogus Irish
> >passport.
> >
> >"The DEA received some information that he was
> going to get on the
> >plane, and they were waiting for him," said Lt.
> Jere Williams of the San
> >Francisco police sex crimes detail. The unit was
> involved because of a
> >pending Florida charge against Tyler for the
> attempted rape of a
> >91-year-old woman.
> >
> >Tyler fled after making a deal with San Francisco
> prosecutors in March
> >1998 to testify in the Foxglove murder conspiracy
> case -- and has been
> >on the lam ever since. He was freed on $100,000
> bail in exchange for his
> >agreement to testify in the then-pending case in
> which elderly men were
> >allegedly poisoned with digitalis -- derived from
> the foxglove plant --
> >for their money and property.
> >
> >At the time, Tyler was already wanted for allegedly
> using a pipe to bash
> >a man's skull in Austin, Texas.
> >
> >And on June 13, 1998, after fleeing San Francisco,
> police said Tyler
> >attacked the elderly woman at her trailer park in
> Hallandale, Fla.,
> >using a stun gun. He has been wanted in Florida for
> a no-bail warrant
> >for attempted sexual battery and false
> imprisonment, but the victim has
> >died, leaving the case in limbo.
> >
> >Fred Gardner, spokesman for the district attorney's
> office, said Tyler
> >may face local charges of willful failure to
> appear. He could also be
> >forced to serve the balance of his agreed-to term
> under the conditions
> >of the original plea agreement. Some of the terms
> are still secret under
> >a judge's order.
> >
> >He may also be sent to Florida or Texas to face
> prosecution for the
> >crimes he allegedly committed in those states.
> >
> >Tyler's attorney, Stuart Hanlon, who brokered the
> deal that got him out
> >on bail, said that Tyler was to be given credit for
> the six months he
> >had served in jail. In addition, he would not serve
> additional jail time
> >for the charge of assault with great bodily injury
> in the Foxglove
> >conspiracy, and would be placed on five years'
> probation. He was ordered
> >to work or attend school full time and to testify
> truthfully in the
> >coming trial.
> >
> >"I think the deal's gone, if he runs," Hanlon said.
> "The case is over. I
> >don't think they have anything against him here.
> They should just let
> >him go."
> >
> >Tyler's testimony was considered very important
> because he was the only
> >one who claimed to actually have seen the two lead
> defendants, Angela
> >Bufford and George Lama, sprinkle poison-laced
> "magic salt" on the food
> >of elderly men.
> >
> >Under a deal in March of last year, the two were
> given terms for elder
> >abuse and the murder case was dropped.
> >
> >Prosecutors originally alleged that at least four
> elderly men were
> >bilked out of more than $1 million in cash,
> property and investments and
> >then slowly poisoned.
> >
>
>http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/2001/08/22/MNL80346.DTL
> >
> >

UNDERGROUND phenomenom. Ironically, without his hard work, ecstsasy might
still be legal, institutionalized and, quite possibly, NOT a key factor for
the youth revolution that unfolded in the wake of his efforts.  Kharma is
such a bitch, ain't it?

Has his control helped one bit?  Nope...  the harder he works at saving us
from ourselves, the more we realize it is worth fighting him and his
dillusionary collegues. And, look at the list of so called liberal,
babyboomer rock n rollers that are signed on to help. Di d they not learn
anything from the 60's?  Like I need to believe a goddamn thing that anyone
named Clinton has to say.

>>=A1Congress Seeks Rave Ban!
>>
>>Ecstasy Prevention Act of 2001:
>>On July 19, 2001, Senator. Graham introduced the Ecstasy Prevention Act
>>of 2001 [S 1208 IS], with co-sponsors, Senators Grassley, Lieberman,
>>Durbin, Landrieu, Clinton, and Schumer.
>>
>>Elements of this bill concern the Mission Statement of EM:DEF.
>>
>>The most important is a description in SEC 3 of "EFFECTIVE PROGRAMS" for
>>preventing ecstasy use.  These include communities "passing ordinances
>>restricting rave clubs," and, "seizing lands under nuisance abatement
>>laws to make new restrictions on establishment's use."
>>
>>View the bill at:
>>http://www.emdef.org/S1208IS_EcstasyPrevAct2001.html
>>
>>Visit the EM:DEF site to learn how you can help stop this bill

Subject: [sfraves] bsp.nocturnal wonderland this weekend

GENERAL INFORMATION

Event Hours:

The gates will open at 5 p.m., the festivities will begin at 6 p.m., Sept. 1=
,=20
and won't let up until 8 a.m., Sept. 2. Fourteen hours of music, art and=20
freedom, featuring mind-altering sets by DJs from all around the world.

Entrances:

Every effort has been taken to ensure a speedy entrance to the festival, but=
=20
nevertheless we strongly advise that you come early.

Parking:
Parking is FREE! The lots are well lit and patrolled by security. You're=20
welcome to arrive the night before the event and camp out. If you do this, w=
e=20
recommend spending the day by the lake, where it's cooler. It's a ten-minute=
=20
drive from the venue. Bring a swim suit; you're gonna need it.

Services:

Hot and cold food stands, clean restrooms, free patrolled parking, friendly=20
staff and security, and On Site first aid. Clean restrooms There will be a=20
high ratio of restroom facilities that will be cleaned frequently throughout=
=20
the duration of the event.

On site first aid:

Medical personnel will be present throughout the duration of the event. Ther=
e=20
will be two emergency medical stations set up within the venue. EMT's are=20
here for the safety of you and your friends.

What To Wear:

It's September. It's Havasu. It's hot. Dress cool. Wear comfortable walking=20
shoes, a hat and sunglasses.=20

What To Bring:

It always helps to make a checklist. Some items you won't want to forget are=
=20
your tickets, money, lip balm, sunscreen and a water bottle. You don't want=20
to get caught out in the desert without protection even for a few minutes.=20
So, whether you're staying for a few days or a few hours, please bring=20
sensible provisions. The Havasu sun can still redden your neck by 6 p.m. Who=
=20
wants that?=20

We fully encourage bringing fun stuff, too. Costumes, still cameras,=20
whistles, horns, drums, glow sticks, body glitter, face paint -- go crazy!=20

What can't I bring:

weapons (includes pocket knives and pepper spray), glass, cans, alcohol,=20
drugs, chains, ice chests, pets, vicks, dust mask, balloons, video cameras,=20
(flash/still cameras are OK), markers, spray paint and food/beverages, Bad=20
Vibes!

What am I wearing:

Plan out your clothing and footwear. It can be really hot in the area during=
=20
this time of year. Shorts and swimsuits are recommended. Mist tents will be=20
provided for a quick cool down.

When you arrive at Nocturnal Wonderland:

* Learn the layout when you arrive and arrange times and places to meet=20
friends.

* Locate the safety services, toilets, food, drinks, and water sources.

* Upon arrival maps will be handed out and are also available on our web sit=
e.

hey all!

one of our roomates is leaving us unexpectedly and we're trying to fill up
the room ASAP so he doesnt have to keep paying when hes not actually living
here. all three of us who are staying are cal students, but we're not really
looking for just cal students. we're in downtown berkeley on hearst, between
shattuck and milvia, close to bart and busses. :) there are 4 bedrooms so
youll get your own room, and a door leading out to the balcony as well as a
skylight in your room. the place is pretty roomy, but there is only one
bathroom. also, donkey, the cat, lives with us so youd have to be okay with
cats. the rent is $710 and the total move in cost is first and last months
rent plus a $100 deposit. we pay for pg&e and cable, the landlord takes care
of water and garbage. theres no parking, but the street parking around here
isnt too bad.

uhm...thats all i can think of. :) email me or call me on my cell phone
(510-384-5246) if youre interested in seeing the house and stuff.

oh yah...the house is available sept. 1.

take care!

- brook

Subject: [sfraves] Re: bsp.nocturnal wonderland this weekend

Just a slight correction... Mark Farina Will NOT BE at Nocturnal Wonderland, He
canceled on the event (to far I guess?)    He is Contracted and confirmed
EXCLUSIVELY for Megga-Buzz.    Have Fun and be safe no matter where you end up
going this weekend.

Keep it alive, Vlad

Yarrow220@aol.com wrote:

> GENERAL INFORMATION
>
> Event Hours:
>
> The gates will open at 5 p.m., the festivities will begin at 6 p.m., Sept. 1,
> and won't let up until 8 a.m., Sept. 2. Fourteen hours of music, art and
> freedom, featuring mind-altering sets by DJs from all around the world.
>
> Entrances:
>
> Every effort has been taken to ensure a speedy entrance to the festival, but
> nevertheless we strongly advise that you come early.
>
> Parking:
> Parking is FREE! The lots are well lit and patrolled by security. You're
> welcome to arrive the night before the event and camp out. If you do this, we
> recommend spending the day by the lake, where it's cooler. It's a ten-minute
> drive from the venue. Bring a swim suit; you're gonna need it.
>
> Services:
>
> Hot and cold food stands, clean restrooms, free patrolled parking, friendly
> staff and security, and On Site first aid. Clean restrooms There will be a
> high ratio of restroom facilities that will be cleaned frequently throughout
> the duration of the event.
>
> On site first aid:
>
> Medical personnel will be present throughout the duration of the event. There
> will be two emergency medical stations set up within the venue. EMT's are
> here for the safety of you and your friends.
>
> What To Wear:
>
> It's September. It's Havasu. It's hot. Dress cool. Wear comfortable walking
> shoes, a hat and sunglasses.
>
> What To Bring:
>
> It always helps to make a checklist. Some items you won't want to forget are
> your tickets, money, lip balm, sunscreen and a water bottle. You don't want
> to get caught out in the desert without protection even for a few minutes.
> So, whether you're staying for a few days or a few hours, please bring
> sensible provisions. The Havasu sun can still redden your neck by 6 p.m. Who
> wants that?
>
> We fully encourage bringing fun stuff, too. Costumes, still cameras,
> whistles, horns, drums, glow sticks, body glitter, face paint -- go crazy!
>
> What can't I bring:
>
> weapons (includes pocket knives and pepper spray), glass, cans, alcohol,
> drugs, chains, ice chests, pets, vicks, dust mask, balloons, video cameras,
> (flash/still cameras are OK), markers, spray paint and food/beverages, Bad
> Vibes!
>
> What am I wearing:
>
> Plan out your clothing and footwear. It can be really hot in the area during
> this time of year. Shorts and swimsuits are recommended. Mist tents will be
> provided for a quick cool down.
>
> When you arrive at Nocturnal Wonderland:
>
> * Learn the layout when you arrive and arrange times and places to meet
> friends.
>
> * Locate the safety services, toilets, food, drinks, and water sources.
>
> * Upon arrival maps will be handed out and are also available on our web site.
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Re: bsp.nocturnal wonderland this weekend

> Just a slight correction... Mark Farina Will NOT BE at Nocturnal
Wonderland, He
> canceled on the event (to far I guess?)    He is Contracted and confirmed
> EXCLUSIVELY for Megga-Buzz.    Have Fun and be safe no matter where you
end up

Hahahaha too far? What a loser. Who would want to see a DJ perform that
wasnt willing to play an event just because its a few hours farther away?
They obviously arent in it for the scene. You don't see all those UK DJs
cancelling (too far? It's an entirely different fucking continent!!) So, I'd
rather go to Nocturnal Wonderland because all the DJs there will have been
willing to go to extra distance to give a great performance!!!

Laurence

-----
Laurence Maar
Developer, Alliance United
-----
Claudia Pfister, a spokeswoman for a Berlin animal rights group, said that
she feared the event would lead to copycat art, such as, get ready for this:
"people throwing their pet dogs out of windows."

Now this crazy bitch is just trying to get offended. She thinks that people
will see a pile of beef fall from a helicopter, and she's worried they're
going to drop their dog out of a window? For that to happen people not only
have to watch Austrian performance art, but they'd have to think their
window was a helicopter, and then forget that dogs are not cows. You might
as well worry that they're going to shave their balls and learn to fly.

- Seanbaby
-----
Among my friends, there is a running joke about me being "molested in New
York."

- Sadie

Last message you got from me was asking about how much a paid DJ gig is.
Well, in my research, I found an a great list.
I know about an amazing paid gigs list available to you: 
There is work in : SF, USA, UK, Canada and a few OZ, NZ, Europe 

"round up" is a mailing list where of a couple of hundred or more 
paid gigs in arts and entertainment to you over 5 week days. 
Subscription is $25 per year. Many other services like this charge $25 
per month and don't send as many gigs out as "round up". 

A few categories of gigs and crew we cater to: 
Art 
Acting, Extras and Voice 
Theater and Events 
Film TV Video Crew 
Costume and Wardrobe 
Dance 
Modeling 
Performance Artists 
Entertainers and Performance Artists 
Production Crew 
Music 
Radio 
DJ 
Photo 
Hair and Make up 
Costume and Wardrobe 
Writers 
Museum and Gallery 
Admin and Management 
Misc 

emailed to you five days a week 
200 to 300 gigs a week 
union and non union 
We post PAID GIGS only 
created by artists for artists 

Did you know you can save the planet with just a flick 
of the wrist? Sure thing... you make your hand grab 
eviro friendly products from the super market shelf. 
More people do that then the companies will have to 
sway under mass consumer pressure.

Date: Mon, 27 Aug 2001 10:54:00 -0700
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <F31AIBBrnUTqy6lCwGX000058fd@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 29 Aug 2001 17:18:44.0671 (UTC) FILETIME=[A827D4F0:01C130AE]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] AEC

Wow, just wanted to throw in my two cents on what was really a wonderful 
party.  Up until about 12:45 it looked like i wouldn't be able to convince 
my girlfriend to put aside here work-week weariness and come on out, but 
after much pleading we were off to the map points.  I have to say that 
getting through the map points was more fun than plenty of parties i've been 
to :)

Well we arrived just after 2 and inched along that ridiculously dark road up 
to the party site.  Man, i was genuinely concerned that we might head off 
the road... damn the glare those dashlights create...

Unfortunately i'd been completely unable to get a nap before the party, but 
an energy bar provided me with enough pep to get out there and dance for a 
while.  Sadly it didn't provide enough pep to keep me going all night, so my 
girl and i took a bit of a nap between 4:30 and 6, so if you saw two ppl 
crashed out on a blanket near that lunar landscape pit, that was us.

Unfortunately it was so dark (SO DARK) and i was a tired boy, so i missed 
out on meeting ANYONE.  How that happens i have no idea, but i think i have 
a special talent for it.  Ah well, if anyone saw me out there in my blue 
hoody and green jacket, say hi next time we see each other, maybe i can 
break the not meeting ppl curse/streak.

But thanks to the SFR-planners for such a fun party, the location was 
incredible, the star-gazing was great, any chance to see the red stickman is 
more than welcome, and the DJs did fantastic jobs spinning new genres!  
Props to the crew, i had a great time.

Zack

From sfraves-return-72167-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Aug 29 18:30:46 2001

Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org

Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 24939 invoked from network); 29 Aug 2001 18:30:45 -0000
Message-ID: <023201c130b8$50401fe0$ec8cf5d1@sauoq>
From: "A. Nonymous" <snowhuoue@mindspring.com>
To: "Alida Brandenburg" <one_little_etoile@hotmail.com>, <BodhiInSF@aol.com>,
        <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
References: <F60z6g6m8XFlx6EIfu40000152c@hotmail.com>
Date: Wed, 29 Aug 2001 11:27:50 -0700
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="iso-8859-1"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Priority: 3
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook Express 5.00.2919.6700
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V5.00.2919.6700
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Question # 8 rephrased: Zero tolerance or harm reduction?

Alida Brandenburg wrote:

> I think *especially* where the rave scene is concerned
> a zero tolerance approach could actually be beneficial.

Maybe it is time for the obvious follow-up question: Could such an approach
be taken?

I suggest that it isn't even a possibility. Sure, one crew or even many
crews could opt for such a policy, but the scene as a whole couldn't. Why
not? Because the law enforcement agencies are correct in at least one
regard; drug use is rampant and pervasive. That's true everywhere, including
our scene. Trying to shift our collective behavior toward a zero tolerance
stance in regards to drug use would only fracture us into two camps: those
supporting zero tolerance and those who who condone the use of controlled
substances. You might argue that this split already exists and that, that is
why we are having this conversation, but as it is now we all go to the same
parties. A zero tolerance approach seems to indicate an active cooperative
relationship with law enforcement, and if that was the case you can bet a
lot of people would avoid those parties altogether. To be frank, I'd avoid
those parties myself.

What's the U for in PLUR again?

Another point which seems to have been ignored in this discussion is that
the use of mind-altering substances almost always seems to go hand-in-hand
with countercultures such as our own which encourage free-thought and
political freedom. Even if one doesn't partake himself, his recognition of
another's right to do so is evidence of an attitude of understanding,
acceptance, and unwillingness to judge others. This is a respectable and
rightfully respected attitude. It may be an unpopular opinion, but I think
that drug use has had some positive effects on our scene. It is, for
instance, a unifying factor almost as considerable as the love of the music
or dancing is. The very "undergroundness" of the scene has an allure of its
own and the drugs more than any other are the reason it has been
underground. The actual effects of at least one drug popular among us
promotes a certain closeness, openness, and empathy in its users and many
very real, close, and strong relationships have grown out of shared drug
experiences. It also strikes me as being perfectly natural. Our events are
social gatherings and chemically altering one's state of mind in a social
atmosphere is an age old practice.

Note: I DO NOT MEAN TO ENCOURAGE DRUG USE. Taking controlled substances is a
dangerous practice and should never be done irresponsibly. Children that are
still developing physically should abstain, as should anyone who isn't
emotionally and mentally mature and stable enough or informed sufficiently
to make rational decisions about the risks they are willing to take.
Experimentation with substances is not for everyone. You can live a very
happy life without ever experiencing the effects of a controlled substance.
If you feel you can't, then that's all the more reason for you to avoid
self-medication and instead seek help through other avenues. Drugs won't
improve your life any more than television will. Drugs won't fix anything.
Drugs should not be used for escapism. Do yourself a favor and avoid them,
but if you choose not to, be informed and do them responsibly.

Does it strike anyone else as absurd that we are actually discussing what
political values the "scene" should embrace? I rather think the scene as a
whole should remain as apolitical as possible.



---------------------------------------------------------------------

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

>walking

> > >
> > > It always helps to make a checklist. Some items you won't want to

>want

> > > sensible provisions. The Havasu sun can still redden your neck by 6

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Question # 8 rephrased: Zero tolerance or harm reduction?

"Does it strike anyone else as absurd that we are actually discussing what

----- Original Message -----
From: "A. Nonymous" <snowhuoue@mindspring.com>
To: "Alida Brandenburg" <one_little_etoile@hotmail.com>;
<BodhiInSF@aol.com>; <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Wednesday, August 29, 2001 11:27 AM
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Question # 8 rephrased: Zero tolerance or harm
reduction?


> Alida Brandenburg wrote:
>
> > I think *especially* where the rave scene is concerned
> > a zero tolerance approach could actually be beneficial.
>
> Maybe it is time for the obvious follow-up question: Could such an
approach
> be taken?
>
> I suggest that it isn't even a possibility. Sure, one crew or even many
> crews could opt for such a policy, but the scene as a whole couldn't. Why
> not? Because the law enforcement agencies are correct in at least one
> regard; drug use is rampant and pervasive. That's true everywhere,
including
> our scene. Trying to shift our collective behavior toward a zero tolerance
> stance in regards to drug use would only fracture us into two camps: those
> supporting zero tolerance and those who who condone the use of controlled
> substances. You might argue that this split already exists and that, that
is
> why we are having this conversation, but as it is now we all go to the
same
> parties. A zero tolerance approach seems to indicate an active cooperative
> relationship with law enforcement, and if that was the case you can bet a
> lot of people would avoid those parties altogether. To be frank, I'd avoid
> those parties myself.
>
> What's the U for in PLUR again?
>
> Another point which seems to have been ignored in this discussion is that
> the use of mind-altering substances almost always seems to go hand-in-hand
> with countercultures such as our own which encourage free-thought and
> political freedom. Even if one doesn't partake himself, his recognition of
> another's right to do so is evidence of an attitude of understanding,
> acceptance, and unwillingness to judge others. This is a respectable and
> rightfully respected attitude. It may be an unpopular opinion, but I think
> that drug use has had some positive effects on our scene. It is, for
> instance, a unifying factor almost as considerable as the love of the
music
> or dancing is. The very "undergroundness" of the scene has an allure of
its
> own and the drugs more than any other are the reason it has been
> underground. The actual effects of at least one drug popular among us
> promotes a certain closeness, openness, and empathy in its users and many
> very real, close, and strong relationships have grown out of shared drug
> experiences. It also strikes me as being perfectly natural. Our events are
> social gatherings and chemically altering one's state of mind in a social
> atmosphere is an age old practice.
>
> Note: I DO NOT MEAN TO ENCOURAGE DRUG USE. Taking controlled substances is
a
> dangerous practice and should never be done irresponsibly. Children that
are
> still developing physically should abstain, as should anyone who isn't
> emotionally and mentally mature and stable enough or informed sufficiently
> to make rational decisions about the risks they are willing to take.
> Experimentation with substances is not for everyone. You can live a very
> happy life without ever experiencing the effects of a controlled
substance.
> If you feel you can't, then that's all the more reason for you to avoid
> self-medication and instead seek help through other avenues. Drugs won't
> improve your life any more than television will. Drugs won't fix anything.
> Drugs should not be used for escapism. Do yourself a favor and avoid them,
> but if you choose not to, be informed and do them responsibly.
>
> Does it strike anyone else as absurd that we are actually discussing what
> political values the "scene" should embrace? I rather think the scene as a
> whole should remain as apolitical as possible.
>
>
>
> ---------------------------------------------------------------------
> To unsubscribe, e-mail: sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org
> For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org
>

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

that..voice was fine all along..now, i am working on
the whole men who are black make better house dj's
(true, lots of times they do..plus, a honey, is a
honey so swwweeeeet...ain't nothing like a honey on
the mic either), 
but anyway, i've been watching some cool chics mc, so
yeah, 
girls we blow'em away. glad i know how to write so
well..glad, i can appreciate sight, sound, touch,
taste and 
smell too without resenting anyone else for it
simultaneously...
glad to uplift people, and not put them down, either.
i think 
a woman who is cold is an abomination. a cold man is
too, but lordy lord, a woman who is cold..ain't
nothing that take the beauty out of a woman as that.
there are a lot of beautiful girls on this
list..MUAH..i love you back.  :)

Claudia Pfister, a spokeswoman for a Berlin animal rights group, said that

going to drop their dog out of a window? For that to happen people not only
have to watch Austrian performance art, but they'd have to think their
window was a helicopter, and then forget that dogs are not cows. You might
as well worry that they're going to shave their balls and learn to fly.

This article was sent to you by someone who found it on SF Gate.  The
original article can be found on SFGate.com here:
http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/2001/08/29/MN150830.DTL

Wednesday, August 29, 2001 (SF Chronicle) 
There goes the neighborhood/After 33 years, children's
TV pioneer Fred Rogers hangs up his sweater 
Tim Goodman 



   The sweater has long since been in the Smithsonian. We are all fast
friends now, in this neighborhood of his. It seems like only yesterday
that he raised yet another generation of children in this country. And
yet, doesn't it seem a little odd that it's over now, that we're losing
Mister Rogers?
   In truth, we're not. Kids love reruns. And there are 33 seasons of
"Mister Rogers' Neighborhood" to choose from. But for Fred Rogers, the
last episodes have already been taped; they'll be broadcast nationally
this week and on KQED next week. At 72, he has ridden off into the Zen
sunset, the Dalai Lama of children's television, having put on his
sneakers and thrown his arms into a warm sweater for the last time. When
the last "new" show airs on KQED (6:30 a. m. Sept. 7), viewers will not
see any tearful farewell or anything different in the show. The next
Monday, the show will start up again in reruns.
   Fred Rogers was ordained a Presbyterian minister in 1962 and was
assigned to work with children through the media. He started a local kids'
show in Pittsburgh, then one in Canada, before returning to Pittsburgh in
1966. Two years later, his "Mister Rogers' Neighborhood" went national on
PBS.
   It's not difficult to fully appreciate Rogers. If you have a decent
bone in your body -- even the most cynical among you -- then in your heart
you know he's quite possibly the nicest man who ever lived.
   In television, we are given daily doses of little lies. We come to love
our characters and our actors, and then our reverence is poked rudely in
the eye once we get to know them better.
   But Rogers was the real deal. That wasn't an act he gave the kids of
this country for 33 years. When someone yelled, "Cut!" he didn't angrily
peel the sweater off, rush out to his Mercedes and lean on his horn all
the way home, cursing life. If you ever met Fred Rogers face to face, you
were changed forever.
   This is a guy who, when presented with a lifetime achievement award at
the Emmys in 1997, asked everyone to bow their heads for 10 seconds and
think of someone they loved or someone who inspired them. Inner reflection
is not a big thing in Hollywood until it becomes a hot trend at the spa,
but television's biggest stars did what Mister Rogers told them to do
because, well, he's Mister Rogers.
   And nobody cut him off. They didn't play music to signal that his time
was up. Nope. The heads stayed bowed. And when the time was up, they were
all probably happier than they'd been all day.
   It's hard to overstate how genuine Rogers is. In the media, we're
cynical by nature. It's an occupational hazard. It's nearly impossible to
imagine that Rogers was legit, that he didn't have skeletons in his
closet. Nobody wanted to probe, mind you, but it was hard not to be
doubtful, given all that goes on with people who claim to be good, to be
really good.
   But five seconds with Rogers made you a convert, made you feel dirty
and guilty for even thinking that he could be anything but as sweet and
pure as the camera showed him to be.
  I once asked him if he ever got angry, if he ever felt like, say,
smashing something. His response: "Oh, I don't lose my temper, but I get
angry." I asked him how he expressed that anger, how he dealt with it.
"Through the piano, or swimming."
   As with the Dalai Lama, there's more to Rogers than a beautiful
serenity. There's forgiveness that just emanates from him. What about all
those spoofs of his persona, whether it was Eddie Murphy on "Saturday
Night Live" or basketball's David Robinson talking about his neighborhood
in commercials? All the mean things said by cynics? "I have a sense of
humor, too," Rogers said.
   And while it's comforting to know that Mister Rogers wasn't Krusty the
Clown in real life, his true achievements took place in front of the
camera. He understood that children were beautiful creatures, the last of
the pure innocents. His brand of teaching -- his entertainment for kids
both on the show and watching at home -- bred a certain sweetness that
touched generations.
   Long before selling toys and cereal was the No. 1 goal of a children's
show, Mister Rogers wanted to instill values, to make a safe place for
kids, far, far away from guns and action figures and all their mayhem.
   Mister Rogers was old school. He didn't have much need for Japanese
animation, giant ninja turtles or even Bugs Bunny. With him, you just took
off your shoes, welcomed the guests and kept your heart rate way, way
down. You didn't have a video game controller hurting your thumb or
quick-cut images making your brain feel as if it were flying on Skittles
and high-test chocolate milk.
   You just chilled. You were mellow. You loved maps and coloring and
inspiring new discoveries. Ultimately, you were a good kid. Mister Rogers
at the very least put you on that path. Once you got older, how you
screwed up or went wrong was up to you, or whomever or whatever you chose
to blame.
   But the foundation was there, thanks to Fred Rogers. Here's hoping he
puts on his most comfortable sweater and enjoys the rest of his life,
while more generations of kids enjoy his show.
   E-mail Tim Goodman at tgoodman@sfchronicle.com.  
----------------------------------------------------------------------

Copyright 2001 SF Chronicle

CLOCKWORK

       Come share an exciting evening with Clockwork Eventz as we gear up for 
our second monthly party at the Backbeat.  Our first party was a blast!! 500 
people came and supported the first of many amazing parties.  The music was 
sweet and funky, the visual decor was off the hook, and the people were 
having a blast!!  So Clockwork gladly invites you to take a journey to our 
second party going down on Friday Sept. 14 at the Backbeat....

On the wheelz of steel...

Tony (Tango Recordings, Gathering, SF)

Simon (Future Dreams, Come-Unity, SF)

Resident DJ's...

Ron Reeser (clockwork)
Jasen Chavez (clockwork)
Anthony Charles (lumatech,clockwork)

As always Clockwork will provide an eye stimulating surrounding featuring 
visual decor and exotic dancers...Rays of light will be provided by 
Lumatech...

Doors: 9pm-2am 21+
Space: The Backbeat @ 777 Lawrence Expy in Santa Clara (old Bullswinkles 
family center)         
Dress: Come as you please...Bring your dance shoes!!!
Contact: 408-747-7742    
Repeat: Friday October 12 ~DONALD GLAUDE




--part1_ff.b792c89.28bed439_boundary--

Not intentionally, but it sure was fun. I was in IL last weekend
visitng my folk's and their new puppy. Took the puppy out back so
he could take car of business & I ended up slipping and landing in a
big pile of dirt left over from some work done on the water lines
to the house and soaked from the recent torrential downpours they've
been getting. 1/2 an hour later I was trying to hose myself and the
dog off with the water hose..3 month old puppys whould much rather
go back to the dirt than get an icy cold shower.
