X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Question # 8 rephrased: Zero tolerance or harm
  reduction?

--=====================_25175494==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed

I think everyone knows my position on this, but to restate.  Drug use has 
always been an integral part of the human experience.  Efforts to ban drugs 
have always failed.  Imprisoning people and destroying valuable 
subcultures, musical or otherwise, to eradicate drugs that are made illegal 
by, it seems to me, pure whimsy is in effect making war on the citizens of 
this country.  We should oppose those who war on us.

A sane policy regarding drug use would,at the very least, concentrate on 
harm reduction, education, aggressive treatment of addictive disease, and 
no criminal penalties for possession of socially unapproved drugs.

The rest of the civilized world seems to be moving in this direction.  See 
below.

Love,

Apollo


                                         U.S. Is on a Lonely Road in Its 
Drug Policy
Nicolas Eyle, AlterNet
August 28, 2001
Canada's recent decision to permit the sick access to medical marijuana is 
just the latest in a long series of refutations by other countries of 
America's drug policies. It comes on the heels of Portugal's 
decriminalizing the personal possession of small quantities of all drugs. 
It follows Mexican President Vincente Fox's call for drug legalization as 
the way to break the black market. The Conservative Party in Great Britain 
is arguing heatedly about whether they should decriminalize marijuana, 
remove penalties for its use or legalize it, which would permit a legal 
distribution system to be set up, ending the contact marijuana users now 
have with sellers of harder drugs. All over the world countries are looking 
at the disastrous results of America's "War on Drugs" and shifting their 
drug policies to avoid making the same mistakes.
In fact, Spain, Italy, Belgium, Germany and nearly every other country in 
Western Europe have some form of decriminalization of personal possession 
of drugs in place and the results are certainly encouraging others to move 
in this direction. In the Netherlands, marijuana is sold in hundreds of 
"coffee shops," over-the-counter and their teenage marijuana use is half of 
what it is in the U.S. In Switzerland a program to supply hard-core heroin 
addicts with heroin has been so successful at lowering health-care costs 
and reducing the crime associated with that drugs use that its biggest and 
most vocal supporters are the police and the insurance companies. Recently 
even the Ukraine, long one of Europe's toughest drug warriors, announced 
that it was going to release some 35,000 drug offenders from prison in 
September and make drug use "a non-arrestable offense."
In the U.S., 9 states have approved medical marijuana use. A recent 
conference of U.S./Mexico border state governors, organized by New Mexico 
Governor Gary Johnson, agreed that the drug problem should be a public 
health issue more than a law-enforcement one. Individual counties have gone 
even farther. Mendicino County California made marijuana offenses the 
lowest priority possible for law-enforcement. If you are a policeman 
looking into a possible marijuana crime and a little old lady calls because 
her cat is stuck in a tree, you have to forget the marijuana and help the cat!
America is in an increasingly difficult position internationally because of 
the drug war. We purport to be the leader of the free world, yet with 5 
percent of the world's population, we have 25 percent of the world's 
prisoners -- more than half serving sentences for drug-related offenses. 
Our troops, arms and money fuel civil wars in Latin American countries like 
Colombia in the name of ridding the world of drugs. Many of our cities are 
in turmoil and minorities are targeted for drug offenses in painfully 
obvious, unjust proportions. And with all this, American kids have better 
access to illegal drugs than to beer!
So who are our allies in our naive quest for a drug-free America through 
prohibition? Iran, Thailand, Laos, Malaysia, Singapore, China and a handful 
of other notoriously repressive nations. These are allies. These countries 
execute drug users regularly and have for years. These countries still have 
large and growing drug problems because, like the U.S., they refuse to 
accept the fact that prohibition does not work.
If the U.S. is serious about protecting it's children from the problems 
associated with drugs then we had better start looking around us. Look at 
what other countries are doing and see what works and what doesn't. With 
adolescent drug use up and drugs purer, cheaper and more available than 
ever before, it should be obvious to us, as it seems to be to most of the 
rest of the world, that prohibition is not the way to solve the problem.
The U.S. has gone down the wrong road many times in its history. There was 
a time when women were not allowed to vote, when it was quite permissible 
for white people to own black people, for segregation to exist. A time when 
Americans were forbidden to drink alcohol. Fortunately we came to our 
senses about these things, changed our laws and became a stronger, better 
country for it.
Sociologist Thomas Sowell once said that the difference between a policy 
and a crusade is that a policy is judged by its results, but a crusade is 
judged by how good it makes the crusaders feel. It's becoming hard to refer 
to what we do with regard to drugs in America as a policy. What we have is 
clearly a Jihad. A holy war with no basis in logic or sense. No interest in 
results or costs. No concern that the medicine may be far worse than the 
disease. Why is it so hard for us to see this and reconsider how we handle 
these drugs in America?

http://www.alternet.org/story.html?StoryID=11400

--=====================_25175494==_.ALT--

> I think everyone knows my position on this, but to restate.  Drug use has
> always been an integral part of the human experience.  Efforts to ban
drugs
> have always failed.  Imprisoning people and destroying valuable
> subcultures, musical or otherwise, to eradicate drugs that are made
illegal
> by, it seems to me, pure whimsy is in effect making war on the citizens of
> this country.  We should oppose those who war on us.

>                                          U.S. Is on a Lonely Road in Its
> Drug Policy
> Nicolas Eyle, AlterNet
> August 28, 2001
> Canada's recent decision to permit the sick access to medical marijuana is
> just the latest in a long series of refutations by other countries of
> America's drug policies. It comes on the heels of Portugal's
> decriminalizing the personal possession of small quantities of all drugs.
> It follows Mexican President Vincente Fox's call for drug legalization as
> the way to break the black market. The Conservative Party in Great Britain
> is arguing heatedly about whether they should decriminalize marijuana,
> remove penalties for its use or legalize it, which would permit a legal
> distribution system to be set up, ending the contact marijuana users now
> have with sellers of harder drugs. All over the world countries are
looking
> at the disastrous results of America's "War on Drugs" and shifting their
> drug policies to avoid making the same mistakes.
> In fact, Spain, Italy, Belgium, Germany and nearly every other country in
> Western Europe have some form of decriminalization of personal possession
> of drugs in place and the results are certainly encouraging others to move
> in this direction. In the Netherlands, marijuana is sold in hundreds of
> "coffee shops," over-the-counter and their teenage marijuana use is half
of
> what it is in the U.S. In Switzerland a program to supply hard-core heroin
> addicts with heroin has been so successful at lowering health-care costs
> and reducing the crime associated with that drugs use that its biggest and
> most vocal supporters are the police and the insurance companies. Recently
> even the Ukraine, long one of Europe's toughest drug warriors, announced
> that it was going to release some 35,000 drug offenders from prison in
> September and make drug use "a non-arrestable offense."
> In the U.S., 9 states have approved medical marijuana use. A recent
> conference of U.S./Mexico border state governors, organized by New Mexico
> Governor Gary Johnson, agreed that the drug problem should be a public
> health issue more than a law-enforcement one. Individual counties have
gone
> even farther. Mendicino County California made marijuana offenses the
> lowest priority possible for law-enforcement. If you are a policeman
> looking into a possible marijuana crime and a little old lady calls
because
> her cat is stuck in a tree, you have to forget the marijuana and help the
cat!
> America is in an increasingly difficult position internationally because
of
> the drug war. We purport to be the leader of the free world, yet with 5
> percent of the world's population, we have 25 percent of the world's
> prisoners -- more than half serving sentences for drug-related offenses.
> Our troops, arms and money fuel civil wars in Latin American countries
like
> Colombia in the name of ridding the world of drugs. Many of our cities are
> in turmoil and minorities are targeted for drug offenses in painfully
> obvious, unjust proportions. And with all this, American kids have better
> access to illegal drugs than to beer!
> So who are our allies in our naive quest for a drug-free America through
> prohibition? Iran, Thailand, Laos, Malaysia, Singapore, China and a
handful
> of other notoriously repressive nations. These are allies. These countries
> execute drug users regularly and have for years. These countries still
have
> large and growing drug problems because, like the U.S., they refuse to
> accept the fact that prohibition does not work.
> If the U.S. is serious about protecting it's children from the problems
> associated with drugs then we had better start looking around us. Look at
> what other countries are doing and see what works and what doesn't. With
> adolescent drug use up and drugs purer, cheaper and more available than
> ever before, it should be obvious to us, as it seems to be to most of the
> rest of the world, that prohibition is not the way to solve the problem.
> The U.S. has gone down the wrong road many times in its history. There was
> a time when women were not allowed to vote, when it was quite permissible
> for white people to own black people, for segregation to exist. A time
when
> Americans were forbidden to drink alcohol. Fortunately we came to our
> senses about these things, changed our laws and became a stronger, better
> country for it.
> Sociologist Thomas Sowell once said that the difference between a policy
> and a crusade is that a policy is judged by its results, but a crusade is
> judged by how good it makes the crusaders feel. It's becoming hard to
refer
> to what we do with regard to drugs in America as a policy. What we have is
> clearly a Jihad. A holy war with no basis in logic or sense. No interest
in
> results or costs. No concern that the medicine may be far worse than the
> disease. Why is it so hard for us to see this and reconsider how we handle
> these drugs in America?
>

Subject: [sfraves] Darkwave and Electro-Industrial (WAS RE: [sfraves] goths and ravers)

Heehee pretty funny post!

But yea, i noticed it said goths only listen to Christian death metal or
something.  That's not true--i know of a goth genre that many people into
electronic music would really appreciate.  It's called darkwave, or
electro-industrial.  You can find some amazing stuff that is really dark and
gothy, but it has some extremely beautiful trance behind it.  In fact, i'm
thinking of DJ'ing it, but it's just too bloody hard to find on vinyl.
	Anyways, if anyone is curious to find out more, check out some of the
following groups:  Apoptigma Berserk, Front Line Assembly, Covenant, Funker
Vogt, Die Form, Juno Reactor, Mesh, Velvet Acid Christ, Claire Voyant, Front
242, Suicide Commando, and many more.  If you want a good idea, go to Hot
Topic and pick up one of the Metropolis Records compilations for 6 bucks.
Also, i know I missed a whole bunch of groups so this is an official request
for Dr. Derailment to add to this post =) as he's a friend of mine and knows
much about this genre.
	You have to get used to the super dark and evil sounding vocals, but after
that, you'll find a beautiful dark side of trance and other electronic music
that you probably haven't been exposed to before

Otheric, you may want to check this out, and for all you other ravers and
goths out there, PEACE!!!

.:nomadic:.
www.nomadicDJ.com

<<<<{dance like no one's watching}>>>>

>gothy, but it has some extremely beautiful trance behind it.  In fact, i'm
>thinking of DJ'ing it, but it's just too bloody hard to find on vinyl.


Yes, at one point industrial dance music seemed to blend into the goth 
scene.  In many record/cd stores the genres are  lumped together these 
days.  There are musical similarities.  I'm an old industrial head and I 
still mix industrial stuff with house on occasion.  Front Line Assembly and 
Front 242 are old favorites and I have pretty much everything they released.

>         Anyways, if anyone is curious to find out more, check out some of the
>following groups:  Apoptigma Berserk, Front Line Assembly, Covenant, Funker
>Vogt, Die Form, Juno Reactor, Mesh, Velvet Acid Christ, Claire Voyant, Front
>242, Suicide Commando, and many more.


>         You have to get used to the super dark and evil sounding vocals, 
> but after
>that, you'll find a beautiful dark side of trance and other electronic music
>that you probably haven't been exposed to before


Love the dark side:)

Apollo



"It is only with the heart that one can see rightly;  what is essential is 
invisible to the eye."
-Antoine de Saint-Exupery

"I'm astounded by people who want to "know" the universe when it's hard 
enough to find your way around Chinatown."
-Woody Allen

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Who woulda thought?

That is _not_ correct.  It was an _intentionally_ ironic quote said by a
british journalist not more than 2 or 3 years ago.

i have an article at home that discussed the origin, but not in front of
me. this will have to suffice for now.

http://www.smh.com.au/news/0106/20/html/spike.html

Quote unquote

This is cited as the quote of the 20th century on
various geek sites, and it's certainly a beauty. But is it genuine? On
our behalf,
Nintendo Australia's Melanie Powell has tried to find
anyone in any branch of her company who either knew Kristian Wilson or
remembers him saying the above. She now reports: "To
the best of my knowledge, no-one named Kristian Wilson has ever
worked in a senior position for Nintendo, nor is there
any evidence the quote really comes from 1989." Bugger!

From sfraves-return-72198-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Aug 30 06:20:54 2001
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-72198-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 92063 invoked by uid 1104); 30 Aug 2001 06:20:53 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 92050 invoked from network); 30 Aug 2001 06:20:53 -0000
Message-Id: <5.1.0.14.2.20010829232907.00a3a430@pop3.norton.antivirus>
X-Sender: apollo/mail.speakeasy.org@pop3.norton.antivirus
X-Mailer: QUALCOMM Windows Eudora Version 5.1
Date: Wed, 29 Aug 2001 23:33:43 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: Apollo <apollo@speakeasy.org>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"; format=flowed
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Fwd: WTO applauded for insulting Gandhi 

I think this interesting little "action" report speaks for itself:)

Apollo

>From: RTMark Quarterly Report <ann0023@rtmark.com>
>Subject: WTO applauded for insulting Gandhi
>
>
>
>
>August 30, 2001
>FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE
>
>WTO INTRODUCES NEW MEMBER
>Gold and one meter long, phallus is brand-new technology to control
>distant workers
>
>Anti-WTO impostors have struck again, delivering a lecture about the
>rights of slavery, the stupidity of Gandhi, and the supremacy of free
>trade to an enthusiastic crowd of scientists, engineers, and marketing
>professionals--all of whom thought they were watching an official WTO
>representative.
>
>The 150 experts at the "Textiles of the Future" conference in Tampere,
>Finland heard one Hank Hardy Unruh explain that Gandhi's "self-
>sufficiency" movement was entirely misguided, because it centered
>around protectionism, and that Lincoln, by outlawing slavery, had
>criminally interfered with the trade freedom of the South, as well as
>with slavery's own freedom to develop naturally. Had slavery never
>been abolished, Unruh said, today's much cheaper system of sweatshops
>would have eventually replaced it anyhow; following this free-market
>logic to the end, Unruh declared the Civil War just a big waste of
>money.
>
>Finally, to applause from the highly educated audience, Unruh's
>business suit was ripped off to reveal a golden leotard with a
>three-foot-long phallus. The purpose of the "Management Leisure Suit",
>he explained, was to allow managers, no matter where they were, to
>monitor their distant, impoverished workforces and to administer
>shocks to encourage productivity--assuring that no "Gandhi-type
>situation" develop again.
>
>"If a group of Ph.D.s cheers at such crudely crazy things, just
>because it's the WTO saying them, what else can the WTO get away
>with?"  said Andy Bichlbaum of the Yes Men, the impostors' umbrella
>group. (The entire PowerPoint lecture is available at
>http://www.theyesmen.org/finland/, along with some shots captured by
>a video crew preparing a film on the Yes Men's activities.)
>
>The Yes Men had a similar experience last October with a group of
>international trade lawyers (http://www.theyesmen.org/wto/). And in
>July, a member of the group, again passing as a representative of the
>WTO, appeared on a major television network show about protest's
>effect on the market (http://theyesmen.org/tv.html); among other
>things, he spoke about how the privatization of education will
>naturally eliminate "unproductive" thinkers from the high-school
>classroom, a long-term solution to the problem of protest. (Because
>the imposture was not noticed and the Yes Men hope for further
>appearances, the show's name is being withheld.)
>
>In other quarterly developments:
>
>* A conference session on techniques to counter anti-corporate
>activism, normally available for $225 to corporate clients, is
>available to activists for free at http://rtmark.com/prsa/, thanks to
>an anonymous donor.
>
>* At the G8 protests in Genoa, activists distributed one thousand
>vanity mirrors, which were then used to reflect the sun into the eyes
>of attacking policemen; this fulfilled RTMark project MIRR
>(http://rtmark.com/archimedes.html), and those who carried it out
>received a $1,000 anonymous investment.
>
>The "Archimedes Project" comes on the heels of the medieval catapult
>attack on the FTAA fortress in Quebec City, for which the workers were
>awarded $200. For the upcoming IMF protests in Washington, D.C., on
>September 29, an RTMark investor has offered $500 to any Lacrosse
>team that harnesses their skills and equipment to throw tear gas
>canisters back to the police (http://rtmark.com/fundhigh.html#LACR).
>
>* A software development kit and book from http://hactivist.com,
>entitled "Child as Audience", allows anyone to reverse-engineer the
>Nintendo Gameboy. Because of content that many will find
>objectionable, RTMark has lent its corporate veil to the project,
>meaning that any legal flak will be absorbed by the RTMark corporate
>body rather than by those responsible.
>
>* The same label that enraged Geffen Records with "Deconstructing
>Beck" is issuing its fourth RTMark-sponsored release, "A Mutated
>Christmas," a paean to musical sharing illegally assembled from
>copyrighted holiday music. Promotional copies will be available in
>late September; press and radio requests should be directed to
>mailto:illegalart@detritus.net.
>
>
>RTMark's primary goal is to publicize corporate subversion of the
>democratic process. To this end it acts as a clearinghouse for
>anti-corporate projects. A list of just-added projects is maintained
>at http://rtmark.com/new.html.
>
>

"It is only with the heart that one can see rightly;  what is essential is 
invisible to the eye."
-Antoine de Saint-Exupery

"I'm astounded by people who want to "know" the universe when it's hard 
enough to find your way around Chinatown."
-Woody Allen

Message-ID: <20010830064554.9246.qmail@web10703.mail.yahoo.com>
Date: Wed, 29 Aug 2001 23:45:54 -0700 (PDT)
From: knowmad AE <knowmadae@yahoo.com>
To: raverg@hyperreal.org, sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] nrr- hehehe...

http://poisyn.com/pillz.htm

"mixmag"
Pilled to the Air Max 

Corporate logos on pills - has anyone told these
companies what's going on? We did, and here's what
they said. 

Motorola ::: [In disbelief] "No! I've never heard of
this! I've never heard of... any company's logos
appearing on these products and it's certainly not
been done with Motorola's consent. Um, I, er.. I have
absolutely no idea where it's coming from, I'm sorry,
and it's not something anyone from this company would
have given any authorization to or would comment on.
[Nervous laughter] Oh my." 

Nike ::: "Nike does not condone or encourage drug use
at all and we are very concerned that our logo is
being used in this way. The only use of the swoosh
should be by Nike on our own products. Goodness!" 

Rolls Royce ::: "Really? [Pause] I wasn't aware of
this going on! You know, the mascot is called 'The
Spirit of Ecstasy' - that's its actual name!" Later
on, after they'd thought about it a bit, Christopher
Springham, director of media relations, sent us this:
"May I request that you ensure it is clear to your
readers that the manufacture of ecstasy is a criminal
act." 

Lacoste ::: "I'm... I'm absolutely disgusted, hold on,
just wait one second... [puts us on hold for a full
five minutes] Hi, I've just spoken to head office and
we're absolutely appalled and disgusted that this type
of thing is going on." 

Teletubbies ::: BBC Children's Programmes' press
office: [Laughter] "You're having a laugh, aren't you?
I haven't seen many two- or three-year-olds in
nightclubs. [More laughter] This is so far removed
from the actual programme. knowing what the makers of
Teletubbies are like I don't think it's something they
want, because we had a similar thing when Teletubbies
appeared on acid tabs... erm..." 

Giorgio Armani ::: "We are completely unaware of any
such use of our corporate logo. We have a very strong
anti-drugs policy. We will, of course, fully
investigate this allegation." 

Bacardi ::: "We're horrified. We take our trademark
very seriously and anyone who uses it without our
permission is infringing ou rights, which is a very
serious issue. People say there's no such thing as bad
publicity, but there is." 

VW ::: "Volkswagen was not aware its logo was being
used in such a way and is not happy. Such illegal use
of the Volkswagon logo is not helpful commercially and
Volkswagen would welcome any information which would
help it take legal action to prevent such use." 

Euro ::: EU commission, Germany: "Well..! [Laughs,
then starts choking] It's... this is the first I've
heard of this, [laughing again] well, er... it's
exploitation... No, I do not think it will encourage
clubbers to consider the benifits of the single
currency! I have no documents on this so... err... I
can't help." 

Mitsubishi ::: "Yes [bored sigh], thank you very much,
we are aware of it. we haven't got a comment at the
moment, not to those questions anyway. You now as well
as I do, this is for entertainment value... So i'm not
going to answer them. I mean tis is an illegal use of
or trademark and we have got absolutely nothing to do
with it."

-----Original Message-----
From: knowmad AE [mailto:knowmadae@yahoo.com]
Sent: Wednesday, August 29, 2001 11:46 PM
To: raverg@hyperreal.org; sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: [sfraves] nrr- hehehe...


http://poisyn.com/pillz.htm

"mixmag"
Pilled to the Air Max

Corporate logos on pills - has anyone told these
companies what's going on? We did, and here's what
they said.

Motorola ::: [In disbelief] "No! I've never heard of
this! I've never heard of... any company's logos
appearing on these products and it's certainly not
been done with Motorola's consent. Um, I, er.. I have
absolutely no idea where it's coming from, I'm sorry,
and it's not something anyone from this company would
have given any authorization to or would comment on.
[Nervous laughter] Oh my."

Nike ::: "Nike does not condone or encourage drug use
at all and we are very concerned that our logo is
being used in this way. The only use of the swoosh
should be by Nike on our own products. Goodness!"

Rolls Royce ::: "Really? [Pause] I wasn't aware of
this going on! You know, the mascot is called 'The
Spirit of Ecstasy' - that's its actual name!" Later
on, after they'd thought about it a bit, Christopher
Springham, director of media relations, sent us this:
"May I request that you ensure it is clear to your
readers that the manufacture of ecstasy is a criminal
act."

Lacoste ::: "I'm... I'm absolutely disgusted, hold on,
just wait one second... [puts us on hold for a full
five minutes] Hi, I've just spoken to head office and
we're absolutely appalled and disgusted that this type
of thing is going on."

Teletubbies ::: BBC Children's Programmes' press
office: [Laughter] "You're having a laugh, aren't you?
I haven't seen many two- or three-year-olds in
nightclubs. [More laughter] This is so far removed
from the actual programme. knowing what the makers of
Teletubbies are like I don't think it's something they
want, because we had a similar thing when Teletubbies
appeared on acid tabs... erm..."

Giorgio Armani ::: "We are completely unaware of any
such use of our corporate logo. We have a very strong
anti-drugs policy. We will, of course, fully
investigate this allegation."

Bacardi ::: "We're horrified. We take our trademark
very seriously and anyone who uses it without our
permission is infringing ou rights, which is a very
serious issue. People say there's no such thing as bad
publicity, but there is."

VW ::: "Volkswagen was not aware its logo was being
used in such a way and is not happy. Such illegal use
of the Volkswagon logo is not helpful commercially and
Volkswagen would welcome any information which would
help it take legal action to prevent such use."

Euro ::: EU commission, Germany: "Well..! [Laughs,
then starts choking] It's... this is the first I've
heard of this, [laughing again] well, er... it's
exploitation... No, I do not think it will encourage
clubbers to consider the benifits of the single
currency! I have no documents on this so... err... I
can't help."

Mitsubishi ::: "Yes [bored sigh], thank you very much,
we are aware of it. we haven't got a comment at the
moment, not to those questions anyway. You now as well
as I do, this is for entertainment value... So i'm not
going to answer them. I mean tis is an illegal use of
or trademark and we have got absolutely nothing to do
with it."

Subject: [sfraves] nrr; life of dreams...

Life Of Dreams

Once loved by all,
Now forgotten like a dream,
Shunned by love,
Caressed by darkness,
Fallen from your arms,
Landing in bitter hate,
Rotting from your screams.

Once an angel in dreams,
Now a demon in your nightmares,
Praying upon your fears,
Waiting to be reality,
Tickling thoughts of death.

The bump in the night,
Followed by screams of pain,
Lifeless body in your arms,
Once waz me,
Now nothing more then death.

Fallen to my own fate,
Hated by those once loved,
Nothing to hide,
Nothing to fear,
Here is my fate,
Here is where i am,
And forever will be.

-ash andrews

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Darkwave and Electro-Industrial (WAS RE: [sfraves] goths

OK, check this out.  I've been going to goth/fetish events for the past
several years where the music there is generally know as industrial/gothic,
like you mentioned.

BUT, in the last several months I've noticed more of a trance/techno sound
being mixed in.  "OK", I thought, that's kinda cool, 'cause I like
trance/techno/whatever music also.

BUT THIS totally knocked me on the floor.  ARE YOU READY?  The DJ played
SANDSTORM.  OMG.

THEN, I saw this girl all dressed in black, looking totally goth, AND she
was dancing with LIGHT STICKS.  OMG.  What's the world coming to.

----- Original Message -----
From: "nomadicDJ" <cs@nomadicDJ.com>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Wednesday, August 29, 2001 8:29 PM
Subject: [sfraves] Darkwave and Electro-Industrial (WAS RE: [sfraves] goths
and ravers)


> Heehee pretty funny post!
>
> But yea, i noticed it said goths only listen to Christian death metal or
> something.  That's not true--i know of a goth genre that many people into
> electronic music would really appreciate.  It's called darkwave, or
> electro-industrial.  You can find some amazing stuff that is really dark
and
> gothy, but it has some extremely beautiful trance behind it.  In fact, i'm
> thinking of DJ'ing it, but it's just too bloody hard to find on vinyl.
> Anyways, if anyone is curious to find out more, check out some of the
> following groups:  Apoptigma Berserk, Front Line Assembly, Covenant,
Funker
> Vogt, Die Form, Juno Reactor, Mesh, Velvet Acid Christ, Claire Voyant,
Front
> 242, Suicide Commando, and many more.  If you want a good idea, go to Hot
> Topic and pick up one of the Metropolis Records compilations for 6 bucks.
> Also, i know I missed a whole bunch of groups so this is an official
request
> for Dr. Derailment to add to this post =) as he's a friend of mine and
knows
> much about this genre.
> You have to get used to the super dark and evil sounding vocals, but after
> that, you'll find a beautiful dark side of trance and other electronic
music
> that you probably haven't been exposed to before
>
> Otheric, you may want to check this out, and for all you other ravers and
> goths out there, PEACE!!!
>
> .:nomadic:.
> www.nomadicDJ.com
>

more trancey stuff like covenant and VNV Nation (can you imagine the view
from the decks at a goth club when it gets goin??  MAN!!)  But I have no

you just can't find it!!  I'm even thinking of getting CD mixers so I can do
it.

person who wants to explore the dark side mwahahahahaha

> that, you'll find a beautiful dark side of trance and other electronic
music
> that you probably haven't been exposed to before
>
> Otheric, you may want to check this out, and for all you other ravers and
> goths out there, PEACE!!!
>
> .:nomadic:.
> www.nomadicDJ.com
>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Darkwave and Electro-Industrial (WAS RE: [sfraves] goths and ravers)

I had this dream once where all these industrial kids at a concert were
decked out in full Road Warrior, post apocolyptic leather outfits and waving
those deep purple glo sticks to the beat of the music. It would be surreal
to see a wave of purple amidst a sea of black. I would love to hear
Headhunter dropped at a party. Hell, KMFDM - Naive (original mix off the out
of print cd that I have) is very house-ish. Oddly it mixes rather well with
Madison Ave - Don't Call Me Baby. Yes I know that's sick and depraved, yet
so amusing! *That's the way of the world - Don't call me baby - What you
waiting for...*

ryan.bailey

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Darkwave and Electro-Industrial 

About, oh, three or four years ago, I was a dancer for
Bondage A Go-Go.  It didn't last for long, but quite
fun, nonetheless.  I used to dress up as a priest, and
yes, I did use glowsticks.

Horrible.

You see, the whole goth thing brought me out of my
shell in the 80s.  And once a goth, always a goth.  I
still have all of my old vinyl...heh, I remember andyW
drooling over my copy of "Stainless Steel Providers"
at Epiphany Goes to Hell II.

So, last Saturday at Otherworld, Boomerang Fidget's
girlfriend asked me, "why do you always wear black?" 
Well, it never really occurred to me.  Floundering, I
replied, "Uh, actually, my shirt's dark blue, and my
jacket's grey..."

"Yeah, well, it all looks black to me."

doh.

I look into my closet.  All black.  Or varying shades
thereof.  Guess it's 'cause I'm still goth.  ah well. 
:P

michael
o)-<
"this is the way...step inside."

Subject: [sfraves] PLease read and post Urgent!!!!!!!!!!

Dear friends & colleagues,

I am forwarding this EM:DEF Action Alert, and urging your support of EM:DEF.=
 =20
Most of you are aware that JUJU Beats was cancelled this year.  The=20
cancellation was the result of the local sheriff's proactive agenda to=20
eliminate the event; going as far as sabotaging the sale of the land where w=
e=20
planned to hold the event.  Furthermore, the canellation cost B3 =20
several thousand dollars.

William Patterson of EM:DEF assisted us in contacting lawyers qualified to=20
represent our case, which seeks damages from the Sheriff's Department. =20
EM:DEF was very active in resolving the New Orleans case, and is now spendin=
g=20
energy on the Ecstasy Prevention Act of 2001 - a bill which encourages local=
=20
governments to restrict raves.  And, EM:DEF continues to assist professional=
s=20
with legal advice and referrals.

I encourage you to match our contribution of $250, or to donate at least=20
$100.  Their services are critical to maintaining the industry we have all=20
worked hard to build.  To donate, visit:

http://www.emdef.org/contribute.html

Feel free to contact me personally to discuss any questions you have=20
regarding EM:DEF.  I can be reached by e-mail at this address.  You can=20
contact Will directly at (310) 450-9036 or will@emdef.org.

Regards,

Brian Alper
B3cande Productions

_________________________________


=A1Congress Seeks Rave Ban!

Please forward & Post to Message Boards


-----> EM:DEF Action Alert <-----


Ecstasy Prevention Act of 2001:

On July 19, 2001, Senator. Graham introduced the Ecstasy Prevention Act of=20
2001 [S 1208 IS], with co-sponsors, Senators Grassley, Lieberman, Durbin,=20
Landrieu, Clinton, and Schumer.


Elements of this bill concern the Mission Statement of EM:DEF.


The most important is a description in SEC 3 of "EFFECTIVE PROGRAMS" for=20
preventing ecstasy use.  These include communities "passing ordinances=20
restricting rave clubs," and, "seizing lands under nuisance abatement laws t=
o=20
make new restrictions on establishment's use."


View the bill at:

http://www.emdef.org/S1208IS_EcstasyPrevAct2001.html


Visit the EM:DEF site to learn how you can help stop this bill

http://www.emdef.org/laws_and_cases.html


Donate to EM:DEF.  Suggested donation: $15 for individuals, $50+ for

professionals.

http://www.emdef.org/contribute.html


Contact EM:DEF with questions:  will@emdef.org

http://www.emdef.org

Subject: [sfraves] YOUE HELP IS NEEDED

=A1Congress Seeks Rave Ban!
By Will94117@aol.com

Ecstasy Prevention Act of 2001:
On July 19, 2001, Senator. Graham introduced the Ecstasy Prevention Act
of 2001 [S 1208 IS], with co-sponsors, Senators Grassley, Lieberman,
Durbin, Landrieu, Clinton, and Schumer.

Elements of this bill concern the Mission Statement of EM:DEF.

The most important is a description in SEC 3 of "EFFECTIVE PROGRAMS" for
preventing ecstasy use.  These include communities "passing ordinances
restricting rave clubs," and, "seizing lands under nuisance abatement
laws to make new restrictions on establishment's use."

View the bill at:
http://www.emdef.org/S1208IS_EcstasyPrevAct2001.html

Visit the EM:DEF site to learn how you can help stop this bill
http://www.emdef.org/laws_and_cases.html

Donate to EM:DEF.  Suggested donation: $15 for individuals, $50+ for
professionals.
http://www.emdef.org/contribute.html

Contact EM:DEF with questions:  will@emdef.org
http://www.emdef.org

------------------------------

End of EMDEF@topica.com digest, issue 16

For additional commands, e-mail: sfraves-help@hyperreal.org

From: SYKPROMO@aol.com

To: sacraves@hyperreal.org, sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: [sfraves] PLease read and post Urgent!!!!!!!!!!


Dear friends & colleagues,

I am forwarding this EM:DEF Action Alert, and urging your support of EM:DEF=
.
Most of you are aware that JUJU Beats was cancelled this year.  The
cancellation was the result of the local sheriff's proactive agenda to
eliminate the event; going as far as sabotaging the sale of the land where
we=20
planned to hold the event.  Furthermore, the canellation cost B3
several thousand dollars.

William Patterson of EM:DEF assisted us in contacting lawyers qualified to
represent our case, which seeks damages from the Sheriff's Department.
EM:DEF was very active in resolving the New Orleans case, and is now
spending=20
energy on the Ecstasy Prevention Act of 2001 - a bill which encourages loca=
l
governments to restrict raves.  And, EM:DEF continues to assist
professionals=20
with legal advice and referrals.

I encourage you to match our contribution of $250, or to donate at least
$100.  Their services are critical to maintaining the industry we have all
worked hard to build.  To donate, visit:

http://www.emdef.org/contribute.html

Feel free to contact me personally to discuss any questions you have
regarding EM:DEF.  I can be reached by e-mail at this address.  You can
contact Will directly at (310) 450-9036 or will@emdef.org.

Regards,

Brian Alper
B3cande Productions

_________________________________


=A1Congress Seeks Rave Ban!

Please forward & Post to Message Boards


-----> EM:DEF Action Alert <-----


Ecstasy Prevention Act of 2001:

On July 19, 2001, Senator. Graham introduced the Ecstasy Prevention Act of
2001 [S 1208 IS], with co-sponsors, Senators Grassley, Lieberman, Durbin,
Landrieu, Clinton, and Schumer.


Elements of this bill concern the Mission Statement of EM:DEF.


The most important is a description in SEC 3 of "EFFECTIVE PROGRAMS" for
preventing ecstasy use.  These include communities "passing ordinances
restricting rave clubs," and, "seizing lands under nuisance abatement laws
to=20
make new restrictions on establishment's use."


View the bill at:

http://www.emdef.org/S1208IS_EcstasyPrevAct2001.html


Visit the EM:DEF site to learn how you can help stop this bill

http://www.emdef.org/laws_and_cases.html


Donate to EM:DEF.  Suggested donation: $15 for individuals, $50+ for

professionals.

http://www.emdef.org/contribute.html


Contact EM:DEF with questions:  will@emdef.org

http://www.emdef.org

To: "nomadicDJ" <cs@nomadicDJ.com>
X-Mailer: Apple Mail (2.388)

Mime-Version: 1.0 (Apple Message framework v388)
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Darkwave and Electro-Industrial (WAS RE: [sfraves] goths and ravers)

Most used record shops carry what you're looking for. Check out 
Amoeba (they had pretty much the entire FLA catalog last time I 
looked), Streetlight, Open Mind, and Recycled Records (all in 
San Francisco). Most of what I've found is in great condition, 
so don't be fooled by beat up sleeves!

Some other artists you might want to look for: Depeche Mode, 
NIN, Skinny Puppy (and side projects, particularly Download), 
Liabach, Project Pitchfork, Spahn Ranch, Leaether Strip, 
Einsturzende Neubaten, Clock DVA, Birmingham 6, and even Lords 
of Acid (cheesy and blatantly sexual, but I'll be damned if they 
don't make people dance!).

happy hunting

shawn
shawn@trnsplnt.com

Subject: Re: [sfraves] Fw: Nikolay Soltys Caught

They have minimal news so far...the radio says they
caught him hiding in his mother's backyard (under a
desk or something?)

Anyway, here is the news article on information so
far...

http://abcnews.go.com/sections/us/DailyNews/rampage010830.html

Nikolay Soltys, the Ukrainian immigrant wanted in the
brutal slayings of six family members, was captured
today in a family member's home in a Sacramento,
Calif., suburb, sheriff's officials told ABCNEWS
affiliate KXTV. 

Despite a nationwide manhunt, Soltys, 27, managed to
elude authorities for 10 days after the rampage. He is
in custody after police found him at his mother's home
in the Citrus Heights suburb of Sacramento.
Police grabbed the fugitive in the backyard after
Soltys' brother called 911, sheriff's officials said.

Officers who captured Soltys at about 8 a.m. said he
was barefoot, dirty and shabbily dressed, "and looked
like he could have been hiding in a field somewhere,"
Sacramento County Sheriff Lou Blanas told The
Associated Press. 

Soltys made the FBI's 10 Most Wanted list, and the
case was featured on the television program America's
Most Wanted. Reward money offered for his capture
exceeded $100,000. 

Soltys allegedly slashed the throats of his family
members on Aug. 20 in a killing spree that lasted
several hours and led police on a gruesome search for
victims throughout the area. 

Police believe Soltys stabbed his 23-year-old pregnant
wife Lyubov to death on the morning of Aug. 20, then
drove to another home where he stabbed and killed his
9-year-old nephew, his 9-year-old niece and his aunt
and uncle. 

Soltys changed his bloody clothes and went to his
mother's house, according to investigators. He picked
up his 3-year-old son, who was later found dead in a
cardboard box. 

Pictures with notes scrawled on the back in Soltys'
abandoned car led police to the boy's body and gave a
hint to a motive for the killings  that Soltys
believed his family members "spoke out" on too many
topics, police said. 

In the days since the slayings, police fielded
reported sightings of Soltys in North Carolina,
Tennessee and Oregon. But law enforcement officials
primarily focused their search in the Sacramento area.


Soltys' relatives in the Sacramento area have been
under police protection since the slayings. 


KFBK Radio in Sacramento contributed to this report.

Subject: [sfraves] real life "traffic"

It's a real version of one scenario in the movie "Traffic."   The DEA 
chief's son is a raver.
http://www.mapinc.org/drugnews/v01/n1551/a10.html?111

- Matt

Source: Chicago Sun-Times (IL)
Author: Frank Main

EVEN DEA CHIEF HAD BRUSH WITH CLUB DRUG SCENE

He's the head of the U.S.  Drug Enforcement Administration.

But like any other parent, Asa Hutchinson has the same struggles over how to 
react to the dangers of drugs.

Hutchinson, tapped in June to run the DEA, was in Oak Brook on Wednesday to 
address a conference on Ecstasy and other club drugs, an increasing problem 
for Chicago and the suburbs.  He wove a personal tale of why he thinks DEA 
needs to do more to educate parents about the risks of club drugs.

After he was appointed to run DEA, Hutchinson said, one of his sons asked 
for permission to go to a "rave," a type of dance party.

"He said, 'Dad, I know there's always drugs out there, but you know I just 
want to hear the music,' " Hutchinson told a group of about 300 federal, 
state and local law enforcement officials.

Hutchinson said he told his son it wasn't a good idea, but his son 
responded: "If you have any doubt, why don't you go with me?"

Hutchinson agreed.  His son was so proud his dad was going to the dance that 
he posted the information on a rave Web site.  The DEA and other law 
enforcement agencies monitor such sites to track raves because club drug 
sales are common there.

"Pretty soon I had a call from Washington--the DEA.  They said, 'Where are 
you going tonight?' They said, 'You can't go to that rave.' "

"I said, 'I have a son who's ready to go, and you better have a mighty good 
reason,' " Hutchinson said.

The DEA responded that agents planned to arrest the promoter of the rave for 
allegedly trafficking in Ecstasy, and Hutchinson decided to stay home.

Indeed, the promoter was arrested and about two weeks later, while out on 
bail, threw another rave in a Little Rock, Ark., warehouse, where a teenage 
boy died with club drugs in his system, Hutchinson said.

"The point of my story," Hutchinson told the group, "is how difficult it is 
to get the right information and make the right decisions." He added that 
"we do not do enough to help parents."

After Hutchinson's speech, Chicago police Supt.  Terry Hillard and Cook 
County Sheriff Michael Sheahan agreed to launch a campaign to educate school 
superintendents and principals about club drugs, which they described as a 
growing scourge for teenagers and young adults in the region.

"This is something that kids think is safe to take," Sheahan said.  "But I 
know of at least three cases in which kids died thinking they were taking a 
safe drug."

Beyond education, authorities think a new law taking effect in January will 
help curb club drug sales.  A conviction for possessing 15 Ecstasy pills 
could result in a prison sentence of at least six years under the new 
legislation.

Club drugs have become a pervasive problem in DuPage County, and are flowing 
into suburban Cook County and the city of Chicago, officials said.  In 
Chicago, police have seized more than 200,000 Ecstasy tablets so far this 
year, Hillard said.

"It's going to be like crack cocaine and heroin," he said.  "It's here to 
stay."

-----Original Message-----
From: Shawn Allen [mailto:shawn@trnsplnt.com]
Sent: 30 August 2001 08:35
To: nomadicDJ
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] Darkwave and Electro-Industrial (WAS RE:
[sfraves] goths and ravers)
Importance: Low


Most used record shops carry what you're looking for. Check out
Amoeba (they had pretty much the entire FLA catalog last time I
looked), Streetlight, Open Mind, and Recycled Records (all in
San Francisco). Most of what I've found is in great condition,
so don't be fooled by beat up sleeves!

Some other artists you might want to look for: Depeche Mode,
NIN, Skinny Puppy (and side projects, particularly Download),
Liabach, Project Pitchfork, Spahn Ranch, Leaether Strip,
Einsturzende Neubaten, Clock DVA, Birmingham 6, and even Lords
of Acid (cheesy and blatantly sexual, but I'll be damned if they
don't make people dance!).

happy hunting

shawn
shawn@trnsplnt.com

> From: Shawn Allen [mailto:shawn@trnsplnt.com]
> Sent: 30 August 2001 08:35
> To: nomadicDJ
> Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
> Subject: Re: [sfraves] Darkwave and Electro-Industrial (WAS RE:
> [sfraves] goths and ravers)
> Importance: Low
>
>
> Most used record shops carry what you're looking for. Check out
> Amoeba (they had pretty much the entire FLA catalog last time I
> looked), Streetlight, Open Mind, and Recycled Records (all in
> San Francisco). Most of what I've found is in great condition,
> so don't be fooled by beat up sleeves!
>
> Some other artists you might want to look for: Depeche Mode,
> NIN, Skinny Puppy (and side projects, particularly Download),
> Liabach, Project Pitchfork, Spahn Ranch, Leaether Strip,
> Einsturzende Neubaten, Clock DVA, Birmingham 6, and even Lords
> of Acid (cheesy and blatantly sexual, but I'll be damned if they
> don't make people dance!).
>
> happy hunting
>
> shawn
> shawn@trnsplnt.com
>

Subject: [sfraves] rave bans - ecstasy bill

the part about raves is here:

SEC. 3. GRANTS FOR ECSTASY ABUSE PREVENTION.

Section 506B(c) of title V of the Public Health
Service Act is amended by adding at the end the
following:

`(3) EFFECTIVE PROGRAMS-

`(A) IN GENERAL- In addition to the priority under
paragraph (2), the Administrator shall give priority
to communities that have taken measures to combat club
drug use, including passing ordinances restricting
rave clubs, increasing law enforcement on Ecstasy, and
seizing lands under nuisance abatement laws to make
new restrictions on an establishment's use.

warrant, search it, take things, and not tell you for up tp 6 months
afterwords..

Subject: Re: [sfraves] rave bans - ecstasy bill

i think that's too optimistic a view.  what the
writers of the bill want is more anti-rave
restrictions such as what has been passed in chicago. 
(see article below.)  and how can you hold someone
accountable for people consuming drugs at a party in
your space?  that's crazy.  what, the owner needs to
be there monitoring every single person every second? 
but that's what they'll try to do.  

and i don't think it's mentioned in this article, but
there's also some kind of fine in chicago of $10,000
against promoters of raves, including djs.  i don't
remember the details of this fine, but i believe it
was first used against someone who had a house party. 


Chicago and Illinois Pursue Anti-Rave Laws 

Looks like cities and states are now following the
federal lead, threatening "rave" promoters (and those
who allow their buildings to be used for a "rave")
with criminal prosecution. This article is from the
Chicago Tribune © May 3, 2001.

City, State, target instigators of raves with stiff
penalties

By Ray Long and Rick Pearson, Chicago Tribune Staff
Reporters. Tribune staff reporters Gary Washburn and
Joe Biesk.

The Chicago City Council and the Illinois General
Assembly moved
aggressively Wednesday to crack down on wild rave
parties that lure
youngsters into environments loaded with dangerous
club drugs, underage
drinking and sometimes predatory sexual behavior.

Mayor Richard Daley pushed through the council an
ordinance that will
send building owners and managers to jail if they
intentionally let a
property be used for raves at which controlled
substances are used,
distributed, stored or made. Violators could face jail
terms of 2 weeks
to 6 months.

Meanwhile, the Illinois House Executive Committee
approved a bill that
would make it a crime to promote raves loaded with
illegal activity.
Rep. Dan Burke (D-Chicago), who handled the bill, said
he expected it to
be amended, but the goal is to make it tough for
promoters to set up a
rave.

Passage of the city ordinance, which took effect
immediately, prompted
Daley to lash out at the people who produce the huge
rogue dance parties
where Ecstasy and other designer drugs are widely
used.

"They are after all of our children," Daley said.
"Parents should be
outraged by this."

Raves are an international sensation. The
one-night-only parties are
often held in warehouses or secret locations where
people pay to dance,
do drugs, play loud music, and engage in random sex
acts. They are often
invitation-only or attended by people who learn about
the location by
checking an Internet site or calling a telephone
number listed on
clandestinely distributed fliers. Despite the
widespread popularity, the
raves can be dangerous and even deadly. They were
linked to three deaths
in the Chicago area last year.

The legislation pending in Springfield would define
what constitutes a
"criminal rave" and impose even tougher penalties on
promoters if they
knew that people under 18 would attend. Promoters
convicted in the worst
cases also could be subject to civil penalties and
could be sued by
parents whose children attend.



--- Booty Shaker <shakedatass20@yahoo.com> wrote:
> Okay, not that I'm supporting this bill or anything,
> but it does say, "restricting rave clubs" not
> banning
> them.  So maybe that just means restricting them
> with
> more strict security on drug issues....
> 
> 
> 
> --- monicat <technoslut23@yahoo.com> wrote:
> > the part about raves is here:
> > 
> > SEC. 3. GRANTS FOR ECSTASY ABUSE PREVENTION.
> > 
> > Section 506B(c) of title V of the Public Health
> > Service Act is amended by adding at the end the
> > following:
> > 
> > `(3) EFFECTIVE PROGRAMS-
> > 
> > `(A) IN GENERAL- In addition to the priority under
> > paragraph (2), the Administrator shall give
> priority
> > to communities that have taken measures to combat
> > club
> > drug use, including passing ordinances restricting
> > rave clubs, increasing law enforcement on Ecstasy,
> > and
> > seizing lands under nuisance abatement laws to
> make
> > new restrictions on an establishment's use.
> >

From: Booty Shaker <shakedatass20@yahoo.com>

  givemehouse7@yahoo.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org

MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] rave bans - ecstasy bill

<snip>and how can you hold someone
> accountable for people consuming drugs at a party in
> your space?  that's crazy.  what, the owner needs to
> be there monitoring every single person every
> second? 
<end snip>

They *will* hold that person accountable b/c by
letting people onto their property, they are taking
responsibility for what they do.  That's why clubs
have security.  I'm not sure how things are done over
in Cali as I am from DC, but over here, you're
practically felt up as a means of security going into
the club.

Back in '99 we had a much loved party (Buzz) shut down
b/c Fox decided they wanted a new Edge to their story
and came in over exaggerating the "blatent drug use"
that was going on.  Luckily, due to much fanagling and
a lawsuit against Fox5, Buzz was allowed to re-open
under certain restrictions.  

The manager/owner or promotoer *is* responsible.  To
say that they wouldn't be is absolutely absurd.  I'm
not saying it's right, that's just the way it is.

Content-Type: text/plain; format=flowed
Message-ID: <F192S8YV2btIXwGO5EE00002215@hotmail.com>
X-OriginalArrivalTime: 30 Aug 2001 20:23:24.0376 (UTC) FILETIME=[9E966580:01C13191]
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] rave bans - ecstasy bill

I just wanted to correct the history referenced in this message.  On May 7th 
1999, Buzz shut itself down because of the negative publicity from the 
"news" report that aired that week on the Washington, DC channel Fox 5.  
Many of us gathered to protest at the Fox-5 headquarters over the next few 
weeks and gained positive media coverage for the scene in the Washington 
Post and elsewhere.

To my knowledge, there was never a lawsuit against Fox 5 and even if there 
was, it did not cause Buzz to reopen.  A month and a half after the report, 
the venue owner and the promoters decided to reopen the club night under a 
different name (Sting) and prohibited pacifiers, vicks, etc. (the list was 
like 12 items long) as a defensive measure.

In reference to your more general point, the venue owner and promoters 
should not be held responsible for drug use that occurs inside.  This would 
be the same as holding ampitheatres responsible for anyone who smokes pot at 
a rock concert.  The idea of prohibiting symbols of rave culture as a means 
of reducing drug use is a bad idea that Buzz helped popularize.

I was happy to see that the ACLU won their injunction agains the New Orleans 
club plea agreement banning glowsticks and pacifiers.  They have shown that 
it is important to promote raving as an expressive activity in our fight 
against the repression of rave culture.  I encourage everyone to read the 
ACLU legal documents which make this point.
http://www.emdef.org/pdf/082101_behan_memorandum.pdf
http://www.emdef.org/pdf/082101_behan.pdf

I will be returning to Buzz on September 28th when I will be in town to 
scale fences in our nations capital (http://www.abolishthebank.org).  It is 
a very different space than it used to be and the Buzz transition 
illustrates the problem with driving rave culture completely into clubs and 
concert venues.  It truly has lost much of its originality, though we will 
still enjoy our reunion trip.

Matt Grossmann
icq: 4984980
aolim: godisunity
matthewg@uclink.berkeley.edu

Original Message Follows----
From: Booty Shaker <shakedatass20@yahoo.com>
To: monicat <technoslut23@yahoo.com>, Booty Shaker 
<shakedatass20@yahoo.com>,  givemehouse7@yahoo.com, sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: [sfraves] rave bans - ecstasy bill
Date: Thu, 30 Aug 2001 12:39:49 -0700 (PDT)

<snip>and how can you hold someone
 > accountable for people consuming drugs at a party in
 > your space?  that's crazy.  what, the owner needs to
 > be there monitoring every single person every
 > second?
<end snip>

They *will* hold that person accountable b/c by
letting people onto their property, they are taking
responsibility for what they do.  That's why clubs
have security.  I'm not sure how things are done over
in Cali as I am from DC, but over here, you're
practically felt up as a means of security going into
the club.

Back in '99 we had a much loved party (Buzz) shut down
b/c Fox decided they wanted a new Edge to their story
and came in over exaggerating the "blatent drug use"
that was going on.  Luckily, due to much fanagling and
a lawsuit against Fox5, Buzz was allowed to re-open
under certain restrictions.

The manager/owner or promotoer *is* responsible.  To
say that they wouldn't be is absolutely absurd.  I'm
not saying it's right, that's just the way it is.

 > i think that's too optimistic a view.  what the
 > writers of the bill want is more anti-rave
 > restrictions such as what has been passed in
 > chicago.
 > (see article below.)  and how can you hold someone

 > your space?  that's crazy.  what, the owner needs to
 > be there monitoring every single person every

 > there's also some kind of fine in chicago of $10,000
 > against promoters of raves, including djs.  i don't
 > remember the details of this fine, but i believe it
 > was first used against someone who had a house
 > party.
 >
 >
 > Chicago and Illinois Pursue Anti-Rave Laws
 >
 > Looks like cities and states are now following the
 > federal lead, threatening "rave" promoters (and
 > those
 > who allow their buildings to be used for a "rave")
 > with criminal prosecution. This article is from the
 > Chicago Tribune © May 3, 2001.
 >
 > City, State, target instigators of raves with stiff
 > penalties
 >
 > By Ray Long and Rick Pearson, Chicago Tribune Staff
 > Reporters. Tribune staff reporters Gary Washburn and
 > Joe Biesk.
 >
 > The Chicago City Council and the Illinois General
 > Assembly moved
 > aggressively Wednesday to crack down on wild rave
 > parties that lure
 > youngsters into environments loaded with dangerous
 > club drugs, underage
 > drinking and sometimes predatory sexual behavior.
 >
 > Mayor Richard Daley pushed through the council an
 > ordinance that will
 > send building owners and managers to jail if they
 > intentionally let a
 > property be used for raves at which controlled
 > substances are used,
 > distributed, stored or made. Violators could face
 > jail
 > terms of 2 weeks
 > to 6 months.
 >
 > Meanwhile, the Illinois House Executive Committee
 > approved a bill that
 > would make it a crime to promote raves loaded with
 > illegal activity.
 > Rep. Dan Burke (D-Chicago), who handled the bill,
 > said
 > he expected it to
 > be amended, but the goal is to make it tough for
 > promoters to set up a
 > rave.
 >
 > Passage of the city ordinance, which took effect
 > immediately, prompted
 > Daley to lash out at the people who produce the huge
 > rogue dance parties
 > where Ecstasy and other designer drugs are widely
 > used.
 >
 > "They are after all of our children," Daley said.
 > "Parents should be
 > outraged by this."
 >
 > Raves are an international sensation. The
 > one-night-only parties are
 > often held in warehouses or secret locations where
 > people pay to dance,
 > do drugs, play loud music, and engage in random sex
 > acts. They are often
 > invitation-only or attended by people who learn
 > about
 > the location by
 > checking an Internet site or calling a telephone
 > number listed on
 > clandestinely distributed fliers. Despite the
 > widespread popularity, the
 > raves can be dangerous and even deadly. They were
 > linked to three deaths
 > in the Chicago area last year.
 >
 > The legislation pending in Springfield would define
 > what constitutes a
 > "criminal rave" and impose even tougher penalties on
 > promoters if they
 > knew that people under 18 would attend. Promoters
 > convicted in the worst
 > cases also could be subject to civil penalties and
 > could be sued by
 > parents whose children attend.
 >
 >
 >

From: monicat <technoslut23@yahoo.com>
To: Booty Shaker <shakedatass20@yahoo.com>, givemehouse7@yahoo.com,
  sfraves@hyperreal.org
In-Reply-To: <20010830193949.91023.qmail@web20110.mail.yahoo.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] rave bans - ecstasy bill


> 
> They *will* hold that person accountable b/c by
> letting people onto their property, they are taking
> responsibility for what they do.  That's why clubs
> have security.  I'm not sure how things are done
> over
> in Cali as I am from DC, but over here, you're
> practically felt up as a means of security going
> into
> the club.

i'm not disagreeing with you.  i'm saying that they
*will* hold that person accountable, which i think is
really fucked up.  i mean, say you have a ug party,
and some people show up and take drugs.  to hold you,
or the space owner responsible, is whack, but of
course that's what the state is going to do.  and it's
one thing to run a professional club, but many of us
throw benefit parties and ugs outside of clubs and to
expect us to search everyone is crazy.  

in addition, people use drugs at concerts and yet
concert promoters are not held responsible.  it's
discrimination against edm events when only these
promoters are held responsible.  

i mean, do we need to be treated like criminals when
we go out to a party?  when my partner and i went out
to tresor in germany, a very much above-ground,
popular club, there were no searches at all.  nothing.
 we were treated like adults.  

personally, i try to avoid clubs w/ strict searches. 
but i'm also concerned about how restrictions on raves
will apply to ugs, or to smaller benefit parties and
such which may be defined as "raves" because
electronic dance music is played.  

and just because promoters *are* held responsible
doesn't mean that we shouldn't resist this, and at
least resist any expansion of police/state powers in
this regard.  
> 
> Back in '99 we had a much loved party (Buzz) shut
> down
> b/c Fox decided they wanted a new Edge to their
> story
> and came in over exaggerating the "blatent drug use"
> that was going on.  Luckily, due to much fanagling
> and
> a lawsuit against Fox5, Buzz was allowed to re-open
> under certain restrictions.  
> 
> The manager/owner or promotoer *is* responsible.  To
> say that they wouldn't be is absolutely absurd.  I'm
> not saying it's right, that's just the way it is. 
> 
> 
> --- monicat <technoslut23@yahoo.com> wrote:
> > i think that's too optimistic a view.  what the
> > writers of the bill want is more anti-rave
> > restrictions such as what has been passed in
> > chicago. 
> > (see article below.)  and how can you hold someone
> > accountable for people consuming drugs at a party
> in
> > your space?  that's crazy.  what, the owner needs
> to
> > be there monitoring every single person every
> > second? 
> > but that's what they'll try to do.  
> > 
> > and i don't think it's mentioned in this article,
> > but
> > there's also some kind of fine in chicago of
> $10,000
> > against promoters of raves, including djs.  i
> don't
> > remember the details of this fine, but i believe
> it
> > was first used against someone who had a house
> > party. 
> > 
> > 
> > Chicago and Illinois Pursue Anti-Rave Laws 
> > 
> > Looks like cities and states are now following the
> > federal lead, threatening "rave" promoters (and
> > those
> > who allow their buildings to be used for a "rave")
> > with criminal prosecution. This article is from
> the
> > Chicago Tribune © May 3, 2001.
> > 
> > City, State, target instigators of raves with
> stiff
> > penalties
> > 
> > By Ray Long and Rick Pearson, Chicago Tribune
> Staff
> > Reporters. Tribune staff reporters Gary Washburn
> and
> > Joe Biesk.
> > 
> > The Chicago City Council and the Illinois General
> > Assembly moved
> > aggressively Wednesday to crack down on wild rave
> > parties that lure
> > youngsters into environments loaded with dangerous
> > club drugs, underage
> > drinking and sometimes predatory sexual behavior.
> > 
> > Mayor Richard Daley pushed through the council an
> > ordinance that will
> > send building owners and managers to jail if they
> > intentionally let a
> > property be used for raves at which controlled
> > substances are used,
> > distributed, stored or made. Violators could face
> > jail
> > terms of 2 weeks
> > to 6 months.
> > 
> > Meanwhile, the Illinois House Executive Committee
> > approved a bill that
> > would make it a crime to promote raves loaded with
> > illegal activity.
> > Rep. Dan Burke (D-Chicago), who handled the bill,
> > said
> > he expected it to
> > be amended, but the goal is to make it tough for
> > promoters to set up a
> > rave.
> > 
> > Passage of the city ordinance, which took effect
> > immediately, prompted
> > Daley to lash out at the people who produce the
> huge
> > rogue dance parties
> > where Ecstasy and other designer drugs are widely
> > used.
> > 
> > "They are after all of our children," Daley said.
> > "Parents should be
> > outraged by this."
> > 
> > Raves are an international sensation. The
> > one-night-only parties are
> > often held in warehouses or secret locations where
> > people pay to dance,
> > do drugs, play loud music, and engage in random
> sex
> > acts. They are often
> > invitation-only or attended by people who learn
> > about
> > the location by
> > checking an Internet site or calling a telephone
> > number listed on
> > clandestinely distributed fliers. Despite the
> > widespread popularity, the
> > raves can be dangerous and even deadly. They were
> > linked to three deaths
> > in the Chicago area last year.
> > 
> > The legislation pending in Springfield would
> define
> > what constitutes a

Subject: [sfraves] Top Ten Reasons Why Vinyl is Better than Ex

hey guys!  I know this looks pretty cheesey, but I came up with it myself
and it's my first cheesy top 10 thing so i'm proud of it, and i want to
share it with y'all =)  Write back and tell me what u think =)

.:nomadic:.
www.nomadicDJ.com

Top 10 Tried and Tested Reasons why a Vinyl Record is Better than an E
Tablet

10)	If you put one in your mouth, it doesn't taste horrible

9)	According to the American ideology of "Bigger is Better" the record
certainly wins at 12 inches versus 5 millimetres

9.5)	Therefore it's much harder to lose or misplace a record

8)	In the US, you can buy a pill for about $20.  You can get two or three
records for that price

7)	Cops don't (usually) put you in jail for being in posession of vinyl

6)	Being under the influence of E makes you want to go out and rub yourself
up against members of the opposite (or same) sex.  Being under the influence
of vinyl CAN make people of the opposite (or same) sex want to rub
themselves up against YOU!

5)	E lasts about 6 hours.  A vinyl record, while it only lasts for about 10
minutes, can be used over and over again countless times, as well as
combined with others to create a high that can last indefinitely

4)	If you mix E with other stuff, it can be very dangerous.  Hell.  You're
SUPPOSED to mix vinyl!!

3)	Vinyl can damage your eardrums.  E can damage your brain

2)	You don't have to wait like an hour for the vinyl to kick in

1)	If you are high on vinyl, it is something that can be shared everyone
else in the room.  Whether it is 10 people, or 10,000 people; if done well
that one individual high will be carried on to all of them.

.:nomadic:.
www.nomadicDJ.com

<<<<{dance like no one's watching}>>>>

 ***************************************
 Government's War on Raves Went Too Far,
 Louisiana Court Rules
 ***************************************
 
 The American Civil Liberties Union scored a victory last Friday when 
 U.S. District Judge G. Thomas Porteous ruled that prosecutors cannot 
 force the organizers of a rave dance party to ban pacifiers or glow 
 sticks.

From: Josh Mitchell <josh@cloudfactory.org>
To: ".aryck." <aK@GrooveFactoryPro.com>
cc: The_List <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <00d301c131b0$1b6b3360$1ee5fea9@simmee>

MIME-Version: 1.0

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] When you buy vinyl online, do you like it better when
 . . . 

>     I was wondering. . .  when people buy vinyl online, you know how
> theres usualy like a 1 or 2 minute sample of one side of the record,
> put up as a .ra or whatever file. . .
>     do you prefer to have one longer sample of one side ? Or would you
> rather have 2 slightly shorter samples, one each side , or even a
> short sample of every track ?

	It depends on the tracks. If it's just remix's that are not that
great then I'd prefer just one longer file. However if for say you have
techno or jungle that is gonna sound the same mostly  the same through
out, but is a EP with very different styles--then sure small clips of all
the trax's are gonna be nicer.

 
>     Do you usually search the stores by label name ? artist name ? or
> title ?

	You need to be able to search all 3, no less!! It depends on the
info you have, or the lack of info you have, so each search I do is gonna
be different.

>     Is it important to you to have a pic of the sleeve of the record
> (if it's a graphic sleeve) ?

	Not at all, that is a sign to me that the stock is not updated on
a daily basis, and I fear the store really doesn't have what they say they
have, so I don't even bother.

>     What do you want to see on online vinyl store sites ? What do you
> think they're lacking ? What do you wish they had ?

	SIMPLE!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! www.juno.co.uk   is the best example. A US
store that is based on that site would be grand.

	I wish record stores would update better, nothing gets me in a
bind more than ordering something and giving my credit card and having the
items be out of stock. 

>     Would you be willing to sign up to a sort of vinyl club, where for
> a monthly charge, you would basically have an agreement to purchase a
> certain amount of vinyl a week or a month ?

	I would prefer something along the line of a vinyl club were the
store did personal recomendations to those customers that bought alot of
vinyl from them. If I go into a local store were I buy alot of vinyl they
are gonna know what I might like and point some good stuff out, with
online stores I don't get this service.
 
>     Do you think it would be useful to have a forum where dj's sell,
> buy and trade their older or unwanted vinyl ?

	I think a ebay style auction that allowed uploaded audio clips of
trax would be the best option, I buy alot of vinyl over ebay, but having
sound clips would be really nice.

>     Do you usually just keep collecting your records, and never get
> rid of them ? Or do you replace old records with new ones and sell or
> give your older stuff away ?

	I don't get rid of old stuff, but I play a genre were playing old
is excepted alot more than jungle. I do get rid of stuff I don't like or
don't want, but alot of it to me is Bargin bin streetlight special.

	jahsh

 ***************************************
 Government's War on Raves Went Too Far,
 Louisiana Court Rules
 ***************************************
 
 The American Civil Liberties Union scored a victory last Friday when 
 U.S. District Judge G. Thomas Porteous ruled that prosecutors cannot 
 force the organizers of a rave dance party to ban pacifiers or glow 
 sticks.

Subject: [sfraves] Dave Clarke & iDance Festival

Dave Clarke is one of the headliner's at this years
iDance Festival in Toronto. iDance is a free festival
(with a bunch of international guests), which is being
held at Nathan Phillips Square (in front of City
Hall). 

"At a time when dance parties and raves are being
threatened in cities all over North America, iDance
hopes to educate the masses (and dispel
misconceptions) about this worldwide cultural
movement." 

Last year's festival drew over 15,000 people on a
Tuesday afternoon. The event was held to protest the
city's ban on throwing a rave on public property. As a
result of this protest (which was held on the day the
city councillor's were to vote on the bylaw) the city
lifted it's ban. 

I did a spotlight on some of Dave Clarke's music on
Equinox @ 1Groove.com - go here and to listen to the
archived show if interested -
http://www.1groove.com/show.php?s=equinox
starts around 1:30:00 into the show.

For more details on iDance - it's message statement
and other details go to www.Tribemagazine.com and
check out the iDance section on the messageboard.

Cheers!

G

X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] When you buy vinyl online, do you like it better when . . . 

do you prefer to have one longer sample of one side ?
Or would you rather have 2 slightly shorter samples,
one each side , or even a short sample of every track
? 

-I'd rather be able to hear each mix/track of the
record or if there's several (say a double EP or
album) then I'd prefer they pick out the best half of
the tracks.

Do you usually search the stores by label name ?
artist name ? or title ?

-My basis is mostly on the style of music but I do
have preferences to labels and producers. Some record
stores I listen to samples on, they do give a
description and I would be more inclined to listen to
it based on their opinion. I do however not listen to
records based on label, producer or title if I know
it's not gonna be my style at all.

Is it important to you to have a pic of the sleeve of
the record (if it's a graphic sleeve) ?

-no. I only care about the sounds cause after all I'm
playing the music off the record!


What do you want to see on online vinyl store sites ?
What do you think they're lacking ? What do you wish
they had ?

-I like the fact there's healthy competition in online
record stores now. Some record stores even offer
overnight delivery which is important to some DJ's
whereas other DJ's dont need them so quickly. I can't
think of anything since the stores I shop at make me
very happy.

Would you be willing to sign up to a sort of vinyl
club, where for a monthly charge, you would basically
have an agreement to purchase a certain amount of
vinyl a week or a month ? 

-Probably not mainly cause I'm looking for mostly a
specific style or sound.

Do you think it would be useful to have a forum where
dj's sell, buy and trade their older or unwanted vinyl
?

-I think it's a good idea. :)

Do you usually just keep collecting your records, and
never get rid of them ? Or do you replace old records
with new ones and sell or give your older stuff away ?

-I usually sell off my records partly cause I get
super broke spells or cause I'm not into the records
anymore. No sense in keeping vinyl I dont ever plan on
playing again.

----- Original Message -----
From: "nomadicDJ" <cs@nomadicDJ.com>


> hey guys!  I know this looks pretty cheesey, but I came up with it myself
> and it's my first cheesy top 10 thing so i'm proud of it, and i want to
> share it with y'all =)  Write back and tell me what u think =)
>
> .:nomadic:.
> www.nomadicDJ.com
>
> Top 10 Tried and Tested Reasons why a Vinyl Record is Better than an E
> Tablet
>
> 10) If you put one in your mouth, it doesn't taste horrible
>
> 9) According to the American ideology of "Bigger is Better" the record
> certainly wins at 12 inches versus 5 millimetres
>
> 9.5) Therefore it's much harder to lose or misplace a record
>
> 8) In the US, you can buy a pill for about $20.  You can get two or three
> records for that price
>
> 7) Cops don't (usually) put you in jail for being in posession of vinyl
>
> 6) Being under the influence of E makes you want to go out and rub
yourself
> up against members of the opposite (or same) sex.  Being under the
influence
> of vinyl CAN make people of the opposite (or same) sex want to rub
> themselves up against YOU!
>
> 5) E lasts about 6 hours.  A vinyl record, while it only lasts for about
10
> minutes, can be used over and over again countless times, as well as
> combined with others to create a high that can last indefinitely
>
> 4) If you mix E with other stuff, it can be very dangerous.  Hell.  You're
> SUPPOSED to mix vinyl!!
>
> 3) Vinyl can damage your eardrums.  E can damage your brain
>
> 2) You don't have to wait like an hour for the vinyl to kick in
>
> 1) If you are high on vinyl, it is something that can be shared everyone
> else in the room.  Whether it is 10 people, or 10,000 people; if done well
> that one individual high will be carried on to all of them.
>
> .:nomadic:.
> www.nomadicDJ.com
>
> <<<<{dance like no one's watching}>>>>
>

----- Original Message -----

> hey guys!  I know this looks pretty cheesey, but I came up with it myself
> and it's my first cheesy top 10 thing so i'm proud of it, and i want to
> share it with y'all =)  Write back and tell me what u think =)
>
> .:nomadic:.
> www.nomadicDJ.com
>
> Top 10 Tried and Tested Reasons why a Vinyl Record is Better than an E
> Tablet
>
> 10) If you put one in your mouth, it doesn't taste horrible
>
> 9) According to the American ideology of "Bigger is Better" the record
> certainly wins at 12 inches versus 5 millimetres
>
> 9.5) Therefore it's much harder to lose or misplace a record
>
> 8) In the US, you can buy a pill for about $20.  You can get two or three
> records for that price
>
> 7) Cops don't (usually) put you in jail for being in posession of vinyl
>
> 6) Being under the influence of E makes you want to go out and rub
yourself
> up against members of the opposite (or same) sex.  Being under the
influence
> of vinyl CAN make people of the opposite (or same) sex want to rub
> themselves up against YOU!
>
> 5) E lasts about 6 hours.  A vinyl record, while it only lasts for about
10
> minutes, can be used over and over again countless times, as well as
> combined with others to create a high that can last indefinitely
>
> 4) If you mix E with other stuff, it can be very dangerous.  Hell.  You're
> SUPPOSED to mix vinyl!!
>
> 3) Vinyl can damage your eardrums.  E can damage your brain
>
> 2) You don't have to wait like an hour for the vinyl to kick in
>
> 1) If you are high on vinyl, it is something that can be shared everyone
> else in the room.  Whether it is 10 people, or 10,000 people; if done well
> that one individual high will be carried on to all of them.
>
