Subject: [sfraves] NRR:  Portugal's Approach to Drugs

--=====================_25530845==_.ALT
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="iso-8859-1"; format=flowed
Content-Transfer-Encoding: quoted-printable

 From Fraser Clark's YOU UPGRADE mag:


PORTUGAL REMOVES IMPRISONMENT
FOR USE OF ALL DRUGS

The new law, enacted by the Socialist government on July 1, eliminates the=
=20
threat of prison for possession of personal supplies of any drug. Drugs=20
remain illegal, however - their possession is just no longer an=20
imprisonable offence. Fines may still be applied, or community service. And=
=20
a single joint could send you to the anti-addiction commission!
Possession of up to 10 "daily doses" is personal, not punishable by=20
imprisonment, but holding more than that is evidence of dealing. A "daily=20
dose" is generally less than what serious users actually consume, however,=
=20
so in practice anyone with more than a few days' doses still risks prison.

Although, if they're within the 10-dose limit, first offenders will=20
normally have their punishment suspended, anyone caught with any quantity=20
of drugs must appear within 72 hours before one of the country's 18=20
anti-drug-addiction commissions. After a hearing, those bodies can impose=20
punishment such as a fine of up to $250 or revocation of a driver's=20
license. Commissions also provide medical help and counseling about the=20
dangers of drug use.
Drug trafficking remains punishable by up to 25 years' imprisonment. The=20
sale of even a single dose of a drug to a friend is considered dealing.

Fines may not be leveled against addicts at all because of concerns that=20
they'd steal to pay them.
Foreigners will be required to appear before the commissions, and police in=
=20
their own countries may be notified.

"A SORT OF THIRD WAY"

"We're trying a sort of third way between the hard approach of the United=20
States and the soft approach of countries like Holland," said Vitalino=20
Canas, Portugal's drug policy czar. "We are not allowing any legal use of=20
drugs. It's not the same as in Holland=85. We think most people who try=20
Ecstasy or hashish will not try other drugs, but some will, so the system=20
should not leave these people alone."

The stated philosophy is that traffickers are criminals who should be=20
punished, but users are victims who should be helped.

Police appear to be more likely to take action against casual users. The=20
government hopes such young people would benefit from getting picked up by=
=20
the police. "Drug users are not criminals but the victims of crime, and=20
should be helped like other victims of crime" said Canas.


"PORTUGAL - SUN, BEACHES'N ANY DRUG YOU FANCY?"

"There will be planeloads of students heading for southern Portugal to=20
smoke marijuana and take a lot worse, knowing we won't put them in jail,"=20
predicts Conservative Popular Party leader Paulo Portas. "We promise sun,=20
beaches and any drug you like."

While Canas insists that Portas "knows this is not true," he admits that=20
his widely reported remark reflects an ongoing political battle over drug=20
policy. "We must have courage, because we must try new alternatives."

Some police have also voiced concern that dealing convictions will go down=
=20
- casual users will no longer need to save their skins by testifying=20
against dealers when those skins are no longer threatened. Other cops=20
admit, however, that most users presently don't actually testify.

Until the new law took effect, police had shown decreasing interest in=20
arresting casual drug users "because they knew that if they got a young guy=
=20
. . . using Ecstasy or hashish, and this unlucky person was sent to jail,=20
he'd probably come out using not hashish but heroin with syringes," Canas=
 said.


So, while America kicks up its War Against Drugs to increasingly insane=20
proportions (including anti-Human Rights legislation and increasingly=20
routine abuse of the law by law enforcers) Europe is moving in the opposite=
=20
direction. Portugal isn't alone. From a pilot program in London that lets=20
marijuana users off with a warning to a new French law that allows police=20
to use discretion, from Holland's long -established soft approach to=20
Switzerland's licensing of pot growing, the chasm between America and the=20
rest of the world increases to some kind of breaking point.
Oh, you lucky ravers whose destiny it is to deal the final blow against the=
=20
War on Vegetables!




"It is only with the heart that one can see rightly;  what is essential is=
=20
invisible to the eye."
-Antoine de Saint-Exupery

"I'm astounded by people who want to "know" the universe when it's hard=20
enough to find your way around Chinatown."
-Woody Allen


--=====================_25530845==_.ALT--

----- Original Message -----
From: "Apollo" <apollo@speakeasy.org>
To: <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sent: Thursday, August 30, 2001 6:51 PM
Subject: [sfraves] NRR: Portugal's Approach to Drugs


>From Fraser Clark's YOU UPGRADE mag:


PORTUGAL REMOVES IMPRISONMENT
FOR USE OF ALL DRUGS

The new law, enacted by the Socialist government on July 1, eliminates the
threat of prison for possession of personal supplies of any drug. Drugs
remain illegal, however - their possession is just no longer an
imprisonable offence. Fines may still be applied, or community service. And
a single joint could send you to the anti-addiction commission!
Possession of up to 10 "daily doses" is personal, not punishable by
imprisonment, but holding more than that is evidence of dealing. A "daily
dose" is generally less than what serious users actually consume, however,
so in practice anyone with more than a few days' doses still risks prison.

Although, if they're within the 10-dose limit, first offenders will
normally have their punishment suspended, anyone caught with any quantity
of drugs must appear within 72 hours before one of the country's 18
anti-drug-addiction commissions. After a hearing, those bodies can impose
punishment such as a fine of up to $250 or revocation of a driver's
license. Commissions also provide medical help and counseling about the
dangers of drug use.
Drug trafficking remains punishable by up to 25 years' imprisonment. The
sale of even a single dose of a drug to a friend is considered dealing.

Fines may not be leveled against addicts at all because of concerns that
they'd steal to pay them.
Foreigners will be required to appear before the commissions, and police in
their own countries may be notified.

"A SORT OF THIRD WAY"

"We're trying a sort of third way between the hard approach of the United
States and the soft approach of countries like Holland," said Vitalino
Canas, Portugal's drug policy czar. "We are not allowing any legal use of
drugs. It's not the same as in Holland.. We think most people who try
Ecstasy or hashish will not try other drugs, but some will, so the system
should not leave these people alone."

The stated philosophy is that traffickers are criminals who should be
punished, but users are victims who should be helped.

Police appear to be more likely to take action against casual users. The
government hopes such young people would benefit from getting picked up by
the police. "Drug users are not criminals but the victims of crime, and
should be helped like other victims of crime" said Canas.


"PORTUGAL - SUN, BEACHES'N ANY DRUG YOU FANCY?"

"There will be planeloads of students heading for southern Portugal to
smoke marijuana and take a lot worse, knowing we won't put them in jail,"
predicts Conservative Popular Party leader Paulo Portas. "We promise sun,
beaches and any drug you like."

While Canas insists that Portas "knows this is not true," he admits that
his widely reported remark reflects an ongoing political battle over drug
policy. "We must have courage, because we must try new alternatives."

Some police have also voiced concern that dealing convictions will go down
- casual users will no longer need to save their skins by testifying
against dealers when those skins are no longer threatened. Other cops
admit, however, that most users presently don't actually testify.

Until the new law took effect, police had shown decreasing interest in
arresting casual drug users "because they knew that if they got a young guy
. . . using Ecstasy or hashish, and this unlucky person was sent to jail,
he'd probably come out using not hashish but heroin with syringes," Canas
said.


So, while America kicks up its War Against Drugs to increasingly insane
proportions (including anti-Human Rights legislation and increasingly
routine abuse of the law by law enforcers) Europe is moving in the opposite
direction. Portugal isn't alone. From a pilot program in London that lets
marijuana users off with a warning to a new French law that allows police
to use discretion, from Holland's long -established soft approach to
Switzerland's licensing of pot growing, the chasm between America and the
rest of the world increases to some kind of breaking point.
Oh, you lucky ravers whose destiny it is to deal the final blow against the
War on Vegetables!




"It is only with the heart that one can see rightly;  what is essential is
invisible to the eye."
-Antoine de Saint-Exupery

"I'm astounded by people who want to "know" the universe when it's hard
enough to find your way around Chinatown."
-Woody Allen

this to me. . .=20


    I want Miva merchant 4.0 shopping cart
   =20
    I guess I need a merchant account through my bank. . .what does this =
merchant account do for me ? Until a couple hours ago, I thought the =
merchant account processed and deposited internet payments, then I =
looked around a little more, and I found out that I needed a "payment =
gateway" in addition to my shopping cart and merchant account, which did =
the actual processing and verification.


    How does this work ? Does anyone have exp. in this ? I'm a little =
confused as to which part the merchant account service and the payment =
gateway play as far as processing payments via internet go.

    Is the payment gateway, basically just a secure server that would =
process the credit card info, then the merchant account takes it from =
there and deposits the $$ into the specified bank account ?


    if someone can give me a full complete explanation of how this all =
works, I'll totally buy you some records or something. . .  or if anyone =
knows of a site that details the processes, I'd be totally grateful. . . =

csr's don't seem to have the time to detail any of this. . .=20

Subject: [sfraves] "EVIL" EDDIE RICHARDS, DAVID DURIEZ, MAZI, HATIRAS . . .!!!!

                                                  !!!JET SET UPDATE!!!

We have new Dj's coming and going at different times,  we are focusing on 
tours that support label releases, as well as overseas talent on a brief U.S. 
trip! Our current roster listed below, as well as tours and selected 
availability's  . . .

Jet Set Fall Roster 2001

Audio Soul Project=Mazi
CZR
David Duriez
"Evil" Eddie Richards
Hatiras
Johnny Fiasco\
Jes

Availability and Tours:

AUDIO SOUL PROJECT=MAZI: Oct.12, 13, 26, 27  Nov. - Europe/Asia Availability

Ready to get back on the road, Mazi has been locked up in the studio 
completing his album, "Community" , which will be released in November on UK 
imprint NRK. Upcoming remixes include work for Carl Cox's Intec label, 
Depeche Mode "Exciter" producer, Mark Bell's, Shaboom imprint, as Joey 
Negro's Akabu Project, and the re-release of the classic Gourmet Recordings 
track "Standing Still" on Airtight.  Mazi's 3rd mix CD will be released in 
Spring as part of the Tech House Phenomena series on Terry Francis' 
Eukahouse/UK.

ALBUM RELEASE/NEWS
http://www.nrksounddivision.com/newsindex.htm
AUDIO SOUL PROJECT BIO
http://www.nrksounddivision.com/labindex.htm


"EVIL" EDDIE RICHARDS: Oct. 25 - 31st

The Godfather of Tech House, making a very appropriate Halloween appearance!!!
Dubbed as Britain's Godfather of house and techno, Eddie Richards is one of 
the giants on the global dance scene. Mentioned in practically every book, TV 
documentary, and film on the urban dance music culture, Eddie is known to 
draw large numbers of dance devotees to all the events he has headlined. His 
past work includes remix work for the Shamen, and Orbital. He has recently 
taken to the studio, releasing new projects on End Recordings, Lunar Tunes 
and Moody Recordings. 

EDDIE RICHARDS INTERVIEW
http://www.madsounds.com/artist/eeddierich1.asp


DAVID DURIEZ: Nov. 25 - Dec. 1
Brique Rouge label heads David Duriez has been making quite some noise as of 
late with releases on Gourmet, 20/20 Vision, Low Pressings, and a CD on UCMG 
titled "Rocks Da House"  . . . We had David over just last month, and had a 
great response!  More on David at the following links:

DAVID:
FOR PICTURES / SOUNDS & BIO-DISCO
http://www.briquerouge.com/davidduriez.html
A MIX RECORDED LIVE IN WINNIPEG IN JULY 2001 (MP3)
http://www.housemuzak.com/housemuziq/mp3/david_duriez_lustremix1.mp3

*Hatiras will be on hiatus in the studio for a few weeks, putting the final 
touches on his album, "Arrival" which will be released on IHR Nov. 6th  . . . 
we will be taking requests for him on a first come basis, and get in touch to 
honor requests starting Oct. 1st. Full tour support will be offered to 
coincide with the release.

Contact:     Lori Riegler   773.539.2285 Gourmetdj@aol.com

Subject: [sfraves] bodyrock records // new record store in the south bay

::: B O D Y R O C K . R E C O R D S ::: 

New record store in San Jose. Dedicated to underground music, Bodyrock 
Records contains various mediums of house, techno, and hip hop. Along with 
vinyl, cd/cassette, and clothing sales, Bodyrock also features an 
audio/video recording and editing studio, as well as sound and lighting 
rentals for small gatherings. For more info, call the shop (408/272-4444) or 
visit their website...

Subject: Re: [sfraves] rave bans - ecstasy bill

Very good point made....I agree with you %100. 
Promoters shouldn't be held responsible.  However,
I've been to concerts where they search also...but I
think they are mostly looking for weapons.  On that
note, I do think that a search before going into
events (parties, raves, concerts, whatever) is a
*great* idea.  But I don't think it should be as
extensive as a pat down.  I think that they should be
looking for weapons alone.  

In my opinion, any harm that you inflict on others
(ie, with weapons) you should be held accountable
for...and any harm you inflict on yourself (ie, doing
drugs) is enough punishment in and of itself.


On a sidenote...I saw Angel Alanis last night....he
was amazing.  This is the second time I've seen him
spin out and he has yet to disappoint. :)

Have a great day everyone!

Subject: [sfraves] (SF) Andy C // Info on DNA Lounge // For the Geeks

Whats up-

ok so tonite in SF is Andy C, as i'm sure you've
heard... what you 
haven't
hread more about is the venue. the DNA Lounge is one
of the oldest 
clubs
in SF, which has recently gone thru a complete gutting
out and 
remodeling. go to
www.dnalounge.com to check it out..

the owner is a guy named Jamie, who used to work for
Netscape, kind of
shy, kind of quiet, kind of goth.. anyway, he bought
this club and for 
the
past year has been rebuilding the place, and has
documented everything
he's done on the website. if you can figure out who he
is, make sure 
you
tell him how awesome the place is.

www.dnalounge.com/backstage/remodeling.html

a couple cool things: on the webiste, theres a
description of the
soundsystem, built and tested from the ground up, for
all you geeks, 
pictures of every piece of
hardware and how it works with all the other pieces.

and the sound... wow. this is most definitely the best
sound system in 
all
of SF. one person i know wept with joy upon hearing
dnb being played in
there, it sounded so hot.

www.dnalounge.com/backstage/sound.html

there are internet kiosks all throughout the club,
with internet/shell
access, for those of you who want to check vital stats
of your servers 
at
home, or just use pine.

another important thing- this club is NOTHING like
1015 or 550 
Barneveld.
you won't find any fucking glitter cowboy hats, house
music sluts, or
etards here. it hasn't been invaded by the bridge and
tunnel crowd- 
yet.

The Groundscore crew and extended family has worked
really hard to get 
the
word out about Andy C coming here, so please come out
tonite and 
support,
you won't regret it.


The Summer - SF

From: vix <netserf@kapu.net>
To: SFRavEs Mailing List <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Message-ID: <B7B52C56.2AC2%netserf@kapu.net>
In-Reply-To: <v04220801b7b554fd4d0d@[216.15.60.33]>

Content-type: text/plain; charset="US-ASCII"
Content-transfer-encoding: 7bit
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: Re: [sfraves] nlr: anyone have DSL that works ?

www.dslreports.com has been pretty helpful.

I was just tortured nonstop by Pacbell for 10 days with a badly botched
install, & I'd say avoid them at all costs. I don't want to even get started
describing how horrible it was dealing with the 398 totally inept
organizations and individuals involved in a single PacBell install, how much
time I spent on hold reaching them, or the fact that they apparently can't
communicate with each other without losing information or making a mistake.
I ended up cancelling the order. I am so grateful I didn't get stuck in a 1
year contract with them. Maybe I was just unlucky, but dayum.

Having said that, Telocity just raised prices 25%, most broadband providers
are teetering on the edge of bankruptcy or are already bankrupt, and in the
end PacBell owns the lines.

I'd recommend AT&T cable, based on how much more organized they are. Plus
you get a static IP address included and free technician install (handy if
there are signal problems). With PacBell, you can get either PPPoe for $50
and free self-install, or Enhanced with 5 static IPs for $65, no inbetween.
BUT if you want Enhanced, you have to pay $200 for a compulsory technician
install. That's ridiculous, if you can do it yourself but they don't let
you.

Or better yet, move next door to a Starbuck's. They have high speed wireless
broadband access through MobileStar, it absolutely rocks, and it costs only
$29.95 unlimited access per month. Plus you can use it in any Starbuck's in
the Bay Area (or outside if you're close by, like next door or across the
street.)

From sfraves-return-72302-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Fri Aug 31 19:21:32 2001
Return-Path: <sfraves-return-72302-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 45684 invoked by uid 1104); 31 Aug 2001 19:21:32 -0000
Mailing-List: contact sfraves-help@hyperreal.org; run by ezmlm
Precedence: bulk
X-No-Archive: yes
list-help: <mailto:sfraves-help@hyperreal.org>
list-unsubscribe: <mailto:sfraves-unsubscribe@hyperreal.org>
list-post: <mailto:sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: mailing list sfraves@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 45673 invoked from network); 31 Aug 2001 19:21:32 -0000
Mime-Version: 1.0
X-Sender: blindspot@mail.mac.com
Message-Id: <p04330104b7b5936cb7a7@[172.16.2.25]>
Date: Fri, 31 Aug 2001 12:20:39 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: blindspot <blindspot@mac.com>
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii" ; format="flowed"
X-Spam-Rating: taz3.hyperreal.org 1.6.2 0/1000/N
Subject: [sfraves] nrr: eX-Girl

Some friends told me about eX-Girl months ago and gushed about the 
energetic experience they had. So I hauled out to the Great American 
Music Hall in SF to see this band kick off their US tour. I was not 
disappointed.

$12 got me my ticket. I joined my friends at the front of the stage. 
The trio of ladies known as eX-Girl were busy fixing and rigging the 
stage with their instruments completely dolled up in short white gogo 
boots and silver shimmering tour jackets. The 200+ crowd of 20 to 30 
somethings with perpetual youth-fixations bustled about oblivious to 
what would happen to them in five minutes or so. The lights then dim 
and M's unforgettable "Pop Musik" intro heralds the landing of the 
mother ship. From behind and both sides the eX-Girls Carmen Miranda 
their way to the stage all the while dancing as seductively as one 
can while wearing abominably huge candyish-looking headresses that I 
only later realized were brightly colored maimed frog corpses. Yes, 
on their heads.

The band takes the stage and with lights and silence demands 
attention and suspense before they launch into a strange hypnotic 
operatic vocal harmony that tells the audience that the frog king is 
trying to get back to his home planet. Suddenly the band lurches into 
an all vocal intro that sounds like Bobby McFerrin giving the beatbox 
treatment to a Metallica tune. Angry guitar foreboding bass and 
crushing drums bring on the mayhem and the rest is a blur.

The show that follows in one of amazing contrasts. Full grown adult 
frog-worshipping women shed their silver full length spaceman tour 
jackets to reveal the cutest bright yellow dresses with glittering 
decapitated frog heads. They then proceed to churn out heavily 
droning, and more often bombastic grooves layered with operatic vocal 
harmonies not heard much in pop since the days of glam and from the 
likes of groups like Queen, Bowie, etc.. The band has been compared 
to Diamanda Galas, Zappa, B-52's, Nina Hagen, Devo, Talking Heads and 
Laurie Anderson. Yet this band makes such a visceral connection that 
it's really hard to intellectualize them or even  want to 
intellectuallize them. You want to, but you shouldn't. The 
order/disorder of Devo really comes across as the girls at times 
robot dance their way through songs at odd time signatures only to 
intantly break off into a fit of chaos and discord. Back and forth.

Their charm is undeniable. I know of know other band that takes 
another band's song, M's "Pop Musik" in this case, and not only 
covers it, but makes it their anthem. Not a bad choice for an anthem 
really, the perfect choice for this band. Their instruments are 
almost as big as they are. The bassist, Kirilo thumps her gourgeous 
white bass guitar fixed with diamond mirrors, while the guitarist, 
Chihiro wields her axe and shakes her shaggy mane like the heaviest 
cock rocker. The drummer, Fuzuki and arguably the cutest eX-Girl, 
stands for the whole set, only playing a two piece kit w/cymbals and 
a machine full of dozens of knobs.

The band starts out singing "Get 5 things and mix those up. It'll be 
fuel for the plane to get back home sweet planet frog" and ends by 
singing "If something new you want, just mix up what you have now." 
eX-Girl are making the only sense they know how.


http://0505.net/ex-girl/

Coming to Amoeba Records Oct. 19


-blindspot

Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nlr: anyone have DSL that works ?

pacbell (sbc) is the worst group of fucking idiots i've ever had the
displeasure of dealing with.  they can barely handle our single regular 
phone line with any degree of competence, so i really shouldn't have been
surprised that two weeks and over 20 hours on the phone speaking to
4 or 5 different organizations within the company after what was
supposedly a successful installation, not one packet had been transmitted
to or from our house.  avoid the provenance of ineptitude that is pacbell
by all means.

also, last i heard pacbell is only doing PPPoE from now on.  which is dumb.

we cancelled our order with pacbell and signed up with flashcom, which
subsequently went out of business.  but they transitioned us over to
speakeasy.net, and things have been perfect ever since.  that was many
months ago.

our experience with speakeasy has been ideal.  we get a (unoffcial) static
ip and 608/128 RADSL for $50/month.  they are responsive, friendly,
intelligent, and *solvent*.  they go through covad, but have agreements
with other companies should covad go completely under.

i would highly recommend speakeasy to anybody looking for dsl.

Subject: [sfraves] sex, money and our scene, honeeeeey. :) nrr

yesterday, i had an interesting conversation with one
of my very favorite mystics. we talked about sex and
money... a popular subject in our little community...
she said that all the men want is sex and money, and
that i should stay away from the men and the bars. :)
kind 
of hard for me to do, considering, i love men, and a
lot of good music and good men happen to be at the
bars..
however, there is some wisdom to be found in her
words..true, a lot of men and women..i never forget
about the ladies :) :) :)...
are all about sex and money, so it is good to be aware
of that and to be careful. i don't like to get my sex
or 
my money from sick sources. i have a firm belief in a
lot of things that are not seen, but are known if you
listen 
to your own heart. i don't know what i am doing yet
this weekend. i have been ill for a bit, and am in
good health 
at the moment. i hope that you all will be safe and
that you will look after one another as best as you
can,
even if that means that you cannot be in the company
of anyone until you get your act together. better to
volunteer 
for that solitude you've been longing for than to be
placed in solitary confinement or a box before your
time is up.  :)

list who are attending. Well, I hope there's no bart strike this week cuz I 
reallyt enjoy taking bart and that's my only form of transportation right 
now.

Subject: Re: [sfraves] sex, money and our scene, honeeeeey. :) nrr - He Said, She Said

I, too, also had an interesting convo. with my seer.
The topic was about women & sex, my two fav things in
the world. See, straight men can't do a thing in this
world if it doesn't lead up to the two fav things in
their world: women & sex. We drive fast cars, try to
make fast money (or a lot of money), develop new,
designer drugs, build smaller video cameras, bigger
harddrives, get a faster Internet connection, and buy
fast computers all in the name of women & sex. Whether
there's actually a woman involved is besides the
point. There was no other single, greater motivating
reason in the world to develop broadband except for
the simple reason to be able to watch a (FREE) porno
stream of a dude's fav porn star in its entirety and
to download all the porn in the world to your heart's
desire. Any man who tells you differently is only
doing so cause he wants you to think he's a civilized
man, yet, were it not for the prurient drives of
ancient man, civilization would be just a wet dream,
for what better way to meet a lot of chicks if not
putting them all in one place? In the immortal words
of Commodus Rex, "...for all that man does, they know
not..."

The last piece of advice my seer gave me before going
to bed with his woman was, "...don't think about it so
much or you'll go blind you f'g perv..."

Have a great Labor Day weekend!

Rick

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nlr: anyone have DSL that works ?

> Two things:
> 
> AT&T broadband has switched to DHCP - no static IP's any more

Starting when? I hate PPPoE, although having a router makes it less
annoying. But I got a static IP yesterday included with my install.  Maybe
it varies by area (though why would it?? Puzzling.)

 
> Not all starbucks even have computers - why would they all have broadband?

http://www.mobilestar.com/starbucks_update.asp

You need your own laptop and it has to have a wireless card installed,
either internal or PCMCIA. It's outrageous that they don't advertise this
more... I was sitting on a brownstone stoop at midnight in New York City
across the street from a SB's and sending files back to Sunnyvale at T1
speed when the broadband connection in my hotel went down. It's a lifesaver
when you need to get something done and they have 600-some wireless access
point locations across the US.

I don't really care for Starbuck's but MobileStar is great.



 
> sarilion
> 
> At 11:58 AM 8/31/2001 -0700, vix wrote:
>> www.dslreports.com has been pretty helpful.
>> 
>> I was just tortured nonstop by Pacbell for 10 days with a badly botched
>> install, & I'd say avoid them at all costs. I don't want to even get started
>> describing how horrible it was dealing with the 398 totally inept
>> organizations and individuals involved in a single PacBell install, how much
>> time I spent on hold reaching them, or the fact that they apparently can't
>> communicate with each other without losing information or making a mistake.
>> I ended up cancelling the order. I am so grateful I didn't get stuck in a 1
>> year contract with them. Maybe I was just unlucky, but dayum.
>> 
>> Having said that, Telocity just raised prices 25%, most broadband providers
>> are teetering on the edge of bankruptcy or are already bankrupt, and in the
>> end PacBell owns the lines.
>> 
>> I'd recommend AT&T cable, based on how much more organized they are. Plus
>> you get a static IP address included and free technician install (handy if
>> there are signal problems). With PacBell, you can get either PPPoe for $50
>> and free self-install, or Enhanced with 5 static IPs for $65, no inbetween.
>> BUT if you want Enhanced, you have to pay $200 for a compulsory technician
>> install. That's ridiculous, if you can do it yourself but they don't let
>> you.
>> 
>> Or better yet, move next door to a Starbuck's. They have high speed wireless
>> broadband access through MobileStar, it absolutely rocks, and it costs only
>> $29.95 unlimited access per month. Plus you can use it in any Starbuck's in
>> the Bay Area (or outside if you're close by, like next door or across the
>> street.)
>>

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nlr: anyone have DSL that works ?

Just to give a different perspective...i've had absolutely no trouble w/ Pac
Bell DSL.  From when we first called they gave an estimate of 3 weeks to get
it all installed.  We got the DSL Modem a few days after that initial call,
plugged it in and it already worked!

Sure it has PPPoE but I've had no trouble with that either...Mac OS X is
nice and has it built into the OS :).

Its damn fast too...1.4 mb downloads on a regular basis.  Only problem with
pacbell is that their relay server is open to all so some ISPs reject email
coming from it because it is a spam source.

Ok, bye!

sugam

Subject: [sfraves] DEMF

Hey guys,

I finally figuerd out how to use DreamWeaver and HomePage so I posted my
pictures from DEMF (Detroit Electronic Music Festival) it was a great
time...there are just a few since I ran out of memory on my camera, but
check 'em out if you want! :)

Just so you know DEMF is the largest EDM festival int he US.  In 2000 the
inagural year they expected 100,000 and got 1,000,000.  I haven't seen stats
from this year's but for all purposes it was way more packed.  I hope next
year it'll be good (but it wont since they fired Carl Craig...those
bastards)

Actually...i just checked the site...most of the pictures are mad
blurry...but you can look for fun anyways...I have some cool shots
(104-0485_IMG.JPG down near the bottom).

http://sugam.cjb.net
Click on DEMF on the left hand side

One,

Sugam

Subject: Re: [sfraves] nlr: anyone have DSL that works ?

Get this peeps... I work for an ISP that used to sell DSL via Pacific Bell..
Pacific bell is now disconnecting DSL users that are more than 15,000 feet
from the CO.  They dont care if it works correctly or not.  They have
already dont this to a few of our customers..  Whatever you do.  NEver call
into Pacbell for issues regarding your DSL if you know your circuit is more
than 15,000 out of the CO.. Just some Friendly advice..

Chris (aka: daWeasel)

X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V5.00.2615.200

Subject: [sfraves] THANKS, you all are just so dope. . . 

OMG it took me soooooOOOoo long to go through all the emails I got back
about the dsl, and the merchant accounts, and the vinyl questions. . .
Ravers are like just fuckin SICK !!! I love you guys. . .

heres some things I've decided. . .

> >     I was wondering. . .  when people buy vinyl online, you know how
> > theres usualy like a 1 or 2 minute sample of one side of the record,
> > put up as a .ra or whatever file. . .
> >     do you prefer to have one longer sample of one side ? Or would you
> > rather have 2 slightly shorter samples, one each side , or even a
> > short sample of every track ?

    I've decided on a 45 sec to one minute sample of each track, some tracks
maybe longer, but some of the vinyl I have has like 2-3 tracks on each side.
. .
    For some records, I'll record a sample at both 33 and 45 rpm so the
people who spin their stuff faster can hear what a normal record sounds like
sped up a bit. This will probably all take a little extra space on my
server, but that shouldn't be a biggie. . .

>
> >     Do you usually search the stores by label name ? artist name ? or
> > title ?

    I'm going to have a search engine, and set it up to search all 3, along
with listing of ea by label. . .

> >     Is it important to you to have a pic of the sleeve of the record
> > (if it's a graphic sleeve) ?

    I was just asking here. . . maybe some "special" release vinyl mught
have a gif with it but the majority of the vinyl I sell come in graphicless
sleeves anyway. .

>
> >     What do you want to see on online vinyl store sites ? What do you
> > think they're lacking ? What do you wish they had ?

    I'm goiung to try to be as direct as possible, and ephasize simplicity
in finding the tracks you want as much as possible. I'm re thinking my lil
graphical approach to my site and the vinyl section will be mostly text and
links. . .
    Some vinyl may or may not have descriptions, but the ones I usually read
tend to be kinda misleading, so I'll let the samples do most of the talking.
Daily updates are important so I'll have new relese sections, specials,
discounted items, package deals, and a few other ideas. . .

> >     Would you be willing to sign up to a sort of vinyl club, where for
> > a monthly charge, you would basically have an agreement to purchase a
> > certain amount of vinyl a week or a month ?

    I don't like the idea of having too much of a committment myself (plus
it's helluva lotta work for me). I'll set up some of my personal and perhaps
various DJ recommendations for various genres of vinyl (everythings mostly
going to be harder, d&b, hardcore, hhc, nrg). I'll figure this out as I go
and ask for peoples recommendations. If possible, when I get going, I'll
have like DJ ??? picks of the week, etc (something along that line).

> >     Do you think it would be useful to have a forum where dj's sell,
> > buy and trade their older or unwanted vinyl ?
    To start, I'll set up an email list designed for trading and discussion
of vinyl. I don't know if a web board will be useful. . . maybe something
like one of those free for all links pages (or something liek that), where
people could post their items and sell them (similar to crasgslist). These
people will definately have to be approved, and there will have to be some
sort of quality assurance if I can find a simple way to administer that.

>
> >     Do you usually just keep collecting your records, and never get
> > rid of them ? Or do you replace old records with new ones and sell or
> > give your older stuff away ?

    This was a general question. . . but in addition to new vinyl, I
personally like lil odd records from here and there places with like nursery
rhymes, audio samples etc, and you normally don't find too many of those
new.

    THANKS ALL. . .

it'll be a lil while before that's set up, but I wanted to figure out all
the background stuff so I can start with a solid base. I've been in some
sort of CSR position since my first job when I was 14 (x-ray equip service
in hospitals). So naturally I'm more customer oriented and not as concerned
with my own personal gains as I am with keeping as many other people happy
as I possibly can. So input it ALWAYS appreciated. . . required actually. .
.

luvyall


huggz n stuff

aryck

Groove Factory

Subject: RE: [sfraves] nlr: anyone have DSL that works ?

OK Sorry for the NRR but I gotta chime in my 2 cents about this.

Pac Bell is an ILEC that has a lot of subscribers and has a bad habit of
over subscribing themselves. The real problem is the facilities ( Wire
and cross connects between you and the CO ) ADSL will go to @ 17K feet
if the facilities are in good working order. This usually means that it
is in an area that is not to old like 40+ years. There are ways around
all this.
(OK Here comes the pitch) 
Despite all the things you have heard about Covad (Chapter 11, gone bye
bye, broke etc....) We are here to stay. We will be out of debt and cash
flow positive before it will effect anyone's DSL lines. We have the best
engineering staff around (That's what I do at Covad) and pride ourselves
as having the best service, and the only (Yes ONLY) Nationwide DSL
network. We provide SDSL, ADSL, IDSL and more technologies very soon
(ILECS only provide ADSL) and our waiting times are very short (if you
ever have to call um). You can use one of our ISP's or you can go
straight to Covad. We have a few different types of packages depending
if you want a Consumer ADSL or a Business SDSL. (Hint if you want to do
streaming make sure you upstream speed is fast enough, most low-end ADSL
upstream speeds are only 128Kbps)I have 2 SDSL 1.5's here at the
groovefactory studio.
Plus "if" you have a problem with you line you can email me and I can
help out.


Try us out www.covad.com
